headline: Sheriff Recorded Making Inflammatory Comments Won’t Face Charges
abstract: Oklahoma’s attorney general said he had found no evidence to charge the sheriff, who was caught on a recording as county officials discussed killing journalists and Black people.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma’s attorney general said on Friday that a sheriff who was caught on a recording as other county officials discussed killing journalists and Black people would not face criminal charges but suggested that the governor endorse another candidate in the next election.

headline: Governor Vetoes Louisiana’s Ban on Transition Care for Transgender Minors
abstract: Gov. John Bel Edwards, a Democrat, also vetoed two other recent bills related to gender expression and sexual orientation in schools and among young people.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana vetoed a ban on gender-transition care for transgender minors on Friday, standing in the way of his state becoming the latest to prohibit that kind of care.

headline: Robert Kennedy Jr. Reports Income of $7.8 Million
abstract: The presidential candidate and anti-vaccine activist made nearly $1.6 million from consulting work for a law firm known for litigation against pharmaceutical companies, a filing showed.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the political scion and prominent vaccine skeptic who is challenging President Biden for the Democratic presidential nomination, reported an income of $7.8 million in the year leading up to his entry into the race, including nearly $1.6 million from his consulting work for a personal injury law firm known for litigation against pharmaceutical companies.

headline: Coast Guard Apologizes for Covering Up Long History of Sexual Assault
abstract: The U.S. Coast Guard acknowledged it had failed for almost two decades to properly investigate sexual assault allegations at the service’s academy or hold perpetrators accountable.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard apologized on Friday for covering up scores of documented sexual assault and harassment cases that took place at the service’s academy, and failing to properly investigate or discipline those accused in dozens more cases over a span of nearly two decades.

headline: Certain Surprise Party?
abstract: Ben Tolkin makes a hip debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I have a soft spot for constructors who debut with themeless puzzles, and there is a lot to love about this grid by Ben Tolkin. The stair-stepped entries at its top and bottom all crackle, and most of them are debuts, as well; there’s excellent wordplay throughout, and a lot of trivia for lovers of language and literature.

headline: On ‘The Bear,’ Interning at a Fine-Dining Restaurant Is Rosier Than Reality
abstract: Real-life chefs said the portrayal of haute cuisine work was a bit soft-focus.
lead_paragraph: In its second season, the hit FX show “The Bear” ventures into the world of fine dining. As the scrappy Chicago restaurant crashes toward a reopening, two of the employees leave to apprentice at top restaurants in Chicago and Copenhagen.

headline: Hollywood Actors Extend Contract Talks at Deadline
abstract: Their union, SAG-AFTRA, and the major studios pushed the expiration date ahead to July 12 and will keep negotiating.
lead_paragraph: The union representing some 160,000 television and movie actors said on Friday night that it would continue contract negotiations with the major Hollywood studios and streaming services, extending the current deal — which had been set to expire at midnight — through July 12.

headline: Before Wimbledon, There’s Practice on Grass at an English Garden Party
abstract: The Boodles, which draws elite players on their way to the All England Club, is unlike nearly anything else on the tennis calendar — a Gatsby-like few days on an estate outside London.
lead_paragraph: Even for the best tennis players in the world, the days before a Grand Slam can be filled with nerves and stress, especially the time leading up to Wimbledon, the grandest Grand Slam of them all.

headline: France Is on Fire
abstract: The country is in the midst of a revolt over police violence and racism.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “I’m a fully grown adult, but my mother still seems nervous whenever I leave the house,” Djigui, one of the thousands of protesters who took to the streets on Thursday afternoon in Nanterre, a working-class suburb of Paris, told me. “I can hear the crack in her voice when she checks to make sure I have my ID card or just says, ‘Watch out.’”

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Ruined Town, Resolved to Stay ’Until the End’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “People used to live here, but they left. Today, I’m the only inhabitant of the street.”

headline: Corrections: July 1, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on June 23 about a hearing regarding the derailment of a freight train in Ohio incorrectly rendered some information as a direct quotation. Robert Wood, Norfolk Southern’s director of hazardous materials, did not say at a hearing, “Eventually, if we did nothing, the cars were going to go through a violent explosion.” That was an element of a question he was asked regarding what he had told the fire chief in East Palestine, Ohio. The article also misquoted Mr. Wood. He said, “We believed that our only alternative left was probably going to be a vent and burn,” not “We believed our only alternative left was a vent and burn.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Gov. Murphy Looks to Burnish Legacy With a $54.3 Billion Budget
abstract: New Jersey’s election-year spending plan is 7 percent higher than last year’s.
lead_paragraph: Philip D. Murphy, a wealthy former Goldman Sachs executive who had never held elected office, took over as governor of New Jersey in 2018 as an unabashed liberal Democrat and in his first term enacted a millionaires tax, a $15 minimum wage and mandatory paid time off.

headline: Where to Watch July 4 Fireworks in the New York City Area
abstract: Macy’s world-famous show, Coney Island’s display and alternative celebrations in Staten Island and New Jersey: here’s where to enjoy a show this year.
lead_paragraph: Numerous firework displays are scheduled to light up the skies in and around New York City this Independence Day, including the 47th annual Macy’s Fourth of July celebration, which will send 60,000 shells into the night sky from five barges in the East River.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: 9 Ways to Stay Shaded on a Sweltering Day in New York City
abstract: The city is preparing for extreme heat by introducing new methods to keep out of the sun and expanding on those more tried and true.
lead_paragraph: With above-average temperatures predicted for this summer, New Yorkers are bracing for a scorcher.

headline: A Fractured Family Heads North
abstract: Remember the people who fled to second homes during the pandemic? Caitlin Shetterly wrote a novel about them.
lead_paragraph: Wherever you go, there you are. The adage rings true in Caitlin Shetterly’s tender debut, “Pete and Alice in Maine.” During the first weeks of the pandemic, Pete and Alice flee New York City for Maine with their young daughters, Sophie and Iris. Life in the city seems impossible during lockdown, but Pete and Alice are also dealing with a crisis of their own. Driving up to Maine, they carry with them confusion, grief, anger, guilt, longing — all the emotions of their troubled marriage.

headline: My Building Manager Wants to Get on My Renter’s Insurance. Is That Legal?
abstract: It depends on what kind of apartment you rent. And it may actually be a good idea.
lead_paragraph: Q: I have lived in my New York rental apartment for over six years, having signed three previous two-year leases. Each lease has requested proof of renter’s insurance. With the current lease, the building management is requesting that I name them as an additional insured party. It seems as though they’re trying to pass on their insurance costs to me. Is that legal?

headline: How Amazon Taught Alexa to Speak in an Irish Brogue
abstract: For Alexa to speak like a Dubliner, Amazon researchers had to crack a problem that’s vexed data scientists for years: voice disentanglement.
lead_paragraph: Like Henry Higgins, the phonetician from George Bernard Shaw’s play “Pygmalion,” Marius Cotescu and Georgi Tinchev recently demonstrated how their student was trying to overcome pronunciation difficulties.

headline: 2 Leading Theories of Consciousness Square Off
abstract: Scientists revealed the results of experiments testing how our brains give rise to conscious thought — and ended a 25-year-old bet.
lead_paragraph: On a muggy June night in Greenwich Village, more than 800 neuroscientists, philosophers and curious members of the public packed into an auditorium. They came for the first results of an ambitious investigation into a profound question: What is consciousness?

headline: The N.F.L.’s Betting Penalties Put Ideal of ‘Integrity’ to the Test
abstract: The penalties have been harsh for players caught breaking the N.F.L.’s gambling rules. That’s partly because the league wants no insinuation that games might be rigged.
lead_paragraph: When the N.F.L. on Thursday announced that three players had been found to have bet on football, the penalties came down with characteristic harshness: indefinite suspensions that can only be appealed after a full season.

headline: TikTok Sells a Lot of Books. Now, Its Owner Wants to Publish Them, Too.
abstract: As ByteDance launches a publishing company, many in the book world wonder if it will create an uneven playing field by boosting its own authors at the expense of others.
lead_paragraph: A new publishing company began courting self-published romance writers earlier this year. The pitch, delivered in a generic email, was impersonal and formulaic. The terms weren’t generous, sometimes amounting to just a few thousand dollars for the rights to a book.

headline: The ‘Unseen’ Students in the Affirmative Action Debate
abstract: Race-conscious admissions helped only a tiny fraction of Black and Hispanic students. It could not address the many obstacles to a college degree.
lead_paragraph: For as long as she remembers, Dolly Ramos hoped to have “the college experience,” she said, and one day become a nurse. But her biggest obstacle wasn’t competing for a spot at the school of her choice — it was attending and affording college at all.

headline: Cameron Norrie is Going to Wimbledon. Great Expectations Follow Him.
abstract: He is the top-ranked British player at the tournament. Seven years ago when that was Andy Murray, he won.
lead_paragraph: Cameron Norrie has had two mystical moments at Wimbledon. Both took place on Centre Court, the most revered venue in the sport.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, June 24-30
abstract: Cornered, many players had to face the music with “plena.”
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: Fifty Years Ago the Men Boycotted Wimbledon. That Changed Everything.
abstract: The walkout was the result of the tennis federation banning Nikola Pilic, an instance of player unity that is still felt today.
lead_paragraph: Stan Smith’s 1972 Wimbledon cup sits alongside his 1971 United States Open winner’s prize in a trophy case inside his Hilton Head Island, S.C., home. Smith had hoped to defend his title in ’73.

headline: Boy George Loves His Deeply Flawed Heroes
abstract: The Culture Club leader on the complicated artists that shape his worldview, and the grand hats that help him make a statement.
lead_paragraph: Boy George was chatting with Leonardo DiCaprio, an acquaintance from years ago, at a Cannes party in May when he realized the actor wasn’t particularly interested in their reunion.

headline: Supreme Court Decisions on Education Could Offer Democrats an Opening
abstract: The decisions this week on affirmative action and student loans give Democrats a way to make a case on class and appeal to voters who have drifted away from the party.
lead_paragraph: Ever since President Bill Clinton advised “mend it, don’t end it,” affirmative action has had an uneasy place in the Democratic coalition, as omnipresent as the party’s allegiance to abortion rights and its promises to expand financial aid for higher education — but unpopular with much of the public.

headline: American Cities Have a Conversion Problem, and It’s Not Just Offices
abstract: Piles of regulations, or “kludge,” and a culture of “no” are limiting the ability to turn building blocks into something new.
lead_paragraph: There is an aging office building on Water Street in Lower Manhattan where it would make all the sense in the world to create apartments. The 31-story building, once the headquarters of A.I.G., has windows all around and a shape suited to extra corner units. In a city with too little housing, it could hold 800 to 900 apartments. Right across the street, one office building not so different from this one has already been turned into housing, and another is on the way.

headline: A ‘Cage Match’ Between Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg May Be No Joke
abstract: Talks over a matchup between the two tech billionaires have progressed and the parameters of an event are taking shape.
lead_paragraph: The day after Elon Musk challenged Mark Zuckerberg on social media to “a cage match” last month, Dana White, president of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, received a text.

headline: Why Bolsonaro Was Barred in Brazil but Trump Can Run in the U.S.
abstract: In both the United States and Brazil, former presidents made baseless claims of fraud, and their supporters stormed government buildings.
lead_paragraph: Down in the polls, the far-right president warned of voter fraud, despite no evidence. After losing, he claimed the vote was rigged. Thousands of his supporters — draped in the national flag and misled by conspiracy theories — then stormed Congress in a bid to overturn the results.

headline: The Mystery That Ended Two Women’s World Cup Dreams
abstract: An assault case that rattled one of France’s best soccer teams remains unresolved despite a series of arrests. Its main characters have paid a heavy price.
lead_paragraph: Aminata Diallo was being escorted from her foul-smelling holding cell to an interview room inside the Hôtel de Police in Versailles the first time she heard the name Tonya Harding.

headline: Cannibalism, or ‘Clickbait’ for Paleoanthropology?
abstract: A recent study offered the “oldest decisive evidence” that our ancient hominid ancestors ate one another. But the field has a long history of overstating such claims, other scientists note.
lead_paragraph: Everybody’s quick to see a cannibal. The Romans thought the ancient Britons feasted on human flesh, and the British thought the same about the Irish. Not a few prehistoric finds have been attributed, evocatively if not accurately, to the work of ancient cannibals. In 1871, Mark Twain commented on the discovery of the bones of a primeval man who purportedly had been made a meal of by his peers: “I ask the candid reader, Does not this look like taking advantage of a gentleman who has been dead two million years?”

headline: To Foreign Policy Veteran, the Real Danger Is at Home
abstract: Richard N. Haass says the most serious threat to global security is the United States.
lead_paragraph: Everywhere he has gone as president of the Council on Foreign Relations, Richard N. Haass has been asked the same question: What keeps him up at night? He has had no shortage of options over the years — Russia, China, Iran, North Korea, climate change, international terrorism, food insecurity, the global pandemic.

headline: Wagner Uprising Highlights China’s Risks With Russia
abstract: Xi Jinping needs Vladimir Putin to remain in power, and Russia to maintain stability, to help uphold the countries’ shared interests and to keep challenging the United States.
lead_paragraph: Just three months ago, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, was in Moscow clinking glasses with Vladimir V. Putin and expressing his confidence in the “firm support” the Russian president enjoyed among his people.

headline: The Art of Drinking? Right This Way, S’il Vous Plaît.
abstract: Anya Firestone leads what she calls “cou-tours” around Paris: Tours tailored to the clients’ interests, be they dinosaurs, drag queens or booze.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning at the Louvre, Anya Firestone handed out bottles of Evian. “Because ‘the art of drinking’ begins with hydration,” she said.

headline: An Early Heat Wave Upsets the Rhythm of Life in the South
abstract: Outdoor workers, fishermen and a group of students who waited all year for an intensive band camp are all searching for ways to adapt to the pervasive heat.
lead_paragraph: The drum line stood beneath a canopy of trees and rattled through rolls of sextuplets, with reddened shoulders glistening. As the sun blistered the parking lot, rows of trumpet, tuba and mellophone players marched back and forth, wiping sweat from their foreheads at the end of each passage of music.

headline: Everyone Knew the Migrant Ship Was Doomed. No One Helped.
abstract: Satellite imagery, sealed court documents and interviews with survivors suggest that hundreds of deaths were preventable.
lead_paragraph: From air and by sea, using radar, telephone and radio, officials watched and listened for 13 hours as the migrant ship Adriana lost power, then drifted aimlessly off the coast of Greece in a slowly unfolding humanitarian disaster.

headline: At the Front Lines of the Inflation Fight, Uncertainty Reigns
abstract: Central bankers and economists gathered and, amid concerns about persistent inflation, wondered about all the things they still don’t know.
lead_paragraph: When prices started to take off in multiple countries around the world about two years ago, the word most often associated with inflation was “transitory.”  Today, the word is “persistence.”

headline: Mutiny Provided Glimpse of a Post-Putin Russia. Is the Window Still Open?
abstract: Yevgeny Prigozhin’s revolt showed the possibility of a Russia after Vladimir Putin — and how pro-democracy forces may not be the ones that take over.
lead_paragraph: For a millisecond, it seemed possible.

headline: Paper Magazine, the Oral History: ‘They Were Wide Open’
abstract: It started as a chronicler of all things downtown. After success came, it morphed into something else. Now Paper has a new owner — and an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: Paper Magazine made its debut in June 1984. The first issue was a foldout poster with a look as minimalist as the publication’s name, matching the raw aesthetic that reigned over Lower Manhattan in those days.

headline: Does It Help to Know How Much the Boss Makes?
abstract: Sky-high C.E.O. pay isn’t a secret. And transparency about those big numbers can have surprising effects on the work force as a whole.
lead_paragraph: In 1933, the U.S. government asked 2,000 corporations listed on stock exchanges in New York to disclose how much they paid their top bosses — its first effort at making the pay of executives more visible. The idea was to encourage the “more conservative management of industry,” The New York Times reported when it published some of the results on its front page.

headline: The Dark Universe Is Waiting. What Will the Euclid Telescope Reveal?
abstract: The European Space Agency mission, which launched on Saturday, will capture billions of galaxies to create a cosmic map spanning space and time.
lead_paragraph: At 11:12 a.m. on Saturday, the Euclid spacecraft launched into space on its mission to chart the history of our universe as far back as 10 billion years ago.

headline: A Mother Reckons With Questions From Her Childhood
abstract: Beth Nguyen left Vietnam and her biological mother when she was a baby. Her memoir “Owner of a Lonely Heart” examines the ripple effect of those departures.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most poignant scenes in Beth Nguyen’s new memoir, “Owner of a Lonely Heart,” take place at night. Waking from restless dreams to scribble a sentence, checking in on her children in their beds, working at her desk after sunset, Nguyen is forever “writing in and into the darkness.” Awake at 3 in the morning, she nurses her newborn, counts the other lit-up windows and ponders questions familiar to all new parents: What was it like for my mom? Did she feel what I feel?

headline: Are Escalators and Moving Walkways Safe?
abstract: A woman in Thailand lost part of her leg after it was caught in an airport walkway this week. The accident has gotten a lot of attention, but such injuries are extremely rare.
lead_paragraph: An airline passenger in Thailand had part of her leg amputated this week after an accident on a moving airport walkway, the Thai authorities said.

headline: Ukraine Says It Is Ready for Arrival of Wagner Troops in Belarus
abstract: Ukrainian officials have tried to tamp down concerns while heralding their preparations, with President Volodymyr Zelensky nodding to plans for reinforcing the border.
lead_paragraph: As Belarus has ratcheted up its messaging about plans to offer refuge — and possibly work — to Wagner group mercenaries after a failed rebellion in Russia, Ukrainian forces say they are ready for any potential threat from their neighbor to the north.

headline: These Runners Confront Challenges Together
abstract: Both volunteer guides and runners with disabilities find community and support on the run through Achilles International.
lead_paragraph: About nine months after Mauricio Blandino suffered a traumatic brain injury in 2011, he was still working on being able to walk without assistance, and his outlook on life was in decline.

headline: An Indigenous Leader Who Raised Corruption Allegations Is Ousted
abstract: The Assembly of First Nations removed RoseAnne Archibald as its national chief this week after a harassment investigation
lead_paragraph: Happy Canada Day.

headline: Macron Cancels State Visit to Germany Amid Unrest at Home
abstract: More than 1,300 people were arrested overnight as riotous protests again gripped France over the police killing of a 17-year-old and the country’s president stayed home to deal with the crisis.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Saturday postponed a scheduled state visit to Germany as his government struggled to rein in violent protests over the deadly police shooting of a 17-year-old this past week.

headline: A Mini Challenge
abstract: A special edition of a Times puzzle designed for Morning readers.
lead_paragraph: Because I’m the creator of the New York Times Mini Crossword, people often assume that I’m a trivia expert. The embarrassing truth is that my trivia knowledge is heavily weighted toward things with four and five letters and a lot of vowels. Sure, I can tell you Elvis Presley’s middle name (Aron), or that a small sewing kit is known as an “etui,” but I’m not going to be much help at your local pub trivia night.

headline: A Salute to the Honest(ish) Russian Warlord
abstract: Now that Yevgeny Prigozhin has left the battlefield, who will tell Russians the truth?
lead_paragraph: Now that Yevgeny Prigozhin has left the battlefield, who will tell Russians the truth?

headline: A Salute to the Honest(ish) Russian Warlord
abstract: Now that Yevgeny Prigozhin has left the battlefield, who will tell Russians the truth?
lead_paragraph: The Opinion Video above is about Yevgeny Prigozhin, the Russian warlord who led a short-lived rebellion in Russia last week. The mutiny stunned the world, but it was a rebellion foretold. For months, Mr. Prigozhin, who commanded a totally ruthless mercenary force and is himself a product of the Russian kleptocracy, had been an unrestrained critic of the Russian military command, unleashing raw and candid critiques via his Telegram account. For reasons that are still not entirely clear, Russia’s leader, President Vladimir Putin, had allowed Mr. Prigozhin to hammer away at the Kremlin, which is particularly astonishing given how many of the government’s critics have wound up either imprisoned or dead.

headline: Where Reparations Stand in the U.S.
abstract: Despite pockets of momentum in various cities, the fight for reparations is an uphill struggle.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Jersey Boy Takes On Florida Man
abstract: With his old pal Trump, Christie goes from enabler to destroyer.
lead_paragraph: I offered to help prep Chris Christie for the debate with Donald Trump.

headline: I Know What Drives People to the Depths of the Ocean
abstract: Fabien Cousteau on the draw and importance of ocean exploration.
lead_paragraph: On my fourth birthday, my father found me at the bottom of the pool, sharing air supply, or “buddy breathing,” with a family friend; I was having my first scuba experience.

headline: How to Stave Off Constitutional Extinction
abstract: The best way to save it is to amend it.
lead_paragraph: Every Fourth of July, Americans celebrate independence, but it might be more significant, more pregnant with meaning, to celebrate amendment — the writing, ratifying and especially the amending of constitutions. Except lately there hasn’t been much to celebrate, with amendment having become a lost art. And a constitution that can no longer be amended is dead.

headline: Breakthroughs in Cancer Research and Treatment
abstract: Readers respond to Kate Pickert’s essay about the recent revolution in tackling cancer.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Supreme Court Has Opened the Door to Discrimination. Here’s How States Can Slam It Shut.
abstract: The court’s rulings are not the final chapter. The people often retain powerful ways to protect themselves through common-sense lawmaking.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has sided with a Christian graphic designer who refuses to create wedding websites for gay or lesbian couples. The result comes as little surprise. Writing for a six-justice conservative majority, Neil Gorsuch said that Colorado’s anti-discrimination law violates the designer’s right to free speech because the state “seeks to force an individual to speak in ways that align with its views but defy her conscience about a matter of major significance.”

headline: Long Live the King!
abstract: In an age of division, there’s something to be said for royals as a unifying symbol — plus, they are good for tourism and gossip.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With the thrill of coronation still in the air outside Buckingham Palace, it’s tempting for a Yankee to mock the British for the shop windows full of coronation plates and King Charles III coffee mugs. And how can we not roll our eyes when a slice of cake from the 2005 wedding between the new king and queen now sells for $1,600?

headline: John Roberts, Conservative Statesman
abstract: The chief justice behaves like a kind of G.O.P. president we haven’t had.
lead_paragraph: The unusual powers of the American Supreme Court have unusual effects on all its members, but especially on whichever justices hold the balance of power: Their role fits especially uneasily with the letter of the Constitution and modern democratic norms, evoking more ancient forms or concepts — the Roman censor, the Greek archon, Plato’s philosopher-king.

headline: Botswana and De Beers Sign Deal to Continue Rich Diamond Partnership
abstract: Under the new joint mining agreement, Botswana will immediately get a 30 percent share of the rough stones extracted, up from 25 percent, and it will rise to 50 percent within a decade, De Beers and government officials said.
lead_paragraph: A Botswana government official and the chief executive of De Beers, the international diamond conglomerate, signed interim agreements on Saturday to continue a lucrative, decades-long diamond mining partnership that had appeared to be breaking down in recent months.

headline: Child’s Play
abstract: An editor recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Why Platonic Friendships Are So Hard to Keep
abstract: On the show “Platonic” and what research says about old straight married people and opposite-sex friends.
lead_paragraph: The show “Platonic” is about a pair of old friends, Sylvia and Will, who reconnect after years on the outs. Sylvia (Rose Byrne) is a stay-at-home mom of three kids, and Will (Seth Rogen) is recently divorced and child-free. In the first episode of the series, on Apple TV+, we learn that their close friendship had broken up in part because Will’s ex-wife didn’t get along with Sylvia. Sylvia reaches out when she discovers they are no longer together.

headline: Fireworks Have a New Competitor: Drones
abstract: The light displays are quieter, safer and better for the environment.
lead_paragraph: Like many in the fireworks industry, Stephen Vitale is in the family business. He runs a fifth-generation company, Pyrotecnico, in New Castle, Pa. In October, he struck a surprising alliance with Nova Sky Stories, the drone company that Kimbal Musk acquired from Intel.

headline: Elena Kagan Has Had Enough
abstract: Her dissent on the student loan decision is revealing.
lead_paragraph: You have probably already heard about the Supreme Court’s decision in Biden v. Nebraska, where a 6-to-3 majority of the court — split along partisan lines — struck down President Biden’s student debt relief plan.

headline: Dutch King Apologizes for His Country’s Role in the Slave Trade
abstract: The Netherlands formally abolished slavery in its colonies in 1863, but has only recently begun to actively acknowledge its participation in the practice.
lead_paragraph: King Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands formally apologized on Saturday for his country’s role in the slave trade, a rare direct apology for a historical injustice by a sitting European monarch.

headline: From the Docks to Dodger Stadium, Los Angeles Workers Are Feeling Emboldened
abstract: California union members are pressuring employers over wages in one of the nation’s most labor-friendly states.
lead_paragraph: In the two months since they went on strike, screenwriters have become a fixture outside studios in Southern California, signs aloft as the traffic roars past. In many parts of America, theirs would be a lonely vigil.

headline: In the Paris Suburb Where Police Shot a Teenager, Violence and Vigilance
abstract: French suburbs have been rocked by riots that have tapped into a deep-seated resentment toward the police. Many residents understand the anger, but not the violence.
lead_paragraph: The first detonations of fireworks echoed through the neighborhood after a long, tense wait. A group of masked young people on scooters sped up a street lined with charred cars, heading toward the noise and billows of black smoke.

headline: At Funeral for Nahel M. Near Paris, Anguish, Anger and Racial Tensions
abstract: For many in the crowd, including hundreds who could not fit in the mosque to mourn the teenager killed by a police officer, his story felt familiar.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For two hours, in a mood of anguish and anger, hundreds of members of the large French Muslim community lined up outside the Ibn Badis mosque in Nanterre to mourn a teenager, one of their own, fatally shot by a police officer at a traffic stop.

headline: DeSantis, Seeking Attention, Uses L.G.B.T.Q. Issues to Attack Trump
abstract: The Florida governor sought to contrast his record opposing gay and transgender rights in a video highlighting comments made by the former president during the 2016 campaign — but has gotten some pushback.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s campaign shared a provocative video on Friday attacking the record of former President Donald J. Trump regarding L.G.B.T.Q. people that was widely condemned as homophobic, including by a prominent group representing gay and lesbian Republicans.

headline: Along With Conservative Triumphs, Signs of New Caution at Supreme Court
abstract: Chief Justice Roberts delivered both landmark victories for the right and significant rulings in which he forged alliances with the liberal justices.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ended its term this week in familiar fashion, issuing blockbuster conservative decisions on affirmative action, gay rights and student loans that divided along partisan lines, with the court’s three Democratic appointees in dissent.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Daughter and a Tale of Two Families
abstract: The story surrounding the president’s grandchild in Arkansas, who has not yet met her father or her grandfather, is about money, corrosive politics and what it means to have the Biden birthright.
lead_paragraph: There is a 4-year-old girl in rural Arkansas who is learning to ride a camouflage-patterned four-wheeler alongside her cousins. Some days, she wears a bow in her hair, and on other days, she threads her long blond ponytail through the back of a baseball cap. When she is old enough, she will learn to hunt, just like her mother did when she was young.

headline: Biden Rules Tighten Limits on Drone Strikes
abstract: The New York Times obtained a declassified version of rules for drone strikes and commando raids, along with a counterterrorism strategy document, via a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: U.S. military and C.I.A. drone operators generally must obtain advance permission from President Biden to target a suspected militant outside a conventional war zone, and they must have “near certainty” at the moment of any strike that civilians will not be injured, newly declassified rules show.

headline: U.S. Attorney in Hunter Biden Case Defends Investigation to House Republicans
abstract: David C. Weiss, a Trump appointee, denied that he had retaliated against an I.R.S. official who testified about divisions in the case.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. attorney in Delaware denied retaliating against an I.R.S. official who had disclosed details of the Hunter Biden investigation, and denied being blocked from pursuing serious charges against Mr. Biden, the president’s son, in Los Angeles and Washington.

headline: You May Not Have Asked; He Answered Anyway
abstract: Dan Schreiber’s “The Theory of Everything Else” is a return to the golden age of the trivia compendium.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when library shelves fairly sagged with strange reference works. Readers could peruse “The Best,” a 1974 hit that cataloged all things superlative, including bedsheets, sunscreens and life insurance policies. They could plunge into the RAND Corporation’s “A Million Random Digits with 100,000 Normal Deviates,” something of a bible among data scientists. Or they could cozy up with “The Dictionary of Imaginary Places,” containing entries on El Dorado and Jurassic Park.

headline: Darren Drozdov, Pro Wrestler Whose Career Was Cut Short, Dies at 54
abstract: A former professional football player, he had a promising career in the ring until an injury in 1999 left him quadriplegic.
lead_paragraph: Darren Drozdov, a former professional football player whose later career in pro wrestling was cut short after an accident in the ring that paralyzed him, died on Friday in Pomona, N.J. He was 54.

headline: About Two Feet
abstract: Rebecca Goldstein and Rafael Musa step it up with an arch Sunday crossword collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: In the Conference Realignment Game, a Deadline Is Not a Deadline
abstract: San Diego State had to make a decision about whether to leave the Mountain West Conference. It stayed put, but a move to the Pac-12 still beckons.
lead_paragraph: The latest turn of the conference realignment carousel driven by college football took me back to the Pleistocene period of journalism, when I worked as a summer news desk clerk amid the telex machines, pneumatic tubes and desk drawers full of booze at the dearly departed Los Angeles Herald Examiner.

headline: A Small Town’s Fourth of July: Flags, a 5K and Trump’s Attacks on American Institutions
abstract: Ahead of a holiday meant to celebrate the country’s history, the former president tore into American institutions and attacked his political opponents.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump drew a crowd of thousands on Saturday to a quiet South Carolina town’s Independence Day event, where he assailed the integrity of major American institutions and painted a dark portrait of the country ahead of a holiday meant to celebrate its underpinnings.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Beating Heat Wave Is Even Harder With Drums
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I’m on the sidelines dripping from every crevice. And they don’t even look grumpy about it.”

headline: Musk Says Twitter Is Limiting Number of Posts Users Can Read
abstract: The change on Saturday came as thousands of users complained about getting an error message that they had “exceeded” their “rate limit.”
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk said on Saturday that Twitter will temporarily limit the number of posts users can read per day to address concerns over data scraping, just hours after thousands of users reported widespread problems using the site.

headline: Proud Boys Fined Over $1 Million for Destroying Property of a Black Church
abstract: A judge in Washington, D.C., called the group’s actions, which included tearing down a Black Lives Matter sign, “overtly racist.”
lead_paragraph: A judge in Washington, D.C., on Friday ordered members of the Proud Boys to pay over $1 million to a historic Black church after it sued the far-right group for destruction of property in a December 2020 episode in which the group’s members tore down the church’s large Black Lives Matter sign.

headline: Mayors Are Targeted in Fifth Night of Protests Across France
abstract: Despite a generally calmer evening of demonstrations over the police killing of a 17-year-old, two attacks aimed at civic leaders highlighted the tinderbox situation.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of a suburb of Paris said on Sunday that protesters had rammed a car into his home and then set the vehicle on fire, injuring his wife and one of his children, as violent demonstrations across France over the police killing of a 17-year-old stretched into a fifth night.

headline: Corrections: July 2, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about financial planning by L.G.B.T.Q. people mis­stated the year that Yassin Adams arrived in the United States from Egypt. It was 2012, not 2015. The article also misstated the amount he pays for hormone care every three months. It is $500, not $5,000.

headline: The Naming of Gaming (and Its History)
abstract: The word “gaming” has been used in The Times to refer to gambling, video games and the recent rise of legalized sports betting.
lead_paragraph: On Page 8 of a Saturday issue of The New York Times in 1931 appeared the headline “‘Old West’ Returns in Nevada Gambling.” It announced a historical moment for the state, which, at the time, was the only one with legal casino gambling. “The hum and hubbub of gambling, the click-clack of machines and the clatter of poker chips were partly drowned by the staccato noise of a compressed air drill operated by a construction crew engaged in cutting through massive walls to enlarge the gaming room,” the article read.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Disappearing Act of Literary Translation, in Full View
abstract: Translators used to be secondary characters in the publishing industry. An issue of The New York Times Book Review aims to put their craft in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: The art of translation was on Gregory Cowles’s mind.

headline: ‘On a Whim, I Decided to Do a Silly, Shirley Temple-esque Tap Dance’
abstract: Waiting for the PATH, leaves fly like birds down Madison Avenue and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How a Mentor to At-Risk Young Men Spends His Sundays
abstract: Toddrick Brockington, who works at the Henry Street Settlement, tends to his mental health and his sneaker collection.
lead_paragraph: Before Toddrick Brockington got his job at the Henry Street Settlement, a nonprofit that supports Lower East Side residents, he served 26 years in prison for homicide. The irreversibility of that act troubles him still. It also keeps him mindful. “I appreciate life more, and when I say that, I don’t mean specifically my life,” he said, “I mean other people’s lives.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Japan’s Native Ainu Fight to Restore a Last Vestige of Their Identity
abstract: A group representing the Indigenous people has sued to regain the right, lost over a century ago, to freely fish for salmon in a Hokkaido river.
lead_paragraph: Masaki Sashima gazed through the fog one recent afternoon onto the gray waters of the Tokachi River in Hokkaido, Japan’s northernmost island. From here, his Indigenous people, the Ainu, once used spears and nets to catch the salmon they regarded as gifts from the gods.

headline: An Elite School, a Boy’s Suicide and a Question of Blame
abstract: An eighth grader was asked to leave Saint Ann’s, a prestigious private school in Brooklyn. Three months later, he ended his life. Now his parents are suing the school.
lead_paragraph: Ellis Lariviere was an eighth grader at Saint Ann’s, an elite private school in Brooklyn Heights, and he had a lot going for him. Teachers praised him as an “abundantly talented” artist, in a school that trumpeted the arts, and they described him as a positive presence in his classes. He had friends at school and an older brother who was thriving there. Ellis liked to cook for his family, and he imagined himself one day being a professional. He also had dyslexia and an attention deficit disorder, and he struggled to express complex thoughts in writing.

headline: A Fatal Shooting and a Hijab Ban: Two Faces of France’s Racial Divisions
abstract: The almost simultaneous police killing of Nahel Merzouk and a ban on head scarves in soccer were coincidental, but they illuminate France’s crisis of identity and inclusion.
lead_paragraph: Mama Diakité is a French citizen, raised in the suburbs of Paris by two immigrant parents, not far from where a 17-year-old boy was shot by the police during a traffic stop last week.

headline: Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s Great ‘Indiana Jones’ Adventure
abstract: “I’m not interested in perfectly behaved men or women,” the actress says. “I’m drawn to the ones who feel a bit dangerous.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m not interested in perfectly behaved men or women,” the actress says. “I’m drawn to the ones who feel a bit dangerous.”

headline: If You Don’t Have Anything Nice to Say, Don’t Be a Reference
abstract: Sometimes maximum awkwardness is worth it, if it means you can be honest.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Married to an Art Monster
abstract: In Charlotte Mendelson’s “The Exhibitionist,” a wife and children live in the shadow of a blustering, egotistic, once important painter.
lead_paragraph: “I prefer stories about squalor,” J.D. Salinger’s Esmé said. Esmé would have gone nuts for “The Exhibitionist,” the fifth novel by the English writer Charlotte Mendelson, which was longlisted for the Women’s Prize for Fiction in 2022. Set in sophisticated if not exactly moneyed quarters of London, with excursions to Edinburgh, it’s a model of tightly controlled domestic chaos.

headline: With End of Affirmative Action, a Push for a New Tool: Adversity Scores
abstract: To build a diverse class of students, the medical school at U.C. Davis ranks applicants by the disadvantages they have faced. Can it work nationally?
lead_paragraph: For the head of admissions at a medical school, Dr. Mark Henderson is pretty blunt when sizing up the profession.

headline: ‘American Made’ T-Shirts Are Having Their Best Year Yet
abstract: Flag-themed apparel and other Americana are always July Fourth favorites, but it now may matter more where those stars and stripes were stitched.
lead_paragraph: When Bayard Winthrop, the chief executive of the retailer American Giant, ordered the batch of shirts that his company would advertise for the Fourth of July, he didn’t think much of it. The retailer, which has been producing its apparel solely in factories around the United States for more than a decade, perennially leans into its “Made in America” pitch for Independence Day.

headline: House Republicans Demand Deep Cuts to Spending Bills They Rarely Support
abstract: G.O.P. leaders are tailoring their government funding legislation to far-right lawmakers who are insisting on deep cuts, but who hardly ever vote for spending bills. That’s raising the chances of a fall shutdown.
lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders working to write and pass the spending bills that fund the government face a major hurdle: Their own party — especially their most powerful, arch-conservative faction — has spent the last decade assailing federal spending and, with growing frequency, casting vote after vote against it.

headline: In Small Victory, Signs of Grueling Combat Ahead in Ukrainian Counteroffensive
abstract: Expecting a quick retreat, a volunteer Ukrainian unit instead faced two days of tough resistance from dug-in Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian soldiers thought the Russians would quickly retreat from Neskuchne, a tiny village in southern Ukraine, especially after a concerted artillery barrage and a rocket strike on their headquarters.

headline: A Rubik’s Cube, Thick Socks and Giddy Anticipation: The Last Hours of the Titan
abstract: Five voyagers climbed into the Titan submersible in hopes of joining the select few who have seen the wreck of the Titanic up close. But within hours, their text messages stopped coming.
lead_paragraph: The last time Christine Dawood saw her husband, Shahzada, and their son, Suleman, they were specks on the North Atlantic, bobbing on a floating platform about 400 miles from land. It was Father’s Day, June 18, and she watched from the support ship as they climbed into a 22-foot submersible craft called Titan.

headline: Andy Murray Returns to Wimbledon Aiming for Another Long Run
abstract: A decade ago, Murray broke the 77-year singles championship drought for British men at Wimbledon. It has been up and down since. Can he recapture the magic?
lead_paragraph: In late May, with most of the world’s best tennis players focused on the red clay at the French Open, Sir Andy Murray was 300 miles away on the other side of the English Channel, dialed in on preparations for the grass at Wimbledon.

headline: Chasing a World Record, They Endured Storms, Sharks and Freak Waves
abstract: In “Completely Mad,” James Hansen tells the stories of two men who in 1969 vied to be the first to row solo across the Atlantic Ocean.
lead_paragraph: The day before the Apollo mission landed two men on the moon, a British man named John Fairfax waded into Hollywood Beach, Fla., greeted by masses of cheering fans, having been the first person to row solo across the Atlantic Ocean. Eight days later, another Briton, Tom McClean, pulled his dory up a deserted beach in Blacksod Bay, Ireland, having rowed solo across the Atlantic in the opposite direction. While Fairfax was acclaimed and feted, McClean walked to the closest pub, alone.

headline: Uncensored Chatbots Provoke a Fracas Over Free Speech
abstract: A new generation of chatbots doesn’t have many of the guardrails put in place by companies like Google and OpenAI, presenting new possibilities — and risks.
lead_paragraph: A.I. chatbots have lied about notable figures, pushed partisan messages, spewed misinformation or even advised users on how to commit suicide.

headline: A Climate Laggard in America’s Industrial Heartland Has a Plan to Change, Fast
abstract: Lawmakers in Michigan have long fought tough pollution controls. But the toll of flooding, lost crops and damage to the Great Lakes appears to be changing minds.
lead_paragraph: From toxic algal blooms in the Great Lakes to sewage pouring into Detroit basements to choking wildfire smoke that drifted south from Canada, Michigan has been contending with the fallout from climate change. Even the state’s famed cherry trees have been struggling against rising temperatures, forcing some farmers to abandon the crop.

headline: A Champion Swimmer Returns, Slowly but Determinedly, to Competition
abstract: Caeleb Dressel, the seven-time Olympic champion, swam in the nationals after taking a break for mental health reasons. He didn’t win, but he loved everything about being back, even the chlorine.
lead_paragraph: During the eight months Caeleb Dressel spent not swimming, he was surprised by the things he came to miss. Some were simple, like blowing bubbles in the water or the feel of his toes on the grip tape of the starting blocks. But he also missed the chlorine — a swimmer’s nemesis — and the dry skin that comes with hours spent in the pool.

headline: A.I. Is Coming for Mathematics, Too
abstract: For thousands of years, mathematicians have adapted to the latest advances in logic and reasoning. Are they ready for artificial intelligence?
lead_paragraph: In the collection of the Getty museum in Los Angeles is a portrait from the 17th century of the ancient Greek mathematician Euclid: disheveled, holding up sheets of “Elements,” his treatise on geometry, with grimy hands.

headline: One Black Family, One Affirmative Action Ruling, and Lots of Thoughts
abstract: The Supreme Court ruling is just the latest version of a question that the Whitehead family — and the nation — has been grappling with for years: How to deal with the legacy of slavery?
lead_paragraph: For the Whiteheads, an African American family living in the city of Baltimore, race is discussed at the dinner table. In the car on the way to work and school and games. In the backyard while the sons practice sports.

headline: Lithium Scarcity Pushes Carmakers Into the Mining Business
abstract: Ford, General Motors and others are striking deals with mining companies to avoid raw material shortages that could thwart their electric vehicle ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Eager to avoid falling further behind Tesla and Chinese car companies, many Western auto executives are bypassing traditional suppliers and committing billions of dollars on deals with lithium mining companies.

headline: Russian Forces Launch Overnight Drone Attacks on Kyiv
abstract: The assault was the first pre-dawn drone barrage to target the Ukrainian capital in almost two weeks, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces launched a wave of drone attacks on Ukraine’s capital before dawn on Sunday, the first aerial assault on Kyiv by unmanned vehicles in nearly two weeks.

headline: Going, Going, Gone? Verstappen Wins Fifth Straight Race.
abstract: Verstappen extended his winning streak and widened his points lead. Is his third straight Formula 1 title only a matter of time?
lead_paragraph: He might oversleep one Sunday. He might take his Red Bull racecar to the mall and forget where he parked it. Or lose the keys. He might run into the worst run of bad luck in Formula 1 history.

headline: Employers Benefited from Affirmative Action. It’s Time to Step Up.
abstract: Colleges can’t do it alone anymore.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been traveling the country speaking to corporate executives about seismic shifts in higher education: a demographic cliff, decreased state funding, ever-rising tuition and a recent poll showing that over half of Americans don’t believe college is worth the cost. And, of course, the Supreme Court’s decision on affirmative action, which was handed down on Thursday, banning the use of race in college admissions.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘A Week With the Wild Children of the A.I. Boom’
abstract: In Silicon Valley’s hacker houses, the latest crop of young entrepreneurs is partying, innovating — and hoping not to get crushed by the big guys.
lead_paragraph: HF0, or Hacker Fellowship Zero, is a start-up accelerator that provides 12-week residencies for batches of fellows from 10 different start-ups. Their experience, which culminates in a demonstration day, is supposed to be the most productive three months of the fellows’ lives. Dave Fontenot, one of HF0’s founders, was inspired by the two years he spent living in monasteries in his 20s: While monastery life was materially ascetic, he found that it was luxurious in the freedom it gave residents to focus on the things that really mattered. And this year at the Archbishop’s Mansion in San Francisco, the home of the fellows, almost everyone has been monastically focused on what has become the city’s newest religion: artificial intelligence.

headline: Biden Is Taking Aim at Trump’s Biggest Strength
abstract: The administration is thickly populated with veterans of the Obama and Clinton White Houses. But it doesn’t see itself in comfortable continuity with those legacies.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden just offered a window into what a Biden-Trump rematch might look like. Well, part of it, at least.

headline: Our Childrens’ Lungs Are Uniquely Vulnerable to All This Wildfire Smoke
abstract: Like the smoke particles that seep into our homes through a window crack, the effects of fossil fuel pollution put nearly every child at risk.
lead_paragraph: When smoke from Canadian wildfires was descending upon parts of the Midwest and Eastern United States in early June, children and parents gathered in the courtyard of Burns Park Elementary in Ann Arbor, Mich., for a picnic celebrating the last week of school.

headline: Half the Police Force Quit. Crime Dropped.
abstract: This charming town has a powerful tale to tell.
lead_paragraph: In a staggering report last month, the Department of Justice documented pervasive abuse, illegal use of force, racial bias and systemic dysfunction in the Minneapolis Police Department. City police officers engaged in brutality or made racist comments, even as a department investigator rode along in a patrol car. Complaints about police abuse were often slow-walked or dismissed without investigation. And after George Floyd’s death, instead of ending the policy of racial profiling, the police just buried the evidence.

headline: As a Rabbi, I’ve Had a Privileged View of the Human Condition
abstract: We need religion now more than ever.
lead_paragraph: For over a quarter century now, I have listened to people’s stories, sat by their bedsides as life slipped away, buried their parents, spouses and sometimes their children. Marriages have ended in my office, as have engagements.

headline: Shooting in Baltimore Leaves 2 Dead and 28 Wounded
abstract: Frustrated officials sought information from the public about the shooting, which happened early on Sunday at a block party in the city’s southern neighborhood of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated Baltimore officials pleaded on Sunday with residents to come forward with information about a shooting at a crowded neighborhood block party that left two people dead and 28 others wounded, many of them teenagers.

headline: Fireworks for All, One Day Only, in Australia’s Last Frontier
abstract: In the vast and sparsely populated Northern Territory, residents’ sense of rugged individualism finds expression every July 1, explosively.
lead_paragraph: As fireworks lit up the three-mile stretch of coastline in the capital of Australia’s remote Northern Territory, a swath of grass along the beach went up in flames.

headline: Better Government in New York Depends on Higher Voter Turnout
abstract: Low turnout may help explain why the actions of elected officials in the city are sometimes bizarrely out of step with the constituents they serve.
lead_paragraph: Preoccupied by daily concerns like paying astronomical sums of rent and deluged by the occasional barrage of apocalyptic wildfire smoke, the average New Yorker clearly wasn’t closely focused on the local primary elections of 2023.

headline: ‘The Bear’ and a Chaotic Vision of Work
abstract: The show offers a depiction of work that’s turbulent, and, in its own way, enviable.
lead_paragraph: Business leaders are resorting to desperate measures to entice workers back to the office, my colleague Emma Goldberg reported recently. “It’s been three years of scattershot plans for returning to in-person work — summoning people in, not really meaning it, everybody pretty much working wherever they pleased,” she wrote. “Now, for the umpteenth time, businesses are ready to get serious.”

headline: Aficionados of TCM Fear for Its Future
abstract: Responses to Maureen Dowd’s column about Turner Classic Movies. Also: Birth control; the homelessness crisis; a landmark church; cultivated meat.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Los Angeles Hotel Workers Go on Strike
abstract: The strike is part of a wave of recent labor actions in the nation’s second-largest metropolis, where high costs of living have made it difficult for workers to stay afloat.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of hotel workers in Southern California walked off the job on Sunday demanding higher pay and better benefits, just as hordes of tourists descended on the region for the Fourth of July holiday.

headline: A Savory Goat Cheese and Dill Dutch Baby Drizzled With Honey and Lemon
abstract: Yewande Komolafe’s new recipe cooks up in a flash and disappears just as fast.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Purple finches have come to our bird feeder lately, eating after the cardinals have had their fill and before the red-winged blackbirds arrive. They whomp on the sunflower seeds and I feel as I do when I’ve served something to the children that they particularly like, as if I’ve achieved something, if only by chance.

headline: Frank Field, Who Brought Expertise to TV Weathercasting, Dies at 100
abstract: The first meteorologist to forecast the weather on New York television, he later became known for, among other things, publicizing the Heimlich maneuver.
lead_paragraph: Frank Field, a meteorologist who brought a groundbreaking credential to his job as a television weather forecaster in New York, and who had a long career presenting network programs on science and medicine, died on Saturday in Florida. He was 100.

headline: No Sparklers for These Folks
abstract: Whether because of crowds, politics or a loss of patriotism, some Americans are conflicted about celebrating the Fourth of July.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Benton, Ark., Malaya Tapp loved celebrating the Fourth of July with her family. “We would go to parades and see firework shows and hang out with friends,” she said. “It was always such a fun holiday.”

headline: Jon Haggins, Designer Who Slipped Into and Out of Fashion, Dies at 79
abstract: He was a member of a cohort of Black designers celebrated in the late 1960s and early ’70s. But struggles with financing led to several changes in direction.
lead_paragraph: Jon Haggins, a fashion designer and bon vivant who found fame in the late 1960s and early ’70s with his sinuous, sensuous designs, but who struggled with financing and shuttered and reopened his business and reinvented himself several times, most recently as the host of a travel show on cable television, died on June 15 at his home in Queens. He was 79.

headline: Tesla Sales Surge as Tax Credits Fuel Demand
abstract: Incentives and price cuts made Tesla electric cars cheaper than comparable gasoline models. But the company faces growing competition in China, a key market.
lead_paragraph: Tesla sales rose a better-than-expected 10 percent in the second quarter as the company led by Elon Musk benefited from government incentives and price cuts that made its electric cars less expensive than comparable gasoline models.

headline: ‘Urban Explorers’ and Accused Spies Chafe in Legal Limbo in Albania
abstract: Since their arrest at a derelict arms factory in Albania that they said they were exploring to document in pictures, the two Russians and a Ukrainian have been unable to leave the country.
lead_paragraph: Striking pictures of urban decay, including Soviet-era bomb shelters overgrown with weeds and the crumbling remains of factories across Eastern Europe, won a Russian photographer hundreds of thousands of Instagram followers eager to track her travels.

headline: As 2024 Voting Battles Heat Up, North Carolina G.O.P. Presses Forward
abstract: Republicans, whose edge in the state has narrowed in recent years, have gone on offense politically, leading to clashes over voting access and control over elections.
lead_paragraph: A closely watched political fight is developing in North Carolina over voting rights and control of elections, as Democrats aim to recapture a presidential battleground and Republicans look to win back the governor’s office.

headline: Robert Sherman, Veteran of the New York Airwaves, Dies at 90
abstract: For more than five decades, he brought together emerging classical and folk performers as well as established stars for interviews and live performances.
lead_paragraph: Robert Sherman, a charming, easygoing radio personality who hosted three long-running shows over more than a half-century on the New York classical music station WQXR-FM, died on Tuesday at his home in Ossining, N.Y., in Westchester County. He was 90.

headline: At the Sonic Sphere, a ‘Whoa’ Moment (and Some Music)
abstract: A hanging concert hall at the Shed in Manhattan purports to offer something “experimental, experiential and communal.” Our critic climbs the stairs.
lead_paragraph: “Whoa,” a man near me said as the curtains swept open.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: A Weekend of Unrest in France
abstract: Also, an investigation into the fatal sinking of a migrant ship.
lead_paragraph: France deployed 45,000 police officers across the country overnight Friday and Saturday, as violent riots convulsed multiple cities after the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old. The government said that about 2,000 people were arrested over two nights of demonstrations, with protesters burning cars, setting fire to buildings and lighting fireworks outside police stations.

headline: Fatal Shooting of a Teenager Shocks an Urban Oasis
abstract: A 15-year-old boy was killed near basketball courts at Riverbank State Park in Harlem, a popular spot for picnics, gardening and swimming.
lead_paragraph: As he often does, Clark Peña was sitting on a bench in Riverbank State Park in Harlem on Saturday evening, catching up on work and watching families play and picnic on a humid Fourth of July weekend.

headline: Large Crack Spotted in Roller Coaster Prompts Its Shutdown
abstract: A visitor to the North Carolina amusement park recorded a crack in a pillar of the ride, Fury 325, which is billed as one of the tallest of its kind.
lead_paragraph: A roller coaster at an amusement park in Charlotte, N.C., was shut down on Friday after a visitor spotted a large crack in one of the ride’s pillars.

headline: Having Initial Success
abstract: Sam Buchbinder offers moral support.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: Chicago and NASCAR, an Odd Couple With High Hopes, Take It to the Streets
abstract: The city and the sport, whose partnership was doubted by many, became acquainted on a soggy weekend downtown. The reviews were mixed.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy holiday weekend, the city of Chicago and the sport of NASCAR celebrated the unlikeliest of marriages with a lakefront ceremony.

headline: Yellen to Visit China in Bid to Steady Economic Ties
abstract: The trip to Beijing will be her first as Treasury secretary and is intended to ease tensions between the world’s two largest economies.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen will travel to China this week, a high-stakes visit that is intended to help stabilize the fraught relationship between the world’s two largest economies.

headline: Israel Launches Biggest Air Attack on West Bank in Nearly Two Decades
abstract: Israel said it used drone-fired missiles and ground troops against militant targets in the Jenin refugee camp. The assault killed at least eight Palestinians, the Palestinian health ministry said.
lead_paragraph: Israel launched its most intense airstrikes on the occupied West Bank in nearly two decades on Monday, and sent hundreds of ground troops into the narrow streets and alleys of the crowded Jenin refugee camp, saying it was trying to root out armed militants after a year of escalating violence there.

headline: Cracking Down on Dissent, Russia Seeds a Surveillance Supply Chain
abstract: Russia is incubating a cottage industry of new digital surveillance tools to suppress domestic opposition to the war in Ukraine. The tech may also be sold overseas.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Ukraine unfolded last year, Russia’s best digital spies turned to new tools to fight an enemy on another front: those inside its own borders who opposed the war.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Simmering tensions in France.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a teenage boy was killed in a fatal traffic stop outside Paris, prompting days of violent protests. Days later, France’s top administrative court upheld a ban on religious symbols that has prevented a French citizen who wears a hijab from playing soccer. The cases are different, but each touches upon deep-seated issues of identity and inclusion in the country.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Fourth of July Fireworks and ‘Moonshine’
abstract: Networks air specials for Independence Day, and the CW premieres a Canadian comedy about a dysfunctional family running a summer resort.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 3-9. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Urban Explorers,’ or Russian Agents?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “People don’t think about Russians as victims of this government, but we are. Everyone is watching you. Everyone looks at you suspiciously.”

headline: No Corrections: July 3, 2023
abstract: No corrections that appeared in print on Monday, July 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Word of the Day: disdainful
abstract: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word disdainful has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 27 in the book review “My Father the Frustrated Artist” by Christopher Sorrentino:

headline: Who’s Winning the Trump vs. DeSantis Meme Wars?
abstract: The battle reflects the importance of social media for campaigns, and the growing threat of fake images and videos.
lead_paragraph: The battle reflects the importance of social media for campaigns, and the growing threat of fake images and videos.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: New Migrants Have a Year to Apply for Asylum. Many Won’t Make It.
abstract: Tens of thousands of people who crossed the border in the last year planned to apply for asylum. But the complexities of the process mean many will fail.
lead_paragraph: Santos Lopez uprooted his family and walked nearly 2,000 miles on a dangerous trek from Honduras to the United States last spring to escape from a violent gang that was extorting him. The group demanded a monthly payment, he said, to allow him to run his car shop in peace.

headline: GOATs Are Everywhere in Sports. So What Really Defines Greatness?
abstract: Athletes from Tom Brady to Serena Williams to LeBron James have all been tabbed the Greatest of All Time. Faced with the term’s pervasive use, our columnist considers how sports heroes become transcendent.
lead_paragraph: If you are reading this column, I have great news: You’re the GOAT!

headline: She’s Going Into 6th Grade and Already Saving for College
abstract: A New York City program encourages children to save from kindergarten.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today, two education-related topics. We’ll meet a rising middle schooler whose focus is on saving for college. And we’ll look at what the decision on affirmative action might mean for students who don’t attend schools with race-conscious admissions policies.

headline: For Most College Students, Affirmative Action Was Never Enough
abstract: The loss of affirmative action is an opportunity to refocus on supporting middle- and lower-tiered colleges.
lead_paragraph: The loss of affirmative action is an opportunity to refocus on supporting middle- and lower-tiered colleges.

headline: Do Yoga Pants Qualify as Real Pants?
abstract: A reader is searching for comfortable, stretchy pants that can be worn for more than sun salutations.
lead_paragraph: Yoga pants — that is to say, leggings but with a higher waist and made from thicker material than actual leggings (sometimes, though not necessarily, with a bit of flare at the ankle) — are garments that, especially during pandemic lockdowns, became something of a joy to wear.

headline: $2.9 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1929 Spanish-style house in Glendale, an Edwardian home in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Solana Beach.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Royal Canyon, a historic district with many Spanish and Mediterranean Revival homes built in the 1920s and an active neighborhood association that holds events throughout the year. It is about a mile from Verdugo Woodlands Elementary School, a well-ranked public school for students in kindergarten through sixth grade. The property is also close to Verdugo Park, which has open space for picnics and fields for soccer and baseball, and to The Americana at Brand, an outdoor shopping mall.

headline: It’s Not America’s Unhappiest Birthday
abstract: How much pessimism about the future of the United States is warranted?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, happy almost Independence Day. In the spirit of the holiday: Is America toast?

headline: The Tragedy of John Roberts
abstract: The term that just ended must have been a torment for the chief justice. But his behavior has only made matters worse.
lead_paragraph: In June 2012, at the end of a contentious Supreme Court term that decided, among other things, the fate of the Affordable Care Act, Chief Justice John Roberts prepared to leave for Malta, to teach a course on the court. “Malta, as you know, is an impregnable island fortress,” he joked on the eve of his trip. “It seemed like a good idea.”

headline: Tell Me There Isn’t a Witch Hunt in Tennessee
abstract: We live in two countries now: one where basic civil and human rights are recognized and another where ideological extremists can decide how everyone else lives.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Two weeks ago, while the rest of America was absorbed by the hunt for a doomed submersible, people in Tennessee discovered that their attorney general was conducting a witch hunt.

headline: At UChicago, a Debate Over Free Speech and Cyberbullying
abstract: A student objected to a class, “The Problem of Whiteness,” and tweeted the lecturer’s photo and email address. Hate mail poured in. What should the school do?
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Journey, a lecturer at the University of Chicago, thought little of calling her new undergraduate seminar “The Problem of Whiteness.” Though provocatively titled, the anthropology course covered familiar academic territory: how the racial category “white” has changed over time.

headline: Number of Migrants Crossing U.S. Southern Border Is Down. But for How Long?
abstract: Officials say the lull after nearly two years of increased crossings is not going to last.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two months since the lifting of a public health order that allowed the United States to swiftly expel migrants at the southern border, the number of migrants crossing into the country has not only sharply declined, but has also remained relatively low.

headline: With DeSantis on the Stump, Disney Sees a Long Campaign Ahead
abstract: The company, long allergic to controversy, is likely to be the subject of very public and partisan criticism throughout the Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: As Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has embarked on his presidential run, a main pillar of his message is “holding woke corporations accountable,” as a fund-raising email put it on Tuesday. And to hammer home that sentiment, he has been railing against one target at nearly every campaign stop: Disney.

headline: America’s Foes Are Joining Forces
abstract: Under both Donald Trump and President Biden, Washington has helped create the very anti-American partnerships it now bemoans.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration recently made two grim announcements: Iran is helping to manufacture drones for Russia. China operates a spy base in Cuba.

headline: 6 Podcasts to Help You Take an Actual Break This Summer
abstract: These shows offer emotional escape with explorations of mysterious cultural moments, soothing soundscapes and stories about petty interpersonal drama.
lead_paragraph: Whatever fantasies you have of a blissfully relaxed summer, the reality often fails to measure up. Many workers can’t (or won’t) take enough time off; parents need to find ways to keep their children occupied once school’s out, and summer travel sometimes comes with enough stressors to cancel out any chill factor. But even if you find yourself in less-than-zen circumstances, you can still choose to slow down and give yourself a mental break this summer.

headline: Ben and Bryan Shelton, Son and Father, Hit the Road as Player and Coach
abstract: Bryan Shelton guided his son for years as a junior and in college. Now he is taking the reins on the ATP Tour. Next up: Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: Last year, when Ben Shelton decided to leave college and turn professional, he wondered aloud to his father, Bryan, a former player on the men’s tennis tour, if they ought to embark on a venture together.

headline: A Blood Test Predicts Pre-eclampsia in Pregnant Women
abstract: The assessment is the first advance in diagnosing the deadly condition since it was discovered more than a century ago, experts said.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a blood test that can identify pregnant women who are at imminent risk of developing a severe form of high blood pressure called pre-eclampsia, a leading cause of disability and death among childbearing women.

headline: Prue Leith’s Great American Road Trip
abstract: The “Great British Baking Show” judge steps out of the tent to sample the flavors of the U.S. on a 2,200-mile drive.
lead_paragraph: ​​Last fall, my husband and I set our hearts on renting an R.V. for a road trip from Los Angeles to Florida. We imagined picnicking on mountaintops in New Mexico, sleeping under the stars in Texas and barbecuing prawns (the R.V. would come with a grill, of course) on a Mississippi levee. In the end, our 2,200-mile American journey ended up being memorable, but for none of those reasons.

headline: When Missiles Strike Kyiv, These Psychologists Race to Help
abstract: Emergency responders in Ukraine’s capital offer not only physical care to the victims of airstrikes, but also mental health support for survivors in crisis.
lead_paragraph: Hands shaking as she covered her mouth, a woman looked toward a gaping hole in the side of a high-rise, the contents of apartments spilling out of its side.

headline: The Days Were Long and the Years Were Longer
abstract: In her new memoir, “The Light Room,” Kate Zambreno looks back on the unending togetherness of family life during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: We find ourselves in the age of Covid literature. The publishing cycle, notoriously long, has caught up with the pandemic, and a book on the subject no longer seems like a novelty. But like the pandemic itself, the genre is still slippery. Are we at its height? Will it come back, in some new variant? How scared should we be?

headline: Giving New York a Try, and Leaving the Big Stuff to Fate
abstract: A woman from Sydney wondered how long she could last in New York. Five years later, she’s really beginning to feel at home.
lead_paragraph: Adriana Stefanatos didn’t know how long she’d stay in New York — Three weeks? Three months? — when she moved from Australia. Five years later, she feels like she’s finally made it her own.

headline: A New Kind of Disaster Aid: Pay People Cash, Before Disaster Strikes
abstract: Experiments suggest that sums as low as $50 can help the world’s poorest protect themselves and their property in ways they couldn’t otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Disasters can push the world’s poorest deeper into poverty. Now aid agencies are trying something new. They’re giving small bits of cash to people just before disaster strikes, instead of waiting until afterward.

headline: Will America Be Ready for Its 250th Birthday?
abstract: History is a partisan battleground. A troubled national planning commission is attempting a reboot. Here comes the Semiquincentennial, ready or not.
