lead_paragraph: It wasn’t the first time we had met a Russian soldier in Ukraine. During the course of our eight-month investigation into potential war crimes committed by Russian forces in Bucha last year, we spoke to two Russian paratroopers in Ukrainian custody.

headline: At Wimbledon, Everyone’s Chasing Swiatek, Sabalenka and Rybakina
abstract: Expect the three top-ranked women to dominate the tournament. But at least one, the defending champion Elena Rybakina, says she isn’t taking any opponent for granted.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Elena Rybakina was nervous. She was embroiled in her first match on Wimbledon’s Centre Court as defending champion. She was facing a tough opponent in Shelby Rogers. The roof was closed and she was recovering from a virus.

headline: Paralyzed by a Police Bullet, He Describes a Life Forever Changed
abstract: “Why did you run from me?” an officer asked Khalif Cooper, then 28, immediately after the shooting in Paterson, N.J. “I was scared,” he answered.
lead_paragraph: The bullet, fired by a police officer who was sprinting into the 3 a.m. darkness, struck Khalif Cooper with improbable precision.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: This Bulgarian Writer’s Books Bend Time
abstract: Georgi Gospodinov won the prestigious International Booker Prize this year for “Time Shelter,” a satirical novel exploring lofty ideas about nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: When the Bulgarian author Georgi Gospodinov was writing the novel “Time Shelter,” in 2019, he agonized over a scene he thought might be over the top, even for a work of absurdist fiction.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Women’s Bracket Showcases a Potential Big Three in the Making
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 5, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I felt so bad, and I just couldn’t watch it. Every time if Wimbledon would be on TV, I would cry.”

headline: Harvard, Howard and Middle Tennessee State: 7 Students on 7 Campuses
abstract: This is a portrait of college life in America before the fall of affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: This is a portrait of college life in America before the fall of affirmative action.

headline: Why Yale and Harvard Should Start Funding High Schools
abstract: The best way to find bright disadvantaged minority candidates is to help create them.
lead_paragraph: The best way to find bright disadvantaged minority candidates is to help create them.

headline: How to Fix College Admissions Now
abstract: With the Supreme Court’s recent ruling on affirmative action, the world of higher education is poised for a transformation.
lead_paragraph: With the Supreme Court’s recent ruling on affirmative action, the world of higher education is poised for a transformation.

headline: The Best Affirmative Action Workaround Is to Invest in H.B.C.U.s
abstract: Black institutions can offer more justice through education than diversity ever could.
lead_paragraph: Black institutions can offer more justice through education than diversity ever could.

headline: What Colleges Across America Can Learn From U.C. Berkeley
abstract: How we’ve fought to maintain diversity on campus — without affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: How we’ve fought to maintain diversity on campus — without affirmative action.

headline: Affirmative Action Still Exists — for the Rich
abstract: Admissions should focus on class, not race, to help the disadvantaged.
lead_paragraph: Admissions should focus on class, not race, to help the disadvantaged.

headline: College Admissions Have Never Been a Meritocracy
abstract: Now that affirmative action is gone, it’s time to rethink the ideal campus.
lead_paragraph: Now that affirmative action is gone, it’s time to rethink the ideal campus.

headline: A Diverse Campus Is Still Worth Fighting For. But How?
abstract: What we’re losing is bigger than just an admissions policy.
lead_paragraph: What we’re losing is bigger than just an admissions policy.

headline: America Is Living on Borrowed Money
abstract: The nation needs to chart a new course on federal debt.
lead_paragraph: The federal debt is as old as the nation, and adding to it is sometimes prudent. For governments confronting existential crises like wars or pandemics, borrowing makes sense as a way to mobilize national resources, as the economist Barry Eichengreen wrote in the 2021 book “In Defense of Public Debt.” Government borrowing and spending are necessary to stimulate the economy during recessions. And Treasuries, safe and liquid, play a critical role in the global financial system — so much so that in the late 1990s, when a period of economic growth and reduced military spending allowed the government to sharply reduce borrowing, economists and bankers raised alarms about the consequences of too little federal debt.

headline: ‘Dig, Dig, Dig’: A Russian Soldier’s Story
abstract: An inmate hoped to start over with a clean slate by fighting in Ukraine. Instead, he was confronted by the drudgery of trench work and the terror of battle. “You’re going in as meat,” he said he was told.
lead_paragraph: The Russian soldier was captured only days after arriving on the front line in eastern Ukraine. He had little training. But he knew how to disassemble and fire his rifle and where to put a tourniquet.

headline: ‘Wham!’ Review: They Made It Big, Then Broke Up
abstract: A new movie documents George Michael and Andrew Ridgeley’s storming of the pop airwaves as the duo Wham! and laughs past the thorny questions.
lead_paragraph: The new documentary about George Michael, Andrew Ridgeley and the music they made as Wham! — it’s just called “Wham!” — found me in a moment of need for a nostalgic, fantastical elixir, something short, sweet and tangential to my feeling of national blues. For one thing, Wham!, the duo, made soul music that popped. And the movie dances past all of the thorny moral and ethical questions of white people making Black stuff. Those questions don’t exist at all in this movie. That’s the fantasy. And I’m here for it. But also: Wham! didn’t have any thorns.

headline: How to Deal With Financial Trauma
abstract: Experiences like economic hardship or medical expenses can distort people’s feelings and behaviors around money, causing them to sabotage their financial futures.
lead_paragraph: Rahkim Sabree owns a home in Hartford, Conn., invests and has money in savings. But that isn’t always enough to make him feel secure. Unexpected expenses, regardless of the cost, bring him discomfort.

headline: It’s a World of Inflation
abstract: Prices are still rising too fast for comfort in many major economies, and policymakers across the globe are trying to wrestle them under control.
lead_paragraph: From Melbourne to Manchester to Miami, people are struggling under the weight of hefty price increases for the things they buy each day.

headline: For Some Key Voters, Trump Has Become Toxic
abstract: But we are still in the dark about 2024.
lead_paragraph: One of the most significant developments in the run-up to the 2024 presidential election has emerged largely under the radar. From 2016 to 2022, the number of white people without college degrees — the core of Donald Trump’s support — has fallen by 2.1 million.

headline: In the Azores: Earth, Water, Fire and Air, Sometimes All at Once
abstract: Volcanic São Miguel, one of the nine islands in this Portuguese archipelago in the Mid-Atlantic, offers landscapes and experiences that are at once wild and serene.
lead_paragraph: It was 6 a.m. — 2 a.m. to my raddled East Coast brain — and my husband, daughter and I were staggering through customs in the Ponta Delgada Airport, on the island of São Miguel, the largest of the nine islands that make up Portugal’s Azores archipelago.

headline: This Melon Salad Is Pure Pleasure
abstract: Flavor and texture take top billing in a simple Jamaican dish.
lead_paragraph: When I cook for myself, the only real guideline I follow is the pursuit of flavor — everything else is a suggestion. And sometimes, particularly with a cuisine I’m not too familiar with, this means following a recipe to the letter. But more often than not, pleasure is the goal, which means steamed cabbage and carrots sprinkled with shichimi togarashi; or Red Stripe-marinated chicken, battered in potato starch, fried and slathered with miso mayo; or, among friends, a whole fried snapper served alongside basil, fried shallots, sa tế and lettuce, for wrapping. Usually, it’s in this quest for flavor that I realize what’s actually most comforting for me in a given moment.

headline: $2.5 Million Homes in Colorado, Washington and Maine
abstract: A midcentury-modern showplace in Denver, a renovated hillside home in Seattle and an 1812 Federal house on the coast in Kittery Point.
lead_paragraph: This house, designed by Richard W. Quinn, a past president of the American Institute of Architects’ Connecticut chapter, is on the market for the first time since it was built in 1966. It is half a block from the popular oversized sundial at Cranmer Park and less than a mile from public elementary and middle schools. A movie theater and a Trader Joe’s are also nearby, on Colorado Boulevard.

headline: Five Minutes That Will Make You Love Avant-Garde Jazz
abstract: This challenging subgenre, including the subset of free jazz, is driven by the fire of spontaneity, and its rules are still being written. Eleven writers, critics and musicians share their favorites.
lead_paragraph: Lately The New York Times has asked jazz musicians, writers and scholars to share the favorites that would make a friend fall in love with Herbie Hancock, New Orleans jazz, Sun Ra or Mary Lou Williams.

headline: Andrew Ridgeley on George Michael and Life After Wham!
abstract: “The only thing I ever wanted to do from the age of 14 was to be in a band,” but he is content with the duo’s short career, which is chronicled in a new documentary.
lead_paragraph: If you weren’t a teenager in 1984, it might be hard to understand this, but here goes: There are Gen X-ers who remember where they were the first time they saw the video for the Wham! clap-along pop anthem “Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go.”

headline: West Bank Teenagers Are Writing Out Their Last Words
abstract: In one of the deadliest periods in years in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, young Palestinians drawn into the struggle against Israel are writing farewell messages to their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Before Amr Khamour, 14, was killed, shot twice by Israeli troops as he hurled stones at a military jeep in his hometown, he spent his time dancing with friends, recording TikTok videos on his phone.

headline: How to Squeeze a Feminist Farce Into an English Country House
abstract: “The Cottage” is a throwback play with a modern mind-set. The cast, playwright and director talk about pulling off the comedy and landing all the “darlings.”
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway comedy “The Cottage” begins with a pair of lovers in an English country house in 1923, the morning after their annual illicit tryst. Sylvia, played by the “Legally Blonde” star Laura Bell Bundy, is aflame with passion for her paramour, Beau, played by Eric McCormack of “Will & Grace.”

headline: Christina Najjar’s Napa Valley
abstract: The influencer known as Tinx offers a list full of the “rich mom” energy she’s known for, but her choices won’t all break the bank.
lead_paragraph: The author and influencer Christina Najjar — known to her more than two million social media followers as Tinx — spent eight formative years in the Bay Area of Northern California, attending Stanford University, where she majored in English, and working in San Francisco for the Gap, Poshmark and other companies. During her time in the region, she frequently decamped to wine country seeking revelry and respite.

headline: Bill de Blasio and Chirlane McCray Are Separating
abstract: Mr. de Blasio’s marriage helped fuel his campaign for mayor of New York, and his intense personal and political bond with his wife drew admiration and scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: About two months ago, after another stale Saturday night of binge-watching television at their Brooklyn home, Bill de Blasio and Chirlane McCray surprised themselves.

headline: At Stoneleigh, a Native Approach to Formal Landscaping
abstract: If you can create a native garden that looks at home on the grounds of a historic Philadelphia Main Line estate, you can do it anywhere.
lead_paragraph: If you can create a native garden that looks at home on the grounds of a historic Philadelphia Main Line estate, you can do it anywhere.

headline: Guess Who’s Been Paying to Block Green Energy. You Have.
abstract: As regulated monopolies, utilities have the unique ability to force customers to fund their political activities through monthly bills.
lead_paragraph: To avoid the worst impacts of climate change, we have to make two big transitions at once: First, we have to generate all of our electricity from clean sources, like wind turbines and solar panels, rather than power plants that run on coal and methane gas. Second, we have to retool nearly everything else that burns oil and gas — like cars, buses and furnaces that heat buildings — to run on that clean electricity.

headline: 250 Pounds of Pot, a Taco Truck and a Cross-Country Road Trip
abstract: Scott Von Doviak’s novel “Lowdown Road” evokes “The Dukes of Hazzard” — in a good way.
lead_paragraph: Scott Von Doviak has done the unthinkable: made me take the television show “The Dukes of Hazzard” more seriously. His latest novel, LOWDOWN ROAD (Hard Case Crime, 287 pp., paperback, $15.95) — with its hapless good ol’ boy antiheroes clad in aviator sunglasses, crotch-hugging Levis and Lynyrd Skynyrd T-shirts — clearly takes inspiration from the series.

headline: Michelle Wie West Wants One More Crack at a Major
abstract: Wie West, one of the savviest stars women’s golf has ever had, intends to step away after the U.S. Women’s Open at Pebble Beach. She could be done as soon as Friday.
lead_paragraph: You could see the head tilts and darting glances when people peered around Pebble Beach's Gallery Cafe, or as visitors sat on the patio that looks toward the cypress-guarded 18th green by Stillwater Cove. They surfaced at a luncheon with Brandi Chastain and Kristi Yamaguchi, and during a climb up a flight of stairs, and a stroll through a lobby.

headline: Formal Landscaping With Native Plants? Yes, It’s Possible.
abstract: If you can create a native garden that looks at home on the grounds of a historic Philadelphia Main Line estate, you can do it anywhere.
lead_paragraph: The task facing anyone designing a garden: “We’re predicting the future — we’re seeing what’s not there.”

headline: Living In ... Hanover, N.J.
abstract: With good schools and relatively low property taxes, this Morris County community is popular with buyers. No surprise, then, that the market is tight.
lead_paragraph: With good schools and relatively low property taxes, this Morris County community is popular with buyers. No surprise, then, that the market is tight.

headline: The D.N.C. Has a Primary Problem
abstract: The White House wanted South Carolina to vote first in 2024. The Democratic National Committee obliged. It hasn’t gone according to plan.
lead_paragraph: Last December,  the 30-odd members of the Democratic Party’s rules and bylaws committee filed in to the Omni Shoreham, the glittering resort hotel that once hosted Franklin D. Roosevelt’s inaugural ball. All of the Democrats, many of them gray-haired habitués of the rubber-chicken circuit, knew they had come to Washington to hash out, after months of debate, what the presidential-primary calendar would look like come 2024.

headline: In ‘The Horror of Dolores Roach,’ the Empanadas Are to Die For
abstract: Justina Machado and Aaron Mark went uptown to sample the savory pastries that play a central role in their new horror-comedy — minus the mystery meat.
lead_paragraph: You know those days when you would kill for an empanada? Well.

headline: Hanover Township, N.J.: ‘A Nice, Family-Oriented Place’
abstract: With good schools and relatively low property taxes, this Morris County community is popular with buyers. No surprise, then, that the market is tight.
lead_paragraph: Tired of the scorching weather and the constant threat of wildfires, Andrew and Carolyn Trexler decided early this year that it was time to abandon their five-year experiment of living in Northern California. So they left to return to their home turf of North Jersey. The only problem was securing a house in a highly competitive market.

headline: An Artist Whose Language Is Painting
abstract: Christina Quarles discusses representation, trades and protein shakes.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Los Angeles as the fair-skinned daughter of a Black father and a white mother, Christina Quarles, 38, can recall the first time her sense of identity was challenged: “In elementary school, there was this book of famous Black people throughout history and my nana was in there,” she said. (Her paternal grandmother, Norma Quarles, was one of the first Black TV journalists.) “I would show the other kids that was my grandmother in the book but get told, ‘No, you’re not Black.’ It was this disconnect between how I was raised with my own personal sense of my biography, and then to be met with such resistance when I would express that to people.”

headline: A Drone and a Crane Save the Day as China Reels From Extreme Weather
abstract: Heavy rains and heat waves have affected parts of China and the Asia Pacific region this week. More of the same was in the forecast.
lead_paragraph: China and several other Asia Pacific countries were reeling from monsoonal floods and stultifying temperatures on Wednesday, the latest disruptions in what forecasters say could be a long summer and autumn of extreme weather around the world.

headline: Today’s Top News: Israel’s Deadly Operation in the West Bank, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: How MrBeast Became the Willy Wonka of YouTube
abstract: The social media megastar regularly goes viral for giving away money in extremely extravagant and colorful ways.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Donaldson, better known as MrBeast, has become a sensation on YouTube for ostentatious and sometimes absurd acts of altruism.

headline: ‘Smallville’ Actress Who Recruited Women for Nxivm Is Released From Prison
abstract: Allison Mack, the former “Smallville” actress, was sentenced to three years in prison in 2021.
lead_paragraph: Allison Mack, the “Smallville” actress who recruited women to the cultlike group Nxivm and assisted prosecutors in convicting its leader of sex trafficking and other crimes, was released from a federal prison this week after serving two years of a three-year sentence on racketeering and racketeering conspiracy charges.

headline: Social Class Is Not About Only Race
abstract: Class diversity has been a blind spot for many colleges. Will that now change?
lead_paragraph: The University of Virginia, one of the country’s top public universities, enrolls a strikingly affluent group of students: Less than 15 percent of recent undergraduates at UVA have come from families with incomes low enough to qualify for Pell Grants, the largest federal financial aid program.

headline: Pro-Vaccine Views Are Winning. Don’t Fear the Skeptics.
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is getting a lot of play, but his views are in the minority.
lead_paragraph: With Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, vaccine skepticism has been back in the headlines. Though Kennedy has said he isn’t anti-vaccine and that his children have had vaccines, and his campaign manager (the former Democratic congressman and presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich) says calling Kennedy “anti-vax” is a “left-handed smear,” Kennedy continues to suggest a link between vaccines and autism — a link that has leaned heavily on flawed and retracted science. He’s also been a vocal opponent of Covid vaccines.

headline: A New Ruling Could Complicate Biden’s Policy on Social Media
abstract: A judge’s decision to limit how the administration can interact with platforms could chill the White House’s efforts to utilize and police big tech.
lead_paragraph: Government efforts to interact with social media platforms took a major hit on Tuesday when a federal judge restricted the Biden administration from communicating with tech companies about a broad array of online content.

headline: Easy Mode: Clues for Friday, July 7, 2023
abstract: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.

headline: I Had an Affair With Someone My Spouse and I See Socially. Help!
abstract: After ending a yearslong extramarital affair, a reader worries about a coming dinner party that will be attended by both the former lover and the reader’s spouse.
lead_paragraph: I had an extramarital affair for several years. It ended recently — abruptly and unpleasantly — and I blocked all digital and telephonic communication with my ex to ensure that I don’t weaken and get involved again. The affair was fulfilling sexually and emotionally, but it was also taboo: We are both otherwise happily married and socialize together as couples. Now, I am apprehensive about future encounters. Recently, we all juggled our calendars to attend a small, upcoming dinner party at a third couple’s home. How should I handle this? I don’t want to reach out and ask for a truce; my emotions are still too raw — with hurt and anger not far from the surface. I don’t know how to justify canceling the dinner to my spouse, but I’m afraid I may lose it if I go.

headline: Meet Blackbraid, a Black Metal Musician With Native American Roots
abstract: Sgah’gahsowáh, the artist behind the one-man band, combines the genre’s traditional heavy sounds with a focus on nature. His new album, “Blackbraid II,” is out Friday.
lead_paragraph: Black metal has long been associated with the gray skies, snowy landscapes and Norse mythology of Scandinavia. Most people know it, if at all, as the musical genre associated with church burnings and gory homicides in early 1990s Norway. (Those events were documented in the book “Lords of Chaos,” which was adapted into a 2019 feature starring Rory Culkin as the misanthropic, occultist musician Euronymous.)

headline: A Tech Checklist for the Dark Side of Summer Weather
abstract: This season has seen excessive heat, violent storms and hazardous smoke already, but you can prepare for future events with a few apps and tools.
lead_paragraph: Summer is in full swing now, but along with vacation trips, camp and lazy days, extreme weather has arrived for many parts of the country. If you live in an area that’s prone to such conditions, it helps to be ready. Here are some tips to help you use your tech through major meteorological moments — sometimes, even when power and cell service are shaky.

headline: How Extreme Weather Could Threaten California’s Dams
abstract: A conversation with Christopher Cox, who wrote about the near-failure of the Oroville Dam and whether it could happen again.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you’ve heard that climate change in California is exacerbating what’s sometimes called “weather whiplash”: Dry periods are stretching longer, interrupted by storms that are growing bigger and more furious.

headline: The Man Who Wants to Be the Biggest Thing in Fashion
abstract: Guram Gvasalia of Vetements revealed that he had been making the costumes for Madonna’s postponed tour right in the middle of couture week. It was a classic move.
lead_paragraph: Of all the many Madonna-related posts that have appeared on social media since it was revealed that the artist had been taken ill and forced to postpone her “Celebration” tour, one in particular stood out — not just because of what it said, but because of what it showed.

headline: China Took Her Husband. She Was Left to Uncover His Secret Cause.
abstract: He was brilliant, quirky and intensely private — and also, she now suspects, an anonymous dissident blogger who had won fame for years of evading the surveillance state.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t as if Bei Zhenying didn’t know that her husband was unusual, or even that he had some secrets.

headline: Federal Officials Hatch a Three-Pronged Defense Against Another ‘Tripledemic’
abstract: This fall, Americans will be urged to get shots against the flu, Covid and, if they’re older, R.S.V.
lead_paragraph: To prevent a repeat of last winter’s “tripledemic” of respiratory illnesses, Americans will be encouraged to roll up their sleeves not just for flu shots but for two other vaccines, one of them entirely new.

headline: Three Vaccines for Fall: What You Need to Know
abstract: Here’s who should get the flu, Covid and R.S.V. vaccines, and when.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans have had one or more shots of the flu and Covid vaccines. New this year are the first shots to protect older adults from respiratory syncytial virus, a lesser-known threat whose toll in hospitalizations and deaths may rival that of flu.

headline: In the Age of A.I., Tech’s Little Guys Need Big Friends
abstract: Creating a new A.I. system requires lots of money and lots of computing power, which is controlled by the industry’s giants.
lead_paragraph: The tech industry loves its garage start-up stories. From Hewlett-Packard to Google, the tales of bootstrapped companies that have turned into giants have inspired generations of entrepreneurs.

headline: As Businesses Clamor for Workplace A.I., Tech Companies Rush to Provide It
abstract: Amazon, Box, Salesforce, Oracle and others have recently rolled out A.I.-related products to help workplaces become more efficient and productive.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Mark Austin, the vice president of data science at AT&T, noticed that some of the company’s developers had started using the ChatGPT chatbot at work. When the developers got stuck, they asked ChatGPT to explain, fix or hone their code.

headline: Large Explosion in Russian-Occupied Makiivka
abstract: A video posted on Telegram and geolocated by The New York Times shows an explosion in Makiivka.
lead_paragraph: A video posted on Telegram and geolocated by The New York Times shows an explosion in Makiivka.

headline: ‘Until Tomorrow, Wordle!’: The Week 2 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
abstract: Jack Cole, 16, reflects on his 648 days of playing the popular New York Times game.
lead_paragraph: Our annual Summer Reading Contest invites teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This week, the second of 10, we received 753 entries. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Jack Cole, as well as to the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.

headline: A Corn Pudding That Tastes Like Elotes
abstract: “It’s like Mexican street corn and cornbread had a baby.”
lead_paragraph: Hi. It’s me, Kim Severson! It’s that time of the summer when everyone but me goes on vacation. This means I get to talk about something my friends and family are tired of hearing, which is how much reporting power fuels everything we do over here in the best section of The New York Times.

headline: Transgender Athletes in Women’s Sports
abstract: Readers respond to a column by David French. Also: Banning nuclear weapons; premature book reviews; walking in the city.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Can I Resell My Taylor Swift Concert Tickets for Thousands of Dollars?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the fairness of selling a scarce good at an exorbitant price.
lead_paragraph: My sister was lucky enough to get six tickets to the Taylor Swift concert in New Jersey for face value ($130) through Ticketmaster Verified Fans. She is using three of them for me, herself and my megafan daughter, and then decided recently to sell the remaining three. She looked at ticket prices online and seats in our section were being offered for around $3,000 each, plus the $900 in fees added on the last page of checkout.

headline: Deadly Louisiana Shooting Caps a Holiday Weekend of Violence
abstract: The shooting, which left four dead and seven wounded, was one of several in multiple cities since Friday.
lead_paragraph: As the long Fourth of July weekend drew to a close, a final spasm of gun violence close to midnight left four people dead and seven others wounded at an outdoor party in Shreveport, La., following earlier shootings in Philadelphia, Baltimore, Fort Worth and other cities.

headline: In Too Deep
abstract: Laura Trethewey’s “The Deepest Map” explores the new world of oceanic exploration — and its dangers.
lead_paragraph: In the past days, the world has been riveted by the story of the Titan submersible, which we now know imploded some 1,600 feet from the wreckage of the Titanic, killing all aboard. Beyond the human tragedy — and the macabre fact that James Cameron’s blockbuster is trending online — comes an opportunity for serious reflection.

headline: New Car Sales Jumped in the Second Quarter
abstract: General Motors, Toyota and other automakers sold more trucks and sport utility vehicles as supply chain problems eased and demand remained strong despite rising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Some of the country’s biggest automakers reported big sales increases for the second quarter on Wednesday, the strongest sign yet that the auto industry was bouncing back from parts shortages and overcoming the effects of higher interest rates.

headline: German Government Slashes Spending, Except on the Military
abstract: The proposed package foresees spending about 6 percent less in 2024 from this year, in a return to financial austerity. But the severity of the cuts to social services drew sharp criticism.
lead_paragraph: Germany plans to slash social benefits and rein in government debt but increase the amount spent on the military in 2024, according to a federal budget approved Wednesday by the government of Chancellor Olaf Scholz.

headline: Pentagon Review Faults Oversight of Classified Information
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin ordered the assessment after accusations that an Air National Guardsman disclosed sensitive information.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon’s security and oversight measures have failed to keep pace with the proliferation of military facilities that handle classified information and the personnel who work there, but the Defense Department does not have a systemic problem in keeping its secrets secret, a new review made public on Wednesday concludes.

headline: Mass Shooting in Philadelphia: What to Know
abstract: An assailant dressed in a ski mask and body armor killed five people and injured two others, the authorities said, in what officials are treating as a random attack.
lead_paragraph: An attacker using a military-style rifle killed five people and injured two children during a shooting spree in a Philadelphia neighborhood on Monday, firing shots on the open street and bringing terror to passers-by before being caught by the police. Officials said they are treating the shooting as a random attack.

headline: With the Stone of Destiny and Mary’s Crown, Scotland Names Charles King
abstract: While this one was purely ceremonial, it offered the king a chance to mend fences with a nation that is not hugely enamored of him or the monarchy.
lead_paragraph: For most royals, one coronation would be enough.

headline: Israeli Woman Held for Months in Iraq by Shiite Militia Linked to Iran
abstract: Elizabeth Tsurkov, an Israeli researcher, was seized in late March by an Iraqi Shiite group shortly after leaving a Baghdad cafe. The office of the Israeli prime minister confirmed she was being held.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli researcher missing for months in Iraq is being held by a Shiite militia, according to a statement from the office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: When Did the U.S. Become a Democracy?
abstract: Until fairly recently, that would have seemed like a peculiar question. But many experts on American history and political science say U.S. democracy is relatively young.
lead_paragraph: How old were you when the United States became a democracy?

headline: GQ Removes Article Critical of Warner Bros. Discovery C.E.O.
abstract: The magazine took down the story on David Zaslav without any explanation, an unusual move for a publication.
lead_paragraph: The article on the GQ website was a fierce critique of David Zaslav, comparing the Warner Bros. Discovery chief executive to the ruthless business tycoon played by Richard Gere in “Pretty Woman.”

headline: Where the Republican Candidates Stand on Ukraine
abstract: The war has illuminated one of the biggest ideological divides within the Republican Party: between members who see a significant global role for the United States, and a more isolationist wing.
lead_paragraph: Few issues have been more divisive among the Republican presidential candidates than the war in Ukraine and how, if at all, the United States should be involved.

headline: Yusef Salaam Is Declared Winner of Harlem City Council Primary Race
abstract: Mr. Salaam was one of the Central Park Five who were wrongly convicted and then exonerated in the rape and assault of a jogger in Central Park in 1989.
lead_paragraph: Yusef Salaam, one of five Black and Latino men whose convictions were overturned in the 1989 rape and assault of a female jogger in Central Park, cemented his victory in a highly contested City Council primary race in Harlem, according to The Associated Press on Wednesday.

headline: Fed Officials Were Wary About Slow Inflation Progress at June Meeting
abstract: Federal Reserve officials are debating how high to raise interest rates to fully wrangle inflation. The debate was in focus at their meeting last month.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials were concerned about sluggish progress toward lower inflation and wary about the surprising staying power of the American economy at their June meeting — so much so that some even wanted to raise rates last month, instead of holding them steady as the central bank ultimately did, minutes from the gathering showed.

headline: P.S.G. Says Mbappé Must Sign a New Deal or Leave the Club
abstract: Nasser al-Khelaifi, the president of Paris St.-Germain, was introducing the team’s new coach when he turned to tough talk on the future of his team’s biggest star.
lead_paragraph: It was at the unveiling of yet another new coach that Paris St.-Germain’s president made his first public statement on the future of his team’s best player. He did not equivocate and left little room for compromise.

headline: Who Knew the Colosseum Was So Old? Tourist Apologizes for Defacement.
abstract: A man who etched his initials and those of his girlfriend in a wall of the nearly 2,000-year-old monument wrote a letter of apology, and his lawyer says he is hoping for a plea bargain.
lead_paragraph: A man seen on video last month using his keys to etch his love for his girlfriend on a wall in the Colosseum in Rome has written a letter of apology, saying he had no idea the nearly 2,000-year-old monument was so ancient.

headline: Commercial-Scale Wind Farm Off New Jersey Coast Approved
abstract: The project in the waters southeast of Atlantic City marks the third major wind farm authorized by the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Bureau of Ocean Energy Management on Wednesday approved the construction of up to 98 wind turbine generators off the coast of Atlantic City, N.J., as part of a Biden administration plan to install offshore wind sites along the country’s coasts.

headline: Biden Says He Is ‘Anxiously’ Waiting for Sweden to Join NATO
abstract: In an Oval Office meeting, President Biden again backed the plan for Sweden to join the military alliance, but movement has been stalled by Turkey’s opposition.
lead_paragraph: President Biden told Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson of Sweden on Wednesday that he was “anxiously looking forward” to the country’s acceptance into NATO, reiterating their shared goal of strengthening the Western alliance against the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Secret Service Investigating Who Brought Cocaine Into the White House
abstract: A baggie that was confirmed to contain cocaine was found in the guest lobby of the West Wing on Sunday evening, an agency spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: The Secret Service is looking to find out who brought a baggie of cocaine that was discovered on Sunday evening into a guest lobby of the West Wing of the White House, an agency spokesman said on Wednesday.

headline: At 20, an Upstate Arts Haven Keeps Breaking New Ground
abstract: The Fisher Center at Bard has become an incubator for commercially promising new work like Justin Peck’s “Illinois,” while holding tight to its experimental roots.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday night, a group of young people were gathered in this bucolic hamlet in the Hudson Valley, building a campfire of sorts. There were no matches or flames, but there were lanterns, chirping crickets, fir trees swirled with haze and, at one point, a zombie attack.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Diplomat’ and More
abstract: I’m a health and science reporter for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a health and science reporter for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: Israel’s Major Incursion in the West Bank Is Over. Did It Solve Anything?
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians said the armed groups that were the targets of the military raid would quickly rebuild and the Israeli soldiers would be back soon.
lead_paragraph: Before 8 a.m. on Wednesday, the Israeli military said it had finished its incursion into the West Bank city of Jenin, aimed at curbing attacks on Israelis by armed Palestinians. Barely five hours later, about 25 miles away, shots fired from a car with Palestinian plates hit an Israeli police vehicle, causing damage but no casualties.

headline: Holiday Fireworks Worsen Air Quality Nationwide
abstract: Seattle, New York City and Los Angeles were among the places with high air quality indexes after fireworks celebrations.
lead_paragraph: The air quality index Wednesday morning reached the “unhealthy” benchmark in cities across the United States including Seattle, Los Angeles and Pittsburgh. Millions of Americans have felt the effects of thick smoke from Canadian wildfires in recent weeks, but experts said the smog this time was likely to be a combination of Fourth of July fireworks, stagnant air and, in some areas, West Coast wildfires.

headline: Sarah Benson Thinks Audiences Want a Challenge
abstract: At the helm of Soho Rep, Benson presided over a long streak of ambitious, thought-provoking works. As she heads out the door, she reflects on her vision for theater’s future and plans for her own.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary American theater would not be the same without a 65-seat theater tucked away on a quiet TriBeCa side street. Founded in 1975, Soho Rep has produced new, often boundary-pushing plays, including, in recent years, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s “An Octoroon,” in 2014, and Jackie Sibblies Drury’s Pulitzer Prize-winning “Fairview,” in 2018.

headline: Prosecutors Face Conspiracy Theories in Jan. 6 Trial
abstract: A man charged with plotting to storm the Capitol is the latest to use baseless assertions as a defense, leading prosecutors to warn of “a circuslike atmosphere.”
lead_paragraph: Almost from the moment that a pro-Trump mob stormed into the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, conspiracy theories have ricocheted from the fringes of the internet to the corridors of Congress. Republican officials and others on the right have dismissed the attack as the work of mere tourists, or sought to depict it as a false-flag operation by shadowy leftist groups — or even the federal government.

headline: Man Gets Life Sentence in Rape of Child Who Traveled for Abortion
abstract: Gerson Fuentes agreed to a plea deal after he was charged with raping a 9-year-old Ohio girl who later traveled to Indiana for an abortion.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio who had traveled to Indiana for an abortion became a flashpoint in the nationwide abortion debate. On Wednesday, the Ohio man who had been charged with raping the girl pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life in prison with the possibility of parole.

headline: The Best Early Prime Day Deals of 2023
‘Elemental’ Review: In Pixar’s New Movie, Sparks Fly
Sweet Cold Foam Recipe
Years After Iranian Missiles Downed a Passenger Jet, a Suit Seeks Answers
abstract: In 2020, Iranian missiles struck a Ukraine Airlines flight, killing all 176 people on board. Four countries have filed suit in The Hague demanding a credible account and full compensation.
lead_paragraph: On a clear January morning in 2020, Ukraine Airlines Flight 752 was struck by two Iranian missiles just three minutes after leaving an airport in Tehran, killing all 176 passengers.

headline: U.S. ‘Fully’ Supports Sweden’s Bid to Join NATO, Biden Says
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has blocked Sweden’s NATO membership bid.
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has blocked Sweden’s NATO membership bid.

headline: The Gift of Holiday Men
abstract: The hole left by generations of absentee fathers is filled by a powerful matriarchy.
lead_paragraph: Kema Christian-Coates’s childhood was filled with “holiday men,” absentee fathers — including her own — who returned each year around Christmas only to disappear again. Her father’s absence left a hole in her life and the fear that she, like her mother and grandmother, would never find a man she could rely on.

headline: Medicare Advantage Plans Offer Few Psychiatrists
abstract: A new study finds that people have a very difficult time finding doctors in their networks under the private-sector policies.
lead_paragraph: People with private Medicare coverage may not be getting the mental health services they need because they cannot find a psychiatrist within their plan’s network, according to a new study.

headline: California Man Hid Mother’s Death for 3 Decades to Collect Her Benefits
abstract: Donald Felix Zampach, 65, received more than $830,000 in payments from the government intended for his late mother. He also took possession of her home while it was still in her name.
lead_paragraph: A California man has admitted that he hid his mother’s death from the federal government for over three decades so that he could collect more than $800,000 in benefits intended for her, prosecutors said.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Israel’s West Bank Raid Ends
abstract: Also, fatal floods in China and other Asian countries.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said yesterday that it had withdrawn from the occupied West Bank city of Jenin after a large-scale incursion that killed at least 12 Palestinians, left one Israeli soldier dead and sent thousands fleeing from their homes over the past two days.

headline: Biden Backed NATO Expansion, but It Won’t Be Easy
abstract: Also, a flurry of gun violence. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson of Sweden at the White House today to emphasize America’s support for the Nordic nation’s swift acceptance into NATO.

headline: For Yusef Salaam, a Landslide Just Might Be the Best Revenge
abstract: After his wrongful conviction as one of the Central Park Five was overturned, Mr. Salaam found it hard to rebuild his life. Now he stands to take office next year.
lead_paragraph: This week, 34 years after he and four other teenage boys who barely knew one another were bound together by notorious failures of justice, Yusef Salaam was officially declared the winner in the Democratic primary for a seat in New York’s City Council, having received almost 64 percent of the vote. Given that more than three-quarters of voters in the district identify as Democrats, we can assume that beginning in January, he will represent Harlem, where he grew up, was arrested and returned after serving nearly seven years in prison for a crime he did not commit.

headline: DeSantis Campaign Continues to Struggle to Find Its Footing
abstract: The Florida governor, who has yet to demonstrate himself as a campaigner on a national stage, has been plagued by a series of unforced errors and has yet to make a strong case against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, looking to shift his run for president into a higher gear after an early series of missteps, spent the last two weeks rolling out an immigration policy and holding town halls with voters. But rather than correcting course, he stumbled again this week, raising questions about where his campaign is heading.

headline: Director of New Women’s History Museum Withdraws, Citing Family Issues
abstract: Nancy Yao was to lead a Smithsonian museum about the influence of American women. Her withdrawal came amid a review of how she had handled sexual harassment complaints in an earlier post.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian’s choice for the founding director of its developing American Women’s History Museum has withdrawn from the role, the institution said Wednesday.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in July
abstract: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out Behjat Sadr’s earthy canvases in Greenwich Village or rafa esparza’s portraits in TriBeCA. And don’t miss John Fahey’s works on paper in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out “Luxe, Calme, Volupté” on the Lower East Side or “Reclamation” at Hudson Yards. And don’t miss Rachel Rossin’s “mechs” in Chinatown.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Olivia Rodrigo Returns, Fall Out Boy Denies History
abstract: Plus: “Barbie” memes and the Grimace Shake attacks.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Disinformation Researchers Fret About Fallout From Judge’s Order
abstract: They said a restriction on government interaction with social media companies could impede efforts to curb false claims about vaccines and voter fraud.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge’s decision this week to restrict the government’s communication with social media platforms could have broad side effects, according to researchers and groups that combat hate speech, online abuse and disinformation: It could further hamper efforts to curb harmful content.

headline: How to Talk About Marital Unhappiness Before It’s Too Late
abstract: Former Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City and his wife, Chirlane McCray, announced they were separating after growing apart. Here’s what experts advise if you’re wondering about your own relationship.
lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City and his wife, Chirlane McCray, announced that they were separating after nearly 30 years in an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday. Their story begins with an “aha” moment in the midst of what the article calls yet another “stale Saturday night of binge-watching television” together.

headline: Threads, Instagram’s ‘Twitter Killer,’ Has Arrived
abstract: Here’s what to know about Instagram’s new app for public conversations and how it differs from Twitter.
lead_paragraph: After months of speculation and secrecy, Mark Zuckerberg’s long-rumored competitor app to Twitter is here.

headline: Ukraine Strikes a Russian-Occupied City, Igniting a Huge Blast
abstract: Ukrainian and Russian officials differed on whether a military or civilian area had been struck. Earlier in the war, Russia lost dozens of soldiers, if not hundreds, in a strike on the city.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military launched an overnight strike on the Russian-occupied city of Makiivka, showing that it could still attack targets deep behind Russian lines as its troops fight in grueling trench warfare in a counteroffensive to reclaim land.

headline: The Supreme Court Didn’t Put Racism on a Leash. It Granted It License.
abstract: By striking down affirmative action, justices take the absurd position that racism must be ignored for racism to be overcome.
lead_paragraph: There is a recurrent theme in American history: the clawing back of hard-won progress. And the Supreme Court last week used the most specious of arguments to do so with affirmative action.

headline: Coco Lee, ‘Crouching Tiger’ and ‘Mulan’ Singer, Dies at 48
abstract: A pop star across Asia by her early 20s, Ms. Lee reached international recognition with an Oscar-nominated song in 2001.
lead_paragraph: Coco Lee, a Chinese American singer and songwriter best known for performing an Oscar-nominated song in the hit film “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,” died on Wednesday in a hospital in Hong Kong. She was 48.

headline: El Paso Gunman Is Confronted by Victims’ Families at Sentencing
abstract: The attacker faces sentencing after pleading guilty to federal hate crimes charges. “Why is it us in pain and not you?” asked one survivor of the rampage that killed 23.
lead_paragraph: Emotional testimony from survivors and victims’ families began on Wednesday in the federal sentencing hearing for the gunman who killed 23 people and injured dozens more at a Walmart store in El Paso, one of the deadliest attacks targeting Latinos in modern U.S. history.

headline: Suspect Showed Troubling Signs Before Philadelphia Rampage, D.A. Says
abstract: People who lived with the suspect told investigators that he was wearing a bulletproof vest around the house in the days before five people were gunned down.
lead_paragraph: As the streets outside his home echoed with pops, Darryl Steplight thought it was fireworks on the eve of the Fourth of July. He quickly learned otherwise. A man in body armor, and carrying an AR-15-style rifle, had opened fire at random in the neighborhood, killing five and wounding two, including a 2-year-old.

headline: Bum Knees, Stress Fractures and Mental Anguish. Oh, Canada.
abstract: Canada has been striving to become a top tennis nation for two decades, and with two Wimbledon finals appearances and a U.S. Open title it seemed to be working. Then things quieted down.
lead_paragraph: It may be a little hard to remember, with all the injuries, career detours and mystifying losses, but there was a time when everything seemed possible for Canadian tennis.

headline: At Least 16 Are Killed in Suspected Gas Leak in South Africa
abstract: A cylinder with a type of gas often linked to illegal mining was found in a shack at an encampment near the city of Boksburg, an official said.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — At least 16 people were killed in a gas leak at an informal housing encampment on the outskirts of Johannesburg, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: Ruling Puts Social Media at Crossroads of Disinformation and Free Speech
abstract: The case, which could alter how the government battles disinformation, is a flashpoint in a broader effort by conservatives to document what they contend is a liberal conspiracy to silence their views.
lead_paragraph: Two months after President Biden took office, his top digital adviser emailed officials at Facebook urging them to do more to limit the spread of “vaccine hesitancy” on the social media platform.

headline: Zelensky said he warned allies the counteroffensive would proceed slowly amid the wait for weapons.
abstract: Ukraine’s president said he had wanted to start the military push sooner, in an interview with CNN.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said he had warned the United States and other Western nations that the counteroffensive would go slowly the longer it took allies to deliver the promised weapons and ammunition needed for the mission.

headline: Judge Unseals More of Affidavit Used to Seek Mar-a-Lago Search Warrant
abstract: The newly disclosed sections revealed more of the evidence cited by the Justice Department as a basis for searching former President Donald J. Trump’s club and residence last summer.
lead_paragraph: A federal magistrate judge unsealed on Wednesday additional portions of the affidavit that the F.B.I. used last summer to obtain a warrant to search for sensitive documents at Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s private club and residence in Florida, revealing a few new details about how that extraordinary process had unfolded.

lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Yankees Pitcher Suspended for Violating Domestic Violence Policy
abstract: Jimmy Cordero, a reliever, will miss the rest of the season after an investigation led by Major League Baseball.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Cordero, a relief pitcher for the Yankees, has been suspended for the rest of the season for violating Major League Baseball’s domestic violence policy, the league and the team announced on Wednesday.

headline: A Russian missile strike kills six people in Lviv.
abstract: The authorities said more than 30 people had been injured and warned that there could still be people trapped under the rubble.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian missiles killed at least six people and destroyed dozens of homes in Lviv before dawn on Thursday, in what officials said was the biggest attack on the western Ukrainian city since Russia launched its full-scale invasion more than 16 months ago.

headline: Yellen Faces a Diplomatic Test in Her High-Stakes Visit to China
abstract: The Treasury secretary will need to defend export controls and tariffs while explaining that the United States does not aim to harm China’s economy.
lead_paragraph: At her confirmation hearing in early 2021, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen struck a tough tone on China, describing it as America’s most important strategic competitor and pledging to confront its “abusive, unfair and illegal practices” that she said were harming businesses and workers in the United States.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Cost of ‘Financial Trauma’? A Distorted View of Money.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 6, 2023.

headline: Corrections: July 6, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about an increase in tuna prices in Tunisia referred incorrectly to salata mechouia. While the dish includes grilled vegetables, it typically does not contain eggplant.

headline: Can A.I. Be Funny? This Troupe Thinks So.

lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at a New York-based comedy group that is using artificial intelligence to generate jokes. And we’ll bring you highlights from an interview with former Mayor Bill de Blasio and his wife, Chirlane McCray, on their separation.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: A meeting between the leaders of the U.S. and Sweden.
lead_paragraph: In less than a week, NATO leaders will meet in Vilnius, Lithuania. But the prime minister of Sweden will continue not to be among them, given the continued opposition of Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, to Sweden’s membership.

headline: How 2 Firefighters Died in a Blaze They Were Ill-Equipped to Face
abstract: The fire broke out on a ship carrying more than 1,000 vehicles, owned by an Italian company and anchored at Port Newark.
lead_paragraph: The 9:30 p.m. call for help came from a place where firefighters from Newark are seldom sent: Port Newark, one of the busiest shipping hubs in the country, and one that operates largely as a world unto itself.

headline: Word of the Day: banquet
abstract: This word has appeared in 135 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word banquet has appeared in 135 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 29 in the Opinion essay “I’ve Spent 28 Years Pondering the Wild World of My Home” by Margaret Renkl:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: In Film and Television, Food for Thought and Interpretation
abstract: Tejal Rao uses her experience as a restaurant critic to write about food served onscreen.
lead_paragraph: Italian beef sandwiches, fruit-studded buns and Flamin’ Hot Cheetos have been top of mind for Tejal Rao lately.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: How Style Not Com Became the Darling of the Front Row
abstract: Beka Gvishiani started as a fan, with little access to powerful people in fashion. Now he’s at every show.
lead_paragraph: What does it take these days to become one of the most sought-after people reporting from fashion’s front row? Beka Gvishiani, the man behind the hit Instagram account Style Not Com, will tell you, in the same straightforward language that defines Style Not Com, nostalgically named for Style.com, the groundbreaking Condé Nast site that brought runway fashion to the internet in 2000. (Style.com shut down and morphed into Vogue Runway in 2015.)

headline: Ex-Prisoners Face Headwinds as Job Seekers, Even as Openings Abound
abstract: An estimated 60 percent of those leaving prison are unemployed a year later. But after a push for “second-chance hiring,” some programs show promise.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. unemployment rate is hovering near lows unseen since the 1960s. A few months ago, there were roughly two job openings for every unemployed person in the country. Many standard economic models suggest that almost everyone who wants a job has a job.

headline: Are These the Most Expensive Jeans in the World?
abstract: Valentino and Balenciaga make the case that sometimes the most spectacular clothes are the hardest to recognize — and replicate. Chanel takes it easy.
lead_paragraph: At around peak rush hour on the penultimate day of the couture shows a line of black cars snaked out of Paris, past grassy fields and factories 30 miles north to the 16th-century Château de Chantilly. Guests in brightly colored plumage were disgorged to teeter down a long stone walkway that opened to a vista of reflecting pools and manicured lawns set around a central fountain surrounded by a labyrinth of benches. That was where, as golden hour set in, a magic Valentino show began — with Kaia Gerber in a pair of jeans and a white shirt.

headline: 36 Hours in the Florida Panhandle
abstract: Pick your own paradise along State Road 30A, long a beloved vacation destination for Southerners.
lead_paragraph: Pick your own paradise along State Road 30A, long a beloved vacation destination for Southerners.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Life After Password Sharing
abstract: A reader’s access to a streaming service has been cut off. Should she pay for her own account?
lead_paragraph: Hannah writes: I shared a streaming-service account with my mom. But we’ve been cut off thanks to the company’s new password-sharing restrictions. I want to pay for a new account. But my partner, Bobby, doesn’t want to reward this company’s behavior. Who’s right?

headline: Uncoordinated? You Can Still Be an Athlete.
abstract: Many people avoid physical activity because they see themselves as clumsy. But, with practice, there are ways to fix that.
lead_paragraph: Carmen Chavez spent much of her life avoiding sports. Her aversion, she said, stemmed from the embarrassment of middle school gym class. As more athletic girls slammed volleyballs across the net, she worried about tripping or being hit by a ball. In order to avoid playing, she often sat on the sidelines and acted as the announcer.

headline: Kennedy, Christie and the Supreme Court: Are They Changing the Race?
abstract: A painful ruling from the court can sometimes free a party from an unpopular stance.
lead_paragraph: When I returned from a trip to China almost exactly eight years ago, I found my inbox full of requests from editors to write about two huge stories that unfolded while I was gone: the Supreme Court’s decision to legalize same-sex marriage and the emergence of a surprising candidate who entered the race after my departure, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Special Episode: Meta’s Twitter Rival Arrives, with Adam Mosseri
abstract: Instagram Threads — it’s like Twitter, except it’s not run by Elon Musk.
lead_paragraph: Instagram is no stranger to taking product ideas from other companies and turning them into their own successes. Just ask Snapchat about Instagram Stories or TikTok about Instagram Reels. This time, the company is coming for Twitter with Instagram Threads.

headline: America, Shall I Compare Thee to a Chevy Volt?
abstract: Move over, apple pie. We’re picking new American symbols.

headline: Douglas Stuart Doesn’t Need 3 People at His Dream Dinner Party
abstract: “I regret that I never met Hilary Mantel,” says the Booker-winning Scottish novelist, whose most recent book, “Young Mungo,” is now out in paperback. “I would be delighted with three of her.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Federal Judge Defends Clarence Thomas in New Book
abstract: Judge Amul Thapar assiduously defends the Supreme Court justice but says courts should foster greater public understanding of how they work.
lead_paragraph: Judge Amul Thapar thinks America is misjudging its judges — one in particular.

headline: Mulling Manhattan One-Bedrooms: Prewar Charm or Modern Amenities?
abstract: A couple of longtime renters searched the West Side for a condo that could accommodate a comfortable work-from-home setup. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: A couple of longtime renters searched the West Side for a condo that could accommodate a comfortable work-from-home setup. Here’s what they found.

headline: ‘The Risk Is Staggering,’ Report Says of Disease From U.S. Animal Industries
abstract: The nation uses an enormous number of animals for commercial purposes, and regulations do not adequately protect against outbreaks, experts concluded.
lead_paragraph: The United States is home to an enormous array of animal industries — including industrial agriculture, fur farming and the exotic pet trade — that pose a significant risk of creating infectious disease outbreaks in humans, according to a new report by experts at Harvard Law School and New York University. Moreover, the nation “has no comprehensive strategy” to mitigate the dangers posed by these practices, many of which operate with little regulation and out of public view, the authors concluded.

headline: Poem: Time of Tyranny, 49
abstract: Lyn Hejinian’s sonnet proposes that liberation might be found in scattering and disorientation.
lead_paragraph: Lyn Hejinian’s poem has the sonnet’s traditional 14 lines and even features the sonnet’s coupletlike resolution, but the length of its lines exceeds tradition, nearly reaching to the very edges of line itself. It borrows prose’s linear momentum but refuses the carelessness of prose’s wraparound ends. The power of these lines is, in part, generated by their quick liftoffs — each begins with a word of a single syllable. This is paired with cunning line breaks that enjamb, suggest, double the words that surround them and intensify the effect of the poem by giving it both vertical and horizontal motion. Throughout, there is thick sound stacked on thick sound, the diction mixed and surprising, the everyday and the erudite sparking like flint and steel. In my reading of the poem, it is as if the line is seeking to enact the poem’s proposition: that in the motion of scattering, in an orientation of disorientation, a possibility of liberation might be found.  Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: What’s Lost When Censors Tamper With Classic Films
abstract: A new edit of ‘The French Connection’ removes a racial slur. But nit-picking old artworks for breaking today’s rules inevitably makes it harder to see the complete picture.
lead_paragraph: The remarkable thing about the censored scene is how ordinary it feels if you've watched a police procedural made before, say, 2010. It’s in William Friedkin’s “The French Connection,” from 1971. Two narcotics cops — Jimmy (Popeye) Doyle, played by Gene Hackman, and Buddy (Cloudy) Russo, played by Roy Scheider — are at the precinct, following an undercover operation during which a drug dealer ended up slashing Russo with a knife. The injury has left Russo struggling to put on his coat. “Need a little help there?” Doyle chuckles, then adds an ethnic jab: “You dumb guinea.” Russo: “How the hell did I know he had a knife?” Here Doyle points a slur at the Black dealer: “Never trust a nigger.” Russo: “He could have been white.” Doyle: “Never trust anyone.” Then he invites Russo out for a drink, and they trade masturbation jokes as they head through the door.

headline: Hudson Tunnel Project to Get $6.9 Billion in Largest U.S. Transit Grant
abstract: The federal funding would allow work on the long-delayed Gateway tunnel to start by next year, said Senator Chuck Schumer of New York.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is on track to give $6.88 billion, the most ever awarded to a mass-transit project, for the construction of a second rail tunnel under the Hudson River to New York City, Senator Chuck Schumer said Wednesday.

headline: What’s the Story With Colleen Hoover?
abstract: Her wildly popular romance novels offer a fantasy that feels attainable: self-actualization.
lead_paragraph: There are the novels the literary world acclaims and there are the novels people actually read. Occasionally — perhaps with decreasing frequency — they are one and the same. But apart from momentary blips when best seller and critical darling align (Colson Whitehead, Margaret Atwood, Ocean Vuong), they usually diverge. Every era has its authors whose novels are at best overlooked and at worst disparaged by the literary cognoscenti and still dominate best-seller lists. These books succeed not only despite the critics but almost as if to spite them.

headline: Chris Paul Knows All About the Cycle of Life
abstract: For the veteran N.B.A. point guard, publication month was a bittersweet mash-up of change, celebration and family.
lead_paragraph: Chris Paul has had an eventful few weeks.

headline: Xi Jinping May Be Souring on His ‘Best, Most Intimate Friend’
abstract: How Putin’s leadership troubles have implications for China.
lead_paragraph: When Xi Jinping ascended to the pinnacle of Chinese power a decade ago, he saw Vladimir Putin as a strong leader who shared his hostility to the Western-dominated international system. They bonded over mutual paranoia about threats to their rule and exchanged best practices for imposing control at home and making the world more accommodating of their authoritarian impulses. Mr. Xi referred to Mr. Putin as his “best, most intimate friend.”

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: Vivante
abstract: Carrie attends a former mentor’s party, where she meets a longtime personal hero. Miranda gets a charley horse.
lead_paragraph: Remember back in Episode 2 this season when Carrie could barely bring herself to say “vagina”? It turns out that same squeamishness doesn’t apply to the word for male ejaculate that rhymes with “whiz.” Carrie says it not once, not twice, but a cringetastic four times — in a row — at the lunch table she shares with Charlotte, Miranda and Anthony (Mario Cantone) in Episode 4.

headline: Where 9-Year-Olds Do 60 M.P.H.
abstract: For kids who dream of racing professionally, steering go-karts around a twisting track is where it all begins.
lead_paragraph: On the second day of the Texas Grand Prix, motors were roaring. As mechanics tinkered with vehicles, drivers talked strategy with their coaches and tried to memorize the curves of the racetrack at the Speedsportz Racing Park outside Houston. “I imagine it in my brain,” said Mikey Collins as he waited for his heat to start on the last weekend in April. “I envision it and try to do laps.”

headline: This Was No Ordinary Sunburn. What Was Wrong?
abstract: The man always loved to bask in the sun. Now, at 80, the rays were making his skin red and itchy.
lead_paragraph: “Come in out of the sun,” the woman shouted to her 80-year-old husband. “You’re turning red!” The man reluctantly trudged toward the house. It was late afternoon — the end of a glorious summer day in Orange, Conn. But when he glanced down at his exposed arms, he could see that she was right. He was a bright pink, and soon he knew his arms and probably the back of his neck would be red and itchy. It was time to go inside.

headline: Orthodox Men Dominate Mayor Adams’s New Jewish Advisory Council
abstract: A majority of the advisers are Orthodox and only a quarter are women, drawing criticism from Jewish leaders including Representative Jerrold Nadler of New York.
lead_paragraph: If there is an archetypical Jewish New Yorker, that person might be found on the Upper West Side, somewhere between Zabar’s and Barney Greengrass.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 4 Fashion: Dressing Your Age
abstract: In the new episode, Carrie bristles at the “our” in “women our age.”
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for Episode 4 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”

headline: For Asian American Actors, Playing a Hot Mess Is Liberating
abstract: Forget the pious immigrant family drama. Films and shows like “Joy Ride,” “Beef” and “Shortcomings” are finally exploring all dimensions of the experience.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Park did not tell her mother much about the drugs, the sex or any of the other debauchery in “Joy Ride,” the over-the-top comedy in which she is co-starring.

headline: What’s a Georgia Summer Without Peaches? Not So Sweet.
abstract: With their state’s signature crop hobbled by inclement weather, Georgians are stretching the fruit they have or turning (heaven forbid!) to California’s.
lead_paragraph: A darkness has fallen across the cobbler belt. You can barely find a peach.

headline: Want a Last-Minute Ticket to Wimbledon? No Problem. Just Get in Line.
abstract: Thousands are waiting, even camping out, in rainy England for a chance to see one Wimbledon match. For some, it is an annual ritual, a pilgrimage for the love of tennis.
lead_paragraph: Tom O’Neill and Roz McArdle stood in Wimbledon’s famous ticketing queue with barely a hope of getting inside the grounds. It was 5:30 p.m. on Wednesday, there were 4,000 people ahead of them, and they were told by a steward that it was “enormously unlikely” they would get inside.

headline: There’s One Hard Question My Fellow Doctors and I Will Need to Answer Soon
abstract: How will A.I. change how we practice medicine?
lead_paragraph: When faced with a particularly tough question on rounds during my intern year, I would run straight to the bathroom. There, I would flip through the medical reference book I carried in my pocket, find the answer and return to the group, ready to respond.

headline: NATO’s Welcome Party for Sweden Is Back on Ice
abstract: Alliance leaders wanted their summit next week to celebrate the arrival of a new member, but stalling by Hungary and objections from Turkey have made that nearly impossible.
lead_paragraph: For months, NATO leaders had hoped that when they convened for their annual summit next week, they could use the occasion to welcome Sweden as the alliance’s newest member.

headline: A Brutally Honest Exploration of What It Means to Be a War Reporter
abstract: In “No Ordinary Assignment,” the correspondent Jane Ferguson is candid about the fears and frustrations that come with her calling.
lead_paragraph: “Afghanistan was the Vietnam of our era,” Jane Ferguson writes in her memoir, “No Ordinary Assignment.” She sees her generation of reporters as descendants of the men and women who covered the first war the United States lost to a largely rural Asian nation. In both cases, America had the overwhelming military advantage of a superpower’s arsenal and the political disadvantage of a superpower’s hubris.

headline: The Little-Known Provision That Could Revolutionize Highway Travel
abstract: Buried in the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act is a possible way to address all the costs associated with Americans’ love of driving.
lead_paragraph: It’s no small irony that so much federal money is being dedicated in various ways to climate-change projects that will do nothing to curtail Americans’ love of driving or to reduce the costs associated with it.

headline: ‘Happy Together,’ Yet Still Indifferent About Marriage
abstract: Dianne Cox and Michael Cammer, who had been together for almost 25 years before saying “I do,” both struggle with traditional labels after six years of marriage.
lead_paragraph: Dianne Cox and Michael Cammer don’t particularly like being married, which is not to say they dislike it. Mostly, it doesn’t matter to them.

headline: ‘Joy Ride’ Review: A Raunch-Com Roller Coaster
abstract: Four friends travel to China in a trip that goes entertainingly off the rails in this terrific comedy, starring Ashley Park and Sherry Cola.
lead_paragraph: The new “Joy Ride” offers a modern-comedy bingo card with pretty much all the squares checked: mismatched besties, an oddball crashing a group outing, said outing going wildly off the rails, freewheeling sex, projectile vomiting, unhinged debauchery involving booze and drugs, and a crucial plot point hinging on an intimate body part.

headline: How Tom Brady’s Crypto Ambitions Collided With Reality
abstract: The superstar quarterback is among the celebrities dealing with the fallout from the crypto crash. Others, like Taylor Swift, escaped.
lead_paragraph: As the FTX cryptocurrency exchange imploded last fall, Tom Brady, the seven-time Super Bowl-winning quarterback, made an urgent phone call.

headline: Eton College Wrestles With Change in a More Modern Britain
abstract: The youngest headmaster in the history of the English boarding school that has educated the British elite for centuries tries to navigate a tightrope between tradition and evolution.
lead_paragraph: At Eton College — the boarding school in the British countryside that has educated princes and 20 prime ministers — students wear tailcoats and white ties to classes. But some have worn waistcoats with the symbol of Black History Month underneath.

headline: Fight or Flight: Transgender Care Bans Leave Families and Doctors Scrambling
abstract: Laws in 20 states have left the fate of clinics in doubt and families with transgender children searching for medical care across state lines.
lead_paragraph: David and Wendy Batchelder hate the thought of putting their spacious house in West Des Moines, Iowa, on the market, disrupting the routines of their six children or giving up the Lutheran church that they have attended for roughly a decade.

headline: 6 Paris Bistros to Try Now
abstract: The city’s restaurant scene is back in full force, and a half-dozen bistro-style eateries showcase the best of what’s new, including a refreshingly simple style of cooking.
lead_paragraph: Paris has recovered its scents, and the city is suddenly ravenous. The whiffs of shallots sautéing in butter, bread baking, meat roasting and bouillon simmering that invisibly punctuate any stroll in this food-loving city are back. In fact, the French capital is in the midst of a restaurant boom.

headline: In Paris, a Dinner at a Former Taxidermy Workshop
abstract: The traveling culinary studio We Are Ona laid down roots in its founder Luca Pronzato’s home city and invited friends to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: For the past four years, the culinary studio We Are Ona has been converting unconventional spaces around the world — the 31st floor of a New York City office building, a tennis court in Milan, the onetime atelier of a 19th-century French photographer — into temporary restaurants. Some operate for just a night, others for up to six months, and the studio’s founder, Luca Pronzato, 31, approaches each one as an elaborate, site-specific production, relying on an international crew of chefs, artisans, designers and florists to bring his vision to life. Though he’s organized 30 ticketed public pop-ups and over 500 private culinary events, he’s never done the same thing twice.

headline: U.S. Is Destroying the Last of Its Once-Vast Chemical Weapons Arsenal
abstract: Decades behind its initial schedule, the dangerous job of eliminating the world’s only remaining declared stockpile of lethal chemical munitions will be completed as soon as Friday.
lead_paragraph: In a sealed room behind a gantlet of armed guards and three rows of high barbed wire at the Army’s Pueblo Chemical Depot in Colorado, a team of robotic arms was busily disassembling some of the last of the United States’ vast and ghastly stockpile of chemical weapons.

headline: German Businesses Bet Big on China, and They’re Starting to Worry
abstract: Geopolitical risks have exposed long-ignored strains on Germany’s socioeconomic model. The family businesses underpinning its economy are seeking a new path.
lead_paragraph: Amid the ruins of a city ravaged by World War II, Karl Haeusgen’s grandfather invented a hydraulic pump he was so proud of that he founded a company to sell it. Back then, there were no revenue projections or five-year growth strategies. The plan was survival: “It was just about grabbing chances,” Mr. Haeusgen said.

headline: Today’s Top News: The Roadblocks to Sweden’s NATO Membership, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Episode 2: The Nurse
