abstract: From Serial Productions. Patients know what happened to them at the clinic. Now they find out who did it.
lead_paragraph: The patients who underwent painful egg retrievals at a Yale clinic know what happened to them: Fentanyl intended for use during their procedures had been replaced with saline.

headline: Russia After the Rebellion
abstract: What Vladimir Putin’s reaction to the Wagner mutiny indicates about the state of his power.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a rebellion inside Russia left lingering questions about what really happened and about what the ramifications would be for President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Why Does New Hampshire Go First?
abstract: New Hampshire has a strikingly poor record of identifying the strongest Democratic presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party is engaged in a roiling debate over the order of its presidential primaries, as a Times Magazine story by Ross Barkan explains.

headline: ‘Biosphere’ Review: It’s the End of the World (and They Caused It)
abstract: What happens when a petulant, anti-intellectual president destroys the planet and he and his childhood buddy, the brainy one, are the only survivors?
lead_paragraph: Over the decades that Billy (Mark Duplass) and Ray (Sterling K. Brown) have been best buds, the world has gotten worse — and they’re to blame. Honestly. “Biosphere,” a honed yet heartfelt two-person dramedy by the first-time feature director Mel Eslyn, takes place in a geodesic dome under a black sky. A few years back, Billy, then president of the United States, destroyed the planet; luckily, his consigliere, Ray, had already built this bunker. Barring a miracle, it will be humanity’s final tomb.

headline: ‘The League’ Review: A Crucial Baseball Legacy
abstract: Sam Pollard’s new documentary traces the history of the Negro leagues.
lead_paragraph: If you thought that Jackie Robinson was the first Black player in professional baseball, “The League” would like to offer a correction. Moses Fleetwood Walker became a catcher for the Toledo Blue Stockings in 1884, before organized baseball was segregated and more than 60 years before Robinson broke the major leagues’ color line.

headline: ‘The Out-Laws’ Review: Adam Devine, Funny at Last
abstract: Devine channels Jack Lemmon as a law-abiding Everyman whose fiancée’s parents rob the bank he manages. (Awkward.)
lead_paragraph: You can really see Adam Devine going for the Jack Lemmon vibes in his latest vehicle, “The Out-Laws.” As Owen Browning, a tidy but slightly schlubby suburban Everyman with an impending wedding, he meets adversity with a broad grin and an implied ambition to ingratiate himself to the whole world. So a superficial Jack Lemmon vibe — except Jack Lemmon never twerked in boxer shorts. Not that he necessarily would have considered it beneath him.

headline: Chloé Bids Goodbye to Gabriela Hearst
abstract: The designer’s departure from the French fashion house is the latest in a string of exits at the top of the luxury industry this year.
lead_paragraph: After months of speculation, Chloé said its creative director, Gabriela Hearst, was leaving the French fashion house after a three-year tenure.

headline: ‘Amanda’ Review: My Loneliness Is Killing Me
abstract: A delusional college grad befriends an agoraphobic misanthrope in this stylish dark comedy by the Italian director Carolina Cavalli.
lead_paragraph: “Amanda,” a smart, stylish debut by the Italian writer-director Carolina Cavalli, plays like “Lady Bird” by way of Wes Anderson’s deadpan existentialism. Its heroine, the prickly Amanda (Benedetta Porcaroli), a college grad and the daughter of wealthy pharmacy owners, would rather twiddle her thumbs than work. Terrified of socializing with people her own age, she claims to prefer hanging out in the family chateau with her prepubescent niece and the maid. She would secretly kill for meaningful companionship — but first, she has to learn not to bite.

headline: ‘The Lesson’ Review: Carefully Taut
abstract: A tense standoff between two writers kindles familial fireworks in this wittily self-aware melodrama.
lead_paragraph: No one is quite what they seem in “The Lesson,” Alice Troughton’s winking literary mystery whose languid summer setting — a swanky estate in the English countryside — hides coldly destructive secrets.

headline: Here’s What Cluster Munitions Do and Why They Are So Controversial
abstract: Here’s a guide to why this type of weapon is controversial and widely banned — and why Kyiv wants it.
lead_paragraph: The United States agreed on Friday to provide Ukraine with cluster munitions, the controversial and widely banned weapons that can often cause indiscriminate harm to civilians, especially children, long after the fighting ends.

headline: In his new spotlight, the Belarusian leader could gain leverage.
abstract: The brief mutiny by the Wagner mercenary force last month has given Belarus’s autocratic leader Aleksandr G. Lukashenko an opening to upend his subservient relationship with Moscow.

headline: List Prices Are Creeping Downward After Years of Inflation
abstract: Is the tiny change a pivotal moment in the housing market?
lead_paragraph: After years of steady increases, the median list price for a home in the United States has finally dropped — if only a little, according to Realtor.com’s June Housing Report. The 0.9 percent decrease is the first downward movement reported since the company began publishing its trends research in 2017.

headline: Advertisers Pay Attention as Meta’s Twitter Rival Surges
abstract: The technology giant’s new social network, Threads, pulled in more than 10 million sign-ups within hours of making its debut.
lead_paragraph: Threads made its debut on Wednesday night with a bang. Meta’s new social network had already racked up more than 10 million sign-ups within seven hours of its launch, and attracted celebrities and politicians like Oprah Winfrey and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York.

headline: Car Crashes Into London School, Killing 8-Year-Old Girl
abstract: The driver of the vehicle that smashed into a private elementary school for girls has been arrested. Officials were not treating it as terrorism-related.
lead_paragraph: An 8-year-old girl was killed and several others were injured on Thursday when a vehicle crashed into a private elementary school for girls in the southwestern London suburb of Wimbledon, the authorities said.

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are three-bedroom homes in Westport, Conn., and Sea Cliff, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath 1,462-square-foot house, built in 2014, with radiant-heated floors and recessed lighting; a kitchen with two sinks, a double oven and an island with room for seating; a dining nook and piano alcove; a family room with a gas fireplace with marble surround, built-in cabinets and deck access; a two-person office with custom bamboo built-ins; an en suite primary bedroom with large windows, two closets, a glass-stall shower with a tub, and a balcony with pond views; a washer/dryer; and a deck that leads to the landscaped waterfront backyard, on 0.06 acres. Ellen Fusco, 203-257-7106; John Foran, 203-981-0785; Compass, compass.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in Turtle Bay, on the Upper West Side and in Long Island City.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, roughly 3,400-square-foot apartment with formal living and dining rooms, built-in cabinets, a wood-burning fireplace, an eat-in kitchen and a powder room on the first level; an en suite primary bedroom, two additional en suite bedrooms and walk-in closets on the second level; plus a washer/dryer and private elevator, in a 38-story doorman building with a concierge, valet, gym, Pilates studio, golf simulator, conference rooms, bike room, shared laundry, extra storage and two decks. Arlene Reed and Rebecca Blacker, Coldwell Banker Warburg, 917-373-8343; cbwarburg.com

headline: A Hawaii Shop Turning Oahu’s Invasive Trees Into Surfboards
abstract: Plus: home décor from Ulla Johnson, a restaurant in a vintage airstream and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: This spring, the chef Molly Levine began serving seasonal cuisine from a refurbished 1971 Airstream trailer parked on a former dairy farm in the Hudson Valley. Westerly Canteen’s trailer holds a compact kitchen with cream-painted walls and blond wood counters. “I had this wild idea, like, ‘What if we took the food truck concept and put it in a space that is still mobile but feels beautiful and welcoming?’” Levine said as she stirred a pot of golden-hued stock, fragrant with spring onion and green garlic. Levine, who previously worked at the Berkeley, Calif., restaurant Chez Panisse, founded Westerly with her partner, Alex Kaindl, a farmer who tends half an acre in Sharon, Conn. Nearly all of their ingredients are sourced from farms nearby. (Starting this month, Kaindl’s crops will also be incorporated.) Developing the weekly menu is a puzzle that requires maximizing limited space and resources. “A lot of our decisions are very creative and passion driven but also very practical,” Kaindl said as Levine ladled the stock over a plate of nettle-stuffed ravioli. “We slice up the spring onions that go into the dish, and the tops are made into the broth,” Levine said. “We’re using every piece of the onion.” The founders hope to engage the surrounding community while also drawing diners from afar. They’ve partnered with Tenmile Distillery, which offers cocktails made with local ingredients to go alongside Westerly’s menu (their take on a Negroni includes Faccia Brutto bitters from Brooklyn, Method sweet vermouth from Romulus and gin made on-site at Tenmile). “We really want people to sit here and stay a while,” Levine said. westerlycanteen.com.

headline: You Told Us About the Best Part of Your Year So Far
abstract: Among your delightful responses: whale sightings, a spectacular 80th birthday party, falling in love and graduations that didn’t come easy.
lead_paragraph: To find some relief in a world that too often feels tumultuous and deeply fractured, I’ve recently been trying to cultivate more delight in my life.

headline: Two Firefighters Die in Blaze on Cargo Ship in Newark
abstract: Firefighters responded to a fire on a cargo ship docked at Port Newark, which was carrying more than a thousand vehicles when the blaze started.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters responded to a fire on a cargo ship docked at Port Newark, which was carrying more than a thousand vehicles when the blaze started.

headline: What 120 Degrees Looks Like in One of Mexico’s Hottest Cities
abstract: During the most recent heat wave, residents of the northern city of Hermosillo struggled to breathe in the scorching temperatures.
lead_paragraph: People in Hermosillo are used to the heat: Enduring scorching temperatures is a local point of pride in this northwestern Mexican city known for its blistering weather and nicknamed the “city of sun.”

headline: Americans Tried to Save Elephants in Zambia. Were They the Good Guys?
abstract: A visit to a remote conservation park reveals the long-term impact on villagers of a crusade by the novelist Delia Owens and her husband to protect animals from poachers.
lead_paragraph: The hunter heard the helicopter coming. He grabbed his AK-47, he said, and jumped behind a tree. He was on an illegal elephant hunt with a group of men inside North Luangwa National Park in the southern African nation of Zambia. Smoke rose from the butchered meat that lay grilling on wooden racks.

headline: The Mayor Had a Photo of a Fallen Officer. Was His Story About It True?
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has often talked about a wrinkled photo of a fallen police officer that he kept in his wallet. Now that photo and the story have been called into question.
lead_paragraph: In Mayor Eric Adams’s first month in office, he was confronted with a tragic crisis: the deaths of two New York City police officers who were responding to a domestic disturbance in Harlem.

headline: The ‘Great Resignation’ Is Over. Can Workers’ Power Endure?
abstract: The furious pace of job-switching in recent years has led to big gains for low-wage workers. But the pendulum could be swinging back toward employers.
lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of Americans have changed jobs over the past two years, a tidal wave of quitting that reflected — and helped create — a rare moment of worker power as employees demanded higher pay, and as employers, short on staff, often gave it to them.

headline: Job Openings Dipped in May, a Sign of Continued Cooling
abstract: Hiring was largely unchanged, and the number of workers quitting their jobs increased. The data will be watched closely by Federal Reserve policymakers.
lead_paragraph: Job openings fell in May while the number of workers quitting their jobs increased, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

headline: Ford’s U.S. Sales Rose 10% in the Second Quarter
abstract: The automaker saw a big jump in deliveries of pickup trucks as demand from consumers and businesses remained strong.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said Thursday that its new-vehicle sales rose 10 percent in the three months of April through June, thanks to robust demand for trucks.

headline: The Winners of Our 6th Annual Student Podcast Contest
abstract: An oral history of Woodstock, an investigation into the origins of the fork, and an answer to the question of what makes a tune memorable. Listen to this year’s winning entries.
lead_paragraph: In our Student Podcast Contest, teenagers can cover any topic they want, in any audio format they like, as long as they provide a complete listening experience in five minutes or less. That freedom makes this contest a joy to judge.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The seeds for this week’s recommended books were planted last winter, when editors at the Book Review noticed a heavier than usual concentration of excellent literature in translation coming down the pipeline. One thing led to another, and we ended up with a whole issue devoted to the topic, filled with books that will take you around the world thanks to the efforts of the translators who brought them into English.

headline: ‘Once Upon a Time in Uganda’ Review: When Ragtag Met Rambo
abstract: A new documentary tells how a Ugandan filmmaker and an American producer have reshaped African cinema.
lead_paragraph: Wakaliwood is more than a production house; it’s a spirit of ragtag moviemaking born from the pure desire to create. Founded in 2005 by the writer-director Isaac Nabwana and based in Wakaliga, a slum in Kampala, Uganda, the studio produces low-budget, hyperviolent action films inspired by “Rambo” and Chuck Norris but starring African actors.

headline: 5 Noteworthy Falsehoods Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Has Promoted
abstract: A longtime vaccine skeptic, Mr. Kennedy is leaning heavily on misinformation as he mounts a long-shot 2024 campaign.
lead_paragraph: He has promoted a conspiracy theory that coronavirus vaccines were developed to control people via microchips. He has endorsed the false notion that antidepressants are linked to school shootings. And he has pushed the decades-old theory that the C.I.A. killed his uncle, former President John F. Kennedy.

headline: Should Colleges End Legacy Admissions?
abstract: Readers offer different views of a complaint against Harvard. Also: Lifesaving care; victim impact statements; relief from the gloom.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Heat Records Are Broken Around the Globe as Earth Warms, Fast
abstract: From north to south, temperatures are surging as greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere and combine with effects from El Niño.
lead_paragraph: The past three days were quite likely the hottest in Earth’s modern history, scientists said on Thursday, as an astonishing surge of heat across the globe continued to shatter temperature records from North America to Antarctica.

headline: Trump Aide Pleads Not Guilty in Classified Documents Case
abstract: Walt Nauta, the former president’s personal aide, entered his plea in federal court in Miami. He is charged with conspiring to obstruct the government’s efforts to retrieve highly sensitive material.
lead_paragraph: Walt Nauta, a personal aide to former President Donald J. Trump, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to federal charges of conspiring with Mr. Trump to obstruct the government’s monthslong efforts to retrieve a trove of highly sensitive national security documents from the former president after he left office.

headline: 3 Easy Dishes, One Near-Effortless Summer Dinner Party
abstract: Turmeric potato salad, smoky pork chops and lemony shortcakes: These recipes from David Tanis are as bright and refreshing as the season should be.
lead_paragraph: A few thoughts about summer cooking: It should be bold, flavorful, refreshing. It should take full advantage of the season’s fresh produce. And, if possible, it should be consumed outdoors.

headline: Ron DeSantis Is Running One Freaky Campaign
abstract: Rather than trying to lift people up, he seems to be running on contempt.
lead_paragraph: If you missed the previous newsletter, you can read it here.

headline: Pieces of Munich Synagogue, Destroyed on Hitler’s Orders, Found in River
abstract: The demolition of the city’s main synagogue was an early sign of the terrible destruction to come under the Nazi regime.
lead_paragraph: Eighty-five years ago, Munich’s main synagogue was demolished on direct orders from Adolf Hitler — a terrible harbinger of the destruction to come.

headline: Winnie Ewing, Who Transformed Scottish Politics, Dies at 93
abstract: Her charismatic nationalism made independence from Britain a mainstream idea. She championed that idea for her many decades in office.
lead_paragraph: Winnie Ewing, who in the late 1960s transformed Scottish politics by bringing the issue of independence from Britain from the electoral fringe to the national mainstream, died on June 21 at her home in Bridge of Weir, a town west of Glasgow. She was 93.

headline: ‘The YouTube Effect’ Review: Tracing a Platform’s Cultural Footprint
abstract: Alex Winter offers an overview of the world’s second most popular website in this unfocused tech documentary.
lead_paragraph: The numbing experience of web video surfing is recreated — intentionally, I think — in “The YouTube Effect,” a discursive documentary that assembles a fair amount of information about the impact of YouTube on society, but struggles to find something new to say with it. Directed by Alex Winter, the film charts the rise of the video sharing platform and then attempts to trace its Sasquatch-size footprint on the culture.

headline: Eagles Join Parade of Acts on Final Tours With a ‘Long Goodbye’
abstract: The band, which performed a “farewell” tour in 2003, will begin what’s billed as a last run of dates in September.
lead_paragraph: Eagles are touring for the last time. Again.

headline: NBC’s New Chief Overhauls Top Ranks
abstract: Donna Langley will gain broader oversight of creative decisions for entertainment content, and Mark Lazarus and Cesar Conde are both getting additional responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: Mike Cavanagh is beginning to put his stamp on NBCUniversal.

headline: Stone Fruit Every Which Way
abstract: In almond upside-down cake, in caprese with creamy mozzarella and lightly pickled with labneh.
lead_paragraph: The text was brief: “Warning: She made you a cake.”

headline: Tour de France Becomes ‘Big, Big Battle’ Between Pogacar and Vingegaard
abstract: The race favorites traded attacks in punishing stages in the Pyrenees.
lead_paragraph: Everyone expected this year’s Tour de France to be a two-cyclist race between the defending champion, Jonas Vingegaard of Denmark, and the 2020 and 2021 winner, Tadej Pogacar of Slovenia. And everyone expected the first true test for them to come on Days 5 and 6 in the Pyrenees mountains.

headline: At Glamorous French Festivals, Poverty Is Only Onstage
abstract: The opening productions of the Avignon and Aix-en-Provence Festivals brought tales of the down-and-out to well-heeled spectators. It got awkward.
lead_paragraph: Two events tower over France’s summer festival season each July, held in cities less than 50 miles apart. One, the Avignon Festival, is a bustling, overcrowded celebration of theater; the other, the Aix-en-Provence Festival, offers a more genteel operatic lineup.

headline: Israeli Court Acquits Police Officer Who Killed Autistic Palestinian Man
abstract: The shooting of the man, Iyad al-Hallaq, who was killed in May 2020, around the same time as George Floyd, cast a light on police violence.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli court on Thursday acquitted a police officer charged with manslaughter in the killing of an unarmed Palestinian man with autism in Jerusalem, a case that drew Palestinian outrage and focused attention on the treatment of Palestinians by Israeli police.

headline: Ohio Moves Closer to Ballot Issue That Would Protect Abortion Rights
abstract: Supporters of protecting abortion in the state’s Constitution submitted enough signatures to get on the November ballot. But another vote in August could make it harder to win.
lead_paragraph: Ohio moved one step closer to becoming the next big test case in the nation’s fight over abortion, after supporters of a measure that would ask voters to establish a right to abortion in the state’s Constitution this week said they had filed more than enough signatures to put it on the ballot in November.

headline: Listen: Serial’s New Episode, Twitter’s Rival Arrives, ‘Bridget Jones’s Diary’
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: We hope you’ve started Serial’s new series, The Retrievals, about the shocking events that unfolded at a Yale fertility clinic, because Episode 2 is out now. Also, don’t miss a special Hard Fork episode with Instagram’s chief executive about the platform’s new competitor to Twitter. And how far would you travel to find your mother’s con man?

headline: Studio Museum in Harlem and Other Clients Cut Ties to David Adjaye
abstract: Cultural institutions try to move projects forward without the star architect in the wake of sexual harassment allegations.
lead_paragraph: The Studio Museum in Harlem announced Thursday that it had taken the significant step of parting ways with David Adjaye, the charismatic Ghanaian British architect who is building its new home in Manhattan. A library project in Portland, Ore., is moving forward without him. A sculpture park in Lincoln, Mass., canceled a show of his work planned for fall. And other cultural institutions from Princeton, N.J., to Liverpool, England, expressed serious concerns in response to the allegations of sexual harassment and misconduct against Mr. Adjaye that surfaced this week.

headline: The ruble hits early war lows, extending a slide that began after Prigozhin’s mutiny.
abstract: The ruble fell as low as 94 rubles per dollar on Thursday before making a slight recovery by the end of the trading day.
lead_paragraph: The Russian ruble slid to lows unseen since the weeks after Moscow launched its invasion of Ukraine, amid fallout from the mercenary boss Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s aborted insurrection and declining Russian oil and gas revenues.

headline: When the Street Moves to the Opera House (and Subverts It)
abstract: The French choreographer Bintou Dembélé brings her desire to create “a fair ecosystem” to the Avignon Festival, which she opened with “G.R.O.O.V.E.”
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Bintou Dembélé, a hip-hop pioneer in France, became the first Black female choreographer to be hired by the Paris Opera. Two years later, during a residency in Chicago, she discovered an English word that has no equivalent in French: “tokenism.”

headline: They Hold Weeds, and an Artist’s Sublime Vision
abstract: The ceramist Doyle Lane created a universe of colors and shapes with his ‘weed pots,’ 100 of which form his first solo show in New York, at David Kordansky.
lead_paragraph: The David Kordansky Gallery has mounted a wonderful wormhole of an exhibition, “Doyle Lane: Weed Pots.” Its point of access is the small unassuming “weed pot,” a frequent accent in modern California interiors starting in the late 1950s. Thrown on a wheel, Lane’s pots were rarely more than 3 or 4 inches high, spherical or elliptical in volume and usually topped by a short, narrow neck, small mouth and turned lip, designed to hold a dried sprig of weed.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: Cyclists keep climbing through the Tour de France, while golfers and soccer players take their turns in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Cyclists keep climbing through the Tour de France, while golfers and soccer players take their turns in the spotlight.

headline: The Crossed ‘Signals’ of MoMA’s Largest Ever Video Show
abstract: Full of experiments with new media, the museum’s giant exhibition displays the powers and the pitfalls of seeing the world through a screen.
lead_paragraph: Beauty is nice, elegance has its place, but sometimes I go to museums to be perplexed: to agree and disagree, to argue and reassess, to leave even less certain than I was before. I sure got my wish with “Signals: How Video Transformed the World,” which closes this weekend at the Museum of Modern Art — and which, screen for screen, hour for hour, stands proud as the most perplexing exhibition of the year.

headline: A Lot of Opera Is Now Streaming. Here’s Where to Start.
abstract: Naxos, which collects videos of productions throughout Europe, has begun to make its catalog available on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_paragraph: Opera isn’t so different from film and television in its glut of streaming platforms — which can be just as challenging, and expensive, to navigate.

headline: OceanGate, Operator of the Titan Submersible, Suspends Operations
abstract: The company made the announcement weeks after a dive to the wreckage of the Titanic presumably imploded, killing five people.
lead_paragraph: OceanGate Expeditions said it had “suspended all exploration and commercial operations” after its Titan submersible presumably imploded during a dive to explore the wreckage of the Titanic last month, killing the company’s founder and four other people.

headline: Nations Aim to Zero Out Shipping Emissions by Midcentury
abstract: Regulators reached a provisional deal on how quickly the transition to zero-emissions fuels should happen for cargo ships, which often burn particularly dirty oil.
lead_paragraph: Negotiators from nearly every country reached a provisional agreement on Thursday to effectively eliminate the shipping industry’s greenhouse gas emissions by as close to 2050 as possible.

headline: Food-Delivery Companies Sue New York City Over Minimum Pay Law
abstract: Uber, DoorDash and Grubhub argued that the city used poor data to calculate how much food delivery workers should earn and that the change would hurt consumers.
lead_paragraph: Three food-delivery giants are suing New York City to block minimum pay standards for gig workers, arguing that regulators used faulty data to calculate the new compensation rules.

headline: The Rage and Joy of MAGA America
abstract: Come for the community. Stay for the vituperation.
lead_paragraph: I’ve shared this fact with readers before: I live in Tennessee outside Nashville, a very deep-red part of America. According to a New York Times tool that calculates the political composition of a community, only 15 percent of my neighbors are Democrats. I’ve been living here in the heart of MAGA country since Donald Trump came down the escalator. This is the world of my friends, my neighbors and many members of my family. That is perhaps why, when I’m asked what things are like now, eight years into the Trump era, I have a ready answer: Everything is normal until, suddenly, it’s not. And unless we can understand what’s normal and what’s not, we can’t truly understand why Trumpism endures.

headline: If the Election Deniers Succeed, Guatemala Will Have Lost the Battle for Democracy
abstract: Though the country’s autocrats have now deployed the full force of the state to steal the elections, they are not the only people mobilizing.
lead_paragraph: Guatemala’s democracy is under assault. Over the past four years, a group of powerful elites tied to organized crime, known as the “pact of the corrupt,” has been steadily dismantling Guatemala’s democratic guardrails by co-opting judicial institutions and arresting and exiling prosecutors, judges, journalists and pro-democracy activists. Now, in their next step to consolidate power, they are trying to manipulate the national elections that are underway.

headline: Threads Becomes Most Rapidly Downloaded App, Raising Twitter’s Ire
abstract: Instagram’s new app was downloaded more than 30 million times in 16 hours. Twitter threatened legal action against its rival.
lead_paragraph: Two hours after pressing the launch button on Wednesday on Threads, Instagram’s new app for real-time, public conversations, Mark Zuckerberg posted that more than two million people had downloaded his latest creation.

headline: ‘Here Lies Love’ Pairs Disco With a Dictator. It’s a Controversial Choice.
abstract: The musical, the brainchild of David Byrne and Fatboy Slim, dramatizes — and, some say, sanitizes — the life of the former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “Here Lies Love” is a rollicking karaoke dance party with an immersive staging and, for the first time in Broadway history, organizers say, an all-Filipino cast.

headline: For Filipino Audiences, ‘Here Lies Love’ Offers Emotional Rip Currents
abstract: For viewers as well as the all-Filipino cast, the musical about the Marcoses’ rise to power is a rare chance to commune, and revisit, together, a not-too-distant past.
lead_paragraph: The disco balls were spinning, the club music was pulsing, and on the dance floor, several Filipino audience members were near tears.

headline: L. Lin Wood, Lawyer Who Tried to Overturn Trump’s 2020 Loss, Gives Up License
abstract: Mr. Wood wrote that the Georgia State Bar had “agreed to drop the disciplinary cases” against him if he retired from the profession.
lead_paragraph: L. Lin Wood, one of the key lawyers who sought to overturn former President Donald J. Trump’s 2020 election loss and faced potential disciplinary action in Georgia as a result, opted to give up his law license in the state.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: “Insecure” has made its way to Netflix. Otherwise, check out an Agatha Christie mystery adapted and directed by Hugh Laurie.
lead_paragraph: ‘Insecure’When to watch: Now, on Netflix or Max.

headline: In South Carolina, Biden Says His Agenda Has Helped Voters in Both Parties
abstract: President Biden cited Republican lawmakers who have attacked his policies but whose constituents have benefited from billions in federal funding.
lead_paragraph: President Biden outlined an economic agenda on Thursday that he believes has helped all voters, regardless of whether they voted for him, and name-checked Republican lawmakers who have attacked his policies but whose constituents have benefited from billions in federal funding.

headline: Jack Goldstein, a Savior of Broadway Theaters, Dies at 74
abstract: He helped secure landmark status for more than two dozen theaters in the 1980s, then initiated the design competition that led to a new TKTS booth.
lead_paragraph: Jack Goldstein, a preservationist who in the 1980s reacted to the razing of several venerable Broadway theaters under a Times Square redevelopment plan by helping to organize a successful campaign to give landmark status to more than two dozen other theaters, died on June 16 in Cold Spring, N.Y., in Putnam County. He was 74.

headline: New Federal Decisions Make Alzheimer’s Drug Leqembi Widely Accessible
abstract: The F.D.A. gave full approval to the drug, but added a black-box warning about safety risks. Medicare said it would cover most of the high cost.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Global Heat Shatters Records
abstract: Plus, Belarus’s president says Wagner’s leader is in Russia.
lead_paragraph: The past three days were quite likely the hottest in Earth’s modern history, scientists said, as an astonishing surge of heat across the globe continued to shatter temperature records from North America to Antarctica.

headline: At Wimbledon, Sofia Kenin Rediscovers Her Fighting Form
abstract: With her straight-sets win over Xinyu Wang on Thursday, Kenin had won a second consecutive match for only the fourth time all year.
lead_paragraph: It has been three and a half years since Sofia Kenin put both hands to her face and teared up in Melbourne. That night, she had just won the Australian Open at 21, highlighting to the world her ferocious will to fight for every point, every shot.

headline: Long Island Steps Up Shark Patrols After Swimmers Are Bitten
abstract: The authorities in Suffolk County said they responded to three shark bites off Fire Island over a two-day period this week.
lead_paragraph: Officials on Long Island have stepped up shark patrols after authorities responded to several reports of people being bitten by sharks in separate locations around the July 4 holiday.

headline: We Are Breaking Heat Records Around the World
abstract: Also, Prigozhin is in Russia. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: An astonishing surge of heat across the globe has shattered temperature records from North America to Antarctica. Scientists say the past three days were quite likely the hottest in Earth’s modern history.

headline: Welcome to the Age of the Cage Match
abstract: These days, powerful men want to beat one another. Literally.
lead_paragraph: Call it the melee of the middle-aged men.

headline: With a Creative Edit, the Wisconsin Governor Raised School Funding. For 400 Years.
abstract: Gov. Tony Evers used a quirky rule to edit the state budget and raise the cap on public school funding — until the year 2425.
lead_paragraph: It took only a few snips of creative editing for Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin to push through a long-term boost to public education funding.

headline: F.B.I. Searched the Home of Crypto Exchange Founder
abstract: Federal agents were investigating Jesse Powell, the founder of the crypto exchange Kraken, over claims that he hacked and cyber-stalked a nonprofit arts group.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. searched the home of the cryptocurrency executive Jesse Powell in March as part of a criminal investigation into claims that he hacked and cyber-stalked a nonprofit that he founded, three people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: What to Know if You’re Considering the Alzheimer’s Drug Leqembi
abstract: Medicare will cover much of the cost for patients in the early stages of the disease, but Leqembi has safety risks and can only modestly slow cognitive decline.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Food and Drug Administration gave full approval to the drug Leqembi for patients who are in the early stages of Alzheimer’s disease, and Medicare said it would cover 80 percent of the cost of the $26,500-per-year medication. The decisions by the two federal agencies will vastly increase access to the drug but also present a dilemma for patients and their families.

headline: 2 Newark Firefighters Brought Years of Service to Their Final Fire
abstract: Augusto Acabou and Wayne Brooks Jr., who died fighting a blaze on a cargo ship, were products of Engine 16 in Newark’s Ironbound neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: When flames raced through a huge cargo ship in Port Newark in New Jersey on Wednesday, it was not some specialized nautical team that ventured into its blazing upper decks. It was city firefighters, whose last job might have been rushing to a burning house or fallen wires, or treating someone with chest pains or helping a woman in labor.

headline: John Kerry to Visit China to Restart Climate Negotiations
abstract: A yearlong freeze in climate talks appears to be ending as the United States and China, the world’s biggest polluters, resume discussions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Kerry, President Biden’s special envoy for climate change, said on Thursday he would travel to China next week to restart global warming negotiations between the world’s two largest polluters.

headline: Misoprostol Alone Safely Ends Pregnancies After 10 Weeks, Study Suggests
abstract: Most women who took abortion drugs were successful even at later gestation periods, researchers reported. Many used only misoprostol, not the usual two-drug combination.
lead_paragraph: An overwhelming majority of women were able to end unwanted pregnancies with abortion medications on their own and without additional medical procedures, even if they were well beyond the first trimester, according to a report published on Thursday.

headline: What Men Should Know Before Coloring Their Hair
abstract: After new photos showed Bill de Blasio sporting noticeably darker hair than he had in his days as mayor, hairstylists offered tips for dyeing with dignity.
lead_paragraph: A change in hair color can be emblematic of a shift in someone’s personal life, a fresh start or an attempt to hit pause on the aging process. Depending on the person, it may be a significant change that lasts for a while — or just till the next haircut.

headline: The Rich Are Crazier Than You and Me
abstract: Why does Silicon Valley love RFK Jr.?
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is a crank. His views are a mishmash of right-wing fantasies mixed with remnants of the progressive he once was: Bitcoin boosterism, anti-vaccine conspiracy theories, assertions that Prozac causes mass shootings, opposition to U.S. support for Ukraine, but also favorable mention for single-payer health care. But for his last name, nobody would be paying him any attention — and despite that last name, he has zero chance of winning the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Why I Still Love the New York Mets
abstract: We don’t watch sports for happiness; we watch for the human drama.
lead_paragraph: Chip … chip … chip. I can feel the New York Mets chiseling out a piece of my soul every week. A blown lead here … chip. A dropped pop-up there … chip. Getting swept at home by an utterly mediocre rival … chip. Maybe you remember that tale of Prometheus chained to a rock, while an eagle comes by every day to rip out his liver. I can relate.

headline: Prigozhin Is Said to Be in Russia, as Wagner Mystery Deepens
abstract: After the mercenary boss staged a brief insurrection in Russia, the leader of Belarus said his country had taken him in, but now says the Wagner leader was in St. Petersburg and then “maybe he went to Moscow.”
lead_paragraph: The mercenary leader Yevgeny V. Prigozhin is in Russia and is a “free man” despite staging a rebellion against Moscow’s military leadership, the leader of Belarus said on Thursday, deepening the mystery of where Mr. Prigozhin and his Wagner group stand and what will become of them.

headline: Shootings in New York Drop by a Quarter as Surge of Violence Eases
abstract: Murders and rapes were also down, part of a nationwide trend after a post-pandemic spike.
lead_paragraph: Shootings in New York City dropped by about 25 percent through the first half of this year compared with the same period last year, extending a downward trend after a spike in violent crime during the pandemic.

headline: Los Angeles Hotel Employees Return to Work but Warn of Additional Strikes
abstract: The hotel workers’ strike is the latest in a wave of labor actions by employees in California in what labor leaders are calling a “hot labor summer.”
lead_paragraph: Thousands of housekeepers, front desk clerks, cooks and other hospitality staff returned to work on Wednesday at hotels in the Los Angeles area after three days of picketing, but union leaders said that more walkouts are likely in the coming days.

headline: Biden Weighs Giving Ukraine Weapons Banned by Many U.S. Allies
abstract: Ukraine is seeking cluster munitions, which are known to cause grievous injuries to civilians, as its ammunition supply runs low.
lead_paragraph: For more than six months, President Biden and his aides have been wrestling with one of the most vexing questions in the war in Ukraine: whether to risk letting Ukrainian forces run out of the artillery rounds they desperately need to fight Russia, or agree to ship them cluster munitions — widely banned weapons known to cause grievous injury to civilians, especially children.

headline: ‘Uncle Vanya’ Review: Confidences by Candlelight
abstract: Unrequited love swirls through this prestige-cast production of Anton Chekhov’s play, in a Manhattan loft.
lead_paragraph: Leaning close in the flickering candlelight, Sonya and the man who makes her stomach flutter share a sneaky midnight snack. He is Astrov, her houseguest, and he is frankly a bit of a mess — drinks too much, is in fact drunk at the moment. He is also endearingly odd and smart and sweet, an eco-nerd physician who’s sending her some incredibly mixed signals.

headline: Ex-Amazon Manager Sentenced to 16 Years in Prison in $9 Million Theft Scheme
abstract: Federal prosecutors said that Kayricka Wortham, a former operations manager at an Amazon warehouse in Georgia, was the leader of a group that stole money from the company.
lead_paragraph: In her role as an operations manager at an Amazon warehouse in Georgia, Kayricka Wortham had the authority to approve new vendors and their invoices.

headline: DeSantis Boasts $20 Million Haul, but Full Picture of Money Race Is Still Hazy
abstract: The Florida governor had an impressive quarter, but the fund-raising numbers also raised questions about his ability to keep pace over the course of the Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida raised $20 million in the first six weeks of his presidential run, his campaign said Thursday, a substantial sum that solidifies his place as the leading rival to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Britney Spears Seeks Apology After Encounter With Victor Wembanyama’s Security
abstract: Spears said on Twitter that a member of the athlete’s security detail had hit her outside a Las Vegas restaurant. The police said Friday that no charges would be filed.
lead_paragraph: The singer Britney Spears asked for an apology on Thursday after accusing a member of a star N.B.A. player’s security detail of striking her in the face outside a Las Vegas restaurant when she tried to greet the player, Victor Wembanyama of the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: Track Around a Park
abstract: Adrian Johnson opens our solving weekend with his first published themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Tracy Bennett enters the variety puzzle pantheon with a twisty challenge.
lead_paragraph: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Tracy Bennett is a member of the Games editorial staff of The New York Times, in charge of Wordle. She is also a puzzle constructor, but this is her first foray into variety puzzles. It’s a terrific solve, and looks like it was a blast to make. It has a big dollop of wit and the kinds of bits and pieces that a creative mind comes up with and reserves for the right setting.

headline: California Leaders Seek Federal Inquiry of Florida for Migrants Trips
abstract: In a letter to the Justice Department, Gov. Gavin Newsom, the California attorney general and a Texas sheriff said the Florida-funded program was based on deception.
lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders in California and Texas urged the Justice Department on Thursday to investigate a Florida program that has solicited asylum seekers in Texas and sent them with no apparent notice to Martha’s Vineyard and Sacramento.

headline: ‘Wherever I Am, I Am Always Birding’
abstract: The field-guide illustrator David Sibley says that drawing birds over a lifetime has shaped his entire way of seeing.
lead_paragraph: This week, for the New York Times summer birding project, we invite birders to try their hand at drawing a bird. You can do this from life or from a photograph. Try to produce at least one sketch in the upcoming week. Share it with us by emailing birds@nytimes.com.

headline: DeSantis Unleashes His Humanizer-in-Chief: His Wife
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s wife, Casey DeSantis, held her first solo campaign event in Iowa, connecting with fellow moms and casting her husband as a champion of the “parents’ rights” movement.
lead_paragraph: She was there to woo the conservative moms of Iowa. So Casey DeSantis, the wife of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, wasted no time in talking about her three young children — and how badly she wanted to leave them home.

headline: How to Draw a Bird the David Sibley Way
abstract: The field guide illustrator David Sibley gave instructions for drawing a bird.
lead_paragraph: The field guide illustrator David Sibley gave instructions for drawing a bird.

headline: They Fell in Love in a Video Game. Now Both Are in Jail.
abstract: The barrier-breaking romance of a Pakistani woman and an Indian man has led to criminal charges and nationalist intrigue.
lead_paragraph: Their love affair across one of the world’s most heavily guarded borders had begun on the virtual battlefields of a video game where players bond over having one another’s back against bloody enemy ambushes to become the last survivors.

headline: Quotation of the Day: 120-Degree Heat Bakes and Broils the ‘City of Sun’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “It was like I was being thrown balls of fire.”

headline: Corrections: July 7, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a suit filed by four countries over an Iranian missile that hit a Ukraine Airlines passenger flight misstated the year that the U.N. rapporteur, Agnes Callamard, published her report about the downing of the flight. It was in 2021, not 2001.

headline: Kissing a Fellow Janitor Amid the Trash
abstract: After two assaults, I sought healing on the coldest, driest and windiest continent on Earth.
lead_paragraph: On my first day of work in Antarctica, I found a vibrator. I had been sorting through a skua cabinet, a freebie bin named after the seabirds that harassed us, demanding snacks.

headline: The TikTok Algorithm That Brought Them Together
abstract: Kelly Winget fell asleep 20 minutes after knocking on Sarah Matteson’s front door for a first date. “It felt so natural to walk in there, and talk to each other a little and then just go to bed,” Ms. Winget said.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Dallas, Kelly Ann Winget’s parents used to remind her that her lifestyle was not the norm, but being gay in a conservative state like Texas had nothing to do with it. Instead, Ms. Winget, who described herself as the daughter of a fifth-generation oil and gas family, said they were “very well-to-do.” But her parents still “wanted us to be exposed to the real world — if we wanted something, we had to work for it,” she said.

headline: A Second Chance at Love and Blended Families
abstract: Michelle Evans and Eric Koch did not think second marriages were in their future — until a mutual friend urged them to connect.
lead_paragraph: The Brady Bunch have nothing on Michelle Lynn Evans and Eric Randolph Koch: Between the two of them, they have eight children and 48 years of marriage with former partners. While Ms. Evans had no intention of marrying again, and Dr. Koch remained ambivalent as well, Facebook and a mutual friend, Susan Ramos, changed all that.

headline: After a Hurricane, Presenting a Rainbow Fabric Ring
abstract: Molly Gaebe proposed to Leila Bozorg with a rainbow fabric ring and the help of the couple’s favorite drag queen.
lead_paragraph: Nothing could stop Molly Beth Gaebe from attending her former college softball teammate’s wedding in Stonington, Conn. Not even knee surgery. “You can’t go,” she recalled her friends saying, to which she replied, “Just watch me.”

headline: She Drew the Line at Marriage, Then Happily Crossed It
abstract: When her first marriage ended badly, Brooke Rinehart swore never to marry again. Then she met Tom Sinnott. The two developed a special closeness and agreed to start a family together.
lead_paragraph: On a hike during a vacation on the Hawaiian island of Kauai, Heather Brooke Rinehart was one month pregnant and needed to stop for a snack at a beach. As she rested, she noticed that someone had written “Will You Marry Me?” in the sand.

headline: What’s the Future of Wood-Fired Pizza in New York?
abstract: New regulations don’t mean the end of traditional pizza ovens. But they raise some issues for restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Last week the internet was concerned about the future of wood-fired pizza in New York City. We’ll take a look at the proposed rules that caused the uproar, talk to local pizza makers and see how the law compares with existing regulations in Naples, Italy.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A weighty decision on contentious weapons for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: After more than six months of deliberation, President Biden appeared on the verge of agreeing to ship cluster munitions to Ukraine. These are widely banned weapons known to cause grievous injury to civilians, and the step would sharply separate the U.S. from allies like Britain, Germany and France who have signed a treaty banning their use, stockpiling or transfer.

headline: How Does Diversity Actually Work at College? We Asked 10 Young Black Americans.
abstract: The group discusses college experiences, affirmative action and race in America today.
lead_paragraph: The group discusses college experiences, affirmative action and race in America today.

headline: Zelensky will discuss the grain deal with Turkey’s president, with a NATO bid in mind, too.
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is wrapping up an intense week of diplomacy with a visit to Istanbul on Friday to meet with Turkey’s president about the Black Sea grain deal that is once again facing an uncertain future, according to Turkey’s state-run Anadolu news agency.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is wrapping up an intense week of diplomacy with a visit to Istanbul on Friday to meet with Turkey’s president about the Black Sea grain deal that is once again facing an uncertain future, according to Turkey’s state-run Anadolu news agency.

headline: Yellen, in Beijing, Criticizes China’s Treatment of U.S. Companies
abstract: The concerns of Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen reflect continuing tensions between the two countries.
lead_paragraph: Of all the economic rifts between the United States and China, one felt personally by American executives is what they describe as the difficult, even hostile, conditions they face doing business in China.

headline: The Contentious U.S.-China Relationship, by the Numbers
abstract: From movie theaters to military spending, here’s how one of the world’s most important economic relationships stacks up.
lead_paragraph: China and the United States are locked in an increasingly intense rivalry when it comes to national security and economic competition, with American leaders frequently identifying China as their greatest long-term challenger.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Creator of ‘The Wire’ Asks Mercy for Man Charged in Actor’s Death
abstract: David Simon said the man, who was part of a crew that sold Michael K. Williams the fentanyl that killed him, deserves leniency as a victim of addiction himself.
lead_paragraph: The 2021 overdose of the actor Michael K. Williams, famous for playing a drug-world gunman, stands out as an example of fentanyl’s deadly march. Now, as one man charged in connection with his death faces sentencing, one of Mr. Williams’s closest friends wants the case to stand for something else: mercy.

headline: Why Backers Say a New Tunnel to Manhattan Benefits the Broader Economy
abstract: A $6.88 billion grant will mean more trains, more passengers, and a boost to the region’s economy.
lead_paragraph: The long-delayed project to build a train tunnel under the Hudson River to New York City received a big boost from the federal government this week, a $6.88 billion grant announced by Senator Chuck Schumer of New York on Thursday.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: This French Open Champion Nearly Gave Up Tennis to Sell Insurance
abstract: After years of frustration in singles, Austin Krajicek nearly quit tennis. Then an old friend asked him if he wanted to give the sport one more shot.
lead_paragraph: The last time Austin Krajicek stormed through the front door, threw his tennis bag into a closet and announced that he was done with the sport for good, his wife, Misia Kedzierski, thought he might actually be serious.

headline: Turning New York’s Stately Public Library Into a Place ‘to Hang Out In’
abstract: Behind the stone lions on Fifth Avenue, the New York Public Library’s imposing Fifth Avenue branch has added a new visitor center and an expanded gift shop and cafe.
lead_paragraph: The palatial Beaux-Arts library on Fifth Avenue guarded by a pair of stone lions was not where Farrah Denson wanted to be when she was a teenager growing up on the Upper West Side.

headline: Fire Breaks Out at Milan Retirement Home, Killing at Least 6
abstract: The cause of the blaze, which also sent dozens of people to the hospital, was under investigation. “It could have been much worse,” said the city’s mayor.
lead_paragraph: Six people died and dozens more were hospitalized for smoke inhalation after a fire broke out overnight in a retirement home in Milan, the authorities said Friday, adding that the toll could have been far higher.

headline: America’s House of the Moment
abstract: In a divided country, a clean look and a neutral color palette is the aesthetic comforting communities around the country.
lead_paragraph: In a divided country, a clean look and a neutral color palette is the aesthetic comforting communities around the country.

headline: How to Set an Outdoor Table
abstract: The interior designer Young Huh offers a step-by-step guide to entertaining outdoors with playfulness and style.
lead_paragraph: The interior designer Young Huh offers a step-by-step guide to entertaining outdoors with playfulness and style.

headline: How to Write Music for Rolling Boulders
abstract: From “Indiana Jones” to “Star Wars,” you know John Williams’s movie themes. But some of his best music has barely been heard.
lead_paragraph: From “Indiana Jones” to “Star Wars,” you know John Williams’s movie themes. But some of his best music has barely been heard.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Wham!"
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Wham!"

headline: No One Can Stop Talking About Justice John Marshall Harlan
abstract: John Roberts and Clarence Thomas have the “colorblind” Constitution all wrong.
lead_paragraph: If nothing else, the Supreme Court’s decision in Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard is a victory for the conservative vision of the so-called colorblind Constitution — a Constitution that does not see or recognize race in any capacity, for any reason.

headline: The I.R.A. Passed a Year Ago. Here’s a Progress Check.
abstract: Robinson Meyer offers a progress check on the Inflation Reduction Act and America’s path toward lower emissions.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the New York Times Audio app here.

headline: What It’s Like to be a Female Tour Guide in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Fatimah Al Zimam has introduced visitors from around the world to her country, which opened to nonreligious tourism in 2019. She discusses her favorite sites, driving a pickup truck and how her country is changing.
lead_paragraph: Fatimah Al Zimam likes to walk around in black leggings and casual tops, and she wears her curly hair loose and uncovered. She owns a silver GMC pickup truck, which she loves to take on solo drives across the Saudi desert. And she is passionate about her work: As a tour guide, she has introduced her country to visitors from the United States, France, Britain, Italy, China and beyond.

headline: The ‘Whisper Listing’ Gets Louder
abstract: Wealthy homeowners who want to avoid attention often try to sell their homes privately. But a tight housing market has led more agents to pursue this tactic.
lead_paragraph: Wealthy homeowners who want to avoid attention often try to sell their homes privately. But a tight housing market has led more agents to pursue this tactic.

headline: A Tragic Act of Gun Violence Repeats Itself in a Small Southern Town
abstract: In Amy Rowland’s second novel, “Inside the Wolf,” a New York City academic returns to her North Carolina roots to reconcile with old ghosts.
lead_paragraph: A cycle of “history, suffering, shame, again” rattles through “Inside the Wolf,” Amy Rowland’s wrenching sophomore novel, set in Shiloh, N.C. Awash with grief, Rachel Ruskin, 42 years old and recently denied tenure at a university in New York City, returns to her rural hometown where “everything except beer and mail requires a trip to Greenvale 20 miles away.” Her older brother, Garland, died by a self-inflicted gunshot a year ago, and after that her parents died together in a car accident. Rowland begins her novel at a crossroads fraught with regret and loss.

headline: Record a Win Every Day — and Other Ways to Practice Gratitude
abstract: Nearly 800 readers shared some of their favorite tips.
lead_paragraph: Jancee Dunn is out this week. I’m Christina Caron, a reporter on the Well desk, filling in.

headline: The Supreme Court Shattered the American Dream
abstract: Tressie McMillan Cottom on the justices’ rejection of affirmative action and student debt cancellation.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Lawrence Turman, 96, Dies; Producer Spotted a Winner in ‘The Graduate’
abstract: He was relatively new to the business when he was struck by an obscure novel and turned it into the biggest film of 1967.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Turman, who as a novice movie producer in 1963 read about a novel by a largely unknown writer named Charles Webb, took a $1,000 option on it and thus set in motion the making of “The Graduate,” the landmark film that helped define the 1960s and the antihero genre, died on Saturday at his home in the Woodland Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 96.

headline: Cottage Cheese Makes a Comeback
abstract: The diet staple of the ’70s is jiggling back into the mainstream — bringing with it a host of health benefits.
lead_paragraph: Some devour it plain, spooned straight from the tub. Others smear it over toast like burrata; blend it with sweet ingredients to make healthier versions of ice cream or cookie dough; or use it as a dip (paired with mustard) for raw veggies, fruits, sausages and more.

headline: How Do You Spell Discrimination?
abstract: MacNolia Cox speaks only one sentence in a picture book about her trip to the 1936 national spelling bee. Zaila Avant-garde, the 2021 champ, writes volumes.
lead_paragraph: In 1936, the eighth grader MacNolia Cox became the first Black student to win the Akron, Ohio, citywide spelling bee. Buoyed by community support, Cox traveled on a segregated train to Washington, D.C., and entered the arena for the national competition through a back door. When she reached the final five, the judges committed an act of racial perfidy. The word they gave her — nemesis — was not on the approved list. Cox spelled it N-E-M-A-S-I-S and was eliminated. The terrible prospect of Black excellence besting Anglo-Saxon smarts was narrowly avoided.

headline: Legacy Admissions Don’t Work the Way You Think They Do
abstract: They are part of the reason less advantaged students get so much out of elite schools.
lead_paragraph: Just four days after the Supreme Court rejected racial preferences in college admissions, a consortium of Black and Latino interest groups filed a complaint against Harvard concerning a different kind of preference: the special consideration given to the children of alumni. The filing notes that the practice of legacy admissions disproportionately benefits white applicants. If racial considerations are to be strictly limited, the plaintiffs argue, other considerations that effectively favor some racial groups must also go.

headline: How Mistaken Identity and One Bullet Revealed a Star Predator Far From Home
abstract: A hunter’s kill in upstate New York brought new hope, and trepidation, that wolves could slowly be making their way back to the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: The rustling in the brush was loud, so Brian Christman raised his muzzleloader for the deer he expected to emerge. It was the end of the season in central New York, and Mr. Christman was hoping to take home a buck.

headline: Sudan Will Not Be Left for Dead
abstract: The world has failed Sudan. This isn’t the first time.
lead_paragraph: Before the war, I’d only ever gotten on my knees and begged in order to pray. This changed when I found myself pleading to escape the annihilation swallowing my country whole.

headline: Gen X Is in Charge. Don’t Make a Big Deal About It.
abstract: The original “latchkey kids” are grown up, in the boss’s seat and ready to make the rules. If that’s OK?
lead_paragraph: The average age of incoming C.E.O.s is around 54. While American government remains squarely in the hands of baby boomers — and while its leadership, at least in certain branches, becomes noticeably older — corporate boardrooms are undergoing a transition. It’s Gen X’s moment, that generation most known for being crowded out of sweeping cultural age analyses by millennials on one end and boomers on the other.

headline: M.L.B. Draft Trades Magic for Efficiency
abstract: The days of unlimited picks are over, and while the league says the opportunities are still there, previous late-round picks aren’t so sure.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday in Seattle, for the fourth year in a row — enough for a full class of college prospects — Major League Baseball will hold a streamlined version of its amateur draft. From an event with unlimited rounds to one with 50 rounds, then 40, and now just 20, the draft is exclusive and efficient, in keeping with baseball’s restructured minor league system.

headline: Donors Are War-Weary, So Ukrainian Soldiers Get Creative for Funds
abstract: A robust fund-raising operation has been critical in supplying Ukraine’s military. But as the war drags on, contributions have lagged.
lead_paragraph: Under the vaulted brick arches of a contemporary art center in central Kyiv, a soldier in military green gave a reading of his own poetry, far from the front lines of the war he has been fighting since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: The Pains and Struggles of Family in Three Debut Novels
abstract: Complicated families abound in new books by Nathan Go, Lucian Childs and Elysha Chang.
lead_paragraph: Early in Nathan Go’s debut novel, FORGIVING IMELDA MARCOS (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 226 pp., $26), Lito, the story’s dying protagonist, prepares his circuitous yarn by asserting “the best way to fit one story among other stories is, I think, always wise to consider.” And it is indeed with wisdom and dexterity that Go intertwines the stories of three periods of Lito’s life: his final months, when Lito writes letters to his estranged son from a nursing home (which is the foundation of the novel); his youth, recounted via the memories that Lito has elected to share; and an extraordinary midlife occasion when, as a driver for the former Philippines revolutionary president Corazon Aquino, Lito is directed to transport the country’s leader to the home of Imelda Marcos, the scandalous widow of Ferdinand Marcos, Aquino’s predecessor and political rival.

headline: How Would Harvard Talk About My Kids?
abstract: We are far more than six categories on a demographic form.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare that I find myself nodding along in agreement with the conservative members of the Supreme Court. But reading Chief Justice John Roberts’s majority opinion striking down affirmative action programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina, I all but turned into a bobblehead.

headline: Setting a Table for Alfresco Dining Is Easy: Here’s How.
abstract: The interior designer Young Huh offers a step-by-step guide to entertaining outdoors with playfulness and style.
lead_paragraph: On a beautiful summer day, you don’t need much of an excuse to dine outdoors — especially if you’ve got a garden, patio or deck surrounded by greenery.

headline: 5 National Park Destinations That Aren’t Parks
abstract: The National Park Service isn’t just the 63 big-name parks. Here are national monuments, a lakeshore and two other less crowded alternatives to explore the country’s natural beauty and attractions.
lead_paragraph: Many of the 63 national parks across the United States have seen an explosion of visitor numbers both during and after the pandemic, which often has led to booked campsites, clogged trails and timed entry requirements in an attempt to limit crowds.

headline: U.S. Raises Pressure on China to Combat Global Fentanyl Crisis
abstract: The Biden administration push comes after cooperation on halting the flow of the drug into the United States was derailed by wider geopolitical tensions.
lead_paragraph: Just four years ago, a joint American and Chinese effort to stem the flow of fentanyl produced in China from reaching the United States appeared set to take off. Beijing had unveiled a sweeping new law banning the synthetic opioid, leading the Trump administration to praise China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, for “a wonderful humanitarian gesture.”

headline: An Uneasy Quiet at NATO’s Newest Border With Russia
abstract: Finland’s membership in the Western military alliance has increased NATO’s borders with Russia by 830 miles — and angered Moscow.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon along Finland’s border with Russia, an attack from Russian military bases a few miles away seemed a distant prospect.

headline: American Ballet Theater Does Not See Me as I See Myself
abstract: There is no separating the Black dancer from the dance.
lead_paragraph: I am a ballet dancer and a Black man, in that order. I left the United States to train at the Bolshoi Ballet Academy in Moscow at age 15 so that people would see my skill first and not my skin. It was a naïve dream, I realize now, since unlike painters, whose work can be regarded without their presence, I am both the artist and the artwork, and there can be no separation.

headline: Millions Danced Joyfully to Her Song. She Drew on Her Pain to Write It.
abstract: Nomcebo Zikode, the South African singer of the pandemic hit “Jerusalema” that inspired a global dance challenge, wrote the chorus while battling her own depression.
lead_paragraph: It starts with a clap, and then the feet tap along to the beat: four times on each side, followed by a quick jump. As the melody rises, dancers dip low and twirl.

headline: Penn Station Is a Perpetual Mess. Change May Be at Hand.
abstract: There may finally be hope for New York’s busiest, dreariest train hub, with a new plan to improve it, the stars aligning and the clock ticking.
lead_paragraph: If the latest flurry of news around two dueling plans to fix New York’s Pennsylvania Station has left you scratching your head, you’re not alone. Various officials I have spoken with are also fuzzy on details.

headline: As a Mexican Fighter Rises, U.F.C. Hopes Others Will Follow
abstract: Even with a long history of fighters of Mexican heritage in combat sports, Brandon Moreno is the first U.F.C. champion born in Mexico. His rise comes as the company looks to expand its reach.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Moreno, the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s flyweight champion, sat on a gym mat and stretched his lower body while music from the Argentine pop group La K’onga blared through speakers overhead.

headline: This Time, Herzog & de Meuron Are Inside the Museum
abstract: The architects behind museums in San Francisco, Miami and Minneapolis, and the Powerhouse Arts complex, in Brooklyn, are the subjects of a major exhibition, in London.
lead_paragraph: In its early years, the architecture firm that Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron founded in 1978 in Basel, Switzerland, was known for buildings that expressed personality through their exterior skins. Each design became a kind of essay on the architectural possibilities of a single material. There were the fiber-cement panels of the 1987 Ricola storage facility in Laufen, Switzerland, and the gabion walls, filled with stones, of the Dominus winery in the Napa Valley, completed a decade later.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, July 7, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The America That Americans Forget
abstract: As tensions with China mount, the U.S. military continues to build up Guam and other Pacific territories — placing the burdens of imperial power on the nation’s most ignored and underrepresented citizens.
lead_paragraph: On the weekends, when Roy Gamboa was a little boy, his grandfather woke him before dawn. He would pour some coffee into a bowl of rice, and that would be the boy’s breakfast. Roy knew better than to question anything; he sat quietly in his grandfather’s truck as they rumbled down the big hill from their village, Hågat, to Big Navy, as the U.S. Naval Base in Guam is known. They passed through the military gates, along a dirt road and onto the shore of a little cove, next to one of America’s deepest harbors, where skipjacks flipped out of the aquamarine water. The boy noodled with seashells as his grandfather cast. When his grandfather caught a fish, he would unhook it and throw it on the ground, and Roy would snatch it up and quickly stuff it, still wriggling, in the bag. If the fish weren’t biting at one spot, they packed up and moved to another. No one from the Navy ever stopped the old man and the young boy.

headline: Fed Watchers to Parse June Jobs Report Closely
abstract: How much more the Federal Reserve raises interest rates this year will hinge on the strength of the economy — particularly the labor market.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve policymakers are debating how much further they need to raise interest rates to ensure that inflation speedily returns to a normal pace, and that calculus is likely to depend heavily on the job market’s strength.

headline: Against the Odds, the U.S. Economy Chugs Along, as Fears Linger
abstract: Hiring slowed last month, a sign that the Federal Reserve’s inflation-fighting campaign is taking hold. But with rising wages and low unemployment, the labor market remains resilient.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. labor market showed signs of continued cooling last month but extended a two-and-a-half-year streak of job growth, the Labor Department said Friday.

headline: How Do ‘Barbie’ and Blackpink Figure in a Dangerous Territorial Dispute?
abstract: Vietnam banned the film over its apparent use of a Chinese map showing disputed territory. Blackpink concerts may be next. Here’s what the fuss is about.
lead_paragraph: Of all the things that could inflame tensions in a region that could someday be a theater of war between superpowers, the movie “Barbie” was not an obvious catalyst. Yet here we are.

headline: The Modern Farmhouse Is Today’s McMansion. And It’s Here to Stay.
abstract: In a divided country, a clean look and a neutral color palette is the aesthetic comforting communities around the country.
lead_paragraph: Drive through any American suburb and odds are you’ll spot a modern farmhouse in its natural habitat. The style is hard to miss: white board and batten vertical siding, large black frame windows, and gables. A covered porch, with a swing or maybe Adirondack chairs. A tin roof. And of course, house numbers in sans serif font.

headline: Today’s Top News: The End of the ‘Great Resignation,’ and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Complicated Future of Student Loans
abstract: The dismissal of a plan to wipe out more than $400 billion in student debt has dashed the hopes of tens of millions of borrowers.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Supreme Court struck down President Biden’s sweeping plan to cancel billions of dollars in student loan debt.

headline: A High-Profile Australia-English Cricket Series
abstract: More than 150 years ago, an Australian tour to England captured the attention of Britons.
lead_paragraph: This week, Australia has, not for the first time, been convulsed by a major cricket controversy that divided cricket fans in England and Australia. (It invited commMore than 150 years ago, a different Australian tour captured the attention of Britons.ent even from the Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese: “Same old Aussies — always winning!”)

headline: How Elba Makes a Living Wage
abstract: We’re covering a hotel strike in Los Angeles, extreme heat and an Alzheimer’s drug.
lead_paragraph: Early in Barack Obama’s recent Netflix documentary series about American jobs, viewers meet a housekeeper at the Pierre Hotel in New York named Elba. She spends her shifts cleaning hotel rooms, and she talks about the job’s challenges, including back pain and guests’ occasional misbehavior. Elba is meant to be a symbol of difficult service-industry work in today’s economy.

headline: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a sweet dragon tale, the new “Avatar” installment and an updated Cinderella story.
lead_paragraph: “My Father’s Dragon,” an adaptation of the 1948 children’s novel of the same name by Ruth Stiles Gannett, follows a young boy named Elmer (Jacob Tremblay, recently the voice of Flounder in “The Little Mermaid”) who is living a blissful life with his mother, Dela (Golshifteh Farahani). When Dela’s business shuts down, it forces her to move to a city tenement and scramble for work. A black cat (voiced by Whoopi Goldberg) tells Elmer to journey to a place called Wild Island and free a dragon named Boris, who can, in turn, bring fame and fortune to Dela. Elmer finds Boris (Gaten Matarazzo of “Stranger Things”) and what ensues is a tender story of friendship, fear and bravery. Beautiful hand-drawn animation and wide-eyed characters are a signature of Cartoon Saloon, the Oscar-nominated Irish animation studio that produced this film along with Netflix and Mockingbird Pictures. And thanks to the director Nora Twomey (“The Breadwinner”) and the screenwriter Meg LeFauve (“Inside Out”), both Oscar nominees, this 2022 film’s sweet, important lessons — that it’s OK to be scared sometimes and that bonds between friends give us courage — are made digestible for young children.

headline: Why a Strong Jobs Report Could Rattle the Markets
abstract: Economists have forecast that employers created 225,000 jobs last month. A bigger-than-expected number could complicate the Federal Reserve’s efforts to tame inflation.
lead_paragraph: Economists and market participants are deeply divided about Friday’s payrolls report — due out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern — and what it may signal for the Fed’s interest rate policy and the chances of a recession this year.

headline: L.S.U. Teammates Are Unprecedented 1-2 Punch in M.L.B. Draft
abstract: In a draft loaded with talent, Paul Skenes and Dylan Crews could be the first teammates to be taken with the top two picks.
lead_paragraph: The top pick in this year’s Major League Baseball draft will probably come from Louisiana State’s College World Series-winning team. The only question seems to be which player will head to the Pittsburgh Pirates at No. 1, and which will go to the Washington Nationals at No. 2.

headline: Canadian Court Rules 👍 Emoji Counts as a Contract Agreement
abstract: The ruling pointed to what a judge called the “new reality in Canadian society” that courts would have to confront as more people express themselves with thumbs, hearts and smiley faces.
lead_paragraph: Be careful before you casually dash off another thumbs-up emoji: A Canadian court has found that the ubiquitous symbol can affirm that a person is officially entering into a contract.

headline: Switzerland and Austria, Both Traditionally Neutral, Join a German-Led Air Defense Initiative
abstract: The Sky Shield initiative is aimed at strengthening Europe’s air defenses to deal with threats highlighted by Russia’s assault on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Switzerland and Austria, two countries with strong traditions of foreign-policy neutrality, signaled their intention on Friday to join a German-led initiative aimed at strengthening Europe’s air defenses to deal with threats highlighted by Russia’s assault on Ukraine.

headline: The Homeless World Cup Arrives in Sacramento
abstract: A remarkable soccer competition for people who have been homeless within the past two years aims to help them regain a sense of purpose.
lead_paragraph: California’s homelessness crisis is no secret.

headline: Tips for Canceling Online Subscriptions
abstract: It’s easy to sign up but not always so easy to stop a service. The F.T.C. is proposing rules to change that.
lead_paragraph: Online subscriptions of all kinds have been mushrooming in recent years. While signing up is easy, managing and cutting them back is difficult, even for savvy consumers.

headline: If We Are What We Eat, We Don’t Know Who We Are
abstract: In “Ultra-Processed People,” Chris van Tulleken takes a close look at the franken-snacks that barely resemble what they’re imitating.
