lead_paragraph: “We have certain recollections,” Marcel Proust once wrote, “that resemble the Dutch painting of our memory.” Laura Cumming doesn’t quote these words in her genre-defying book “Thunderclap: A Memoir of Art and Life and Sudden Death,” but their spirit suffuses its pages. Like Proust, Cumming suggests that we recall the past through pictures, and like him, she identifies such pictures with the paintings of the 17th-century Dutch, who made enduring images from the humble materials of ordinary life.

headline: Substance Abuse Is Climbing Among Seniors
abstract: Many aging baby boomers have long histories with drugs, cannabis and alcohol. “The field wasn’t ready for that,” said one expert.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Benjamin Han, a geriatrician and addiction medicine specialist, meets new patients at the School of Medicine at the University of California, San Diego, he talks with them about the usual health issues that older adults face: chronic conditions, functional ability, medications and how they’re working.

headline: A Look Back at Megan Rapinoe’s Best Moments
abstract: The women’s soccer star, who announced on Saturday that she would retire later this year, always seemed to deliver in the biggest games.
lead_paragraph: Megan Rapinoe, who announced on Saturday that she planned to retire from professional soccer later this year, rose to stardom in part because of her outspoken political views and her leadership in her sport beyond the field. But much of that was possible because her career on the field had so many highlight-reel-worthy moments.

headline: Grazed and Confused: In ‘The Vegan,’ a Guilty Hedge Funder Eats His Feelings
abstract: Andrew Lipstein’s shrewd novel finds a moneyed Brooklynite so unmoored that he starts to identify with animals he has long overlooked.
lead_paragraph: We should all be feminists, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie wrote, and at this point in climate change, we should probably also all be vegans (at least for part of the week).

headline: Nikki Haley Makes Her Pitch in New Hampshire. It’s Unclear Whether Voters Will Swing.
abstract: The former South Carolina governor and United Nations ambassador is intensely focused on the state. But her brand of politics may not resonate in the 2024 political climate.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor and United Nations ambassador, five months into her first run for president, acknowledges the position she is in.

headline: Number of Migrants at the Border Plunges as Mexico Helps U.S. to Stem Flow
abstract: Mexico is taking steps to keep migrants from massing along the border. But as they flow into southern Mexico the calm may be short-lived.
lead_paragraph: Migrant shelters with plenty of empty beds. Soup kitchens with food to spare. Soldiers patrolling intersections where migrant families once begged for spare change.

headline: Men Are Baring Midriffs in Crop Tops
abstract: Some are cropping their shirts at home and others are buying them from stores’ women’s sections.
lead_paragraph: It is often the case that, as summer rolls around and temperatures rise, so do hemlines. As men have embraced shorter shorts over the past few years, some have also started to wear shorter shirts — specifically, crop tops.

headline: An Era of Dynamic Catchers Is Upon Us
abstract: Sean Murphy, Adley Rutschman, Jonah Heim, Will Smith and Gabriel Moreno lead a generation of catchers as good with their bats as their gloves.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel Moreno was at home in Venezuela last Dec. 23 when Ross Atkins, the general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, called him.

headline: Verstappen Tops a Very British Podium at Silverstone
abstract: Max Verstappen collected his sixth straight victory, but the British drivers Lando Norris and Lewis Hamilton were celebrating, too.
lead_paragraph: Lando Norris took the lead early. Then he took the fight right to Max Verstappen. But a British Grand Prix that offered some early drama at Silverstone Circuit on Sunday eventually ended in the most predictable way possible: with Verstappen taking the lead back, pushing his Red Bull far out in front, and leaving everyone else racing for second place.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hoping for a Silver Lining After a Tornado in the Delta
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “My heart is in Rolling Fork, it will always be there. But now this has happened, we have an opportunity.”

headline: This Drug Holds Promise for Cult Survivors
abstract: A Nxivm survivor and her mother are trying psychedelics as treatment.
lead_paragraph: Catherine Oxenberg and her daughter, India, have been through hell. In 2011, Catherine, an actor best known for starring in the 1980s hit “Dynasty,” and India, then 19, enrolled in what they were told was an “executive success” seminar. The sessions made Catherine uneasy. But when India threw herself into ongoing training sessions, her mother suppressed her doubt, wanting her child to find her own way.

headline: Look at What John Roberts and His Court Have Wrought Over 18 Years
abstract: The constitutional world is profoundly different from when John Roberts became chief justice 18 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The end of a Supreme Court term always sparks a lively conversation about how to characterize what just happened, and this year was no exception. In refusing to weaken the Voting Rights Act any further, did the court show itself to be a bit less dogmatically conservative than the year before? Did the 6-to-3 rejection of a dangerous theory that would have stripped state courts of the authority to review election laws show that the justices could still build bridges across their ideological divide?

headline: A NATO Invitation Will Make or Break Ukraine
abstract: The world won’t be a safer place if Ukraine is kept out of NATO.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — For decades, discussions about whether or not Ukraine should be admitted to NATO have revolved around the risks — to both Ukraine and member nations — of Ukraine being in the alliance. And at the core of those risks had been one overriding fear: that Ukraine’s membership might push President Vladimir Putin of Russia into a corner, prompting him to escalate his war.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Spy Who Called Me’
abstract: For years, Spanish society has been rocked by revelations from the secret tapes of José Manuel Villarejo Pérez, a former intelligence agent now facing prison. He told our reporter his story.
lead_paragraph: The wave of scandals that would engulf Spain began with a police raid on a wooded property outside Madrid. It was Nov. 3, 2017, and the target was José Manuel Villarejo Pérez, a former government spy. Villarejo’s name had been circulating in the Spanish press for years. He was rumored to have had powerful friends and to have kept dirt on them all. The impressive variety of allegations against him — forgery, bribery, extortion, influence peddling — had earned him the nickname “king of the sewers.”

headline: Who Truly Threatens the Church?
abstract: Two competing philosophies of Christian political engagement.
lead_paragraph: There’s a popular story in Christian circles that’s literally too good to be true. According to legend, in the early 1900s, The Times of London sent an inquiry to a number of writers asking the question, “What’s wrong with the world today?” The Christian apologist G.K. Chesterton responded succinctly and profoundly: “Dear Sirs, I am.”

headline: Threads Takes on Twitter
abstract: How Meta did what no other Twitter competitor could.
lead_paragraph: To many users, Twitter had become like a bad boyfriend.

headline: Ukraine Celebrates Return of Azov Commanders Held as Prisoners of War
abstract: Five members of the regiment returned home from Turkey to a heroes’ welcome on Saturday. The Kremlin accused Ankara of violating the terms of the deal that freed them.
lead_paragraph: Five Ukrainian commanders of the Azov Regiment, extolled in Ukraine for defending the port city of Mariupol last year during an 80-day Russian siege before they surrendered as prisoners of war, have been given a heroes’ welcome after returning home.

headline: Why We Shouldn’t Lose Faith in Organized Religion
abstract: It is still a force for good in our country.
lead_paragraph: Eboo Patel wants to tell a better story about religion in America.

headline: Saharan Dust Blowing Across the Atlantic Could Reach South Florida
abstract: Residents could experience less rain and higher temperatures because of the dust, and it might affect air quality.
lead_paragraph: As Florida recovers from the tangled seaweed blob plaguing its coasts, nature may have something else in store for the state: dust from the Sahara.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Tarnished Reputation
abstract: A member of the court’s bar is resigning, and others express their dismay. Also: Groundwater and the Earth’s wobble; politicians as messiahs; helping the homeless.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Is Aretha Franklin’s True Will the One Found in the Couch or a Cabinet?
abstract: A trial starting on Monday is to decide whether either of two handwritten documents represents the singer’s last wishes. Her sons have battled in court for years over the question.
lead_paragraph: At first, Aretha Franklin’s family believed the division of her estate after her death in 2018 would be a straightforward task: Without a known will, the celebrated singer’s assets would be equally distributed among her four sons.

headline: 3 Takeaways From Janet Yellen’s Trip to Beijing
abstract: The U.S. Treasury secretary met with China’s new economic policy leaders and toned down Washington’s talk of “decoupling.” But the two nations remain at odds on many issues.
lead_paragraph: The deep chill between the United States and China moderated a little over the past few days as Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen held marathon talks with a new group of top economic policymakers in Beijing.

headline: How to Make a Perfect Cacio e Pepe, Every Time
abstract: Julia Moskin’s adapted Roscioli recipe features a clever trick that ensures a silky emulsified sauce.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You can spend your whole adult life doing something absolutely correctly and never quite feel as if you’ve mastered the task. This is especially true in cooking. For instance, how many hard-boiled eggs have you made in the last 10 years? Now, be honest: How many of them were you proud of — perfect little pouches of fudgy yolk and silken, just-set white?

headline: Pope Francis Names 21 New Cardinals, With a Focus Beyond Europe
abstract: In choosing men from around the world for the college that will elect his successor, the pontiff aimed to reflect “the universality of the church.”
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis announced Sunday that he would create 21 new cardinals in September, choosing clerics from across the world to reinforce the church’s global reach, as he has done with past choices.

headline: Biden Says Ukraine Is Not Ready for NATO Membership
abstract: President Biden, who will attend a NATO summit in Europe this week, said it was “premature” to allow Ukraine to join the alliance as the war with Russia continues.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said in an interview that aired on Sunday that Ukraine was not ready for membership in NATO and that it was “premature” to begin the process to allow Ukraine to join the alliance in the middle of a war.

headline: On Her Renaissance Tour, the World Is Beyoncé’s Ball
abstract: The pop superstar’s first solo outing in seven years draws on the dance-music cultures that inspired her 2022 album, and her work that led up to that ecstatic release.
lead_paragraph: It was a crowd that had come to dance, dressed for a rodeo in the distant future: sparkling cowboy hats, silvery fringe, outré sunglasses and any other sartorial detail that represented “Renaissance,” Beyoncé’s dazzling seventh album and the occasion for her first solo tour in seven years. But as the imperial pop superstar took the stage at the Rogers Center in Toronto on Saturday night for the first North American show of her Renaissance World Tour, she reminded the club-ready audience just who was in charge. Because if they were prepared to move, she was going to make them wait a little longer.

headline: BBC Suspends Male Staff Member After Report of Payments for Sexual Images
abstract: A report in The Sun newspaper said that an unnamed male presenter at the BBC had paid tens of thousands of pounds to a teenager in exchange for “sexually explicit photographs.”
lead_paragraph: The BBC, Britain’s public broadcaster, suspended a male staff member on Sunday after a report in The Sun newspaper that an unnamed male presenter had paid tens of thousands of pounds to a person starting when they were 17 years old in exchange for “sexually explicit photographs.”

headline: Pogacar Cuts Further Into Vingegaard’s Tour de France Lead
abstract: The cycling race returned to the formidable Puy de Dôme after 35 years.
lead_paragraph: There were three climbs in the early part of Sunday’s Tour de France stage that would break any normal person on a three-speed. But everyone was really waiting for Jonas Vingegaard versus Tadej Pogacar on Le Puy de Dôme.

headline: Henry Kamm, Pulitzer-Winning New York Times Journalist, Dies at 98
abstract: In a 47-year career at The Times, he covered Cold War diplomacy in Europe, famine in Africa and genocide in Southeast Asia and was also an author.
lead_paragraph: Henry Kamm, a former Pulitzer Prize-winning foreign correspondent for The New York Times who covered Cold War diplomacy in Europe and the Soviet Union, famine in Africa, and wars and genocide in Southeast Asia, died on Sunday in Paris. He was 98.

headline: At a French Opera Festival, Premieres in Pursuit of Happiness
abstract: Two works at the Aix-en-Provence Festival, by two inventive opera partnerships, use fables to explore grief and queer utopian dreams.
lead_paragraph: Happiness doesn’t come quickly. Aristotle claimed that as one swallow does not make spring, neither does one good day make someone happy. That would take a lifetime, at least.

headline: Fire on Newark Ship Is Slowly Being Contained, Coast Guard Says
abstract: The fatal fire in Port Newark, N.J. is no longer spreading, officials said. The ship continued to list, but the danger of its capsizing is lessening.
lead_paragraph: Emergency workers had contained a fatal fire aboard a cargo ship at Port Newark, N.J., to its 11th deck and had reduced the risk that it could capsize, officials said on Sunday.

headline: Several Executives of P.R. Firm Joele Frank to Start Own Firm
abstract: The business of advising companies on corporate crises is growing, and so is the number of firms specializing in it.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when companies doing big deals could turn to only a handful of firms for advice. But the booming demand for counsel on acquisitions, activist investors and corporate crises has widened that circle and, increasingly, led to the creation of new firms.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: NATO Prepares to Meet
abstract: Also, Janet Yellen leaves Beijing with hope, but no breakthroughs.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of NATO countries are preparing for two days of meetings starting tomorrow in Vilnius, Lithuania’s capital.

headline: Overdue Book Is Returned to a Library After Nearly 120 Years
abstract: The book was checked out in 1904 or 1905, according to the director of the New Bedford Free Public Library in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: As books go, James Clerk Maxwell’s “An Elementary Treatise on Electricity” is hardly a household name, but it has gained renewed attention after a copy was returned last month to a Massachusetts library nearly 120 years overdue.

headline: Man Is Charged With Murder in Random Scooter Shooting Spree
abstract: Thomas Abreu, 25, was charged with the murder of Hamod Ali Saeidi, an 86-year-old immigrant from Yemen who was out for his daily stroll in Queens.
lead_paragraph: A man who drove a scooter through Queens, firing randomly at people on the street, was charged on Sunday with the murder of an 86-year-old man during the half-hour shooting spree, the police said.

headline: Message Concealers
abstract: Brad Wiegmann lets the cat out of the bag.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: At Least 1 Dead as Heavy Rains Set Off Flash Flooding in New York
abstract: The Hudson Valley was the most affected by the storm system on Sunday, with sections getting up to eight inches of rain, the National Weather Service said.
lead_paragraph: A slow-moving storm system brought heavy rain across a wide section of New York State on Sunday evening, flooding streets, prompting dozens of rescues for drivers whose vehicles were stranded on inundated roads and causing at least one death, the authorities said.

headline: For Rapinoe, a Final Send-Off Before a Final World Cup
abstract: One day after announcing her plan to retire this year, Megan Rapinoe began her farewell tour as an unused substitute in her team’s send-off match.
lead_paragraph: Megan Rapinoe began her long goodbye with the equivalent of a homecoming.

headline: Manhunt Continues for ‘Survivalist’ Murder Suspect Who Escaped Jail
abstract: The police said that the escapee, Michael Burham, could be hiding in the steep, rugged wilderness near Warren, Pa., which borders a national forest.
lead_paragraph: A manhunt continued on Sunday for a murder suspect who escaped from a Pennsylvania jail late on Thursday using bedsheets he tied together to climb down from the roof, officials said.

headline: The Southwest Bakes With More Heat on the Way
abstract: Phoenix could be on track to break its record of 18 consecutive days with temperatures above 110 as a heat dome has settled over the desert Southwest.
lead_paragraph: As the heat engulfed Tucson, Ariz., on Sunday afternoon, six people, part of a new mutual aid group they call Gator-Aid, were dropping seven-pound bags of Reddy Ice on the hot sidewalks and loading coolers with hundreds of bottles of water and Gatorade.

headline: In an M.L.B. Draft First, Teammates Are Taken With the Top Two Picks
abstract: After winning the College World Series, Paul Skenes and Dylan Crews of Louisiana State were the first two players off the board Sunday in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana State’s baseball program pulled off an unprecedented feat on Sunday, with players from its College World Series-winning team being taken with the top two picks in Major League Baseball’s draft in Seattle. With the No. 1 overall pick, the Pittsburgh Pirates chose Paul Skenes, a right-handed starting pitcher, and the Washington Nationals chose Dylan Crews, an outfielder, at No. 2.

headline: Initial Victim in Philadelphia Shot 44 Hours Before Larger Attack, Police Say
abstract: A 911 call reported gunshots near the victim’s house, but the police were dispatched to the wrong address and the body was not discovered until four more people were killed.
lead_paragraph: One of the five people named as fatalities in the mass shooting in Philadelphia on the night of July 3 was killed 44 hours beforehand, the city’s police department said on Sunday.

headline: Heavy Rain Causes Flash Flooding in New York
abstract: Some towns declared states of emergency, and authorities said the storm killed at least one.
lead_paragraph: Some towns declared states of emergency, and authorities said the storm killed at least one.

headline: Glow of Baseball’s All-Star Game Can’t Obscure Athletics’ Departure
abstract: Major League Baseball’s midsummer celebration comes on the heels of an announced agreement to build a stadium for the Athletics that would relocate the franchise to Las Vegas from Oakland.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball wants you to believe in its fairy tale. It wants you to see the talented players at Tuesday’s All-Star Game — Shohei Ohtani, Bo Bichette, Ronald Acuña Jr. — and be mesmerized into forgetting.

headline: For a President and a King, the View From the Top Is Curiously Similar
abstract: Despite hints of tension between Washington and London, President Biden and King Charles III share interests and have faced comparable challenges, which might have helped smooth their meeting.
lead_paragraph: The two men — the American president and the British king — waited decades for their dream jobs, projecting a sense of normalcy and unity when they finally reached their thrones. They both prefer to ditch executive palaces for their respective retreats. And they share a passion for confronting threats to the environment.

headline: Leaders push to resolve disagreements on the eve of the NATO summit.
abstract: President Biden and other NATO leaders are making a last minute push before an annual summit to address crucial disagreements that threaten to overshadow the alliance’s unity in opposition to Russia’s war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and other NATO leaders are making a last minute push before an annual summit to address crucial disagreements that threaten to overshadow the alliance’s unity in opposition to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: 13 Looks That Did the Most at the ‘Barbie’ Premiere
abstract: Margot Robbie, Ryan Gosling, Issa Rae, Kingsley Ben-Adir, Billie Eilish and many more stars came out on the pink carpet.
lead_paragraph: Were only Susan Sontag alive today to rewrite her famous “Notes on ‘Camp,’” she might have had a field day at the “Barbie” movie premiere, which took place at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles on Sunday night (and, for all we know, she might have even been cast in the movie — it seems every other person on Earth appeared in the trailer). If the message of the movie is that all of us are Barbie and Barbie is all of us, the pink carpet did a good job of reinforcing that message (at least that’s what the cryptic trailers imply, but we’re not sure, as no screeners have been made available).

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: A setback in Ukraine’s bid for NATO membership.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine is not ready for membership in NATO, President Biden said in an interview that aired yesterday on CNN. It would be “premature,” he said, to begin the process to allow the country to join the alliance in the middle of a war, because doing so would thrust all NATO members into military conflict with Russia.

headline: No Corrections: July 10, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Relying on Desperate Measure to Save Lifeline of Everglades
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “They just love the smell of death and decay.”

headline: The Flawed Moral Logic of Sending Cluster Munitions to Ukraine
abstract: The weapons will remain a threat to the people of Ukraine, no matter the outcome of this conflict.
lead_paragraph: In the brutal logic of warfare, cluster munitions may appear to make solid sense for Ukraine’s slow-moving counteroffensive against well-dug-in Russian troops. Delivered by artillery, a 155-millimeter shell packed with 72 armor-piercing, soldier-killing bomblets can strike from 20 miles away and scatter them over a vast area.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘What We Do in the Shadows’ and ‘Barbie Dreamhouse Challenge’
abstract: The series about Staten Island vampires is back for a fifth season on FX and HGTV premieres a “Barbie” themed show.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 10-16. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: dilettante
abstract: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word dilettante has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 14 in “OpenAI Plans to Up the Ante in Tech’s A.I. Race” by Cade Metz:

headline: Six Dead After Stabbing at a Preschool in China
abstract: The police in southern China arrested a 25-year-old man in relation to the attack. Knife attacks are not uncommon in China, and many have targeted schools.
lead_paragraph: Six people were killed in a knife attack at a preschool in China’s southern Guangdong Province on Monday.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Tuberville Blockade Over Abortion Policy Threatens Top Military Promotions
abstract: The Alabama Republican’s bid to force the Pentagon to drop a policy ensuring access to abortion services for personnel could leave the Joint Chiefs of Staff with more temporary occupants than it has ever faced.
lead_paragraph: A lone Senate Republican’s bid to reverse a Pentagon policy ensuring abortion access for service members is delaying the smooth transfer of power at the highest echelons of the armed forces, including in the ranks of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as a monthslong partisan dispute over social policy drags on.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Snapshot of 2024 Candidates’ Financial Strength Is Coming Up
abstract: The deadline for campaigns to file their quarterly fund-raising reports is Saturday, offering a look at their momentum.
lead_paragraph: The deadline for campaigns to file their quarterly fund-raising reports is Saturday, offering a look at their momentum.

headline: How Biden Might Try to Cancel Student Debt Next
abstract: The administration proposed to use its “compromise and settlement” powers under the Higher Education Act of 1965. But what does that mean?
lead_paragraph: On June 30, in the wake of losing a Supreme Court lawsuit over his $400 billion plan to cancel student loan debt, President Biden said he was going to try again.

headline: The Case That Could Be Fox’s Next Dominion
abstract: Tucker Carlson, before he was sidelined by Fox, repeatedly endorsed a conspiracy theory about an Arizona man, who may sue for defamation. Legal experts say it would be a viable case.
lead_paragraph: Of all the distortions and paranoia that Tucker Carlson promoted on his since-canceled Fox News program, one looms large: a conspiracy theory that an Arizona man working as a covert government agent incited the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the Capitol to sabotage and discredit former President Donald J. Trump and his political movement.

headline: Where Does New York City Office Furniture Go When No One Wants It?
abstract: Some office furniture in the metro area has been caught in pandemic limbo. What awaits it in the afterlife?
lead_paragraph: Herman Miller is one of the most revered makers of office furniture in the world, its designs so esteemed that its Aeron chair, which became a fixture of New York City cubicles, was put in the Museum of Modern Art’s permanent collection.

headline: They Caught the Fish, but the $3.5 Million Prize Got Away
abstract: The guys aboard Sensation celebrated like lottery winners when they boated a monster marlin in the last hours of the fishing tournament. The party ended when they got back to shore.
lead_paragraph: If you want to hear about the day the guys aboard the fishing boat Sensation landed a giant marlin and danced to Tina Turner because they were sure they had won $3.5 million, only to find out they hadn’t, first you need to know about Ashley Bleau and the Big Rock Blue Marlin Tournament in Morehead City, N.C.

headline: Jazz in the Garden: A Summertime Delight in Brooklyn
abstract: The Brooklyn Botanic Garden began outdoor programming during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we will fill you in on a delightful summertime treat in Brooklyn. And we’ll bring you an update on the deadly cargo ship fire in Newark.

headline: Do I Really Need to Pack a Capsule Travel Wardrobe?
abstract: A reader hopes to construct a practical and chic wardrobe that weighs in at less than 33 pounds.
lead_paragraph: The capsule holiday wardrobe is the holy grail of travel: an interchangeable, efficient system of dressing that in an ideal world necessitates no more than a tote and a bag that will fit in an airplane overhead bin. This is a particularly pressing ideal this summer, as warnings grow of airport chaos and the potential for lost luggage, but packing light also provides what I think of as a much overlooked psychological boost.

headline: Does Sugar Actually Feed Cancer?
abstract: Many patients say they avoid sweets to help fight the disease. But while a healthy diet is important, you can’t “starve a tumor.”
lead_paragraph: During the eight years Stacy Shawhan has worked as an oncology dietitian, she has heard many questions from her cancer patients about how their diets influence their prognosis. But one question has come up more than the rest: Will consuming sugary foods and drinks feed my cancer cells, making my condition worse?

headline: A Language-Learning Institute With a Disturbing Secret
abstract: In her debut novel, “The Centre,” Ayesha Manazir Siddiqi explores class anxiety, identity, appropriation and more through a sinister language school.
lead_paragraph: In her ingenious debut novel, “The Centre,” Ayesha Manazir Siddiqi introduces us to a world where language learning doesn’t stop with a textbook. The would-be polyglots in this thriller aren’t just striving to memorize verb conjugations and recite poetry; they’re up to something far more sinister.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern home in Walnut Creek, a Cape Cod-style house in Burbank and a 1925 Tudor Revival in Albany.
lead_paragraph: This house is one of more than 300 in the Rancho San Miguel neighborhood built by the prolific midcentury developer Joseph Eichler. The neighborhood abuts San Miguel Park, which has play areas for children and dogs, and is near John Muir Health Walnut Creek Medical Center, which has an emergency room and imaging facilities.

headline: Full Speed Ahead on A.I. Our Economy Needs It.
abstract: The problem isn’t that technology is developing too quickly; it’s developing too slowly to bolster our sagging productivity.
lead_paragraph: The workers were furious. Believing that new mechanical looms threatened their jobs, they broke into factories, seized machinery, brought it into the street and set it afire, all with widespread public support, even tacitly from the authorities.

headline: Ann Beattie’s Stories Confront Charlottesville, a City Remade
abstract: Her new collection, “Onlookers,” is about shattered certainties in the wake of quarantine, growth and unrest.
lead_paragraph: The Covid lockdown period already seems, as a subject, like a flattened corpse over which the whole of American culture and commentary has trampled. But it was only three years ago. Fiction is still catching up.

headline: An Open Marriage, a Bad Decision and a Grandmother Who Needs Cash
abstract: In his riotous new novel, “Hope,” Andrew Ridker finds the humor in a family’s plummet from grace.
lead_paragraph: If for Emily Dickinson “hope” is the thing with feathers, for Andrew Ridker, in his novel called “Hope,” it’s an upstanding liberal Jewish family outside Boston, grasping at air as they plummet from grace. Think Harvard-educated physician father, socially conscious Brookline mother and young adult offspring struggling to self-actualize. HOPE is also the name of a study — the Human Outpatient Pericarditis Evaluation, “so named to force a snappy acronym” — for which Scott, the doctor, manipulates data, eventually losing his license and launching the family nosedive.

headline: Ron DeSantis Doesn’t Know Whether He’s Coming or Going
abstract: The strange case of the governor of Florida’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, about Ron DeSantis. Last week, I criticized him for weenie stuff like big book advances and questionable road repair materials. At the time, I definitely felt like I was carping.

headline: The Tale of Two Invasions: What the Last Attack on Jenin Tells Us About Israel Now
abstract: The Israeli Army once again went into the refugee camp — this time without a peace process to return to.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Our screens are filled once again with images of weeping women, children, and the elderly marching down the street with their hands raised or waving white garments from slow-moving vehicles. Palestinians have seen this before, having lived through a long history of expulsions from their homes and villages under the threat of fire.

headline: Do Hormone Treatments for Menopause Increase Dementia Risk?
abstract: A new study suggests a link, but experts caution that there’s more to the story.
lead_paragraph: A large new study in Denmark suggested that hormone therapy — which women use to manage menopausal symptoms — was associated with an increased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease and other types of dementia. The study found that the heightened risk was even present in women who started the therapy at 55 or younger and in short term users.

headline: The Turtle Who Came Back From the Dead
abstract: Most people love turtles and want to help them. So it’s odd that we are the cause of most of their problems.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I admit it: I’m jealous of my writing-group partners, Mary Laura Philpott and Maria Browning. I don’t begrudge them their brilliant writing — I’m grateful for their brilliant writing — but I deeply envy their box turtle neighbors, whose frequent appearances are such a source of delight. A turtle named Frank is featured right on the cover of “Bomb Shelter,” Mary Laura’s most recent book. Frank may be the most famous wild turtle in America.

headline: A Global Warming Book for the Streaming Age
abstract: In “The Parrot and the Igloo,” the novelist and journalist David Lipsky spins top-flight climate literature into cliffhanger entertainment.
lead_paragraph: In the preface to “The Parrot and the Igloo,” the journalist David Lipsky’s new book on global warming, he admits he thought about opening it with a threatening line: “This story put a hole through my life. Now it’s your turn.” You can see why. Reading it is like watching a car crash in slow motion. You know where this is headed.

headline: Timothy Olyphant Is Back for a New Chapter of ‘Justified’
abstract: If he seems relaxed about reprising the role that transformed his career, that’s just an expression of the cool demeanor that helped get him here.
lead_paragraph: “I like to think there’s been some growth.”

headline: The Next Battle Over Colorblindness Has Begun
abstract: All race-conscious policymaking is at risk.
lead_paragraph: Last month the Supreme Court sharply curtailed the use of race-based affirmative action in higher education. That’s a big deal, but it’s by no means the end of the campaign to eliminate race-conscious policies in education and elsewhere. Indeed, it’s just the beginning.

headline: Let Them Swim
abstract: Munich has done its residents a great service by purifying the Isar River.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — The mesmerizing scene along the banks of Munich’s lime-green Isar River on a recent summer afternoon made me, an out-of-towner, quiver with envy. Clusters of students, off-duty office workers, families and nude sunbathers were sprawled out on blankets with bottled beer and light meals. Every so often, a swimmer or tuber passed by, carried by the swift current.

headline: Travel Confessions: Tell Us About the Time You Crossed the Line
abstract: Maybe you didn’t deface a monument or endanger anyone, but have you ever committed a travel foul, accidental or otherwise? Share your story with us.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a video went viral showing a man etching his name (and that of his girlfriend) into the wall of the Colosseum in Rome. We’ve all seen them: bad travelers. The internet is cyclically gripped by stories like these.In recent years, New Zealand was captivated by the unruly antics of a British family who reportedly stole a Christmas tree from a gas station, among other mischief, on their vacation. A couple of Czech influencers got in hot water after making a crude joke involving a sacred fountain at a temple in Bali. And an airline passenger in South Korea opened the plane’s emergency door minutes before landing, hoping for a speedy exit.

headline: An Expensive, Rustic Brand Faces Backlash for Its ‘Poverty’ Aesthetic
abstract: Celebrities appreciate the antique look of Magnolia Pearl, a brand that takes inspiration from Victoriana, carnivals and “hobos,” and has recently drawn ire on social media.
lead_paragraph: Robin Brown sat on the patio of her home in Fredericksburg, Texas, in a dark pink bucket hat decorated with roses and birds, which covered most of her long platinum hair. Over video chat, the 59-year-old designer behind the fashion brand Magnolia Pearl was describing her aesthetic: butterflies, religious iconography, inspirational quotes, roses and lace.

headline: A Tangled Past Complicates Poland’s Welcome to Ukrainian Refugees
abstract: Polish memories of ethnic pogroms by Ukrainian nationalists in the 1940s jostle with the trauma left by Russia and its war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: In a rural village with fewer than 500 residents, strangers stand out. Even Anna Osinska, a 93-year-old villager with failing eyesight, noticed when people she did not recognize — refugees from the war in Ukraine — started appearing on the narrow street outside her kitchen window.

headline: It’s Never Been a Better Time for Vegan Ice Cream
abstract: As the bases for nondairy versions have improved, so have the offerings at plant-based dessert shops around the country.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, as dairy-free ice cream gained a foothold in the commercial market, its flavors were limited, its texture was often watery and its taste could be questionable.

headline: Future of Wagner Leader’s Business Empire Is Cloudy After Rebellion
abstract: Over decades, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin amassed considerable clout in Russia and built businesses in at least 15 countries. His whereabouts and the future of his extensive portfolio are now uncertain.
lead_paragraph: A chocolate museum in St. Petersburg. A gold mine in the Central African Republic. Oil and gas ventures off the Syrian coast.

headline: The Renaissance Is Having a Renaissance
abstract: In revisiting early modern European history, artists and designers are finding old ways to address contemporary anxieties.
lead_paragraph: The Algerian Brazilian director Karim Aïnouz’s new film, “Firebrand,” which debuted at Cannes in May, takes place at a vast country estate where members of the British elite have retreated to avoid a rapidly spreading plague. Inequality has reached new heights, the role of religion in public life is a matter of urgent debate, political factionalism is tearing society apart and Europe is destabilized by war. The year: 1546. Based on the English writer Elizabeth Fremantle’s 2012 novel, “Queen’s Gambit,” the film depicts the last months of Henry VIII’s reign from the vantage of his sixth and final wife, Katherine Parr, portrayed by Alicia Vikander. Playing fast and loose with the historical record, it’s an allegory for our own era in the guise of a period drama.

headline: Why China’s Young People Are Not Getting Married
abstract: Marriages in China are at a record low. Recent political and economic turmoil have added another reason to postpone tying the knot.
lead_paragraph: It has been a brutal three years for China’s young adults. Their unemployment rate is soaring amid a wave of corporate layoffs. Draconian coronavirus restrictions are over, but not the sense of uncertainty about the future they created.

headline: An Art-Filled Swiss Idyll in Lausanne and the Joux Valley
abstract: Breathtaking modern architecture, museums dedicated to watch-making, and bucolic views from a train window await visitors willing to venture beyond Switzerland’s major cities.
lead_paragraph: One morning in late August, I headed north from Lausanne, the Swiss lakeside city about 40 miles east of Geneva, on a nearly empty local train. Within minutes, buildings fell away and the train pushed through a green, working country of farm fields and tractors. The train stopped at a dozen villages that aren’t on the usual tourist map: Arnex, Le Day, Les Charbonnières. Lakes appeared, and forest. This was another Switzerland, beyond worldly Geneva, Zürich and Basel, where awe softened to something on a more human scale.

headline: How a Distant War Is Threatening Livelihoods in the Arctic Circle
abstract: The fighting in Ukraine has disrupted a region in northern Norway that had thrived on cross-border trade and cooperation with Russia.
lead_paragraph: In this corner of Norway’s far north, just five miles from the border with Russia, road signs give directions in Norwegian and Russian. Locals are used to crossing from one country to the other visa-free: Norwegians to fill up on cheap Russian gasoline; Russians to hit the Norwegian malls.

headline: It’s Too Hot to Cook. Make These Cool Summer Recipes Instead.
abstract: Here are 24 no-cook recipes for when it’s too sweltering outside to sear, roast, sauté, boil or even think of turning on the stove.
lead_paragraph: It’s inevitable. At some point this summer, it’s going to be too hot, too humid, too overwhelming to cook.

headline: Flooding Closes Roads and Threatens Towns Through Much of Vermont
abstract: At least one person died as rain inundated New York’s Hudson Valley and the surrounding areas. In Vermont, rivers were expected to crest on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rainfall and widespread flooding wreaked havoc in the river valleys and mountain towns of Vermont and New York State on Monday, ravaging communities and drawing comparisons to the devastation of Tropical Storm Irene more than a decade ago.

headline: Turkey Clears the Way for Sweden’s Entry to NATO on the Eve of Summit
abstract: The announcement allows the military alliance to project unity, which is getting harder to sustain as the war in Ukraine goes on.
lead_paragraph: Turkey agreed on Monday to clear the way for Sweden to join NATO, a sudden reversal that allows the alliance to project an image of unity and expansion on the eve of a critical summit intended to prepare for what could be a long war to repel Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Biden meets with Sunak, with the war on the agenda.
abstract: The two men met briefly in London on the eve of a summit of NATO leaders in Lithuania.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Biden met with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain on Monday, making a brief stop in London on the eve of a NATO summit where leaders are expected to focus on supporting Ukraine against the Russian invasion.

headline: At Wimbledon, the Human Eye Keeps Dropping the Ball
abstract: Line judges made incorrect calls in the first week that changed the trajectory of matches for Andy Murray, Bianca Andreescu and Venus Williams, among others. Is it time to give computers the job?
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray was a victim.

headline: Today’s Top News: Biden on Ukraine’s NATO Bid, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Rutte’s Exit Leaves a Void in Dutch and E.U. Politics
abstract: The prime minister, who announced he would leave politics in the Netherlands, gave his small country an outsize influence in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Mark Rutte, the long-serving Dutch prime minister who on Monday said he would leave politics after his coalition government collapsed, curated an image of an ordinary guy.

headline: Will Threads Kill Twitter?
abstract: The rival platform from Meta has become the most rapidly downloaded app ever.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, released Threads, a social media platform to compete with Twitter. In just 16 hours, Threads was downloaded more than 30 million times.

headline: Quiet fears hang over Russia’s newest border with a NATO nation.
abstract: On a recent afternoon, an attack from Russian military bases a few miles from here seemed a distant prospect.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, an attack from Russian military bases a few miles from here seemed a distant prospect.

headline: Ukraine’s Struggles
abstract: The much-anticipated counteroffensive is off to a slow start.
lead_paragraph: The recent mutiny in Russia has distracted attention from a more positive development for President Vladimir Putin: Ukraine’s much-anticipated summer counteroffensive hasn’t made much progress so far.

headline: State Senator Roland Gutierrez Seeks to Unseat Ted Cruz, Widening Democratic Field
abstract: The state senator, who represents Uvalde, Texas, vowed to make his passionate appeals for gun control a centerpiece of his campaign.
lead_paragraph: Roland Gutierrez, a Democratic state senator who has been an outspoken gun-control proponent since last year’s massacre in Uvalde, Texas, announced on Monday that he would seek Senator Ted Cruz’s seat next year.

headline: A PGA Tour Director’s Exit Casts a Pall Over Deal With LIV Golf
abstract: In resigning from the body’s board, Randall Stephenson said he could not support the group’s potential tie-up with its Saudi-backed rival.
lead_paragraph: Just days before Tuesday’s PGA Tour hearing before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, a prominent tour board member, Randall Stephenson, has resigned. His reason? He said he cannot support the golf organization’s proposed tie-up involving LIV Golf, its Saudi -backed rival, DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch and The Times’s Alan Blinder report.

headline: Israeli Government Presses Ahead With Judicial Overhaul
abstract: In a first reading of a bill that would limit the Supreme Court’s ability to strike down decisions by elected officials, lawmakers voted to pass the provision early Tuesday. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: After a three-month hiatus, Israel’s far-right governing coalition moved forward early Tuesday with part of its deeply contentious plan to limit judicial powers, a gambit that critics say will undermine Israel’s democracy and that has deepened rifts within the society.

headline: Turkey Agrees to Support Sweden’s NATO Bid, Clearing Main Obstacle
abstract: The move came after the Turkish president’s surprising new demand that the European Union should move forward with his country’s bid to join the bloc, one day before a high-profile summit.
lead_paragraph: Turkey agreed on Monday to clear the way for Sweden to join NATO, a sudden reversal just hours after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said that the European Union should first advance his country’s bid to join the E.U. bloc.

headline: Artifacts Stolen From Kenya Decades Ago Are Returned
abstract: Even after museums decide to return stolen artifacts to their countries of origin, tariffs and red tape can prolong the process.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the 1980s, vigango, sacred wooden memorial statues, were stolen from Kenya, sold to art dealers and eventually arrived at tourist shops and museums.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of July 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: Hill Harper, ‘Good Doctor’ Actor, Enters Senate Race in Michigan
abstract: Mr. Harper is challenging Representative Elissa Slotkin from the left and will have an uphill climb in a heated Democratic primary race in a 2024 presidential swing state.
lead_paragraph: Hill Harper, an author and actor, on Monday entered Michigan’s 2024 Senate race, pledging to run to the left of Representative Elissa Slotkin, a moderate Democrat, in what is expected to be one of the most closely watched Democratic primary races in a 2024 presidential battleground state.

headline: California to Provide $20 Million to Flooded Central Valley Farm Town
abstract: The undocumented status of many residents of Planada, east of Merced, meant they were ineligible for federal aid after winter storms ravaged their town.
lead_paragraph: When an “atmospheric river” dumped torrents of rain over the Central Valley in January, the small rural town of Planada was devastated.

headline: Deadly Monsoon Flooding and Landslides Lash India
abstract: At least 49 people have died since the weekend amid unusually heavy downpours that have pummeled the northern part of the country and caused widespread damage.
lead_paragraph: A weekend of heavy rains and flooding has left destruction across large swaths of northern India, killing at least 49 people and causing landslides and flash floods that washed away bridges and buildings, officials said.

headline: U.S. and E.U. Complete Long-Awaited Deal on Sharing Data
abstract: The agreement ends legal uncertainty for Meta, Google and scores of companies — at least for now.
lead_paragraph: A deal to ensure that data from Meta, Google and scores of other companies can continue flowing between the United States and the European Union was completed on Monday, after the digital transfer of personal information between the two jurisdictions had been thrown into doubt because of privacy concerns.

headline: The New York Times to Disband Its Sports Department
abstract: Coverage of games, players and leagues will now come primarily from The Athletic, the sports website that the company bought last year.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times said on Monday that it would disband its sports department and rely on coverage of teams and games from its website The Athletic, both online and in print.

headline: Pimento Cheese Recipe
‘Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny’ Review: Turning Back the Clock
The ‘Ethic of Life’ in the Political Arena
abstract: Responses to an essay by Tish Harrison Warren. Also: Tom Brady and the crypto crash; Bill de Blasio and Chirlane McCray’s breakup; artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Our ‘Best Gazpacho’ Is a Five-Star Reader Favorite to Sip All Summer
abstract: “I could live on it, and might,” writes one reader. “This is my third weekend making a double batch,” notes another.
lead_paragraph: Hello all, Julia Moskin here again. My friend and yours, Melissa Clark, will be back on Wednesday.

headline: Summer Heat Waves Killed 61,000 in Europe Last Year, Study Says
abstract: Researchers suggest that strategies to cope with higher temperatures aren’t keeping pace with global warming.
lead_paragraph: More than 61,000 people died because of last year’s brutal summer heat waves across Europe, according to a study published on Monday in the journal Nature Medicine.

headline: Were You at a Wedding During the 2003 Blackout? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: A massive blackout in New York City interrupted many celebrations 20 years ago. We want to hear from couples and guests who were at a wedding during the power outage.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 14, 2003, New York City went powerless in a massive blackout. Some people were stranded on trains, some got stuck in elevators, and others were … getting married.

headline: Nassar Is Said to Have Been Stabbed Multiple Times in Florida Prison
abstract: Lawrence G. Nassar, 59, is in stable condition after he was attacked by another inmate at a federal prison in Central Florida.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence G. Nassar, the doctor convicted of sexually abusing young female gymnasts, was stabbed multiple times in the chest, back and neck on Sunday at the federal prison in Florida where he is serving a 60-year sentence, according to three people with knowledge of the situation.

headline: Spain Rescues Migrants After Search for Missing Boat
abstract: The country’s maritime rescue authority said it had rescued a migrant boat with 86 people aboard in the Atlantic, after an aid group raised concerns about vessels that had departed from Senegal.
lead_paragraph: Spain rescued more than 80 people aboard a boat in the Atlantic on Monday, after an aid group reported several vessels, carrying migrants from Senegal and bound for the Canary Islands, had not been heard from in about two weeks.

headline: Can You Find the Hidden Titles of a Dozen 19th-Century Novels?
abstract: After you find the titles concealed in this fictional passage, you get a reading list with links to free e-book copies of the novels.
lead_paragraph: After you find the titles concealed in this fictional passage, you get a reading list with links to free e-book copies of the novels.

headline: With Art Colleges Closing, a Chicago Museum Has an Alternative
abstract: The cost of studying fine art is another fact that inspired a short-term intensive program led by artists of color that is an apprenticeship of sorts.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago and the educator Romi Crawford have become partners in a new program that focuses on pairing instruction by artists of color with hands-on learning by students working alongside them. This intensive, semester-long course, which its founders announced on Monday, is called the New Art School Modality and will start in September at the museum.

headline: As Strike Continues, Writers Turn Focus to Ryan Murphy’s Productions
abstract: Even as other movie and television projects have paused their work during the weekslong stoppage, “American Horror Story” has continued.
lead_paragraph: As the Hollywood writers’ strike has pressed on for the past 10 weeks, the vast majority of movie and television productions from New York to Los Angeles have gone on pause. Some have been all but forced to suspend work because of union picketing and crew members’ refusal to cross the picket lines. In other instances, showrunners have decided to stop their work out of solidarity.

headline: Review: Ted Hearne’s Sweet, Sad American Elegy
abstract: “Farming,” a choral work that had its New York premiere at Caramoor, is a chaotically ambitious reflection on colonization, consumption and marketing.
lead_paragraph: Google search results broke my heart this weekend.

headline: Behind ‘Oppenheimer,’ a Prizewinning Biography 25 Years in the Making
abstract: Martin Sherwin struck the deal and dived into the research. But it was only when Kai Bird joined as a collaborator that “American Prometheus” came to be.
lead_paragraph: Martin Sherwin was hardly your classic blocked writer. Outgoing, funny, and athletic, he is described by those who knew him as the opposite of neurotic.

headline: Deadly New York Floods Are ‘Like Something Out of a Horror Movie’
abstract: The flash floods killed one woman in New York, who was swept away by rising waters while she tried to save herself and her dog, and caused tens of millions of dollars in damage.
lead_paragraph: Residents began digging — and drying — out from a spasm of severe flash flooding in New York’s Hudson Valley on Monday, as officials estimated that the damage would likely run into the tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Trial Guide: The Jemaah Islamiyah Case at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: Three prisoners are accused of terrorism, murder and conspiracy in bombings in Indonesia 20 years ago that killed more than 200 people.
lead_paragraph: Three prisoners at Guantánamo Bay are accused of terrorism, murder and conspiracy in bombings in Indonesia 20 years ago as members of Jemaah Islamiyah, an extremist group founded in the 1980s with the goal of establishing an Islamic state in Southeast Asia.

headline: The Fed’s Vice Chair for Supervision Suggests Big-Bank Regulation Changes
abstract: In a series of changes that has bank lobbyists on the defensive, Michael Barr is calling for higher bank capital and tougher annual stress tests.
lead_paragraph: Michael S. Barr, the Federal Reserve’s vice chair for supervision, announced on Monday that he would be pushing for significant changes to how America’s largest banks were overseen in a bid to make them more resilient in times of trouble — partly by ratcheting up how much capital they have to get them through a rough patch.

headline: Madonna Officially Postpones Celebration Tour
abstract: The pop superstar’s global outing spotlighting her decades of hits will begin in October in Europe. “My focus now is my health,” she wrote on social media.
lead_paragraph: Madonna’s North American tour is officially postponed.

headline: Officials say the flooding is the worst since Hurricane Irene.
abstract: In 2011, Irene killed at least 40 people in 11 states and caused more than $6.5 billion in damage. Some officials fear the current rains  could surpass Irene’s.
lead_paragraph: The flash floods across New England, New York and Quebec on Monday evoked frequent comparisons to Hurricane Irene, which inundated the region in 2011 after making landfall and being downgraded to a tropical storm. Irene killed at least 40 people in 11 states and caused more than $6.5 billion in damage.

headline: Rain Floods New York’s Hudson Valley
abstract: Torrential rainfall in New York’s Hudson Valley flooded roads and residential areas with as much as eight inches of water in some areas.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rainfall in New York’s Hudson Valley flooded roads and residential areas with as much as eight inches of water in some areas.

headline: Downpours Cause Dangerous Flooding in Vermont
abstract: Rain washed out roads and swept through residential areas in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: Rain washed out roads and swept through residential areas in Vermont.

headline: Review: In ‘Malvolio,’ Hope (and a Title Role) for a Damaged Heart
abstract: The Classical Theater of Harlem follows up last year’s winning “Twelfth Night” with a sequel that feels like a sweet summer frolic.
lead_paragraph: Poor old Malvolio. Amid the comic romance of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night,” he is the imperious steward who gets cruelly pranked for sport, duped by a band of smart alecks who forge a love letter seemingly addressed to him.

headline: Prosecutor Rebuts I.R.S. Official’s Account of Request in Hunter Biden Case
abstract: David Weiss, the U.S. attorney in Delaware, said he never asked to be named a special counsel, disputing testimony to a House panel.
lead_paragraph: David C. Weiss, the federal prosecutor in Delaware who has led the criminal investigation of Hunter Biden, on Monday rebutted a key element of testimony to Congress by an Internal Revenue Service official who said that Mr. Weiss complained about being blocked from pursuing the case the way he wanted.

headline: The ‘Representative Agent’ Is Always Rational. The Rest of Us Are Not.
abstract: A new model called HANK recognizes that one person can’t possibly represent all.
lead_paragraph: Economists have an imaginary person they call a “representative agent,” who is about as realistic as the Easter bunny or the Abominable Snowman. The representative agent is supposed to stand in for all of us in a model of how the economy works: 335 million Americans, for example, boiled down to one. As originally conceived, the representative agent is fully rational and unemotional, forward-looking and with perfect information about all the relevant facts. Just like nobody you know.

headline: Silence Is a ‘Sound’ You Hear, Study Suggests
abstract: In auditory illusion tests, people perceive silence as a form of sound, just as Simon and Garfunkel suggested.
lead_paragraph: The hush at the end of the musical performance. The pause in a dramatic speech. The muted moment when you turn off the car. What is it that we hear when we hear nothing at all? Are we detecting silence? Or are we just hearing nothing and interpreting that absence as silence?

headline: The Waves, a New Retail Site, Specializes in Natural Wine
abstract: Small-batch olives and peppers from Greece and Turkey, an Eataly spotlight for pistachio ice cream, urgent reporting on farmed salmon, and more food news.
lead_paragraph: I knew and was impressed with the wines of Pearl Morissette on the Niagara Peninsula in Canada when I visited in 2015, but I was not familiar with the Ars Amandi orange pet-nat from Tenuta Santa Lucia in Emilia-Romagna, in northern Italy. I ordered both as I prowled The Waves, a new platform for buying natural wines. All its featured offerings, selected by Rajat Parr, a sommelier and winemaker, and Billy Smith, a sommelier who worked at the Four Horsemen in Brooklyn, must be made from organic grapes, without synthetic additives, and fermented with native yeasts. Off-the-grid choices like mine or less esoteric bottles of Beaujolais-Villages are sold. The website offers a tempting shopping experience, with regular additions, for those ready to shed stereotypes in the glass. Most bottles are less than $40. And, if you prefer, you can leave your choices to the experts.

headline: BBC Suspension of Staff Member Fuels Speculation, Despite Few Facts
abstract: The suspension followed a report that a person had paid for sexually explicit images from a teenager. On Monday, the BBC said, a lawyer for the teenager said the allegations were “rubbish.”
lead_paragraph: For three days, the BBC has been caught up in a feverish mystery over allegations that a prominent personality for the British broadcaster paid tens of thousands of pounds to a teenager for sexually explicit photos.

headline: Lil Uzi Vert and Olivia Rodrigo Oust Morgan Wallen From No. 1
abstract: After weeks of dominance on Billboard’s album and singles charts, the country superstar was bested by the rapper’s LP “Pink Tape” and the singer-songwriter’s track “Vampire.”
lead_paragraph: Olivia Rodrigo and the rapper Lil Uzi Vert have shaken up the Billboard charts after weeks of dominance by the country superstar Morgan Wallen, with Rodrigo taking the top single and Lil Uzi Vert the top album.

headline: Climate Disasters Daily? Welcome to the ‘New Normal.’
abstract: Around the United States, dangerous floods, heat and storms are happening more frequently.
lead_paragraph: Catastrophic floods in the Hudson Valley. An unrelenting heat dome over Phoenix. Ocean temperatures hitting 90 degrees Fahrenheit off the coast of Miami. A surprising deluge in Vermont, a rare tornado in Delaware.

headline: How to Make the Best Piña Colada
On Beyoncé’s Renaissance Tour, the World Is Her Ball
Why More Men are Wearing Crop Tops
James W. Lewis, Suspect in the 1982 Tylenol Murders, Dies at 76
abstract: He was never charged with the deaths of seven people from cyanide-laced Tylenol, but he was convicted of extortion after he sent a letter to Johnson & Johnson demanding $1 million to “stop the killing.”
lead_paragraph: James W. Lewis, the prime suspect in the deaths of seven people in 1982 from cyanide-laced Tylenol — a poisoning that terrified the nation and changed the way manufacturers packaged medications — died on Sunday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 76.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Turkey backs Sweden’s NATO bid
abstract: Plus, floods and landslides batter northern India.
lead_paragraph: In a sudden reversal, Turkey agreed yesterday to clear the way for Sweden to join NATO. NATO’s secretary general announced the decision in Vilnius, Lithuania, where the alliance was preparing to open its annual summit today. Hours earlier, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had said that the E.U. should first advance Turkey’s bid to join the European bloc before Sweden could join the alliance.

headline: The Twitter Watch Party Is Over
abstract: Ten years after “Sharknado” spun Twitter and TV together, the online water cooler is running dry.
lead_paragraph: On July 11, 2013, a superstorm made landfall on the internet. “Sharknado,” the meteorologically and ichthyologically dubious disaster movie, premiered on Syfy, and Twitter lost its collective mind.

headline: Amazon Union Dissidents, in Challenge to Leader, Move to Force Vote
abstract: A split over the stewardship of the union’s high-profile president, Christian Smalls, has led a rival faction to file a lawsuit seeking an election.
lead_paragraph: A dissident group within the Amazon Labor Union, the only certified union in the country representing Amazon employees, filed a complaint in federal court Monday seeking to force the union to hold a leadership election.

headline: Where Mortals Become Fashion Gods
abstract: At the couture shows in Paris, the street style can rival the fashion on the runway.
lead_paragraph: For a brief moment, after Celine canceled its men’s wear show in Paris because of the recent unrest in France, there were concerns about whether last week’s couture shows would go as planned. But by the time guests started to arrive at Alaïa, one of the first events of couture week, dutifully carrying the custom chairs that the brand had sent them to sit on, it had become clear: The shows would go on.

headline: Floods and Heat Sweep the United States
abstract: Also, Turkey clears the way for Sweden to join NATO. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rainfall caused widespread flooding today in the river valleys and mountain towns of New York State and western New England. One woman died, and dozens more were rescued from rising waters. The Northeast is forecast to receive several more days of rain, especially in Vermont, where officials warned of “life-threatening flash flooding” throughout the day. Follow our live updates.

headline: Is A.I. the Greatest Technology Ever for Making Dumb Jokes?
abstract: It may or may not alter the course of humanity, but at least the memes are fun.
lead_paragraph: It may or may not alter the course of humanity, but at least the memes are fun.

headline: More Heat, and Little Respite, Is Expected in the Southwest
abstract: Forecasters predict that the heat wave could be “one of the longest,” with monsoons running late and nights that stay warm.
lead_paragraph: The soaring temperatures baking much of the desert Southwest this week are not only strikingly high but also unusually persistent.

headline: Judge Should Consider Contempt of Court Action Over Rikers, Monitor Says
abstract: A contempt finding could force the Correction commissioner, Louis A. Molina, to implement new policies to improve conditions in the jails.
lead_paragraph: A federal monitor overseeing New York City’s violent and dangerous jails asked a judge on Monday to consider holding the Department of Correction and its commissioner in contempt for disobeying court orders, opening the possibility that officials could be punished for failing to improve conditions.

headline: When the Water Rushed In, Help Rushed Over
abstract: It was as if a river had suddenly been diverted into an apartment complex in Highland Falls, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Three friends and a 5-year-old girl had just finished rolling up an old rug and unrolling a new one on Sunday afternoon when the storm outside changed from heavy rain to something different.

headline: Other Sports Faced Congress’s Glare. Now Golf Will Get Its Turn.
abstract: A Senate hearing on Tuesday is just one part of Washington’s scrutiny of the PGA Tour’s deal with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund.
lead_paragraph: Sports executives and players have sometimes defended themselves or patiently absorbed hours of fury. They have occasionally apologized or pleaded for help. They have shifted blame or used celebrity and childhood memory as a charm offensive. In other instances, they have lied or obfuscated or simply said little at all.

headline: Nikki Haley Raises $7.3 Million, With More in an Allied Super PAC
abstract: The amount showed Ms. Haley’s strength with small donors, but fell well below numbers broadcast by her leading Republican presidential rivals, Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor and United Nations ambassador, raised $7.3 million through her presidential campaign and affiliated committees from April through June, a modest sum that still showcased her robust appeal to small donors.

headline: Who Employs Your Doctor? Increasingly, a Private Equity Firm.
abstract: A new study finds that private equity firms own more than half of all specialists in certain U.S. markets.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, private equity firms have been gobbling up physician practices to form powerful medical groups across the country, according to a new report released Monday.

headline: Iceland Monitors New Volcanic Eruption
abstract: Larger eruptions have disrupted European air travel, but officials said this small one, in an uninhabited area that until recently had been dormant for centuries, posed no immediate risks.
lead_paragraph: A minor volcanic eruption began on Monday afternoon in an uninhabited area on Iceland’s Reykjanes Peninsula, the country’s weather officials said.

headline: Sarah Silverman Sues OpenAI and Meta Over Copyright Infringement
abstract: The comedian has joined two lawsuits accusing the companies of training their A.I. models using her writing without permission.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Sarah Silverman has joined a class-action lawsuit against OpenAI and another against Meta accusing the companies of copyright infringement, saying they “copied and ingested” her protected work in order to train their artificial intelligence programs, according to court papers.

headline: No, ‘Socialism’ Isn’t Making Americans Lazy
abstract: All we needed was policy that gave work a chance.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Marcus, a co-founder of Home Depot, had some negative things to say about his fellow Americans in an interview last December. “Socialism,” he opined, has destroyed the work ethic: “Nobody works. Nobody gives a damn. ‘Just give it to me. Send me money. I don’t want to work — I’m too lazy, I’m too fat, I’m too stupid.’”

headline: Putin Met With Mercenary Leaders He Had Called Traitors During Mutiny
abstract: The Kremlin’s disclosure of the meeting with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin and other Wagner group commanders hinted at the power they wield, but left many questions unanswered.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia held a lengthy meeting with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin and commanders of his Wagner private military company just days after they had launched a mutiny that put the nation on the brink of a civil conflict, the Kremlin disclosed on Monday.

headline: Ex-Priest Sentenced to 25 Years in Prison for Preying on Men in New Orleans
abstract: Stephen Sauer, a 61-year-old former Catholic priest, pleaded guilty to drugging and sexually assaulting over a dozen men.
lead_paragraph: A former Catholic priest in Louisiana who preyed on 17 men who were intoxicated or needed help, drugging and photographing them — and sexually assaulting at least a dozen of them — was sentenced on Friday to 25 years in prison.

headline: Benno Schmidt Jr., a Reforming Leader at Yale and CUNY, Dies at 81
abstract: A noted constitutional law scholar, he also led Columbia University Law School and two networks of for-profit private schools.
lead_paragraph: Benno C. Schmidt Jr., a constitutional law scholar who became one of the country’s leading education executives, bringing difficult but necessary reforms to Yale and the City University of New York, died on Sunday at his home in Millbrook, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley. He was 81.

headline: Biden Bets High-Level Diplomacy Can Cool Fiery Relations With China
abstract: President Biden hopes the diplomatic trips this summer by his aides lead to frank talks with Xi Jinping and other Chinese officials before the 2024 U.S. elections.
lead_paragraph: After three years of self-isolation by China, President Biden’s top aides are flying into Beijing throughout the summer to try to convince and cajole Chinese officials, including Xi Jinping, the nation’s leader, on building a new foundation for relations.

headline: At the All-Star Game, Learning Opportunities Abound
abstract: The days of being overly competitive are over, as stars from across Major League Baseball gather for a fun weekend and share the tips and tricks that make them great.
lead_paragraph: The All-Star Game is baseball’s ultimate learning lab: the best of the best, teammates for a moment, swapping stories and secrets. The days of Bob Gibson snarling through the festivities, impervious to camaraderie with enemies turned teammates, are gone.

headline: Philadelphia Police Officials Detail Botched Response to a Fatal Shooting
abstract: Officers were sent to the wrong address, delaying discovery of the victim who investigators believe was the first of five people killed by the gunman.
lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of July 2, the 1600 block of South 56th Street in southwest Philadelphia exploded with the sound of gunfire. It was so loud that Zahirah Muhammad threw herself under her bed. “I didn’t know if it was coming from the back street behind me or in front of me,” she recalled in an interview.

headline: Man in California Pleads Guilty to Murder in Fentanyl Death of 15-Year-Old
abstract: The conviction of a 21-year-old drug dealer in a fatal fentanyl overdose is believed to be the first of its kind in the state.
lead_paragraph: A local prosecutor in California has secured what he says is the state’s first murder conviction in connection with a fatal fentanyl overdose, marking a legal milestone in the efforts to curb sales of the increasingly deadly drug.

headline: In Southern California, Hilltop Homes Sink Into a Canyon
abstract: A landslide destroyed a dozen homes and forced residents to flee a wealthy city on the Palos Verdes Peninsula. The effects of torrential winter storms may be to blame.
lead_paragraph: A dozen hilltop homes in one of the most affluent areas of coastal Los Angeles County were collapsing into a canyon on Monday after a landslide over the weekend forced the evacuation of a neighborhood in the community of Rolling Hills Estates.

headline: New Map Shows Titan Submersible Debris’s Proximity to Titanic Wreck
abstract: The map, released in a legal filing by a company with salvage rights to the famous ship, aided the hunt for the missing craft.
lead_paragraph: The company that possesses the exclusive salvage rights to the Titanic shipwreck and the ship’s artifacts filed in federal court on Saturday a map of the surrounding seabed that shows where searchers found the twisted remains of the Titan submersible.

headline: Desperate to Debate: Why a G.O.P. Candidate Is Offering $20 for $1 Donations
abstract: The candidate, Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota, is one of several Republican presidential candidates going to great lengths to reach a crucial threshold to qualify for the first primary debate.
lead_paragraph: How much is a dollar worth?

headline: Northwestern Fires Pat Fitzgerald, Football Coach, Amid Hazing Allegations
abstract: An investigation found that players had participated in widespread hazing for years, fostering a punishing culture.
lead_paragraph: Northwestern University on Monday fired Pat Fitzgerald, its longtime head football coach, after an investigation found that his players had participated in widespread hazing, including forced nudity and sexualized acts.

headline: Mental Cloud
abstract: Aaron M. Rosenberg takes inventory.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: Bob Huggins Claims He Never Resigned From West Virginia
abstract: Huggins, the Hall of Fame coach, said he had not signed a statement announcing his retirement after being charged with driving under the influence and that he was awaiting reinstatement.
lead_paragraph: Bob Huggins asserted on Monday that he had never resigned as the West Virginia men’s basketball coach after being arrested and charged with driving under the influence last month, contrary to a statement released by the university, and that he expected to be reinstated after completing a voluntary rehabilitation program.

headline: Corrections: July 11, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the difference in how baseless claims of voter fraud by former presidents were handled in the United States versus Brazil misstated the amount of time between the 2020 U.S. presidential election and the declaration of its winner. It was a few days, not a week.

headline: Quotation of the Day: 17 Years After Suburb of Paris Burned, Rage Engulfs Streets Again
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 11, 2023
lead_paragraph: “We had to make ourselves heard! How can someone be killed for refusing a traffic stop? Are we in America or what?”

headline: U.S. Students’ Progress Stagnated Last School Year, Study Finds
abstract: Despite billions in federal aid, students are not making up ground in reading and math: “We are actually seeing evidence of backsliding.”
lead_paragraph: Despite billions of federal dollars spent to help make up for pandemic-related learning loss, progress in reading and math stalled over the past school year for elementary and middle-school students, according to a new national study released on Tuesday.

headline: Jessica Pegula Draws Inspiration From Her Mother’s Healing. It’s Mutual.
abstract: For more than a year, Kim Pegula has been recovering from cardiac arrest. Her daughter Jessica’s climb in the tennis rankings reflects the strength the two find in each other.
lead_paragraph: It was already Tuesday in Sydney, Australia, but Jessica Pegula was watching “Monday Night Football” on her phone on Jan. 3 as she waited to go onto the court at the United Cup. Suddenly, she felt the same sickening fear many football fans had that day, but perhaps with more resonance.

headline: A Survivor in New York, Cycling With Other Wounded Warriors
abstract: Danielle Green, who lost much of her left arm in Iraq, will participate in the “Soldier Ride” to Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll introduce you to a hero. You may see her riding the streets of New York later this week.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A breakthrough on Sweden’s accession to NATO.
lead_paragraph: The night before a critical summit, in a sudden reversal, Turkey agreed to accept Sweden’s application for membership of NATO. The shift came just hours after Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, said the E.U. should first advance his country’s bid to join the bloc before he would clear the path for Sweden.

headline: NATO Isn’t What It Says It Is
abstract: From its origins, the alliance was never primarily concerned with military power.
lead_paragraph: NATO leaders convening this week in Vilnius, Lithuania, have every reason to toast their success.

headline: Word of the Day: spite
