abstract: This word has appeared in 245 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word spite has appeared in 245 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 10 in “Taylor Swift Fans Grapple With Breakup Reports” by Madison Malone Kircher:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Second Strike Is Threatening Hollywood
abstract: If actors go on strike when their deal with studios ends on Wednesday, it will be the first time they and the writers have been out at the same time since 1960.
lead_paragraph: The actors may soon be joining Hollywood screenwriters on the picket lines if their union, SAG-AFTRA, and the major studios fail to reach a deal by midnight on Wednesday. The two sides are haggling over the same issues that are front and center for the Writers Guild of America: higher wages, increased residual payments (a type of royalty) and significant guardrails around the use of artificial intelligence.

headline: A Reckoning in Real Estate
abstract: Debra Kamin interviewed real estate agents who have been sexually harassed while on the job and left with little recourse.
lead_paragraph: It was a series of posts shared to different real estate Facebook groups that startled Debra Kamin, a real estate reporter for The New York Times, earlier this year.

headline: What Haunts Child Abuse Victims? The Memory, Study Finds
abstract: A study of adults who were mistreated in childhood found that those who did not recall it showed fewer psychological aftereffects.
lead_paragraph: For generations, our society has vacillated about how best to heal people who experienced terrible things in childhood.

headline: A Tiny Fish That Fuels an Atlantic Ecosystem Now Fuels Industry Debates
abstract: A mainstay of the commercial fishing industry, menhaden are the primary food source for all sorts of fish and birds along the Eastern Seaboard.
lead_paragraph: Researchers hoped to find evidence of a healthy new generation of ospreys when they checked 84 nests of the fish-eating bird in mid-June at Mobjack Bay, an inlet at the southern end of the Chesapeake Bay. They found only three young.

headline: Tracing Mining’s Threat to U.S. Waters
abstract: Environmental concerns are raised anew about potential contamination from Canadian open-pit mines flowing through the waterways into Montana’s lakes, harming fish.
lead_paragraph: PABLO, Mont. — In the mountain streams of southern British Columbia and northern Montana, a rugged part of the world, fish with misshapen skulls and twisted spines have been caught over the years.

headline: North Korea Ramps Up Rhetoric Ahead of U.S. Nuclear Submarine Visit
abstract: The country warned that it would shoot down American spy planes, escalating verbal attacks on the U.S. as South Korea’s leader traveled to attend a NATO summit.
lead_paragraph: North Korea threatened military action against American spy planes operating off the country’s east coast, its state media reported on Tuesday, as a United States submarine capable of shooting nuclear ballistic missiles planned to visit South Korea for the first time in four decades.

headline: Flooding and Landslides Hit Japan
abstract: The deluge hit the island of Kyushu with what one official called the “heaviest rain ever experienced” in the region.
lead_paragraph: The deluge hit the island of Kyushu with what one official called the “heaviest rain ever experienced” in the region.

headline: Hardly Working
abstract: As background extras in video games, some nonplayer characters are programmed to do one thing forever: drudgery.
lead_paragraph: As background extras in video games, some nonplayer characters are programmed to do one thing forever: drudgery.

headline: All Work, No Play for These Video Game Characters
abstract: As background extras, some nonplayer characters are programmed to do one thing forever: drudgery.
lead_paragraph: In this short documentary, a laundress, a stablehand, a street sweeper and a carpenter are observed with ethnographic precision. They are nonplayer characters, or NPCs, in the blockbuster Wild West-themed video game Red Dead Redemption 2, and many of them are trapped in work.

headline: Why I Regret Debating Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
abstract: Opinion columnist Farhad Manjoo on why it’s a bad idea to debate conspiracy theorists.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: Utah G.O.P.’s Map Carved Up Salt Lake Democrats. Is It a Legal Matter?
abstract: The Utah Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday over whether a congressional map drawn to dilute Democratic votes was subject to judicial review, or a political issue beyond its reach.
lead_paragraph: Utah’s Supreme Court justices appeared skeptical on Tuesday of arguments put forward by the State Legislature that it had essentially unreviewable power to draw a map of the state’s congressional districts that diluted the votes of Democrats.

headline: My Unlikely Writing Teacher: Pedro Martinez
abstract: Looking to a maestro on the mound to improve your writing game.
lead_paragraph: Socked in during Covid lockdown, I became increasingly obsessed with archival footage of “actual human life,” so I scoured the internet for any videos I could find of Pedro Martinez, my favorite baseball player, in action. Watching him pitch was like gaining access to memories I’d forgotten or never quite had. Fortunately, the most illustrious game of his career — which took place on Sept. 10, 1999, when his team, the Boston Red Sox, played the Yankees, in New York, amid that year’s playoff race — is now widely available online. Contemporary viewers can see what I would argue is not merely a baseball game but a novel, an opera, a lyric masterpiece. Watching it feels a bit like witnessing Virginia Woolf write “Mrs. Dalloway,” in real time, right in front of you.

headline: Why Crack Became the 1980s ‘Superdrug’
abstract: In “When Crack Was King,” Donovan X. Ramsey offers a fresh history of the epidemic that gripped minority communities, inflamed media coverage and led to draconian drug laws.
lead_paragraph: Crack erupted across America’s marginalized urban neighborhoods in the 1980s like a biblical plague torn from the pages of Revelation. The drug offered an inexpensive, nirvana-like high, leaving users clamoring for ever larger doses in a hopeless yet insatiable quest to sustain the same levels of bliss. It was the perfect “superdrug,” and Black communities, redlined in concrete city blocks, were neglected as their wealthier white neighbors escaped crack’s worst embrace. Those left behind absorbed the brunt of an apocalyptic epidemic that redrew a generation with ruthless precision across racial and economic fault lines.

headline: Can Stress Cause Hair Loss?
abstract: If your hair is thinning during particularly tense times, experts have thoughts on what might be going on.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’ve been really stressed out at work lately and have noticed that my hair is thinning and clumping in the shower. Is it true that stress can make your hair fall out?

headline: Encountering the Infuriating, Overwhelming and Unwanted Smart Tech in My Hotel Room
abstract: Turns out that automatic mood lighting and motorized drapes do not make me a relaxed and happy traveler. And for the last time, I don’t want to download your app.
lead_paragraph: At my boutique hotel high in the Swiss Alps, I returned from dinner, jet lagged and a tad tipsy, to discover that a television set inside a bathroom mirror had been turned on during turndown service. I pressed all of the buttons on the wall panel and then tried the switches on a control box next to the bed. Nothing.

headline: Six Ways to Find a Little Elbow Room in Dubrovnik
abstract: Visitors can get through the stone gates of this medieval city and meander through its cobbled streets without logjams, even in the high season. They can also get far from fellow travelers with easy jaunts to nearby islands.
lead_paragraph: The Pile and Ploce Gates, the two entrances into Dubrovnik’s Old Town, once had drawbridges that lifted during the overnight hours, forcing visitors wanting to enter to wait outside its stone walls until morning. The bridges no longer lift, yet the bottlenecks of morning visitors remain.

headline: A.I. Could Solve Some of Humanity’s Hardest Problems. It Already Has.
abstract: Demis Hassabis, the chief executive of DeepMind, discusses how A.I. systems can accelerate scientific research.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the New York Times Audio app here.

headline: Some of the Worst Troll Armies Are Gaining Ground. Just Look at Cambodia.
abstract: How Prime Minister Hun Sen is leveraging his people’s dependence on Facebook to quash opposition as elections approach.
lead_paragraph: The Cambodian People’s Party created its Cyber War Room about a decade ago. The goal was to support Prime Minister Hun Sen’s regime through social media propagandizing. Led by the prime minister’s son Hun Manet, a troll army used Facebook and other digital platforms to attack his father’s opposition with disinformation and even, allegedly, wield death threats.

headline: Iowa Republicans Move to Sharply Limit Abortion
abstract: Gov. Kim Reynolds called the Legislature for a special session to consider sweeping new restrictions on abortion.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month after a deadlocked Iowa Supreme Court left a six-week abortion ban unenforceable, lawmakers returned to the State Capitol on Tuesday and passed a nearly identical set of restrictions on the procedure.

headline: The Inner Life of a Cat
abstract: A previously unknown manuscript by Alice and Martin Provensen explores the ultimately unknowable psyche of a favorite feline.
lead_paragraph: Alice and Martin Provensen were the American picture book’s Ginger and Fred: a supremely poised and stylish illustrator team who, in a collaboration that spanned nearly 40 years and more than 40 children’s books (19 of which they also wrote and edited), beguiled fans with their deadpan wit, far-flung curiosity and midcentury-modernist flair.

headline: The Supreme Court Case That Has Me Worried, for Survivors and for My State
abstract: I carry the name of my grandmother, a survivor of domestic abuse. The effects of domestic violence are not limited to a single generation, nor should our vigilance against it be.
lead_paragraph: When my mother turned 70, she had a unique birthday wish. Instead of a party or a cake, she told our family she needed our help to open a transitional home for survivors of domestic violence and their children.

headline: The Republican Governor of Utah Wants to Spare Kids From Their Phones
abstract: Utah is working to restrict teenage social media usage. Jane Coaston interviews Gov. Spencer Cox about why — and what’s the limit of government power.
lead_paragraph: How much should 14-year-olds be on their phones? The effects of phones and social media on teenagers — and adults — continue to be at the center of public health, tech, civil liberties and more.

headline: Sudanese City Becomes Center of ‘New Phase’ of War
abstract: Fierce fighting has erupted in the city of Omdurman, across the Nile from the capital, Khartoum, in a desperate battle to control supply routes.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Sudan heads into its fourth month, Omdurman — the city across the Nile River from the capital, Khartoum — has become the site of some of the most fierce fighting between the two forces battling for power: the army and its rival, the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces.

headline: When Trains Block a Road, Local Officials Have Few Options
abstract: The federal government has begun offering $3 billion for bridges and tunnels, but many local governments say they cannot take advantage of the money.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is spending billions of dollars on bridges, tunnels and other infrastructure to route traffic over, under and around railroads tracks. But to many residents and local officials, that is an imperfect way to alleviate congestion on roads that are frequently blocked by freight trains.

headline: Scientists Have Found a Hot Spot on the Moon’s Far Side
abstract: Data from two Chinese orbiters helped a team of scientists explain why a patch of lunar terrain is so much warmer than the surrounding area.
lead_paragraph: The rocks beneath an ancient volcano on the moon’s far side remain surprisingly warm, scientists have revealed using data from orbiting Chinese spacecraft.

headline: Underground Heat Is Shifting Chicago’s Foundations
abstract: Basements and train tunnels constantly leak heat, causing the land to sink and straining building foundations. Scientists call it “underground climate change.”
lead_paragraph: Underneath downtown Chicago’s soaring Art Deco towers, its multilevel roadways and its busy subway and rail lines, the land is sinking, and not only for the reasons you might expect.

headline: Greta Gerwig’s ‘Barbie’ Dream Job
abstract: Mattel wanted a summer blockbuster to kick off its new wave of brand-extension movies. She wanted it to be a work of art.
lead_paragraph: The moment Greta Gerwig knew for certain that she could make a movie about Barbie, the most famous and controversial doll in history, she was thinking about death. She had been reading about Ruth Handler, the brash Jewish businesswoman who created the doll — and who, decades later, had two mastectomies. Handler birthed this toy with its infamous breasts, the figurine who became an enduring avatar of plastic perfection, while being stuck, like all of us, in a fragile and failing human body. This thought sparked something for Gerwig. She envisioned a sunny-minded Barbie stumbling upon a dying woman in her barbecue area. Then Gerwig kept going. It was the beginning of the pandemic. Maybe no one would ever go to the movies again. Maybe no one would ever see what she was working on. Why not go for broke?

headline: Blocked Rail Crossings Snarl Towns, but Congress Won’t Act
abstract: The industry has used its muscle to prevent federal, state and local governments from penalizing companies that park freight trains across roads for hours or days.
lead_paragraph: Freight trains frequently stop and block the roads of York, Ala., sometimes cutting off two neighborhoods for hours. Emergency services and health care workers can’t get in, and those trapped inside can’t get out.

headline: They Know the Blessing and Curse of Warhol and Basquiat
abstract: Paige Powell and Brigid Berlin documented the world of artists who overshadowed them. With shows in New York and Paris, can these women escape their connections?
lead_paragraph: For many of the ambitious young people who circled Andy Warhol, the enigmatic pop artist opened otherwise inaccessible doors but also cast an inescapable shadow.

headline: A Place Where You Can Trade a Cat for a Burial Plot
abstract: Instead of using Craigslist and Facebook Marketplace, some people in rural America call their local radio stations to buy, sell and barter goods.
lead_paragraph: If you listen to local radio stations in much of rural America, you may hear a host bantering with a caller in search of help installing an oil pump in a Chevy engine. Another caller may be trying to trade a few bales of hay for a wheelchair lift. Perhaps even a burial plot for a cat.

headline: A Hamptons Home Fit for a James Bond Villain
abstract: The interior designer who renovated the Southampton, N.Y., house indulged his obsessions: James Bond movies and modernism. And he did it on a budget.
lead_paragraph: The interior designer who renovated the Southampton, N.Y., house indulged his obsessions: James Bond movies and modernism. And he did it on a budget.

headline: A Bond Villain’s Lair in the Hamptons? That’s Only the Half of It.
abstract: The interior designer who renovated the Southampton, N.Y., house indulged his obsessions: James Bond movies and modernism. And he did it on a budget.
lead_paragraph: The experimental midcentury-modern architecture of the Hamptons has long been a source of fascination to many in the design world — including Timothy Godbold, an interior designer based in Southampton, N.Y. So in the fall of 2019, when he noticed an unusual modernist house in town listed for sale, he was intrigued.

headline: Dirty Socks and Rotting Bodies: What Russians Left Behind in the Trenches
abstract: As Ukrainian troops inch forward in the counteroffensive, they are occupying positions abandoned by enemy troops. Says one: “It’s not very pleasant.”
lead_paragraph: A bottle of syrup made from Siberian berries, legions of dirty socks and a military-issued tea bag stamped with “For Victory!”

headline: Gotta Save the Castle? Start a Podcast.
abstract: The Duchess of Rutland learned the art of running a castle on the job. Then she started interviewing other duchesses on how they make it work.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Emma, Duchess of Rutland, sat in her drawing room and weighed the pros and cons of living over the shop. Specifically, Belvoir Castle, a stately and splendid pile perched on a wooded hilltop in the English countryside with more than 356 rooms and soaring neo-Gothic towers and turrets. It has been the site of the family seat since the 16th century.

headline: Today’s Top News: Extreme Weather Sweeps the U.S., and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Many Countries Banned Cluster Munitions. The U.S. Is Sending Them to Ukraine Anyway.
abstract: The weapons have been known to cause indiscriminate harm to civilians, especially children, long after the fighting ends.
lead_paragraph: For months, President Biden has been wrestling with one of the most vexing questions in the war in Ukraine: whether to risk letting Ukrainian forces run out of the artillery rounds they desperately need to fight Russia, or agree to ship them cluster munitions — widely banned weapons known to cause grievous injury to civilians, especially children. On Friday, the Biden administration announced that it would send the weapons, which have been outlawed by many of Washington’s closest allies.

headline: Protesters Throng Israeli Airport After Government Moves to Rein In Judiciary
abstract: Tens of thousands of demonstrators across the country caused widespread disruption after the governing coalition pushed forward with plans to limit the power of the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of Israelis demonstrated across the country on Tuesday, blocking the road outside the country’s main airport and about a dozen other thoroughfares and clashing with police officers to protest an overnight vote in Parliament that advanced efforts by the far-right ruling coalition to limit judicial oversight of the government.

headline: The Global Immigration Backlash
abstract: Left-leaning parties in both Europe and the U.S. are often out of step with public opinion on immigration.
lead_paragraph: The global migration wave of the 21st century has little precedent. In much of North America, Europe and Oceania, the share of population that is foreign-born is at or near its highest level on record.

headline: ‘Heaviest Rain Ever’ in Japan’s South Sets Off Floods and Landslides
abstract: Unusually heavy rain on the mountainous island of Kyushu has killed at least six people and left three others missing.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains in southwestern Japan have washed away homes, flooded hospitals, disrupted mobile phone services and cut off power and water for hundreds of households, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Trump Lawyers Seek Indefinite Postponement of Documents Trial
abstract: The former president’s legal team argued in a court filing that no trial date should be set until all “substantive motions” in the case were resolved, setting up an early key decision by Judge Aileen M. Cannon.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump asked a federal judge on Monday night to indefinitely postpone his trial on charges of illegally retaining classified documents after he left office, saying that the proceeding should not begin until all “substantive motions” in the case had been presented and decided.

headline: Read the Filing
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers requested on Monday that a federal judge indefinitely postpone his trial on charges of illegally retaining classified documents after he left office.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers requested on Monday that a federal judge indefinitely postpone his trial on charges of illegally retaining classified documents after he left office.

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy Takes Aim at a Political Fund-raising ‘Oligopoly’
abstract: The longshot Republican candidate is seeking to raise an army of fund-raisers — by giving them a cut of any money they collect for his campaign.
lead_paragraph: As a biotech entrepreneur, investor and conservative activist, Vivek Ramaswamy cuts a different profile from the veteran politicians who are also seeking the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Award-Winning ‘Cabaret’ Revival Plans Spring Broadway Bow
abstract: The production opened in London with Eddie Redmayne in a starring role; the New York cast has not yet been announced but he is expected to join it.
lead_paragraph: Willkommen, bienvenue, Broadway!

headline: California Bill Aims to Reduce Waste by Reining In ‘Sell By’ Dates
abstract: Consumers throw away more food than they need to because of confusing product labels, advocates say.
lead_paragraph: California’s residential composting program, which began last year, is an enormous undertaking meant to reduce the amount of trash going into the state’s landfills and the climate-polluting gases the facilities release.

headline: Will Turkey Become a Member of the E.U. Now? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: As part of his U-turn on unblocking Sweden’s bid for NATO membership, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey appears to have received vague promises about changing his country’s strained relationship with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: As part of his surprising U-turn that unblocked Sweden’s bid for NATO membership Monday evening, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey appears to have extracted vague commitments to “re-energize” his country’s complicated relationship with the European Union.

headline: At This Brewery, Blessings Are as Important as Barley and Hops
abstract: At Mount Saint Bernard Abbey, the monks help make Britain’s only Trappist beer, a full-bodied brew that has won fans since its launch five years ago.
lead_paragraph: The conveyor belt was ready, the empty bottles were stacked and the machinery was about to splutter into life. But one more step was needed before any beer bottling could get underway.

headline: ‘My Love for Queer Literature’: The Week 3 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
abstract: E., 16, chose a piece from T Magazine about the power of writers like Audre Lorde, Leslie Feinberg and James Baldwin.
lead_paragraph: Our annual Summer Reading Contest invites teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This week, the third of 10, we received 889 entries. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, who would like to be known as E., as well as to the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.

headline: Ticketmaster Pauses Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Sale in France
abstract: Fans trying to purchase tickets to six of the pop superstar’s concerts faced long queues and technical issues before the company said that a new on-sale time would be announced.
lead_paragraph: Ticketmaster has once again cracked under the weight of a Taylor Swift ticket sale — this time in France.

headline: PGA Tour Says Saudi Wealth Fund Could Put at Least $1 Billion Into Golf Deal
abstract: The acknowledgment came as two tour leaders went before a Senate subcommittee in a hearing that was sometimes contentious.
lead_paragraph: A PGA Tour executive told Congress on Tuesday that Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund could invest more than $1 billion in an ambitious alliance that stands to reshape professional golf — if it withstands scrutiny in Washington and a wellspring of suspicion and outrage over the Saudis’ widening role in a global sport.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Demis Hassabis
abstract: The July 11, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Demis Hassabis. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Suspecting Clandestine Plots Behind Every Door
abstract: In “Under the Eye of Power,” Colin Dickey unearths the long, disturbing history of fearmongering in American politics and culture.
lead_paragraph: The Memorial Day pancake breakfast in Blue Hill, Maine, is hosted by the Oddfellows, an 18th-century craftsmen’s guild turned community service organization, related to the Freemasons. While there this spring, I pondered the elderly members pouring coffee and selling raffle tickets to fund college scholarships. How bizarre, even funny, that this group was once perceived as a threat to America. Right?

headline: A Pie Shop on Chicago’s South Side Serves More Than Dessert
abstract: With her first brick-and-mortar bakery, Justice of the Pies, the pastry chef Maya-Camille Broussard focuses on creativity — and inclusivity for people with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: The South Side of Chicago brims with inimitable African American culture and history, and the pastry chef Maya-Camille Broussard is adding her brand of sweetness to the place where she was born and raised. In June, Ms. Broussard opened the first brick-and-mortar store of her longtime delivery and wholesale pie business, Justice of the Pies.

headline: DeSantis’s Striking, Risky Strategy: Not Trying to Trick Small Donors
abstract: Diverging from Donald Trump, who has often cajoled, guilt-tripped and even misled small donors, the DeSantis team is pledging to avoid “smoke and mirrors” in its online fund-raising.
lead_paragraph: In the months before the 2020 presidential election, Roy W. Bailey, a Dallas businessman, received a stream of text messages from Donald J. Trump’s re-election campaign, asking for money in persistent, almost desperate terms.

headline: Heat Endures in the Southwest as the Monsoon Season Lags
abstract: A high-pressure dome parked over the Southwest is elevating temperatures from Florida to California, a heat wave that forecasters say could last two weeks.
lead_paragraph: Many Texans are familiar with the chorus of cicadas that fills the air on the hottest days of early July. But this week, the bugs seem particularly raucous.

headline: No-Cook Puttanesca Chickpea Salad and One-Pot Sesame Salmon Rice Bowls
abstract: Weeknight meals that feel weekend fancy.
lead_paragraph: Hi, friends! Margaux Laskey here filling in for Emily Weinstein today (she’ll be back next week). I’ve missed this little corner of the internet! I hope you’ve been well.

headline: Japan’s Supreme Court Lifts Restroom Restriction at Work for Trans Woman
abstract: The decision represents some forward momentum in L.G.B.T.Q. rights in Japan, which lags behind other G7 nations in extending them.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the country’s trade ministry acted illegally in restricting a transgender woman from using restrooms at work that aligned with her gender identity, a step forward for L.G.B.T.Q. rights in a nation that has lagged in recognizing them.

headline: Raw Milk Is Being Legalized in More States. Is It Safe?
abstract: Health experts warn that drinking it could come with risks.
lead_paragraph: On July 1, Iowa officially became one of more than two dozen states that have legalized the sale of raw milk, or milk that has not been pasteurized.

headline: Judge Rejects F.T.C. Delay of $70 Billion Microsoft-Activision Deal
abstract: Microsoft also said it was negotiating changes to the deal to satisfy objections made by a British regulator, which could allow it to complete its purchase of the video game giant as soon as this month.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday ruled against the Federal Trade Commission’s attempt to delay Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, setting the stage for the tech giant and the video game publisher to merge as soon as this month.

headline: Vermont Floods Show Limits of America’s Efforts to Adapt to Climate Change
abstract: The lack of a comprehensive national rainfall database and current flood maps hampers the ability to prepare for storms intensified by climate change.
lead_paragraph: This week’s flooding in Vermont, in which heavy rainfall caused destruction even miles from any river, is evidence of an especially dangerous climate threat: Catastrophic flooding can increasingly happen anywhere, with almost no warning.

headline: A Hollywood Diner Becomes a Writers’ Room of a Different Sort
abstract: In their third month on the picket lines, Los Angeles screenwriters are drawing inspiration — and sustenance — from a local restaurant as their industry faces pressures from changing viewer habits.
lead_paragraph: They are usually fresh off the picket lines when they sink into plaid booths behind red Formica tables, or pull up to the terrazzo countertop, not far from the jukebox that switches from Sam Cooke to Joan Jett.

headline: A Centuries-Long Manhunt Stretches Across Mexico and Beyond
abstract: “Not Even the Dead,” a novel by Juan Gómez Bárcena, is a transhistorical epic with echoes of Cormac McCarthy and Joseph Conrad.
lead_paragraph: We’ll never know what the late Cormac McCarthy might have thought of Juan Gómez Bárcena’s “Not Even the Dead,” but I wager that the novel would have appealed to him, and also to Roberto Bolaño and Joseph Conrad, if for no reason other than their egos. Each of them would have seen strong evidence of their influence on Bárcena, whose previous work — a story collection and a prizewinning novel, “The Sky Over Lima” — has already established him as a leading writer in Spain. His latest book, splendidly translated by Katie Whittemore, only adds to his standing, thanks to its successful blend of ambitious literary dynamism with contemporary social and political commentary.

headline: What to Know About ChatGPT’s New Code Interpreter Feature
abstract: Graphs, maps and data analyses? Now ChatGPT can do even more.
lead_paragraph: ChatGPT, the artificial-intelligence-powered chatbot made by OpenAI, has wowed the world in recent months with the text it can generate. Now the chatbot is delighting users anew by creating charts and maps and turning images into videos.

headline: Schumer Asks Judicial Policymakers to End Single-Judge Divisions in Texas
abstract: The letter is the latest push by Democratic lawmakers to amend a system in which all cases filed in a particular geographic region are assigned to only one judge.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York has urged the policymaking body for the federal courts to end a case assignment system that he says allows parties to select their judges, escalating an effort to enact change at the federal judiciary.

headline: Why the Early Success of Threads May Crash Into Reality
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg has used Meta’s might to push Threads to a fast start — but that may only work up to a point.
lead_paragraph: A big tech company with billions of users introduces a new social network. Leveraging the popularity and scale of its existing products, the company intends to make the new social platform a success. In doing so, it also plans to squash a leading competitor’s app.

headline: ‘Mission: Impossible — Dead Reckoning Part One’ Review: Still Running
abstract: In this franchise’s seventh entry, Tom Cruise’s mission includes increasingly improbable leaps, chases and stunts. Luckily for us, he chooses to accept it.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know if anyone has ever clocked whether Tom Cruise is faster than a speeding bullet. The guy has legs, and guts. His sprints into the near-void have defined and sustained his stardom, becoming his singular superpower. He racks up more miles in “Mission: Impossible — Dead Reckoning Part One,” the seventh entry in a 27-year-old franchise that repeatedly affirms a movie truism. That is, there are few sights more cinematic than a human being outracing danger and even death onscreen — it’s the ultimate wish fulfillment!

headline: Bank of America Fined $150 Million Over ‘Junk Fees’ and Fake Accounts
abstract: The bank double-charged overdraft fees, withheld card perks and opened unauthorized accounts, regulators said. It will repay customers more than $80 million.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America withheld promised perks from some of its credit card customers, double-charged overdraft fees and secretly opened card accounts in customers’ names without their knowledge or consent, federal regulators said on Tuesday.

headline: Erdogan’s Flip on Sweden Signals Mending of Ties With U.S.
abstract: Long seen as an in-house disrupter in NATO, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey could be trying to repair relations with the Biden administration, partly by scaling back close ties with Russia.
lead_paragraph: While Europe and the United States were trying to isolate Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey referred to Russia’s president as “my friend.” While NATO leaders worked to enlarge the alliance, Mr. Erdogan held up the process by seeking concessions for his nation.

headline: More Than Five Days Later, Fatal Cargo Ship Fire Is Out
abstract: The fire erupted late last Wednesday evening. Two Newark firefighters lost their lives trying to battle the blaze.
lead_paragraph: The blaze that killed two firefighters aboard an Italian cargo ship at Port Newark, N.J., last week has finally been extinguished, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Ugandan President and His Son Are Accused of Crimes Against Humanity
abstract: Testimonies sent to the International Criminal Court detail accusations of torture and abuse committed against hundreds of victims before and after the elections in 2021.
lead_paragraph: A trove of testimonies from more than 200 people who accuse senior Ugandan officials, including the president and his son, of torture, killings and other crimes against humanity has been submitted to the International Criminal Court in The Hague, a lawyer for the complainants said on Tuesday.

headline: A Trans Woman Is Crowned Miss Netherlands for the First Time
abstract: Rikkie Valerie Kollé, 22, will represent the Netherlands at the 72nd annual Miss Universe pageant in El Salvador later this year.
lead_paragraph: Rikkie Valerie Kollé, Miss Netherlands 2023, can still hardly believe she won her country’s annual pageant.

headline: The Human Age Has a New Symbol. It’s a Record of Bomb Tests and Fossil Fuels.
abstract: A scientific panel has picked Crawford Lake, Ontario, to represent the Anthropocene, a proposed, and hotly contested, new chapter in geologic time.
lead_paragraph: For almost 15 years, a panel of scholars has been chewing over a big question: Has our species transformed the planet so much that we have plunged it into a new interval of geologic time?

headline: What NATO Said About Ukraine: Highlights of the Alliance’s Communiqué
abstract: Ukraine’s president wanted firmer commitments about when his country could join, but NATO’s 31 members did make some new pledges to draw Kyiv closer to the alliance.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of tense negotiations, NATO on Tuesday invited Ukraine to join the alliance at some unspecified point in the future, but only when allies agree that conditions are ripe and that Ukraine has met the qualifications to join.

headline: Metro-North and Amtrak Service Still Affected by Sunday’s Storm
abstract: Officials are still scrambling to address the damage done by torrential rain on Sunday that poured over the region and crippled its rail lines.
lead_paragraph: Floodwaters are starting to recede in the Hudson Valley, but officials are still scrambling to address the damage done by torrential rain on Sunday that poured over the region and crippled its rail lines.

headline: A Film About Child Trafficking Takes on Summer Blockbusters
abstract: “Sound of Freedom,” a film championed by the right, was behind only “Insidious: The Red Door” and “Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny” at the box office last weekend.
lead_paragraph: “Sound of Freedom,” a thriller starring Jim Caviezel as a federal agent who takes on child traffickers, will not be the summer box office’s biggest hit. But it may be its unlikeliest.

headline: After a Year of Climate Protests, the Toll Rises for Museums and Activists
abstract: Museums must pay for added security and the conservation of precious paintings. Now they are suing eco-activists for damages, and authorities are bringing serious charges.
lead_paragraph: Two climate activists made a beeline for a beautiful Monet painting exhibited at the National Museum in Sweden on a recent Wednesday morning. They wanted to convey the urgency of the environmental crisis — pollution, global warming and other man-made disasters — that could turn the artist’s gorgeous gardens at Giverny into a distant memory. So the young protesters followed what has become a familiar playbook: gluing a hand to the artwork’s protective glass and smearing it with red paint.

headline: Weighing the Morality of Giving Ukraine Cluster Munitions
abstract: Readers discuss an editorial criticizing the U.S. decision. Also: Disbanding The Times’s sports desk; censoring school plays; Sudan’s plight.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Personal Reflections on Parenting, Lesbian History and Autism
abstract: New books by Heidi Julavits, Amelia Possanza and Fern Brady explore a future of self-discovery by mining the past.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Julavits knows where she’s going in DIRECTIONS TO MYSELF: A Memoir of Four Years (Hogarth, 287 pp., $27), or at least she has to believe she does. In this narrative of parenthood and processing, there can be little room for doubt, except, of course, when it makes for good writing. Julavits’s young son faces what she calls “the end times of his childhood” — her eldest already a teenager — and over the course of breezy Maine summers and tumultuous school years, she documents their relationship out of one part of life and into another. To raise a boy in the current American climate is to reckon with much more than awkward growing pains: A sexual assault case lingers in the background of Julavits’s teaching life, her son learns what “slut” means, she regales her family with scary stories from her past, including an attempted murder victim stumbling, bloodied, onto her childhood porch.

headline: Humanitarian Aid to Syria Is Imperiled After Failed U.N. Security Council Votes
abstract: Dueling resolutions failed after Russian- and U.S.-led opposition, cutting off a cross-border lifeline from Turkey to more than four million people.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Tuesday failed to adopt two rival resolutions to extend cross-border aid deliveries into northern Syria from Turkey, effectively cutting off a vital lifeline to about 4.1 million people in opposition-held territories.

headline: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
abstract: Listen to tracks by Palehound, Sampha, the Armed and more.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I put together one of these monthly collections of “songs you should hear now,” culled from our weekly new music Playlists, my brain leaps to the “Now That’s What I Call Music!” font. Do you remember those compilations? I’m guessing you do, because a quick scan of the series’ impressively long Wikipedia page tells me they are released all over the world, and that they began in the United Kingdom in 1983. 1983! The “Now” albums didn’t arrive stateside until 1998, but to my surprise they’re still being released, even if the evolution toward streaming means they’ve receded from the album charts. Nevertheless, they persist. “Now That’s What I Call Music! Vol. 86” was released just a few months ago.

headline: A Dining Experience Inspired by the Floating Markets of Thailand
abstract: Rua Thai opens in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, another dinner option at the Hotel Chelsea and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Kornpon Theeraumpornkul, the chef and an owner of this charming new Thai spot, comes from central Thailand, where Damnoen Saduak, one of the largest of the country’s famous floating markets, is located. His new restaurant is inspired by those markets, and decorated with photos of them and food they might deliver. (His family also worked in the market.) He has spent the past 20 years working in Thai restaurants in New York, and has brought some of his colleagues from those restaurants to this venture. Dolporn Thongneam, the bartender, is one of them. Brick walls, some with gilded Thai script, crystal chandeliers, bright upholstery and pillows, and baroque Lucite chairs define the space. Mr. Theeraumpornkul’s lengthy menu features fresh summer rolls, curry dumplings, fish curry custard, shrimp doughnuts stacked on sugar cane, grilled river prawns, pineapple seafood fried rice served in a pineapple, and kai tod had yai, fried chicken with a massaman curry dip. The colorful, inventive cocktails and mocktails include ingredients like lemongrass, lychee, butterfly pea juice and milk tea.

headline: Dude, Where’s My Recession?
abstract: A tale of a disaster wrongly foretold.
lead_paragraph: Almost a year has passed since the Bureau of Economic Analysis, which estimates gross domestic product, announced that real G.D.P. had declined over the previous two quarters — a phenomenon that is widely, although incorrectly, described as the official definition of a recession.

headline: Inside the N.B.A.’s Version of Comic-Con
abstract: Promoted as a celebration of the league’s cultural relevance, the convention also highlighted the N.B.A.’s business ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere under the lights of the Mandalay Bay Convention Center over the weekend, the Jabbawockeez danced during a television special that could have been an email as part of the “most culturally relevant basketball experience on the planet.”

headline: Britney Spears Will Tell Her Side in Memoir Arriving in October
abstract: The book, “The Woman in Me,” will delve into the pop megastar’s account of the conservatorship that governed her life for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Britney Spears’s highly anticipated memoir, which is expected to chronicle the years she spent in a restrictive conservatorship that ultimately came to a dramatic end in a Los Angeles courtroom, will be released on Oct. 24 by Gallery Books, the publisher announced Tuesday.

headline: The Ups and Downs of Europe’s Most Interesting Opera Festival
abstract: Not everything was an artistic or audience success at the 75th Aix-en-Provence Festival in France. But everything was worth discussing.
lead_paragraph: Christian Gerhaher never left the stage.

headline: The Many Lives of Lil Durk
abstract: How the Chicago rap veteran reinvented himself, and became a star largely in the shadows.
lead_paragraph: One of this year’s most popular rap songs is “All My Life,” a singing-kid-chorus collaboration between the Chicago rap veteran Lil Durk and the superstar J. Cole. It is the most successful song of Durk’s career, which in the past three years has also included breakout collaborations with Drake, Lil Baby and Morgan Wallen.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Who I Was Without a Wedding Ring’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the 1950s, I was an unathletic, slightly effeminate gay boy. In my late teens, I finally became conscious of my “difference.” My father sensed it and tried hard to “shame away the gay.” It didn’t work. At my mother’s urging, my parents attended Pflag meetings (Parents and Friends of Lesbians and Gays). In June 1979, they marched in New York City’s Gay Pride Parade. My father carried an “I’m Proud of My Gay Son” sign. Someone asked to take our picture. The shutter clicked. We faced each other and laughed — until tears came to our eyes. — Mark N. Reiter

headline: When Climate Change Hits Home
abstract: A dispatch from the flooded house of our new lead writer.
lead_paragraph: Even if you’ve been paying attention to climate change, it can sometimes feel very far away, distant in both space and time. But on Sunday night, as I was writing my first edition of this newsletter, it came roaring into my kitchen.

headline: Restaurant Review: For Striking Malaysian Food, Follow the Chickens
abstract: Hainan Chicken House in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, is decked out in images of poultry — a tribute to its specialty, chicken rice.
lead_paragraph: Poached chickens and roasted chickens dangle in the window of Hainan Chicken House on Eighth Avenue in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. A chicken-size sculpture of a chicken stands above the door. Scattered among the plain white tiles on the dining-room walls are other tiles printed with images of chickens. And if you order one of the noodle soups, it will come to the table in a white bowl with a picture of a chicken on the outside.

headline: 6 People Killed in Helicopter Crash Near Mount Everest
abstract: Local authorities in Nepal said the victims were a male pilot and five Mexican tourists who were flying in the remote mountainous region.
lead_paragraph: Six people were killed on Tuesday morning when a helicopter crashed during a sightseeing trip over Mount Everest, according to local officials in Nepal.

headline: What Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson Meant When She Said ‘Blink’
abstract: Two lessons from one little verb.
lead_paragraph: To a linguist, there is so much to appreciate in just about every word. And over the past couple of weeks, I have been delighting in none other than the word “blink.”

headline: Four Pages Found in a Couch Are Ruled Aretha Franklin’s True Will
abstract: In deciding a family dispute over her estate, a jury in Michigan ruled that a handwritten document found in a couch at Franklin’s home after her death represented her last wishes.
lead_paragraph: More than four years of family conflict over the estate of Aretha Franklin ended Tuesday when a Michigan jury decided what her family could not — which of two hand-scrawled wills represented the famed singer’s true wishes for how to divide her estate.

headline: See How Much Rain Fell in the Northeast
abstract: Mapping where the extreme levels of rainfall in the Northeast unleashed widespread flooding across the region.
lead_paragraph: Mapping where the extreme levels of rainfall in the Northeast unleashed widespread flooding across the region.

headline: The G.O.P. Backed Him on Hunter Biden Claims. Now He Has Been Indicted.
abstract: Gal Luft, promoted by House Republicans as possessing evidence of corruption by the Biden family, was charged by federal prosecutors with lobbying and sanctions violations and with brokering arms deals with China and Iran.
lead_paragraph: The co-director of a Maryland-based research group who claims to have damaging information about Hunter Biden has been charged with arms trafficking, sanctions violations and acting as an unregistered agent for China, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Monday.

headline: Creative Flavors, Classic Sundaes and Exceptional Soft Serve
abstract: It’s hot, sticky and sweltering. Time for ice cream.
lead_paragraph: Well, folks, it’s miserable out there. The heat, the humidity, the bugs, the wildfire smoke, the impending threat of El Niño.

headline: Former Manson Family Member Leslie Van Houten Is Released on Parole
abstract: At the direction of Charles Manson, Ms. Van Houten participated in the murder of a California couple in 1969. She was initially sentenced to death.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Van Houten, a former Charles Manson follower who played a role in the gruesome double murder of a Los Angeles couple in the summer of 1969, was released on parole on Tuesday after serving more than half a century in prison, according to her lawyer.

headline: Inside the White-Hot Center of A.I. Doomerism
abstract: Anthropic, a safety-focused A.I. start-up, is trying to compete with ChatGPT while preventing an A.I. apocalypse. It’s been a little stressful.
lead_paragraph: It’s a few weeks before the release of Claude, a new A.I. chatbot from the artificial intelligence start-up Anthropic, and the nervous energy inside the company’s San Francisco headquarters could power a rocket.

headline: Trump Is Picking Fights in Iowa, No Matter the 2024 Consequences
abstract: The former president snubbed one influential Iowa leader and attacked another, testing his immunity to traditional political pitfalls in a crucial state.
lead_paragraph: Iowa may be the most important state on Donald J. Trump’s early 2024 political calendar, but he hasn’t been making many friends there lately.

headline: Biden Administration Is Quietly Debating Whether to Send Ukraine ATACMS Missiles
abstract: The United States already has plans for its limited stock of long-range Army Tactical Missile Systems.
lead_paragraph: Britain sent long-range “Storm Shadow” cruise missiles to Ukraine in May. And France pledged a shipment of the same missiles, which it calls SCALPs, as NATO leaders gathered in Lithuania on Tuesday.

headline: Bannon Owes $500,000 to Lawyers Who Won His Pardon, Judge Rules
abstract: The adviser to Donald J. Trump must pay Davidoff Hutcher & Citron, which helped him after his indictment for bilking donors to a border wall project, and in other legal scrapes.
lead_paragraph: With hours left in his presidency, Donald J. Trump granted pardons to a long roster of people. Prominent among them was his former chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon, who had been charged by federal prosecutors in Manhattan with conspiring to swindle donors of money to build a wall along the Mexican border.

headline: BBC Crisis Grows as Staff Member Is Accused of Abuse by 2nd Person
abstract: The British broadcaster was facing questions about its handling of an internal inquiry over explicit photos after another person accused the male staff member of sending abusive messages over a dating app.
lead_paragraph: A crisis at the BBC over the conduct of a senior staff member deepened on Tuesday with a report that a second person had come forward with allegations that the unnamed male staff member had sent angry and abusive messages to the person via a dating app.

headline: In Phoenix, Heat Becomes a Brutal Test of Endurance
abstract: Arizona is used to scorching summers, but the region’s long stretch of days with 110-degree temperatures is straining patience and resources.
lead_paragraph: Rachelle Williams was sick of delivering mail in Indiana winters, so in 2019, she put in for a transfer to Arizona and joined the flood of newcomers who have made Phoenix one of the country’s fastest-growing cities.

headline: Not Every Prime Day Deal Is Great. But These Are.
The ‘Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse’ TikTok Trend That Almost Wasn’t
abstract: The “canon event” videos play on the film’s idea of certain events in life being immutable. But the directors nearly went a different way with the concept.
lead_paragraph: In one video, an older brother watches with dread as his younger brother gets a perm. In another, a girl agonizes while her 10-year-old sister buys a maroon lifeguard hoodie.

headline: Presidency Doesn’t Shield Trump From Carroll’s Suit, Justice Dept. Says
abstract: In a reversal, the department said it could no longer argue that Donald Trump was acting in his official capacity when he insulted the writer E. Jean Carroll.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said Tuesday that it would no longer argue that President Donald J. Trump’s derogatory statements about E. Jean Carroll in 2019 were made as part of his official duties as president — a reversal that gives new momentum to her case.

headline: The Force Is With Elina Svitolina Once More
abstract: Svitolina, a new mother who has said she is playing to give strength to her people back home in Ukraine, is one match away from an improbable and inspiring spot in the Wimbledon final.
lead_paragraph: It is time to consider whether having a child, and spending a year away from the sport to raise money to help her compatriots back home in Ukraine, have made Elina Svitolina an even better tennis player.

headline: ‘Horseman of the Year’ Killed Horse While Shooting at Son, Authorities Say
abstract: John Victor Russell, 75, shot at his son after an argument on the family horse farm, the sheriff’s office in Polk County, N.C., said. The son was unharmed, but the horse he was riding was struck and had to be euthanized.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina man who was recently inducted into the Carolinas Show Hunter Hall of Fame tried to shoot one of his sons during an argument on the family farm last week but instead fatally injured the horse that the son was riding, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: NATO Won’t Invite Ukraine to Join Yet
abstract: Plus, floods in Japan.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine wanted a clear timeline for when it can join NATO. But the alliance’s leaders would not commit to one.

headline: Nonprofit Buys 22 Newspapers in Maine
abstract: The National Trust for Local News will take over five of the six daily papers in the state and 17 weeklies.
lead_paragraph: A nonprofit that aims to maintain local ownership for newspapers will buy 22 papers in Maine, including The Portland Press Herald and The Sun Journal of Lewiston.

headline: Coronavirus Probably Spread Widely in Deer and Perhaps Back to People, U.S.D.A. Says
abstract: From late 2021 to early 2022, humans transmitted the coronavirus to white-tailed deer more than 100 times, research suggests.
lead_paragraph: Humans transmitted the coronavirus to white-tailed deer more than 100 times in late 2021 and early 2022, according to new research led by the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. The research also suggests that the virus probably spread widely among deer, that it mutated in the animals and that they may have passed these altered versions of the virus back to people at least three times.

headline: NATO Says It Will Invite Ukraine to Join, but Offers No Timeline
abstract: Also, there was another Taylor Swift ticket fiasco. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Since before Russia invaded Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky has been asking NATO for membership — an aspiration fixed in Ukraine’s Constitution since 2019. Today, at the alliance’s summit in Vilnius, Lithuania, all 31 NATO leaders agreed to offer an invitation. Yet Zelensky was left disappointed.

headline: ‘Top Chef’ Selects Kristen Kish, a Former Winner, as Its New Host
abstract: Kish, who will bring considerable TV experience to the role, succeeds Padma Lakshmi, who hosted the show for 19 of its 20 seasons.
lead_paragraph: Kristen Kish, an acclaimed chef who won the 10th season of “Top Chef” more than a decade ago, will return as the next host of the long-running culinary competition, Bravo announced on Tuesday. She will succeed Padma Lakshmi, who said last month she would be departing the show, which she had hosted for 19 of its 20 seasons.

headline: Finnish Right-Wing Party Leader Apologizes After Racist Posts Surface
abstract: Riikka Purra, who leads the nationalist Finns party, was the second member of her faction to come under fire for offensive comments since the government was formed a month ago.
lead_paragraph: Finland’s deputy prime minister apologized on Tuesday for “stupid social media comments” after a series of racist and sometimes violent remarks posted in 2008 surfaced in the Finnish press — the latest scandal for the party she leads, the right-wing Finns, since it joined the country’s governing coalition less than a month ago.

headline: Ruth Fitzpatrick, Crusader for Letting Women Be Priests, Dies at 90
abstract: Feeling called to the Roman Catholic priesthood but denied entry, she became a leader of a national group that has pushed the Vatican to ordain women.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Fitzpatrick, who felt she was called to the Roman Catholic priesthood beginning as a teenager and later helped lead a movement to press the church to stop barring women like her from being ordained, died on June 15 in Fairfax, Va. She was 90.

headline: NATO Says It Will Invite Ukraine Some Day, Resisting Calls to Act Soon
abstract: The alliance firmed up its plans to include Ukraine eventually, but gave no timetable, siding with President Biden and frustrating some East European members.
lead_paragraph: NATO declared on Tuesday that Ukraine would be invited to join the alliance, but did not say how or when, disappointing its president but reflecting the resolve by President Biden and other leaders not to be drawn directly into Ukraine’s war with Russia.

headline: Ellen Hovde, ‘Grey Gardens’ Documentarian, Dies at 97
abstract: She worked with the Maysles brothers on the groundbreaking film about two Long Island recluses, and she later shared an Emmy for a mini-series about Ben Franklin.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Hovde, a documentarian who was one of the directors of “Grey Gardens,” the groundbreaking 1975 movie that examined the lives of two reclusive women living in a deteriorating mansion on Long Island and inspired both a Broadway musical and an HBO film, died on Feb. 16 at her home in Brooklyn. She was 97.

headline: The U.S. Reassessment of Netanyahu’s Government Has Begun
abstract: Israel’s extremist governing coalition is going too far on too many fronts.
lead_paragraph: Whenever people ask me what I do for a living, I tell them that I’m a translator from English to English. I try to take complex subjects and make them understandable, first to myself and then to readers — and that is what I want to do here regarding three interrelated questions: Why is Israel’s cabinet trying to crush the country’s Supreme Court? Why did President Biden tell CNN that “this is one of the most extreme” Israeli cabinets he’d ever seen? And why did the U.S. ambassador to Israel just say that America is working to prevent Israel from “going off the rails”?

headline: Scientists, Under Fire From Republicans, Defend Fauci and Covid Origins Study
abstract: Two virologists testified that they remained convinced that the coronavirus was natural in origin and said Dr. Anthony S. Fauci did not exert influence over a study they wrote.
lead_paragraph: Two world-renowned virologists appeared on Capitol Hill on Tuesday and delivered a pointed defense of their findings that the coronavirus pandemic was natural in origin, and told skeptical Republicans that Dr. Anthony S. Fauci did not exert influence over a scientific paper they wrote to that effect.

headline: Speech We Loathe Is Speech We Must Defend
abstract: Government cannot deputize the private sector to act as a censor.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1950s, the Rhode Island legislature created a commission “to encourage morality in youth.” One of its practices was to send notices to out-of-state distributors and retailers of publications it deemed obscene, asking for “cooperation” in suppressing them. The notices warned that the commission had circulated lists of objectionable materials to local police departments, and that it would recommend prosecution against those found to be purveying obscenity.

headline: The Hottest Thing in Baseball Is a Grid of Nine Blank Squares
abstract: Immaculate Grid has become a daily obsession for fans, journalists and even some ex-players. Being purchased by Baseball Reference should only help it grow.
lead_paragraph: They are indelible All-Star snapshots, midsummer memories for a sport steeped in tradition: a boyish Ted Williams clapping in delight after his walk-off homer in Detroit; a triumphant Tony Gwynn sliding in for the winning run in Pittsburgh; a stately Cal Ripken Jr. blasting a homer in his All-Star farewell in Seattle.

headline: Hard Right Presses Culture War Fights on Defense Bill, Imperiling Passage
abstract: Right-wing Republicans want to use the annual military budget and policy legislation, traditionally a bipartisan affair, as a tool to pick fights on abortion and other social issues.
lead_paragraph: Hard-right House Republicans are pushing to use the yearly bill that sets the United States military budget and policy as an opportunity to pick fights with the Biden administration over abortion, race and transgender issues, imperiling its passage and the decades-old bipartisan consensus in Congress around backing the Pentagon.

headline: F.T.C.’s Court Loss Raises Fresh Questions About Its Chair’s Strategy
abstract: Lina Khan has said a fear of defeat should not deter the agency from suing big tech companies. But after Microsoft won a ruling this week, her critics say that strategy is flawed.
lead_paragraph: Lina Khan became chair of the Federal Trade Commission two years ago on a promise to bring bold action against the biggest tech companies.

headline: This, That or Whichever
abstract: Brooke Husic and Brian Thomas help us pass the time.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Manhattan Cannabis Chain Raided by Police and State Agents
abstract: Empire Cannabis Club is the target of stepped-up state efforts to crack down on unlicensed shops.
lead_paragraph: New York Police Department officers and state tax agents raided one Manhattan dispensary and were thwarted from raiding another on Tuesday in an exercise of their newly expanded powers to crack down on unlicensed cannabis shops.

headline: Corrections: July 12, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the collapse of the Dutch coalition government over a proposed refugee policy referred imprecisely to Jan Paternotte’s role in the D66 party. He leads the party in the House of Representatives, not the party overall. The error was repeated in an article on Tuesday about the Dutch prime minister Mark Rutte’s exit from politics.

headline: In Cities and Small Towns, Vermonters Reckon With the Devastation of Flooding
abstract: Calls for search and rescue missions continued, as residents and business owners started assessing damage, fueling an anxious, unsettled mood.
lead_paragraph: As floodwaters began to ebb on Tuesday, and Vermonters reckoned with the devastation of a record-breaking storm, shock mixed with a growing sense of dread at the long recovery ahead — and with a lingering uneasiness that more losses might yet be uncovered.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Russia Leaves Rotting Bodies and Old Socks
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The soldiers will learn. It’s complicated. And yes, it’s going slowly. But importantly, it’s going.”

headline: Chinese Hackers Breached Government Email Accounts, Microsoft Says
abstract: The hack, by a Chinese group that the company said was intent on conducting espionage, went undetected for a month.
lead_paragraph: Chinese hackers intent on collecting intelligence on the United States gained access to government email accounts, Microsoft disclosed on Tuesday night.

headline: Penn Station Is a Disgrace. Can a New Plan Improve It?
abstract: A private firm’s proposal for the station tries to restore some of its old romance, unlike the M.T.A. plan, our architecture critic says.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll hear from The Times’s architecture critic on something that would change the look of a much-traveled stretch of Midtown Manhattan, inside and out — a plan for a new Pennsylvania Station.

headline: How to Revive a Dying Main Street? One U.K. Landlord Offered Free Rent.
abstract: In a coastal English town, a floundering shopping district was given new life after 10 local businesses were given free rent for two years.
lead_paragraph: For two decades, Steven Wyatt was in a cycle of drug addiction and rehab. In 2006, during a stint at a recovery center, he learned how to restore furniture, a skill that led him to an unexpected place: running his own store in Poole, a coastal town in southwest England.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Developments on Ukraine’s bid to join NATO.
lead_paragraph: NATO leaders meeting at a summit in Vilnius, Lithuania, agreed in a joint statement to offer Ukraine an invitation to join the military alliance. But they remained vague on how and when, wording that essentially marked a victory for President Biden, who has said that Ukraine was not ready to be a member. European states closest to Russia have pushed for faster support.

headline: Scapegoated by Everyone, Wanted by No One
abstract: Syrians in Turkey do not want to go home. They may not have a choice.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — It was the Syrians who were responsible for the earthquakes. That’s what a Turkish man told Seyfeddin Selim, a refugee from Homs, Syria, who used to sell groceries in Antakya, the capital of Hatay province in southern Turkey. When the earthquakes hit in February, Mr. Selim’s shop was cleared out by looters before he could get there.

headline: Word of the Day: versatile
abstract: This word has appeared in 199 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word versatile has appeared in 199 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 27 in the Opinion essay “The Newest Immigrants Will Change American Spanish. That’s a Good Thing” by Ilan Stavans:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Energy Transition Is Underway. Fossil Fuel Workers Could Be Left Behind.
abstract: The Biden administration is trying to increase renewable energy investments in distressed regions, but some are skeptical those measures would be enough to make up for job losses.
lead_paragraph: Tiffany Berger spent more than a decade working at a coal-fired power plant in Coshocton County, Ohio, eventually becoming a unit operator making about $100,000 annually.

headline: From 400 Feet Above, a Lake’s Algae Problems Look Clear
abstract: To understand the challenges at Lake Okeechobee, a vast inland sea in Florida, The New York Times piloted a drone.
lead_paragraph: Lake Okeechobee, in South Florida, has a problem that grows every summer.

headline: Far From the Tour de France, Colombia Falls Hard for Cycling
abstract: Soccer still reigns supreme in Latin America, but a popular ride in the hills above Medellín showcases a nation’s second love.
lead_paragraph: The route up Las Palmas starts near the valley floor, but it doesn’t stay there for long. It is 10 miles up to the summit, an arduous climb of roughly 3,400 vertical feet, a journey of long rises and sharp turns, of straining muscles and heaving lungs.

headline: A Royal Soldier Fainted in the Heat. It Holds a Lesson for All of Us.
abstract: Even as climate change upends our lives, we seem set on doing things the way we’ve always done them.
lead_paragraph: It was a dress rehearsal in which everyone seemed to be wearing the wrong clothes.

headline: This Fried-Zucchini Pasta Took Three Generations to Perfect
abstract: Capers and pistachios play on a tradition from Yotam Ottolenghi’s family.
lead_paragraph: If I had to pick one central food memory of my childhood, it is my grandmother’s Passover Seder, where a humble plate of fried zucchini — a culinary relic from 1920s Italy in 1980s Israel — was what everyone gravitated toward.

headline: The Puny Power of ‘Woke Capitalism’
abstract: Companies embrace progressive values to expand their market share while obscuring their raw political power.
lead_paragraph: Early last year, the musician India.Arie posted a video on her Instagram that caused a lot of headaches for my then-employer, Spotify. It was a mash-up of the many times Spotify’s star podcaster, Joe Rogan, had used a racial slur for Black people on his show. I don’t need to tell you which slur it was. Unsurprisingly, the video quickly went viral, and a huge uproar ensued.

headline: To Help Cool a Hot Planet, the Whitest of White Coats
abstract: Scientists at Purdue have created a white paint that, when applied, can reduce the surface temperature on a roof and cool the building beneath it.
lead_paragraph: Xiulin Ruan, a professor of mechanical engineering at Purdue University, didn’t set out to make it into the Guinness World Records when he began trying to make a new type of paint. He had a loftier goal: to cool down buildings without torching the Earth.

headline: This Is One Republican Strategy That Isn’t Paying Off
abstract: Voter suppression isn’t what it’s cracked up to be.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, determined to push back the ascendant Democratic coalition that elected America’s first Black president, Republicans capitalized on their control of legislatures and governor’s mansions in 20 states to enact measures designed to suppress minority Democratic voters.

headline: How Hot Is the Sea Off Florida Right Now? Think 90s Fahrenheit.
abstract: Researchers are recording ocean temperatures that pose severe risks to coral reefs and other marine life.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s coral reefs are facing what could be an unprecedented threat from a marine heat wave that is warming the Gulf of Mexico, pushing water temperatures into the 90s Fahrenheit.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Conservatives Control Even More Than You Realize
abstract: In addition to deciding cases, those justices also have the votes to decide which cases the court hears, setting the agenda in the process.
lead_paragraph: Add this to the ways in which the Supreme Court is increasingly resembling just another political institution: Only one side of the ideological divide has the power to set the institution’s agenda.

headline: The Holocaust in Poland and the Erasures of the Past
abstract: In “Jews in the Garden,” the journalist Judy Rakowsky helps a relative uncover the truth of what happened to their family during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Three decades ago, the veteran reporter Judy Rakowsky began accompanying her elderly relative Sam on trips to Eastern Europe. Sam had survived the ghettos and camps of the Holocaust in Nazi-occupied Poland and Germany. He performed forced labor in a factory, as did an aunt and uncle who were among the Jews employed by Oskar Schindler, the German industrialist made famous in Steven Spielberg’s movie “Schindler’s List.”

headline: What to Know About Vermont’s Devastating Floods
abstract: One person died after the state was inundated by days of heavy rain that flooded rivers to some of their highest levels on record.
lead_paragraph: A powerful storm dumped as much as nine inches of rain on parts of Vermont this week, causing at least one death and leaving residents of the state capital and small mountain towns to grapple with some of the worst destruction the state has ever experienced.

headline: On TV Killer Fungi Are a Horror Plotline. In This Book They’re Real.
abstract: “Blight,” by Emily Monosson, chronicles the threats fungal pathogens pose to humans, animals and plants as the world’s most devastating agents of disease.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in Don DeLillo’s novel “White Noise” in which the protagonist reminisces with an ex-wife who was “ultrasensitive to many things,” as she puts it. “Sunlight, air, food, water, sex,” he says. She doesn’t disagree: “Carcinogenic, every one of them.”

headline: Who Is Daddy’s Little Meatball?
abstract: The slogan has taken over New York City’s souvenir shops, and the T-shirts are worn by tourists and downtown Manhattanites alike.
lead_paragraph: On an afternoon in June, Erica Scalise was walking through Little Italy in Manhattan when the window of a kitschy souvenir shop gave her pause. Hanging in the display was a white T-shirt with a phrase printed in the red and green colors of Italy’s flag: “Daddy’s Little Meatball.”

headline: Translating Traditional Korean Movement to ‘a Language for Our Time’
abstract: “One Dance,” part of Korean Arts Week at Lincoln Center, puts a contemporary spin on rituals and ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: Like many court ceremonies, the Confucian ritual that has been performed for centuries at the royal Jongmyo shrine in Korea, is meticulous and measured, stately and restrained. In the shrine’s stone courtyard, a large group of women stand in place, arranged in rows, holding symbolic objects like bamboo flutes and wooden swords and periodically shifting the position of their arms in perfect, unhurried unison. This part is called il mu, which can be translated as “line dance” or “one dance.”

headline: $1.1 Million Homes in Kentucky, Texas and Pennsylvania
abstract: An 1888 Queen Anne Revival house in Versailles, a Craftsman bungalow in Denton and a split-level home in New Hope.
lead_paragraph: This house is near the city center, a few blocks from the public library on Main Street and half a block from the Woodford County Historical Society. It is across the street from Big Spring Park and about five minutes from a public elementary school. The Woodford Reserve Distillery and Wild Turkey Distillery, popular stops on the Kentucky Bourbon Trail, are less than 15 minutes away by car.

headline: Maggie Siff and Erica Schmidt on a Williams Play ‘Shot Through With Desire’
abstract: “Orpheus Descending,” a rarely revived play about the treatment of outsiders, has only become more meaningful for its star and its director.
lead_paragraph: After Maggie Siff’s husband died of brain cancer in 2021, the last thing she wanted to do was a play about a woman with a husband dying of cancer.

headline: The Essential John le Carré
abstract: His clever, melancholic mind produced some of the most enduring heroes in spy fiction. Here are his best books.
lead_paragraph: The English novelist John le Carré (given name: David Cornwell) never sufficiently explained his nom de plume. Of course, we know why he needed one: He still worked for MI6, the British equivalent of the C.I.A., when he wrote his first three books. For years, he told reporters that he’d glimpsed the name on a storefront while riding a bus. That was a lie, he later admitted, a “tiny deception operation” devised to conceal an even more banal truth: that he just couldn’t remember. “I just got sick of saying, ‘I don’t know where it came from,’” he confessed.

headline: An Exiled Publisher Creates a ‘Brotherhood Across Tibetans’
abstract: Bhuchung Sonam co-founded a press to nurture the writing of Tibetans, helping provide through literature a sense of home for a stateless population.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 1982, Bhuchung Sonam left his home in Central Tibet. For five days, he trekked with his father across the Himalayas to the Nepali border. Only around 11 years old then, he knew little about what they were fleeing — China’s decades-long colonization of his homeland — and why. He also didn’t realize that he would never again see his homeland, his mother or his six siblings.

headline: 2,000 Miles, a Balky R.V. and a Swim with Whale Sharks: How We Got Our Travel Mojo Back
abstract: A pandemic-delayed journey to Australia’s Ningaloo Reef helped a family regain its belief in the serendipity of the open road.
lead_paragraph: All we wanted after a magnificent snorkeling session off the coast of Western Australia was for the stupid motor home to start, to stop grinding away with that almost-but-not-today sound that made our hearts race faster than the engine. Bertie, as we called the 21-foot recreational vehicle we had rented, sounded like she wanted to work. She just lacked the energy.

headline: Inflation Cools Sharply in June, Good News for Consumers and the Fed
abstract: The Consumer Price Index climbed far more slowly in June, a relief for shoppers and a hopeful — though inconclusive — sign that America might pull off a “soft landing.”
lead_paragraph: Inflation cooled significantly in June, offering some of the most hopeful news since the Federal Reserve began trying to tame rapid price increases 16 months ago — and boosting the chances that the central bank might be able to stop raising interest rates after its meeting this month.

headline: DeSantis Confronts a Murdoch Empire No Longer Quite So Supportive
abstract: The Florida governor has faced tough questions and critical coverage lately from Fox News and other conservative outlets, in a sign of growing skepticism.
lead_paragraph: In March, as Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida laid the groundwork for his presidential run, he joined the Fox News host Brian Kilmeade to play a nationally televised game of catch on his hometown baseball field outside Tampa.

headline: ‘An Act of War’: Inside America’s Silicon Blockade Against China
abstract: The Biden administration thinks it can preserve America’s technological primacy by cutting China off from advanced computer chips. Could the plan backfire?
lead_paragraph: Last October, the United States Bureau of Industry and Security issued a document that — underneath its 139 pages of dense bureaucratic jargon and minute technical detail — amounted to a declaration of economic war on China. The magnitude of the act was made all the more remarkable by the relative obscurity of its source.
