lead_paragraph: We are living through an information revolution. The traditional gatekeepers of knowledge — librarians, journalists and government officials — have largely been replaced by technological gatekeepers — search engines, artificial intelligence chatbots and social media feeds.

headline: Some Squirmy Stowaways Got to the Arctic. And They Like It There.
abstract: The unexpected presence of earthworms in the Far North could cause rapid changes in some of the planet’s most fragile ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: Worms are on the move, and people are nervous.

headline: Britain’s Conservatives Are Imploding
abstract: Elections next week will tell us how much trouble the Tories are in.
lead_paragraph: Almost the first thing I saw when I arrived in the London suburb of Uxbridge was two teenage girls in school uniforms getting into a fistfight in the shopping mall outside the underground station. Uxbridge is a middle-class place, stodgy but diversifying, whose voters are squeezed by a cost of living crisis and anxious about rising public disorder. Until last month, it was represented by Boris Johnson, and, as the Labour lawmaker Steve Reed told me, it hasn’t sent a member of the left-leaning Labour Party to Parliament since 1966.

headline: If Loneliness Is an Epidemic, How Do We Treat It?
abstract: It can’t be cured; it can be treated.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Cacioppo thought she would be single forever. “I was an only child,” says Dr. Cacioppo. “I always thought that was my fate to be alone.”

headline: A Federal Judge Asks: Does the Supreme Court Realize How Bad It Smells?
abstract: The reported behavior of some justices is not a matter of politics or judicial philosophy. It’s about ethics.
lead_paragraph: What has gone wrong with the Supreme Court’s sense of smell?

headline: A Beach Town Where Broken People Go to Disappear
abstract: “The Stolen Coast,” by Dwyer Murphy, is a heist novel involving rough diamonds, crooked lawyers and masters of the double cross.
lead_paragraph: If you, like me, lament the absence in modern-day Hollywood of the whip-smart neo-noir thrillers that flourished in the 1990s — films like “One False Move,” “The Last Seduction,” “After Dark, My Sweet,” “Red Rock West” and “Out of Sight,” to name a few — then I have great news for you. It comes in the form of Dwyer Murphy’s second novel, “The Stolen Coast,” which offers all the abundant pleasures of those films, and more.

headline: At American Apparel, a Sex-Positive Veneer Belied Abuse Underneath
abstract: Kate Flannery’s “Strip Tees” is a racy, thoughtful memoir of her tenure during the rise and fall of the controversial retail company.
lead_paragraph: After a chance meeting with a recruiter at a dive bar in the winter of 2005, Kate Flannery walked into American Apparel’s Los Angeles headquarters wearing tight surf shorts and her mother’s floppy felt hat. That day — as Flannery writes in her first book, “Strip Tees,” a racy, thoughtful memoir of her tenure during the rise and fall of the controversial company — she watched garment workers produce “quivering piles of kelly-green men’s underwear”; posed for Polaroids in a leg-baring velour romper; and encountered the company’s brash, charismatic founder, Dov Charney, “a flip phone pressed to one ear while another waited in a holster on his belt loop.”

headline: When Did Humans First Occupy the Americas? Ask the Sloth Bones.
abstract: The discovery of ancient, handcrafted ornaments revives a longstanding debate about the arrival of the earliest Americans.
lead_paragraph: Of all the long-running disputes in archaeology, few roil scholars more than the question of when humans arrived in the Americas. For much of the past century, the reigning theory was that in or around 11,500 years ago big-game hunters from Asia trudged to North America across a land bridge spanning the Bering Strait, hung a right through a corridor between glaciers and, in less than a millennium, reached the tip of South America.

headline: He Followed in the Family Footsteps. And He Found a Home.
abstract: Anthony Couverthier tried his hand at different jobs, but being a building superintendent came naturally and with an apartment for his family.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Couverthier’s father was a building superintendent. His brother is a super, too. His longtime partner’s stepfather also works as a super. But Mr. Couverthier spent years trying to be something else: a tour manager for a hip-hop group, a store clerk at Sprint, a Home Depot employee. After graduating high school in 1998, he was a communications major at Stony Brook University in Southampton.

headline: For Many Small-Business Owners, a Necessary Shift to Digital Payments
abstract: The pandemic accelerated a transition to cashless payments, forcing a reckoning among small-business owners. But there are benefits: An owner said one cashless system saved her $3,000 a month.
lead_paragraph: “Making It Work” is a series about small-business owners striving to endure hard times.

headline: Uruguay Saw Opportunity in China. It Got Schooled in the Hazards of Trade.
abstract: Uruguay’s pursuit of a trade deal with China has angered its powerful neighbors while failing to yield economic gains.
lead_paragraph: Word that Uruguay was seeking a trade deal with China prompted exultation at El Álamo ranch, a lush expanse of grass punctuated by cactus and herds of cattle on the eastern plains of Uruguay.

headline: 5 Restaurants in Naples Where You Can Forget About Pizza
abstract: Fried zucchini, classic ziti with Neapolitan ragù, mussel soup and artichoke hearts filled with mountain truffle cream: When it comes to food, there’s more to this coastal Italian city than pizza.
lead_paragraph: The worldwide culinary fame of Italy’s third-largest city boils down to one word: pizza. You can hardly hurl a tomato in the food’s purported birthplace — a scruffy, graffiti-stained port city of monumental Baroque buildings and narrow cobbled passageways — without hitting a gaggle of culinary pilgrims jockeying to enter one of the hundreds (or thousands, by some counts) of pizzerias.

headline: In Ontario, a Tiny Cabin With Style to Spare
abstract: Building a big new house would have been easier and cheaper. But saving the rotting 19th-century structure resulted in something better.
lead_paragraph: Building a big new house would have been easier and cheaper. But saving the rotting 19th-century structure resulted in something better.

headline: Saying Goodbye to the Dead. (Again.)
abstract: Jerry Garcia died in 1995. The band bade fans farewell in 2015. This weekend, Dead & Company will close out its Final Tour. Why can’t we stop quitting one of rock’s beloved acts?
lead_paragraph: The first time Albie Cullen said goodbye to the Grateful Dead was on Aug. 9, 1995.

headline: At 600 Square Feet, the Cabin Was Big Enough: ‘It’s Just Me and My Dog’
abstract: Building a big new house would have been easier and cheaper. But saving the 19th-century structure resulted in something better.
lead_paragraph: When Stephan Weishaupt began looking for a weekend home outside Toronto, buying a 19th-century log cabin was the furthest thing from his mind.

headline: Ruined, Empty, Mined and Overgrown: Ukraine’s Forgotten Villages
abstract: Settlements along Ukraine’s eastern steppe were reduced to wreckage as the war passed through them. Now choked with weeds and with few residents, they are at risk of disappearing.
lead_paragraph: Leave the eastern Ukrainian city of Izium and turn west onto rougher roads, where dead trees and twisted power lines give way to a string of shattered villages.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, July 14, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The Strangest Trees Grow in East Hampton
abstract: At the Folly Tree Arboretum, a natural museum curated by an artist with a historian’s eye, every oak, magnolia and sycamore has its own peculiar tale.
lead_paragraph: The clone of the tree that grew from a seed that went to the moon doesn’t look like much. It’s still a callow sapling, a flurry of bright green leaves on a spindly six-foot trunk. But in 20 years or so, this American sycamore will be a formidable presence at the Folly Tree Arboretum, an unusual collection of some 250 trees planted by Tucker Marder, a 33-year-old artist, on five acres of his family’s land in East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: Today’s Top News: Hollywood Actors Go on Strike, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: How Clarence Thomas Came to Reject Affirmative Action
abstract: The Supreme Court justice has long been among the most ardent critics of the policy.
lead_paragraph: Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, the second Black justice to sit on the court after Thurgood Marshall, has spent years opposing affirmative action. When the high court struck down the policy last month, Justice Thomas was one of the most influential figures behind the ruling.

headline: Risk, Regulation and Personal Responsibility in Australia’s Last Frontier
abstract: Setting off fireworks in the Northern Territory, with a sense of time running out.
lead_paragraph: Standing in line outside a fireworks store in Darwin on the morning of July 1, a man mentioned to me that he had acquired some kind of metal pipe, out of which he was planning to shoot fireworks that night. It was morning, and the store hadn’t opened yet, but he had wanted to arrive early to beat the rush on the one day a year when residents could buy and set off fireworks.

headline: Corrections: July 14, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on July 3 about the meteorologist Frank Field misstated where he was born. It was Brooklyn, not Queens. It also misstated when his wife, Joan, died. It was last year, not this year. And it omitted the name of a survivor. In addition to those named, Dr. Field is survived by a brother, Allan.

headline: The Semiconductor Struggle
abstract: The U.S. and China are engaged in a great-power struggle, and chips are part of the fight.
lead_paragraph: Publicly, the U.S. and China have turned down the heat recently on their relationship. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Secretary of State Antony Blinken have both visited Beijing in recent weeks partly to improve communication between the two countries. “President Biden and I do not see the relationship between the U.S. and China through the frame of great-power conflict,” Yellen said at the end of her trip.

headline: Investors Look for Reasons the Market Could ‘Grind Higher’
abstract: Companies are expected to report a fall in profits, but some analysts see brighter times ahead.
lead_paragraph: As companies prepare to open their books to investors over the coming weeks, in the quarterly ritual known as earnings season, market watchers are balancing relatively weak estimates for past profits with brighter forecasts for future performance.

headline: A Ukrainian commander describes the grueling battle against dug-in Russian forces.
abstract: Troops with the 36th Marine Brigade have been the tip of the spear in Ukraine’s counteroffensive and have advanced about five miles into a bulge into Russian lines in southern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Even as he commanded troops in a fierce, weeklong fight to capture one Russian position, Col. Viktor Sikoza received disturbing news: The Russians were using this time to build yet another fortification behind it.

headline: The Economic Stakes in the Hollywood Shutdown
abstract: Strikes by actors and screenwriters have ground movie and TV productions to a halt, with consequences likely to be felt across the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: It’s happening: America’s $134 billion movie and TV industry has ground to a halt after the Hollywood actors’ union voted to strike, joining screenwriters and shutting down virtually all productions.

headline: JPMorgan’s Profit Jumps, but Interest Rates Remain a Threat
abstract: It was another quarter of banner financial results for the largest lender in America.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, the largest lender in the United States, made $14.5 billion in profit last quarter, a big jump from the same period last year, it reported on Friday. The bank was helped by growth virtually across the board, including increases in lending and credit-card transactions, as well as relative stability in investment banking. JPMorgan’s stock rose 0.6 percent at the close of trading.

headline: Extreme Weather Hits Europe, and It’s Not Over Yet
abstract: In some places, a record-breaking heat wave created ideal conditions for wildfires to spread. In others, rain flooded streets. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Extreme weather has battered Southern Europe and North Africa this month, with sweltering heat aggravating conditions for wildfires in some countries and thunderous storms leading to flooding in others.

headline: Tropical Storm Calvin Passes South of Hawaii
abstract: The storm was passing near the Big Island on Wednesday, bringing high winds and heavy rain, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Calvin passed just south of Hawaii on Wednesday, bringing high winds, dangerous surf and heavy rainfall even as it moved away from the Big Island, forecasters said.

headline: Wells Fargo Beats Expectations but Sets Aside Money for Loan Losses
abstract: The U.S. economy “continues to perform better than many had expected,” said Charlie Scharf, the bank’s chief executive, but “there will likely be continued economic slowing.”
lead_paragraph: Higher interest rates and rising loan balances helped Wells Fargo top analysts’ expectations for the second quarter, even as it socked away more money as a buffer against bad loans.

headline: How a Jay-Z Retrospective Took Over the Brooklyn Public Library
abstract: “The Book of Hov,” an elaborate summer exhibition at the borough’s main branch, was quietly conceived by his team as a surprise tribute that opens Friday.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, when passages of Jay-Z lyrics from songs like “Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)” and “Justify My Thug” appeared on the Art Deco-style, curved limestone facade of the Brooklyn Public Library’s main branch, fans and passers-by could only speculate on the occasion for the building’s sudden makeover. A surprise concert for the rapper’s home borough? A tribute to the 50th anniversary of hip-hop this summer?

headline: A French Music Maker Lost His Voice. A Comedian Helped Get It Back.
abstract: The rap producer known as Pone, who has A.L.S., speaks through a computer that makes him sound robotic. He asked a comic impersonator to try to recapture his distinctive sound.
lead_paragraph: Guilhem Gallart used to speak with a thick, southern French accent, his voice deep and slightly nasal, topped by a faint lisp.

headline: It’s Been a Good Stretch for the Markets, but Not as Good as It Looks
abstract: While stocks, bonds and money market funds have generated positive returns for the year, a quirk in the calendar is creating deceptively strong performances.
lead_paragraph: It has been a fine half year for stocks, money market funds and, to a lesser extent, bonds — so good, in comparison with last year, that you may feel like celebrating when you look at your quarterly portfolio statement.

headline: Hollywood Actors Join in California’s ‘Hot Labor Summer’
abstract: Actors voted to join screenwriters on the picket lines today — the first time since 1960 that both unions have been on strike at the same time.

headline: Water Bills Are Rising. Here’s What to Do About It.
abstract: Consumers face higher costs as water systems replace old pipes and equipment. Shorter showers and water-efficient appliances can help manage the expense.
lead_paragraph: Scorching temperatures blanketing much of the country make cool showers enticing. But beware the water bill.

headline: Two Filmmakers, Two Dramas and the Pain of the Foster-Care System
abstract: The directors of “Earth Mama” and “A Thousand and One” compare notes on complex portraits of Black motherhood that reject ’90s stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: “Earth Mama” opens with a fake-out: a young Black woman named Gia (Tia Nomore) happily tickling a cooing newborn. But as the camera pulls away, a more ambivalent reality is exposed. The baby belongs to an older couple visiting the mall portrait studio to take their family photo, while Gia, very much pregnant, wistfully gazes after them.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 6: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by July 21 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 1.
lead_paragraph: Update, July 28: You can submit your response for Week 8 here.

headline: Louis Langrée Wraps Up a Quietly Transformative Era of Conducting
abstract: With a new job, Langrée is reaching the end of undersung runs with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Rehearsals led by the conductor Louis Langrée tend to follow a trajectory. Early on, he speaks poetically and tells stories; during preparations for a May concert with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, where he is the music director, he explained Saint-Saëns with references to the Kyrie of a Mass and the paintings of Hieronymus Bosch. But then his language becomes technical and specific; that day, broad explanations of mood gave way to meticulous balance and bowing as the playing took shape like an increasingly detailed, fine sculpture.

headline: New York’s Public Theater Lays Off 19 Percent of Its Staff
abstract: The institution, a titan among nonprofit theaters, is suffering from the combined effects of falling revenue and rising costs plaguing the arts world.
lead_paragraph: The Public Theater, one of the nation’s most prestigious and successful nonprofit theaters, laid off 19 percent of its staff on Thursday as a financial crisis sweeps across the field.

headline: Bastille Day Is Usually a Fireworks Bonanza. Not This Year.
abstract: Many French cities canceled their traditional firework shows over a familiar issue in France, social unrest, and a more daunting one, climate change.
lead_paragraph: Bastille Day in France has long been synonymous with grand fireworks displays over towns and villages, as dancing crowds celebrate their nation’s revolutionary birth.

headline: On his stops in Europe, Biden adds to talk of a new Cold War.
abstract: President Biden and his national security team have contended since he took office that all the easy, tempting comparisons between this era and the Cold War are misleading, a vast oversimplification of a complex geopolitical moment.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his national security team have contended since he took office that all the easy, tempting comparisons between this era and the Cold War are misleading, a vast oversimplification of a complex geopolitical moment.

headline: Small Town ‘Tradio’ and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Suspect Arrested in Serial Killings of Women Near Gilgo Beach
abstract: Rex Heuermann, a 59-year-old architect who lives in Nassau County, was charged with killing three women and is the “prime suspect” in the death of a fourth woman.
lead_paragraph: The bodies were unearthed near remote Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore more than a decade ago, terrifying residents and leaving the victims’ families bereft. In all, the remains of nine women, a man and a toddler were discovered.

headline: Israeli Unions and Military Reservists Renew Resistance to Judicial Overhaul
abstract: Labor groups helped delay earlier efforts to limit the top court’s power. As the government revives its plan, powerful social movements are again voicing their opposition and threatening strikes.
lead_paragraph: Union chiefs, business leaders and military reservists in Israel have warned the far-right government that proceeding with its plan to limit judicial powers without a social consensus will open the door for another wave of national strikes and business closures.

headline: Alcohol Poisonings Rise in Iran, Where Bootleggers Defy a Ban
abstract: Iran’s prohibition of the drinking and selling of alcohol has led to a flourishing underground market. But even officials have acknowledged a wave of hospitalizations and deaths in recent months.
lead_paragraph: When a renowned Iranian artist hosted friends at his apartment in Tehran last month, he served, as he did often, a bottle of homemade aragh, a traditional Iranian vodka distilled from raisins, that he had secured from a trusted dealer.

headline: New Heat Wave Descends on Europe, as It Struggles to Adapt
abstract: European governments have been slow to put in place broader mitigation strategies for extreme heat, allowing deaths to increase. This year may be no different.
lead_paragraph: Tourists sheltered under umbrellas as they lined up at Florence’s majestic cathedral this week, looking for shade. Street vendors peddled fans and straw hats. Locals splashed their faces at water fountains, all seeking a respite from Europe’s latest heat wave.

headline: Biden and D.N.C. Announce $72 Million in Fund-Raising, a Substantial Haul
abstract: The figure far surpasses what Donald Trump raised, though it is well short of what Mr. Trump and his allies collected during the same period in the 2020 election cycle.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s campaign announced on Friday a combined fund-raising haul of more than $72 million from April through June alongside the Democratic National Committee and a joint fund-raising committee, a figure that far surpasses what former President Donald J. Trump and other leading Republican presidential candidates have announced.

headline: When You Can’t Believe What You’re Seeing
abstract: The story, more than the sport, is what matters.
lead_paragraph: Nobody is quite sure where the term “kayfabe” originated. It may be a bastardized form of pig Latin, something to do with the actual word “fake.” It may have its roots in the culture of wandering 19th-century carnivals, the world inhabited by P.T. Barnum and the confidence men and the salesmen who sold actual snake oil.

headline: In ‘The League,’ Black Baseball’s Field of Dreams
abstract: Five questions for the director Sam Pollard about his documentary, and the preservation of the history of the Negro leagues.
lead_paragraph: Sam Pollard’s documentary “The League” introduces audiences to the teams, stars and little-known figures who populated the Negro leagues by chronicling how Black professional baseball first sprouted. It covers the period from just before the majors instituted a gentlemen’s agreement banning African Americans from playing with white players, to the Negro leagues becoming one of America’s biggest Black-owned businesses, to its demise.

headline: In U.K. Trial, Kevin Spacey Denies Abusing Position of Power
abstract: Facing accusations of sexual assault, the actor defended himself against multiple claims. He also admitted he got “the signals wrong” during one encounter.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Spacey told a British jury on Friday that some of the sexual assault accusations against him were “pure fantasy” and “absolute bollocks.”

headline: A Victorian Dinosaur Park Finds Its Way in the 21st Century
abstract: Statues of extinct animals peek out from the trees, delighting onlookers in this London park. But don’t expect them to be scientifically accurate.
lead_paragraph: Imagine: It’s 1854. The concept of evolution won’t be introduced for another five years or so. The word dinosaur is only about a decade old. There are no David Attenborough documentaries teaching you about extinct animals.

headline: Butter, Garlic, Spice, Sweetness, Umami and Starch
abstract: Eric Kim’s instant-classic recipe for gochujang buttered noodles is a launching pad for all sorts of improvisations.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Make any recipe more than three or four times and you’re going to change it, either for reasons of taste or expediency, occasionally both. Make that recipe six or seven times and it’s altered forever. It’s no longer the recipe you originally found. It’s yours.

headline: They Put on a Show at Camp, and It Changed Their Lives
abstract: In honor of “Theater Camp,” a new movie about a fictional sleepaway site, we asked Broadway veterans and movie stars for their favorite camp memories.
lead_paragraph: Molly Gordon and Ben Platt met as children at the Adderley School, a theater studio in Los Angeles that runs after-school programs and summer day camps. There are photos and home videos of them starring opposite each other in some very grown-up shows like “Chicago” and “Damn Yankees.” Two decades later — with the help of the actor-writer Noah Galvin, Platt’s fiancé, and the writer-director Nick Lieberman — they have spun those memories of wonky vibrato, stumbling choreography and an ardent sense of belonging into the feature comedy “Theater Camp,” opening Friday.

headline: Trump Employee Warned of Charges in Classified Documents Case
abstract: Prosecutors sent a target letter to a low-level worker at former President Donald J. Trump’s company, suggesting the possibility of indictment and confirming that the investigation is continuing.
lead_paragraph: A low-level employee of the Trump Organization has received a target letter from the special counsel Jack Smith in connection with the investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified documents, suggesting that the employee could face charges and confirming that the broader inquiry continues, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Autoworkers Open Contract Talks in a Fighting Mood
abstract: The U.A.W., with a more confrontational leader, aims to win back wage and benefit concessions and insulate jobs from the rise of electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: The three Detroit automakers and the United Auto Workers union have begun negotiating a new labor contract in what could become the most contentious talks between the two sides in perhaps half a century.

headline: Belarus says some Wagner fighters are training its forces.
abstract: Television news footage of a training exercise involving the Russian mercenaries offered a rare, if vague, glimpse of the group after its failed mutiny last month.
lead_paragraph: Belarus’s Ministry of Defense said Friday that soldiers from Russia’s Wagner military company were training its security forces, offering a rare if vague sign of the group’s presence in the country after its failed uprising against Moscow last month.

headline: U.S. Cluster Munitions Arrive in Ukraine, but Impact on Battlefield Remains Unclear
abstract: U.S. officials and military analysts say the weapons, which are banned by many countries, will ease Ukraine’s artillery ammunition shortage but may not have an immediate impact in the war.
lead_paragraph: U.S. officials and military analysts warn that American-made cluster munitions probably will not immediately help Ukraine in its flagging counteroffensive against Russian defenses as hundreds of thousands of the weapons arrived in the country from U.S. military depots in Europe, according to Pentagon officials.

headline: In Iowa, Pence Is Put on the Spot Over Jan. 6
abstract: An exchange with an Iowa voter who accused the former vice president of putting President Biden in the White House illustrated a larger issue for his 2024 campaign.
lead_paragraph: It was midway through a three-day swing of Iowa for Mike Pence when Luann Bertrand confronted him at a Pizza Ranch.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: From angst-ridden military dads to the threat of doomsday cults, this month’s action picks push their heroes to the edge.
lead_paragraph: Since the even-keeled Jamie (Clayne Crawford), an Army veteran, returned home to New Orleans, times have been difficult: His daughter needs an operation. When his impulsive brother, Mic (Max Martini), approaches him about a bank robbery job, the financial gain becomes too much to ignore.

headline: ‘10 Seconds’: Outrage Follows Acquittal in Italy Abuse Case
abstract: A court in Rome said it had decided to acquit a janitor accused of improperly touching a student in part because the episode lasted “a handful of seconds” and took place in a public area in front of other students.
lead_paragraph: For days, many Italians have flooded social media with two unusual calls to outrage: “#10secondi” and “#palpatabreve,” or “10 seconds” and “brief grope.”

headline: Rick Froberg, Singer of Artful Intensity, Is Dead at 55
abstract: A longtime linchpin of a 1990s underground music scene, he built a devoted and enthusiastic following and was also a prolific visual artist.
lead_paragraph: Rick Froberg, the vocalist and guitarist best known for his work with the influential 1990s post-hardcore band Drive Like Jehu, whose urgent howl was one of rock’s most distinctive voices, died on June 30 in San Diego. He was 55.

headline: George Santos Used New Campaign Cash to Pay Himself Back
abstract: Mr. Santos brought in $179,000 in the most recent quarter and spent much of it repaying loans he made to his campaign, new filings show.
lead_paragraph: Representative George Santos, the New York Republican facing federal criminal charges, raised about $179,000 for his re-election campaign from April through June — a modest sum that he used in large part to pay back money he had lent to his past congressional bids.

headline: Education Dept. Cancels $39 Billion in Student Debt for 800,000 Borrowers
abstract: One-time credits will wipe out loans, fixing mistakes made by loan servicers when collecting payments under income-driven repayment programs.
lead_paragraph: More than 800,000 borrowers will have $39 billion in federal student loan debt eliminated under a government effort to remedy years of mistakes by the loan servicers that collect payments on the government’s behalf.

headline: Seeing the World Like a Character From a Disney Classic
abstract: “Beauty and the Beast,” C.S. Lewis and other classics can offer useful ways of approaching world events, and summer reading.
lead_paragraph: In Disney’s “Beauty and the Beast,” a movie that I’ve loved since childhood, you can tell a lot about people by the way they respond to the enchanted castle. Gaston, the movie’s misogynist boor of a villain, sees a tool to be exploited to sow fear and manipulate others.

headline: Billie Eilish’s Forlorn ‘Barbie’ Ballad, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Troye Sivan, Jamila Woods, C. Tangana and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: 2022-23 Student Opinion Writing Prompts
abstract: A PDF of the Learning Network’s 2022-23 Student Opinion Writing Prompts
lead_paragraph: A PDF of the Learning Network’s 2022-23 Student Opinion Writing Prompts

headline: Little Big Men: ‘The Luckiest Guy in the World’ and ‘Goliath’
abstract: New documentaries explore the star-crossed careers and delicate spirits of Wilt Chamberlain and Bill Walton, two of basketball’s greatest.
lead_paragraph: Pity the poor 7-footer.

headline: Contemporary African Royals, in Regalia and Complexity
abstract: A new photography exhibition at London’s Tate Modern includes images of monarchs from across the continent, steering away from Western imagery.
lead_paragraph: On a wall of London’s Tate Modern, a large photo from 2012 depicts a seated Nigerian king, wearing a green beaded hat and a lavish robe with a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II printed on the front.

headline: The Big Number: 160,000
abstract: The union representing television and movie actors is on strike, joining screenwriters on the picket lines and creating Hollywood's first shutdown in 63 years.
lead_paragraph: The union representing television and movie actors is on strike, joining screenwriters on the picket lines and creating Hollywood's first shutdown in 63 years.

headline: The Climate Protesters and the Museums
abstract: When protesters attack art in museums. Also: Justice Clarence Thomas and friends; the Ukraine war; A.I. and doctors; cheering for losing teams.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump Seeks Court Order to Quash Investigation in Georgia
abstract: Lawyers for the former president asked the state’s highest court to throw out the work of a special grand jury that investigated 2020 election interference and recommended indictments.
lead_paragraph: In his latest legal maneuver, Donald J. Trump sought a court order on Friday that would throw out the work of an Atlanta special grand jury and disqualify Fani T. Willis, the prosecutor leading an investigation into election interference in Georgia.

headline: How Kristine Hayes Got Retirement Ready
How Kristine Hayes Got Retirement Ready
How David Oscarson Got Retirement Ready
The Weekender
abstract: The end of the magic world's 50-year grudge. Also in this edition: a boardjacking sea otter and how to sleep better at every age.
lead_paragraph: The end of the magic world's 50-year grudge. Also in this edition: a boardjacking sea otter and how to sleep better at every age.

headline: Three Big Banks Rake In Better-Than-Expected Profits
abstract: Three of the biggest banks in the United States made a cumulative $22.3 billion in profit last quarter, a hefty jump from the same period last year.
lead_paragraph: Three of the biggest banks in the United States made a cumulative $22.3 billion in profit last quarter, a hefty jump from the same period last year, the lenders reported Friday.

headline: Newly Published, From Nuclear Close Calls to Hollywood’s Greatest Love Affair
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: ANAÏS NIN: A Sea of Lies, by Léonie Bischoff. Translated by Jenna Allen. (Fantagraphics, $29.99.) The writer’s exploration of her sensual inner life — “few know how many women live inside of me,” she says — is gorgeously rendered by Bischoff in rich, undulating, jewel-toned color pencil illustrations.

headline: Little by Little, Pogacar Gains on Vingegaard at the Tour de France
abstract: An incremental strategy closes the gap but doesn’t change the yellow jersey, for now.
lead_paragraph: Tadej Pogacar gained a little more time on Jonas Vingegaard in the Tour de France on Friday, preferring to chip away at the reigning champion’s lead rather than making one huge move to grab the yellow jersey — and maybe clinch the Tour.

headline: Wonking Out: In Economics, a Game of Teams
abstract: Were we all equally wrong, or were some more equal than others?
lead_paragraph: HBO may have captivated millions with its series “Game of Thrones,” but economists have lately captivated, well, not millions — maybe a few hundred nerds — with their Games of Teams: noisy and sometimes testy public disputes between opposing factions over economic prospects.

headline: What’s in a Screenshot?
abstract: Leaked text messages list the “boundaries for romantic partnership.”
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, Sarah Brady, a semiprofessional surfer, posted a number of screenshots of text messages she claims she exchanged with her then-boyfriend, the actor Jonah Hill. In one of the texts, Hill appears to dictate a highly specific list of “boundaries for romantic partnership,” which included not surfing with men, not maintaining friendships with “women who are in unstable places” and not posting pictures of herself in a bathing suit.

headline: 4 Easy Dishes That Embrace Everyday Vegetables
abstract: These vegetarian recipes transform affordable produce and pantry staples into spectacular dishes.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible to separate vegetables from seasonality — especially at the height of summer — but you can be liberated from the anxiety of cooking certain vegetables at specific times of the year. Eat seasonally if you can, but don’t stress if you can’t. There are enough causes of angst in the world; finding vegetables should not be one of them.

headline: Strike Prevents Actors From Promoting Films at Premieres or Festivals
abstract: While on strike, actors are barred from publicizing any studio projects they’ve appeared in. Their absence could affect movie theaters and the festival circuit.
lead_paragraph: It has already been a difficult year for movie theaters, with the North American box office down roughly 20 percent from last year. And that was when actors could promote their films.

headline: Blending Dance and Sculpture Creates a Fresh View of Art
abstract: An exhibition at the Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia is one of several recent projects using the two forms to explore how people interact with art.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago artist Brendan Fernandes doesn’t need his work to fit neatly into one category. “People ask, ‘Is it a prop? Is it a sculpture? Is it an artwork?’ And I’m like, ‘It’s all those things,’” he said recently by phone.

headline: Listening to Beyoncé’s ‘Renaissance’ References
abstract: A tour through key samples, references and influences on the pop star’s 2022 album as her world tour arrives in North America.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, I traveled to Toronto to catch the first North American date of Beyoncé’s Renaissance World Tour. I returned home feeling like the human incarnation of the starry-eyed emoji (so many sparkles!) and with a new appreciation for “Renaissance,” the loose and sprawling album that Beyoncé released this time last year.

headline: Andy Cruz, Amateur Legend, to Find Out if Pro Boxing Fits
abstract: Cruz left Cuba to chase his dream to be a professional boxer (and be paid like one). His first fight, against Juan Carlos Burgos, should help him learn how he compares with other contenders.
lead_paragraph: Andy Cruz and Juan Carlos Burgos squared off and locked eyes on a stage set up in a hotel ballroom in downtown Detroit, and did what boxers usually do when they stand face to face.

headline: Margot Robbie And Ryan Gosling Are Bringing “Barbie” to the Big Screen
Writers Where They Work
abstract: Bookshelves, typewriters, pills and booze: Writing spaces can evoke romance, glamour and despair at once.
lead_paragraph: Helen Gurley Brown, the longtime editor of Cosmopolitan magazine and author of books including “Sex and the Single Girl,” at home in New York in 1979. In a 2012 opinion essay for The New York Times, Jamie Brickhouse recalled that Brown was “thoroughly modern, but not contemporary when it came to email. Letters — typed or handwritten — were her preferred way of communicating.”

headline: A Timeline of Events in the Gilgo Beach Serial Killings
abstract: The Suffolk County police found 11 bodies in all while searching for an aspiring actress who disappeared in 2010. No arrest was made in connection with the killings until now.
lead_paragraph: An architect who had lived most of his life in Nassau County and worked in Manhattan was arrested on Thursday night in connection with the killings of four women near Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore. The discovery of their bodies and seven others in 2010 and 2011 terrified residents and the case remained unsolved for more than a decade.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Including memoirs by Charles McGrath and Doreen Cunningham, fiction by Jamil Jan Kochai, Alexis Schaitkin and more.
lead_paragraph: Including memoirs by Charles McGrath and Doreen Cunningham, fiction by Jamil Jan Kochai, Alexis Schaitkin and more.

headline: My Salary Is Too High. Is It Wrong to Stay in My Job?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what makes fair compensation.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, I switched from a job at a nonprofit whose mission I was deeply passionate about to a more senior role at a nonprofit in a different sector. I was very underpaid previously and nearly doubled my salary in this new role. Because this role is outside my field of expertise, however, my job satisfaction is not nearly as high as it was in my previous job.

headline: A Climate Hawk’s Issues With Electric Vehicles
abstract: Toyota is notoriously skeptical of a rapid transition to all-electric E.V.s. It may have a point.
lead_paragraph: I get why the Biden administration is pushing electric vehicles so hard. To stop the planet from overheating, we’ll eventually need motor vehicles to produce zero greenhouse gas emissions, and only fully electric vehicles can do that. Hybrids, which have combustion engines along with electric motors, will always puff some carbon dioxide (and other bad stuff) out of their tailpipes.

headline: Biden Switches Up His Big-Money Operation Ahead of 2024
abstract: The president and his advisers are elevating a new super PAC, Future Forward, as their leading outside group to rake in cash from his wealthiest benefactors.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his advisers are elevating a new outside group as the leading super PAC to help re-elect him in 2024, making it the top destination for large sums of cash from supportive billionaires and multimillionaires.

headline: How Manga Was Translated for America
abstract: The wildly popular Japanese genre is now published close to its original form in the United States. That wasn’t always the case.
lead_paragraph: The wildly popular Japanese genre is now published close to its original form in the United States. That wasn’t always the case.

headline: Actors Picket From Coast to Coast as Strike Gets Underway
abstract: In Los Angeles and New York, actors and screenwriters braved the heat to admonish the major studios and demand a new deal.
lead_paragraph: It was 10 a.m., adoring union members had already more or less mobbed their president, Fran Drescher, and the crowd was growing by the minute.

headline: Review: In ‘The Saviour,’ Past Trauma Is Very Much Present
abstract: The gravitational pull of the hurts of yesteryear is on vivid display in Deirdre Kinahan’s drama at Irish Repertory Theater.
lead_paragraph: Back stories can be dangerous things. A character besotted with them — especially reductive trauma-filled ones — colludes in her own miniaturization.

headline: Ex-New York Resident Sentenced to Life in Prison for Helping ISIS
abstract: Mirsad Kandic, a Kosovo native who had lived in New York before traveling to ISIS territory, was found guilty last year of conspiracy and of providing material support to the group.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, Mirsad Kandic began working with the Islamic State, helping to advance its campaign of global jihad.

headline: How to Mix and Match Your Sheets
abstract: There's no rule that your sheets have to match.
lead_paragraph: There's no rule that your sheets have to match.

headline: The Year Is Half Over. Here Are the Books You Might Have Missed.
abstract: A look back at 2023’s buzziest titles so far.
lead_paragraph: This week on the podcast, Gilbert Cruz is joined by fellow editors from the Book Review to revisit some of the most popular and most acclaimed books of 2023 to date. First up, Tina Jordan and Elisabeth Egan discuss the year’s biggest books, from “Spare” to “Birnam Wood.” Then Joumana Khatib, MJ Franklin and Sadie Stein recommend their personal favorites of the year so far.

headline: Putin wants to travel to South Africa next month. The host country would prefer he didn’t.
abstract: An arrest warrant for the Russian leader from the International Criminal Court has created a diplomatic quandary ahead of an August summit.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is pushing ahead with plans to attend a summit in South Africa next month, even as the host nation grapples with diplomatic and legal fallout of his expected presence, South Africa’s deputy president said on Friday.

headline: My Unexpected Love Affair With ‘Notre Dame de Paris’
abstract: One reporter is hooked on the French spectacle that mixes acrobatics with a rock opera score.
lead_paragraph: It seemed as if nothing would ever displace “The Phantom of the Opera” as my most-viewed musical.

headline: The Maverick Design Choices That May Have Doomed Titan
abstract: Engineers interviewed by The New York Times pointed out several weak points in Titan that were cost-saving departures from proven submersible designs.
lead_paragraph: Engineers interviewed by The New York Times pointed out several weak points in Titan that were cost-saving departures from proven submersible designs.

headline: Review: Rennie Harris’s Hip-Hop Dance Mixtape
abstract: The choreographer and his Puremovement troupe brought their touring show, “Nuttin’ but a Word,” to Prospect Park for BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn!
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the opening set at BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn! on Thursday, the rapper and performance poet Decora dedicated a song to a man he called a mentor: the folk singer Pete Seeger. The song, played by a full band with horns and electric guitar, was a riff on Seeger’s “Where Have All the Flowers Gone?”

headline: What We Know About the Gilgo Beach Victims
abstract: Rex Heuermann was accused of killing three women and is the prime suspect in the death of a fourth. All were found in the same spot, wrapped in burlap.
lead_paragraph: The three women that Rex Heuermann is accused of killing — Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman and Amber Lynn Costello — were discovered wrapped in burlap near Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore in December 2010.

headline: Students, What Questions About Paying for College Can We Answer?
abstract: We hope to tackle some essential queries — but we need your help.
lead_paragraph: The college admissions process is a fraught one, to put it mildly. But there is one subject that often dominates the discussion: paying for college.

headline: Iowa Governor Signs Six-Week Abortion Ban Into Law
abstract: Gov. Kim Reynolds had vowed to approve the ban, which was being challenged in court as she signed it.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa, a Republican, signed a strict abortion ban into law on Friday, even as a judge heard arguments to suspend it.

headline: How Taylor Swift’s ‘Speak Now’ Became the ‘Scary’ Version
abstract: A fan thought she had ordered a new vinyl pressing of the pop star’s album. But what came out of the speakers was entirely different.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Hunter could not wait to play her new vinyl recording of Taylor Swift’s “Speak Now.”

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Tom Hanks
abstract: The July 14, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Tom Hanks. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Visitors Are Briefly Trapped at Former Home of Agatha Christie
abstract: In a moment of literary irony, visitors were stranded at Greenway House, where the mystery novelist once lived, when a fallen tree blocked the road.
lead_paragraph: In “And Then There Were None,” the classic novel by Agatha Christie, 10 people are invited to a mansion on a remote island, cut off from the rest of the world. A mystery follows.

headline: Love Letter: A Second Skin to Escape Racism
abstract: Tired of encountering overt racism while dating, a Korean American man finds liberation in latex.
lead_paragraph: “On gay dating apps, East Asians routinely face dehumanization that reduces us to nothing more than featureless clones in the eyes of others,” Preston Gyuwon So writes in this week’s Modern Love essay.

headline: Despite Aspartame Warning, Beverage Companies Likely to Stick With It
abstract: A health agency warned the artificial sweetener may be a carcinogen, but others say that risk is overblown and consumers flock to the taste.
lead_paragraph: About eight years ago, in response to customer concerns about possible health risks associated with the artificial sweetener aspartame, PepsiCo decided to remove the ingredient from its popular diet soda.

headline: Do You Qualify for Biden’s $39 Billion Student Debt Cancellation?
abstract: The Education Department announced that more than 800,000 borrowers would see their debt eliminated thanks to fixes made to its income-driven repayment programs.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of borrowers with federal student loans are probably wondering: Is my debt load about to get a little lighter?

headline: No One Can Needle Tom Cruise Like Henry Czerny Can
abstract: A star of the first “Mission: Impossible” film makes a welcome return 25 years later, bringing a delight in exposition that few actors can match.
lead_paragraph: “Mission: Impossible” is a franchise known for its big-budget, death-defying stunts, but sometimes there’s nothing more suspenseful than a good old-fashioned, face-to-face staredown.

headline: The House Passes a Defense Bill Limiting Abortion Access
abstract: Also, actors started picketing. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans, under pressure from a faction of far-right lawmakers, narrowly passed a deeply partisan defense bill today that would limit abortion access, transgender care and diversity training for military personnel. Speaker Kevin McCarthy celebrated it as an effort to force the Biden administration to “stop using taxpayer money to do their own wokeism.”

headline: Jesse Jackson to Step Down From Rainbow PUSH Coalition
abstract: A successor to Mr. Jackson, the civil rights leader, will be announced at the group’s convention this weekend. Mr. Jackson, 81, announced in 2017 that he had Parkinson’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr., the longtime civil rights leader and former Democratic presidential candidate, plans to step down as president of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, the organization he founded, the group said in a statement on Friday.

headline: U.S. Virgin Islands Seeks $190 Million From JPMorgan in Epstein Lawsuit
abstract: The U.S. territory wants JPMorgan to pay damages for failing to spot Jeffrey Epstein’s activities on the island.
lead_paragraph: The government of the U.S. Virgin Islands said in a court filing on Friday that it is seeking at least $190 million in penalties from JPMorgan Chase for the bank’s failure to detect and report the sex trafficking operation run by the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein in the U.S. territory.

headline: Vulnerable Republicans Take a Political Risk With Abortion Vote
abstract: In uniting his party behind a defense bill loaded with social policy restrictions, Speaker Kevin McCarthy has raised questions over whether his short-term victory could imperil his majority.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jen Kiggans, a minivan-driving mom and Navy veteran, narrowly won election last year in her suburban Virginia swing district after a fiercely competitive race that focused on her opposition to abortion rights.

headline: John Uelses, First to Pole-Vault 16 Feet, Is Dead at 85
abstract: In an era when track and field athletes could rise to national celebrity, Uelses became a newsreel idol and made the cover of Sports Illustrated.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s and ’60s, track and field athletes could become models on Wheaties boxes, stars on television and objects of fascination to the news media. There were Bob Richards, an ordained minister and pole-vaulter nicknamed the Vaulting Vicar, and Dick Fosbury, a high jumper whose distinctive leap became renowned as the Fosbury Flop.

headline: Tucker Carlson Turns a Christian Presidential Forum Into a Putin Showcase
abstract: The Iowa evangelical leader Bob Vander Plaats gathered Republican White House hopefuls in Des Moines, then gave Tucker Carlson the microphone.
lead_paragraph: Bob Vander Plaats, the conservative evangelical kingmaker in Iowa politics, now knows what happens when you turn over your Republican presidential showcase to Tucker Carlson.

headline: Novak Djokovic Relaxes, and Lands in Another Wimbledon Final
abstract: The 23-time Grand Slam champion may have mellowed, but he is as determined as ever to win his favorite title again. He will play Carlos Alcaraz on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Six months ago, having just won the Australian Open one year after being deported from the country, Novak Djokovic collapsed in the arms of his family and his coaches in a moment of strained ecstasy.

headline: Hollywood Productions Grind to a Halt as Actors Go on Strike
abstract: SAG-AFTRA members voted to walk out after contract negotiations with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers stalled.
lead_paragraph: SAG-AFTRA members voted to walk out after contract negotiations with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers stalled.

headline: Social Media Restrictions on Biden Officials Are Paused in Appeal
abstract: A Fifth Circuit panel temporarily lifted a judge’s order that had blocked the administration from contacting platforms about most of their content.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Friday paused a judge’s order that had blocked much of the Biden administration from talking to social media sites about content.

headline: Pence Raises Just $1.2 Million, Aides Say, in Worrying Sign for 2024 Bid
abstract: The notably low figure raised new doubts about Republican voters’ enthusiasm for the former vice president, as well as questions about whether he will qualify for the first G.O.P. debate.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence has raised a paltry $1.2 million for his presidential campaign, according to two campaign aides, a sum that raises dire questions about Republicans’ appetite for Mr. Pence in 2024.

headline: University of Tennessee Fined Millions for Cash Payments to Athletes
abstract: The N.C.A.A. said Tennessee had a culture of wrongful payments to athletes, including cash for hotels, meals and car payments, among other things. The university was fined $8 million but avoided a postseason ban.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. punished the University of Tennessee football program for recruiting violations and direct cash payments to athletes, imposing an $8 million fine and taking away scholarships for what it described as a culture of brazenly skirting rules in hopes of chasing wins.

headline: André Watts, Pioneering Piano Virtuoso, Dies at 77
abstract: One of the first Black superstars in classical music, he awed audiences with his charisma and his technical powers.
lead_paragraph: André Watts, a pianist whose mighty technique and magnetic charm awed audiences and made him one of the first Black superstars in classical music, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 77.

headline: For Years, Quiet Gilgo Beach Was a Place of ‘Murders and Mayhem’
abstract: The arrest of a man charged in three of the killings brought a sense of safety to a community long accustomed to being on edge.
lead_paragraph: For a killer looking to hide evidence of his crimes, it was the perfect spot. The straight, quiet stretch of Ocean Parkway would give him plenty of time to listen and watch for coming cars. Just off the road, a tall bramble of bushes and weeds grew so thick and thorny, even trained cadaver-sniffing dogs could barely penetrate it.

headline: Northwestern Fires Baseball Coach Amid Turmoil Over Culture in Athletics
abstract: Jim Foster had been the team’s head coach for a season. His firing came days after the university fired Pat Fitzgerald, its longtime football coach.
lead_paragraph: Northwestern University on Thursday fired Jim Foster, its head baseball coach, just three days after firing its longtime football coach amid a hazing scandal, deepening concerns over a toxic culture in the university’s athletics.

headline: Wagner Troops Can Keep Fighting, but Without Prigozhin, Putin Says
abstract: As Russia’s president reasserts control after a failed mutiny, he wants to sideline the Wagner leader while keeping its fighters — who have started training troops in Belarus — working for him.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after a brief mutiny in Russia by the Wagner mercenary group, President Vladimir V. Putin said its troops could keep fighting, but without their controversial leader, while the government of Belarus said some Wagner fighters were there, training its forces.

headline: An Oasis in the Middle of a Scorching Texas Summer
abstract: Barton Springs, whose cool, natural waters have created summer memories for generations in Austin, Texas, has become an important refuge during the current heat wave.
lead_paragraph: It was six o’clock on Friday morning, at least 15 minutes before dawn over Texas’ capital city, and scores of vehicles had already crowded into the parking lot at Barton Springs Pool, a few miles — and in some ways, an entire world — from the lighted skyscrapers of downtown.

headline: Without Hollywood, What Happens to Los Angeles?
abstract: With actors and screenwriters on strike, Hollywood is shut down for the foreseeable future. Los Angeles isn’t a pure company town, but the industry is inextricable from the city in many ways.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles County has 88 cities. Ten million people. Two hundred-plus languages spoken.

headline: The Case Against Rex Heuermann: Read the Document
abstract: Suffolk County, N.Y., prosecutors argued against bail for Mr. Heuermann in a 32-page document that explicitly details the investigation into the Gilgo Beach killings. The New York Times has redacted phone numbers, email addresses, personal addresses and the names of private social media accounts. It has also redacted offensive material that was included in Mr. Heuermann’s internet searches.
lead_paragraph: Suffolk County, N.Y., prosecutors argued against bail for Mr. Heuermann in a 32-page document that explicitly details the investigation into the Gilgo Beach killings. The New York Times has redacted phone numbers, email addresses, personal addresses and the names of private social media accounts. It has also redacted offensive material that was included in Mr. Heuermann’s internet searches.

headline: Women React to News About an Over-the-Counter Birth Control Pill
abstract: Most potential consumers were excited by the prospect, though sticker price and safety were lingering concerns.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Food and Drug Administration approved a hormonal birth control pill, called Opill, to be sold over the counter — a landmark decision that was largely received with excitement by many women and teenage girls in New York. The pill will be sold in stores and online, without age restrictions, beginning early next year.

headline: Where Spies Work
abstract: Jeff Chen’s themeless grid is stacked with surprises.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Jeff Chen is a prolific constructor who collaborates with seemingly everyone in the puzzleverse, including Jim Horne on the indispensable crossword statistics site xwordinfo.com. This is his first solo Saturday grid since 2017; its design is complex (with unusual left-right mirror symmetry), and there’s a ton of wild fill, as one would expect from a guru.

headline: South Korea’s Monsoon Rains Set Off Deadly Landslides and Flooding
abstract: With at least 40 people dead, the current monsoon season is already proving to be a particularly dangerous one in South Korea, with rain forecast to continue.
lead_paragraph: Four more bodies were recovered from a flooded highway underpass in South Korea, officials reported Monday, bringing the death toll in the recent floods to at least 40. The country has been reeling from intense rainfall from the monsoon, which has swept across the nation in recent days, burying homes, knocking down trees, canceling flights and trains, and cutting power to tens of thousands of residents.

headline: Quotation of the Day: U.A.W. Talks Quite Likely to Be Testy
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 15, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We are seeing in very diverse workplaces a new interest in unions and a willingness to strike. What we don’t know yet is how large this movement is going to become and how far it is going to go.”

headline: Corrections: July 15, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 15, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about federal prosecutors’ inquiry into President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election misstated who first made public a recording of Stephen Bannon, a former adviser to Mr. Trump, telling associates that Mr. Trump was going to summarily declare he had won. The recording was first reported by Mother Jones, not the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: What to Watch in the 2024 Money Wars as a Big Deadline Arrives
abstract: Which presidential and Senate candidates are swimming in cash? Which ones are growing desperate? That and more is becoming clearer on Saturday, when campaigns must file their latest federal reports.
lead_paragraph: The financial landscape of the 2024 presidential race — the contest’s haves and have-nots, their momentum and desperation — is coming into sharper focus on Saturday, the deadline for campaigns to file their latest reports to the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Carlos Alcaraz Gets a Shot at Novak Djokovic in Wimbledon Singles Final
abstract: “For Novak, it is one more day, one more moment,” Alcaraz said of Sunday’s final. “For me, it’s going to be the best moment of my life, I think.”
lead_paragraph: If Carlos Alcaraz were more patient, perhaps he could just wait for Novak Djokovic to fade away. At 20, Alcaraz is 16 years younger than the great champion, and the day is likely to come when Djokovic is either retired or in decline, and Alcaraz can claim the tennis kingdom as his own.

headline: Suspect in Gilgo Beach Killings Led a Life of Chaos and Control
abstract: Rex Heuermann was painstaking in his Manhattan professional pursuits. At home in Massapequa Park, he left neighbors discomfited.
lead_paragraph: At his office near the Empire State Building, Rex Heuermann was a master of the meticulous: a veteran architectural consultant and a self-styled expert at navigating the intricacies of New York City’s building code. He impressed some clients and drove others crazy with his fine-toothed directives.

headline: New York Has $1.1 Billion to Fight Flooding. Will It Be Enough?
abstract: “It’s kind of like we’re patching the boat but it’s already filling up with water,” one climate researcher said.
lead_paragraph: For Franco Montalto, a flooding expert and engineer, decades of research were suddenly amplified by a real-life emergency in the Adirondacks, where he and his family were on vacation this week.

headline: The Gilgo Beach Victims Were Always More Than Escorts
abstract: From the beginning, the women who were found murdered were reduced to being prostitutes. More than a decade after they went missing, that seems to have changed.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, on the Monday after Easter in 2011, on a gray afternoon in New London, Conn., Melissa Cann sat at a picnic table on a pier, talking about her big sister, Maureen Brainard-Barnes, who disappeared on a trip to Manhattan four years earlier. While Ms. Cann described herself as a homebody, she said that her older sister was a free spirit, artistic, daring and often clashing with their mother. Maureen had worked as a blackjack dealer, as a clerk at a ShopRite and, in the six months or so before she vanished, as an escort.

headline: How a Master of Japanese Ink Painting Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Koho Yamamoto studied her art in an internment camp for Japanese Americans during World War II and then opened a school. At 101, she still finds time to teach.
lead_paragraph: “People keep making me older every day,” said Masako Yamamoto, who is 101. “I don’t remember my age anymore, so I’m surprised when people say how old I am.”

headline: Why Sunscreen Is the Only Anti-Aging Product You Need
abstract: The sun’s rays cause the majority of skin changes as you grow older. Here’s how sunscreen helps prevent the damage.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever looked at the skin on the buttocks of a 90-year-old? Dr. Fayne Frey has. “It’s beautiful,” said the dermatologist and author of the book “The Skincare Hoax.” “There’s very little pigment, there’s very little wrinkling, there are very few blood vessels.”

headline: Rent-Controlled vs. Rent-Stabilized: How Much Can a Landlord Charge?
abstract: Owners of the city’s roughly 16,000 rent-controlled homes can raise the rent, but only so often, and only by so much.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a rent-controlled apartment on the Upper West Side, and I’d like to know what the rent increase will be this year. I have read a lot about the increases for rent-stabilized apartments issued by New York’s Rent Guidelines Board, but for not rent-controlled apartments. Is there an increase, and will it be retroactive? Will we receive formal notice from a government agency, or is a note from the landlord enough?

headline: Tiffany Haddish Dances to the Beat of Her Never-Ending Internal Soundtrack
abstract: The actress employs grapeseed oil for rough skin and an Eddie Murphy classic for rough days.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Tiffany Haddish plays a marijuana-smoking cat (“The Freak Brothers”), a detective pulled out of retirement (“The Afterparty”), a psychic in a film based on a Disneyland ride (“Haunted Mansion”) and the mother of a child who broadcasts his love life to aliens (“Landscape With Invisible Hand”). For her, the mom is the most relatable.

headline: America’s Foreign Vacations Tell Us Something About the U.S. Economy
abstract: Prices are high, but Americans are opening their wallets for international flights and hotels. It’s the latest evidence of consumer resilience.
lead_paragraph: Forget Emily. These days, a whole flood of Americans are in Paris.

headline: Can A.I. Invent?
abstract: A group of legal experts are pressing patent agencies, courts and policymakers to address the question as generative A.I. seems on the brink of invading another uniquely human endeavor.
lead_paragraph: Generative artificial intelligence, the technology engine powering the popular ChatGPT chatbot, seems to have a limitless bag of tricks. It can produce on command everything from recipes and vacation plans to computer code and molecules for new drugs.

headline: The U.S. and China Are Restarting Climate Talks: Here’s Where Things Stand
abstract: John Kerry travels to Beijing for three days of talks, as the world’s two biggest economies, and two biggest polluters, try to cooperate on climate action.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a year, talks between the planet’s two biggest polluters, China and the United States, have been suspended as the impacts of global warming have only grown more intense in the form of deadly heat, drought, floods and wildfires.

headline: How a Rocky, Inhospitable Place Became a Beacon of Calm
abstract: In “Returning Light,” Robert L. Harris reflects on his many years as the caretaker of a lonely outpost off the west coast of Ireland.
lead_paragraph: When he first comes upon the advertisement for a job opening on a remote island eight miles off the coast of western Ireland, Robert L. Harris is already primed for sublimity. Visiting a friend in the area in 1985, two years earlier, he and his wife had impulsively joined a small group of tourists heading to Skellig Michael. As the boat nears the island, seabirds wheel in the sky, and everything changes:

headline: Furby, Is That You?
abstract: The animatronic toy got a makeover. It’s getting mixed reviews.
lead_paragraph: The original Furby, released in 1998, had the head of an owl, the beak of a chicken, the feet of a cat, the ears of a pig, the fur of a rabbit, the mohawk of a tufted titmouse and the eyes of a robot, which it was — a robot that whirred, clacked, spoke a made-up language called Furbish and, famously, never turned off (unless its batteries were removed).

headline: Was She Murdered? Kidnapped? Or Did She Fake Her Own Disappearance?
abstract: In Polly Stewart’s novel, “The Good Ones,” a professor investigates what happened when her best friend vanished 20 years earlier.
lead_paragraph: This month’s books all feature women making bad decisions — about themselves, about other people and about how to confront the threats swirling around them. Each is unwise in her own interesting way.

headline: In Hollywood, the Strikes Are Just Part of the Problem
abstract: The entertainment industry is trying to figure out the economics of streaming. It’s also facing angst over a tech-powered future and fighting to stay culturally dominant.
lead_paragraph: Existential hand-wringing has always been part of Hollywood’s personality. But the crisis in which the entertainment capital now finds itself is different.

headline: ‘For the Love of the Water’: Tours for the Swimming-Obsessed
abstract: Swimming island to island in the Adriatic, gliding over coral reefs in the Caribbean, dipping into Iceland’s freezing waters and steamy hot springs: Travel companies are building entire tours around organized swims.
lead_paragraph: During the pandemic, when Miriam Leitko couldn’t swim because pools were closed, the lifelong swimmer built a lap pool at her home in Willis, Texas. As soon as travel restrictions were lifted in 2021, she signed up for a weeklong trip to Hawaii with SwimVacation, a Maine-based tour operator that specializes in open-water swimming.

headline: Barbie: A Visual Dictionary
abstract: The things that make Barbie Barbie.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve heard there’s a Barbie movie coming out?

headline: They Put Down Roots In Small-Town Vermont. Then the River Reared Up.
abstract: Bex Prasse and Craig Kovalsky had worked nearly a year to restore a rundown building so they could open a gourmet deli. The river behind it had other plans.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a year, Bex Prasse and Craig Kovalsky had labored to restore every inch of the run-down building where they envisioned their future business, on an up-and-coming Main Street in the small Vermont ski town of Ludlow.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, July 8-14
abstract: No amount of exhortation could help with this week’s toughest word.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: They Lost Their Legs. Doctors and Health Care Giants Profited.
abstract: Medical device makers have bankrolled a cottage industry of doctors and clinics that perform artery-clearing procedures that can lead to amputations.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Hanna’s leg was amputated on a summer day in 2020, after a Michigan doctor who called himself the “leg saver” had damaged her arteries by snaking metal wires through them to clear away plaque.

headline: After Suffering Heavy Losses, Ukrainians Paused to Rethink Strategy
abstract: Early in the counteroffensive, Ukraine lost as much as 20 percent of its weapons and armor. The rate dropped as the campaign slowed and commanders shifted tactics.
lead_paragraph: In the first two weeks of Ukraine’s grueling counteroffensive, as much as 20 percent of the weaponry it sent to the battlefield was damaged or destroyed, according to American and European officials. The toll includes some of the formidable Western fighting machines — tanks and armored personnel carriers — the Ukrainians were counting on to beat back the Russians.

headline: His Sexuality Doesn’t Define Him, but It Can Set Him Apart
abstract: Eric Bach is an openly gay broadcaster for the Fredericksburg Nationals. He has major league aspirations, but his path has been much lonelier than he would prefer.
lead_paragraph: The hateful email was a surprise, but for Eric Bach, it was not entirely unexpected.

headline: Honoring Tradition, and Personal Choice, With a Persian Wedding Custom
abstract: The Sofreh Aghd is a symbolic wedding display that involves a variety of rituals. But many couples are choosing to add their own modern twist.
lead_paragraph: Weddings are steeped in tradition, but where do those rituals come from? “Traditions,” a new column, explores the origins of various wedding customs from around the world.

headline: Canadian Politicians Who Criticize China Become Its Targets
abstract: As China increases its reach in diaspora communities, Chinese Canadian politicians in Vancouver are the focus of Chinese state interference in Canadian politics.
lead_paragraph: The polls predicted a re-election victory, maybe even a landslide.

headline: ‘Not for Machines to Harvest’: Data Revolts Break Out Against A.I.
abstract: Fed up with A.I. companies consuming online content without consent, fan fiction writers, actors, social media companies and news organizations are among those rebelling.
lead_paragraph: For more than 20 years, Kit Loffstadt has written fan fiction exploring alternate universes for “Star Wars” heroes and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” villains, sharing her stories free online.

headline: In the Land of Football, a Cricket Oasis Rises Outside Houston
abstract: The game of cricket has taken hold in Texas’ largest city, as a culture of sports competition meets a growing South Asian population.
lead_paragraph: Drive northwest out of Houston, and as cow pastures wrestle back the flat expanse from the city’s tentacled sprawl, there arise along the road, suddenly, improbably, many, many cricket fields.

headline: To Entice Women to Racing, the F1 Academy Picks Up Where the W Series Left Off
abstract: The academy is another attempt to get women into Formula 1 in various roles, but also behind the wheel.
lead_paragraph: It has been 47 years since a woman drove in a Formula 1 Grand Prix, when Lella Lombardi of Italy finished 12th at the Austrian Grand Prix in 1976.

headline: Russian Forces Are Doing ‘Everything They Can’ to Stop Counteroffensive, Zelensky Says
abstract: The Ukrainian leader has secured new weapons pledges, but it was not clear when the aid would arrive, or how consequential it would be on the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that Russian forces were throwing “everything they can” at Kyiv’s troops fighting to retake land in the south and east, again emphasizing the grueling nature of a counteroffensive that is moving more slowly than some allies had hoped and later stressing the importance of their continued support.

headline: Frank Gehry Returns to the Streets of His Canadian Childhood
abstract: The renowned architect was back in Toronto for the start of construction on his second project in the city where he was born and raised.
lead_paragraph: Frank Gehry, the architect whose free-form Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, redefined architecture and set off a surge in museum construction in the late 1990s, was recently back in Toronto, celebrating the beginning of a new project.

headline: Listen Early to This American Life: The Florida Experiment
abstract: What’s it like in Ron DeSantis’s Florida?
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Reconsidering the Staycation
abstract: You don’t necessarily have to travel to experience the benefits of a summer vacation.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always been skeptical of the staycation. The coinage is too cute for what feels like a consolation prize: While other people are off exploring the Blue Lagoon by camper van, you get to stay in your very own home and go to your usual supermarket for Cheerios!

headline: At the University of Chicago: Was It Free Speech, or Harassment?
abstract: Readers react to a conservative student’s attempts to shut down a course called “The Problem of Whiteness.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: You’re Not Imagining It: Social Media Is in Chaos
abstract: It is a sign that the industry is undergoing a major shift.
lead_paragraph: War is breaking out on social media, and it could radically change how the internet works and how we experience it.

headline: Amanda Gorman: In Memory of Those Still in the Water
abstract: By writing an elegy through the words of history, I hope to unearth, or unwater, the dead from beneath a mass of waves.
lead_paragraph: On June 14, 2023, the migrant boat Adriana capsized off the coast of Greece, killing more than 600 men, women and children who had been crammed onboard the trawler by traffickers. As investigations by the BBC and The New York Times have revealed, officials and coast guard crews failed to treat the crisis as a rescue mission until the last few hours.

headline: Watch Out for the Fake Tom Cruise
abstract: Hollywood is about to get even more phony!
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the 2002 movie “Simone,” Al Pacino plays a director whose star, played by Winona Ryder, walks out on him after saying her trailer on set isn’t grand enough.

headline: How to Break a Country
abstract: A road trip through Eastern Europe underscores how Putin has diminished Russia.
lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — Vladimir Putin has compared himself to the czar Peter the Great. But to travel through Eastern Europe is to see how much he has instead caused Russian influence to shrink.

headline: Summer Birthdays, Casablanca and Boreal Forests
abstract: A critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: And Just Like That, Everyone Is Part of the 1 Percent
abstract: “Sex and the City” explored complications of work, money and identity that are missing from the reboot.
lead_paragraph: In honor of the 25th anniversary of the debut of “Sex and the City,” The Cut posted a set of memes from the show on Instagram, including some of the series’s most recognizable lines. When I saw the one about Miranda — “She was a lawyer. He was a sandwich.” — I finally realized what I missed most about the original series that is absent in its reboot, “And Just Like That ….”

headline: Why Deep-Sea Mining Is the Next Battleground in the Energy Transition
