abstract: Countries and companies are in a fight between those that want to excavate minerals used in electric vehicles and others that warn the cost is too high.
lead_paragraph: Surging demand for metals used in electric vehicle batteries has kicked off an international race to mine the deep seas. And there are no rules.

headline: In Brazil, Beauty Is a Right. Are They On to Something?
abstract: Brazil’s unique plastic surgery subsidies represent the country’s view that beauty is a form of self-care.
lead_paragraph: Every person with a toddler knows that her child is in constant imminent peril. Trying to prevent the next near death or disfiguring accident is a parent’s unending occupation.

headline: Wasting Away With Rachael Ray
abstract: The stars of the Food Network help a teenage patient make it through the long days in the hospital with no solid food.
lead_paragraph: When I was 15, I fell in love with the voice of Rachael Ray. That velvety contralto was the soundtrack of my days in the children’s hospital I hated — with its plaid curtains and kind nurses — but called home.

headline: Search for a Century-Old Shipwreck Turns Up One Even Older
abstract: Researchers and a television crew were looking for two naval ships lost in Lake Superior a century ago. Instead, they found a tugboat that mysteriously sank in 1879.
lead_paragraph: In September, a Discovery Channel film crew traveled to Paradise, Mich., searching for two French naval ships that disappeared in 1918. But on a voyage to find them, they stumbled upon another shipwreck that was four decades older.

headline: Home Is Where the Horses Are for a Threatened Culture
abstract: The Appleby Horse Fair draws tens of thousands of Gypsies and Irish Travellers each year to a rural patch of England to celebrate their culture. Our photographer spent four days there.
lead_paragraph: There is the world, and then there is Appleby.

headline: Poland Doesn’t Want Migrants, but These Foreign Workers Are Welcome
abstract: A tiny village is taking in 6,000 laborers from Asia. They are needed by a petroleum company controlled by the right-wing government, which has vowed to keep migrants out.
lead_paragraph: Determined to resist a European Union plan to spread the burden of migrants and asylum seekers around the continent, Poland’s prime minister, Mateusz Morawiecki, says his country wants to ensure that “Poles can safely walk the streets,” so it will not take in foreigners it does not want.

headline: Melvin Wulf, Transformative Civil Liberties Lawyer, Dies at 95
abstract: As legal director for 15 years, he made the A.C.L.U. a more aggressive organization and worked with Ruth Bader Ginsburg before she became a United States Supreme Court justice.
lead_paragraph: Melvin Wulf, a constitutional lawyer who reshaped the American Civil Liberties Union into a more aggressive litigator, argued 10 cases before the United States Supreme Court and supported the future Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in bringing a landmark sex discrimination case, died on July 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Marketa Vondrousova Wins Wimbledon and Her First Grand Slam Title
abstract: Vondrousova of the Czech Republic overpowered Ons Jabeur of Tunisia in the first set and never looked back, winning 6-4, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: Marketa Vondrousova of the Czech Republic, among the most unlikely of Wimbledon champions, is unlikely no more.

headline: Netanyahu Says He’s ‘Very Well’ After Being Rushed to Hospital
abstract: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said he was feeling better on Saturday after feeling dizzy and rushing to the hospital. Mr. Netanyahu, 73, is currently facing one of the most testing phases of his political career.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, said he was feeling “very well” on Saturday evening after experiencing mild dizziness and being rushed to a hospital for examination.

headline: Turmoil in Florida’s New State Guard, as Some Recruits Quit
abstract: Some who volunteered for the force commissioned by Gov. Ron DeSantis said the group, billed as a natural disaster relief organization, had become too militarized.
lead_paragraph: Early last summer, complaining that Washington had failed to provide adequate staffing for Florida’s National Guard, Gov. Ron DeSantis announced that for the first time in 75 years he was activating the State Guard, a force of volunteers that could respond to hurricanes and other public emergencies.

headline: Israeli Reservists Threaten Mass Resignations if Judicial Plan Proceeds
abstract: Military reserves are critical to Israel’s operational readiness. Reservists are again using that leverage against the government’s effort to curb judicial power.
lead_paragraph: At least 180 senior fighter pilots, elite commandos and cyber-intelligence specialists in the Israeli military reserve have informed their commanders that they will no longer report for volunteer duty if the government proceeds with a plan to limit judicial influence by the end of the month.

headline: Rare Dinosaur ‘Bonebed’ Is Discovered in a Maryland Park
abstract: Experts said it could be the widest-ranging discovery of fossils of different species on the East Coast.
lead_paragraph: Fossils from animals including dinosaurs and stingrays more than 100 million years old were uncovered in a Maryland park in what experts said could be the widest-ranging discovery of fossils of different species on the East Coast.

headline: Carlos Alberto Montaner, Prominent Critic of Castro’s Cuba, Dies at 80
abstract: After fleeing the island in 1961, he became one of the leading voices of opposition against the country’s Communist dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Alberto Montaner, a writer who escaped Cuba shortly after its Communist revolution, then built a career as one of the exile community’s leading opponents of the Castro regime, died on June 29 at his home in Madrid. He was 80.

headline: The Weather by the Numbers
abstract: Lots of triple-digit numbers tell the story of the early summer’s torrid heat wave.
lead_paragraph: A suffocating heat wave has swept across the South and Southwest in the United States, bringing dangerous temperatures and breaking heat records. Here’s what the numbers tell us about the heat and how it is affecting Americans.

headline: Lionel Messi Signs With Inter Miami, Starting New Era for M.L.S.
abstract: Messi is expected to join the team this week on a contract that runs through the 2025 Major League Soccer season.
lead_paragraph: The greatest soccer player of his era, and maybe the greatest of all time, is coming to the United States for the twilight of his career. Lionel Messi, 36, officially joined Inter Miami of Major League Soccer, the club announced in a release on Saturday.

headline: Ons Jabeur Calls Wimbledon Loss ‘the Most Painful’ of Her Career
abstract: “Honestly, I felt a lot of pressure, feeling a lot of stress,” Jabeur said after losing the women’s singles final to Marketa Vondrousova.
lead_paragraph: With the hopes of a country, a continent and a world of tennis lovers who felt she was long overdue urging her toward history, Ons Jabeur fell agonizingly short. For the second time at Wimbledon, and the third time in a year at a Grand Slam, Jabeur had hoped to become the first woman from Tunisia, the first from Africa and the first Arabic speaker to win a major women’s singles tournament.

headline: With a Centrist Manifesto, No Labels Pushes Its Presidential Bid Forward
abstract: The bipartisan group, facing enormous opposition from Democrats, hopes a new policy document will advance its political cause — and possible third-party White House run.
lead_paragraph: A new political platform focused on cooperative governance by the bipartisan group No Labels has something for everyone to embrace — and just as much for both sides to reject.

headline: Everett Mendelsohn, Who Linked Science and Society, Dies at 91
abstract: A longtime professor at Harvard, he lectured on atom bombs, genetics and more, examining how science, culture and politics influence one another.
lead_paragraph: Everett I. Mendelsohn, a Harvard professor who as a scholar of the history of science explored how science’s evolution has been influenced by historical and cultural trends and vice versa, died on June 6 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91.

headline: The Southwest Braces for Record-Breaking Heat
abstract: The National Weather Service forecast 45 record-high temperatures across the country, mostly in the Southwest, ahead of the weekend.
lead_paragraph: People across the southwestern United States were trying to stay cool on Saturday as a punishing heat wave was posed to break temperature records.

headline: Marga Minco, Who Chronicled Jewish Life in Wartime, Dies at 103
abstract: Her best-known book, “Het Bittere Kruid” (“Bitter Herbs”), described her experiences as a young woman after the Nazi invasion of the Netherlands in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Marga Minco, a Dutch novelist who was one of the last of a generation of European Holocaust authors whose works are widely considered literary classics, died on Monday at her home in Amsterdam. She was 103.

headline: Man Sought in Georgia Killing Spree Is Dead, Authorities Say
abstract: Andre Longmore, 40, of Hampton, Ga., was fatally shot by police on Sunday, a day after the killings of four people in the city, south of Atlanta. The motive remains unknown.
lead_paragraph: A man wanted in connection with the killing of four people in Hampton, Ga., was fatally shot by police on Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: The Game Is Afoot
abstract: Michael Schlossberg’s Sunday puzzle merrily marches along.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Police Capture ‘Survivalist’ Murder Suspect Who Escaped Jail
abstract: The police said that the escapee, Michael Burham, was found in the woods on Saturday in a “worn-out” state, with his clothes dirty and wet.
lead_paragraph: The manhunt for a murder suspect who escaped from a Pennsylvania jail on July 6 by tying bedsheets together to climb down from a roof ended on Saturday when the suspect was captured by the police, the authorities said.

headline: Alabama Woman Who Was Missing After Reporting a Child on a Highway Is Found
abstract: Carlee Russell told a 911 dispatcher on Thursday night that there was a toddler walking along the side of an interstate, the police said. She was not seen again until late Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A 25-year-old woman in Alabama who was reported missing on Thursday night after telling a 911 dispatcher that she saw a toddler walking along the side of an interstate and would pull over to help was found late on Saturday, according to the police.

headline: DeSantis Burns Cash, and Pence Struggles: 5 Takeaways From 2024 Filings
abstract: Warning signs for Ron DeSantis were among the biggest developments of the latest campaign filings, which created a fuller financial picture of the 2024 field.
lead_paragraph: As a fuller financial picture of the 2024 presidential race emerged with Saturday’s campaign filing deadline, trouble appeared to lurk below the surface for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Two Sports Connected by Squabbling
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 16, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “This would never go down at Coney Island. Somebody would just get shot.”

headline: Corrections: July 16, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 16, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 4 this weekend about a revival of the play “Orpheus Descending” misidentifies Erica Schmidt’s role in the making of the 2021 film “Cyrano.” She wrote the screenplay; she did not direct.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Airs Bigoted New Covid Conspiracy Theory About Jews and Chinese
abstract: The long-shot candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination has a history of embracing conspiracy theories. His latest comments claimed the virus spared certain ethnic and religious groups.
lead_paragraph: A conspiracy-filled rant by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that the Covid-19 virus was engineered to spare Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese people has stirred accusations of antisemitism and racism in the Democratic candidate’s long-shot run for president.

headline: A National Treasure, Tarnished: Can Britain Fix Its Health Service?
abstract: As it turns 75, the N.H.S., a proud symbol of Britain’s welfare state, is in the deepest crisis of its history.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen hours after she was taken out of an ambulance at Queen’s Hospital with chest pains and pneumonia, Marian Patten was still in the emergency room, waiting for a bed in a ward. Mrs. Patten, 78, was luckier than others who arrived at this teeming hospital, east of London: She had not yet been wheeled into a hallway.

headline: Small, Hidden and Deadly: Mines Stymie Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
abstract: To gain ground, Ukrainian forces have to make their way through a variety and density of Russian land mines they never imagined.
lead_paragraph: It was a grisly scene of bloody limbs and crumpled vehicles as a series of Russian mines exploded across a field in southern Ukraine.

headline: DeSantis Sheds Staff Amid Heavy Spending
abstract: The dismissals come as his campaign for the Republican nomination for president struggles to gain traction against former President Donald J. Trump, who is leading in polls.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has started cutting campaign staff just months into his presidential bid, as he has struggled to gain traction in the Republican primary and lost ground in some public polls to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: ‘We Must Go Faster’: Yellen Says Rich Nations Must Speed Debt Relief
abstract: Helping the world’s low-income countries will be a central topic as U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and other G20 finance ministers gather in India.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen called on Sunday for international creditors to speed up their efforts to provide debt relief to developing countries facing default, arguing that shoring up their deteriorating finances would benefit the global economy.

headline: In Florida, Trump Says DeSantis Has No Path to Victory
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump taunted Gov. Ron DeSantis, his chief Republican rival, for his absence from the conservative Turning Point Action Conference.
lead_paragraph: On the home turf of his chief Republican rival and in his adopted state, former President Donald J. Trump told a sprawling conservative gathering in Florida on Saturday night that it was futile for Gov. Ron DeSantis to keep battling him for the party’s presidential nomination.

headline: Which Presidential Candidates Are Leading the 2024 Money Race?
abstract: See who has amassed the most campaign cash so far.
lead_paragraph: See who has amassed the most campaign cash so far.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Hot Trends, Hotter Temperatures
abstract: As dangerous heat waves spread across the United States, there is one word on many minds: hot.
lead_paragraph: “The summer of 2023 is shaping up to be a hot one,” two New York Times reporters wrote in June. They meant temperatures, not trends.

headline: In Gilgo Beach Killings, an Arrest Bears Out a Decade-Old Prediction
abstract: In 2011, experts made a list of characteristics they predicted the suspect would have. The man charged in three of the killings checks many of those boxes.
lead_paragraph: In April 2011, just months after the bodies of four women were discovered buried near Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore, several experts and criminologists put together a sketch for The New York Times of the characteristics they expected to see in a suspect.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: An Online Comments Section Where Everybody Knows Your Screen Name
abstract: Metropolitan Diary, a column that captures the serendipity of New York City life, provides a place for regulars to meet.
lead_paragraph: When Sivaram Pochiraju told a group of friends that he and his wife were having a difficult week, Janet Cathcart reassured him that the couple had the support of “a large extended family.”

headline: Detroit Takes On Problems That Were Once Beyond Reach
abstract: Ten years after becoming the largest American city to file for bankruptcy, Detroit is stepping up code enforcement and sprucing up parks. The new moment carries risks, too.
lead_paragraph: On a stretch of Detroit’s West Side with mostly empty storefronts, the building with “Fried Fish” painted on its window had not served a meal in years. A small forest had sprouted in the alley. Plywood patched holes in the back.

headline: Who Gets to Wear G-Strings Now?
abstract: More women are adopting the “less is more” philosophy.
lead_paragraph: Codi Maher noticed that bikini bottoms were shrinking a few years ago. “First it was cheeky cut, then Brazilian,” said Ms. Maher, a 30-year-old real estate agent in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. As the fabric covering women’s derrières disappeared, she started thinking about getting a thong swimsuit of her own: “I was just like, everyone’s wearing them, screw it, I don’t care.”

headline: ‘The Man Looked Familiar, but I Couldn’t Quite Place Him’
abstract: A Manhattan reunion, dinner at Mamma Leone’s and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: What’s Worse Than Heat and Humidity? Heat and Humidity on the Subway.
abstract: In most New York City subway cars, the air-conditioning works. But if you find yourself in a hot car, the journey can be excruciating. Just ask the riders of Car 1859.
lead_paragraph: You make a mad dash out of one subway car and into another before the doors slam shut. Or you use your hands as fans. Or you sit by an open window, hoping for even the slightest hint of a breeze. Or, resigned to your sweaty fate, you call out to fellow commuters, warning them not to step aboard: “It’s very hot!”

headline: Tennis Style, Anyone?
abstract: At Wimbledon, the off-court fashion included three-piece suits, smart-looking hats and lots of tennis whites.
lead_paragraph: If you spend any time around the All England Club during Wimbledon, as I did for several hours last Monday, you start to notice that many people dress in what could be described as starter kits: a lot of men wear button-down shirts and shorts, while women tend to opt for summer dresses or skirts.

headline: How the Hollywood Strikes Could Affect Fall Festivals and Oscar Season
abstract: Without stars on the red carpet, prestige titles like the Leonard Bernstein biopic “Maestro” and the Elvis Presley tale “Priscilla” may not get the push they need.
lead_paragraph: With summer movie season at its midpoint, Hollywood typically begins to turn its gaze toward the fall, when a trio of major film festivals acts as the unofficial kickoff to Oscar season. Seven of the last 10 best-picture winners had their debuts at a fall festival, coming out of the gate with standing ovations and critical acclaim that helped propel them through the monthslong awards-show gantlet.

headline: Biden, With Sluggish Small Donations, Waits for Liberal Energy to Rise
abstract: Wealthy Democrats have thrown their money behind the president’s re-election bid, but for many reasons, the party’s small donors have yet to step up their contributions.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden traveled to San Francisco last month, he raised more than $10 million in 36 hours from wealthy Democrats. Trips to Chicago and New York netted millions more, as did fund-raising events around Washington, proving that the party’s big-donor class is fully committed to Mr. Biden’s re-election campaign.

headline: My Boss Made Me Post This
abstract: Your employer can put limits on what you put out on social media, but should not force you to spam your friends.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Alabama Scrambles to Redraw Its Voting Map After a Supreme Court Surprise
abstract: State lawmakers have until Friday to come up with new congressional districts that do not illegally dilute the power of Black voters.
lead_paragraph: Under orders from the Supreme Court to produce a voting map that no longer illegally dilutes the power of Black voters in Alabama, the state’s lawmakers are now facing a high-stakes scramble to come up with an acceptable replacement by the end of this week.

headline: Fossils Where They Don’t Belong? Maybe We Just Didn’t Look Hard Enough.
abstract: Researchers are fiercely debating whether claims about the origins of mammals result from a bias toward Northern Hemisphere fossil sites.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, paleontologists made a startling discovery in northwestern Madagascar. Among dinosaur bones and sandy sediment there emerged a 167-million-year-old tiny jaw fragment with three teeth. It belonged to Ambondro mahabo, a species that was 25 million years older than any mammal of its kind ever found.

headline: How to Make Your Home Accessible
abstract: Tap into the resources available from states, nonprofits, developers and housing groups to make spaces work for families of all abilities.
lead_paragraph: Tatiana Martinez needed an accessible home. Her then 7-year-old son, who uses a wheelchair, was too heavy to carry upstairs to his second-floor bedroom.

headline: We Are All Background Actors
abstract: Why should you care about the strikes in Hollywood? Because they are much more than a revolt of the privileged.
lead_paragraph: In Hollywood, the cool kids have joined the picket line.

headline: A New Job for Electric Vehicles: Powering Homes During Blackouts
abstract: Some energy experts say battery-powered vehicles will increasingly help keep the lights on and support electric grids, rather than straining them.
lead_paragraph: In early March, strong winds brought down trees and power lines in the Nashville area, leaving thousands of homes without power. But about 20 miles outside the city an electric pickup truck fed energy to John and Rachelle Reigard’s home, keeping their lights on.

headline: Water, Water, Everywhere, and Now Her Husband Is Gone
abstract: In Stephanie Bishop’s psychological thriller, “The Anniversary,” tragedy strikes on a cruise.
lead_paragraph: In love, in art, in crime, what is done intentionally and what is done unintentionally? This is the question at the core of Stephanie Bishop’s fourth novel, “The Anniversary.”

headline: As Climate Shocks Multiply, Designers Seek Holy Grail: Disaster-Proof Homes
abstract: The homebuilding industry has been slow to adopt changes that can better protect against extreme weather. Some architects are showing what’s possible.
lead_paragraph: Jon duSaint, a retired software engineer, recently bought property near Bishop, Calif., in a rugged valley east of the Sierra Nevada. The area is at risk for wildfires, severe daytime heat and high winds — and also heavy winter snowfall.

headline: As Iraq Tries to Chill Critics, Its Newest Target Is Social Media
abstract: New regulations on “degrading content” are part of a broader campaign to silence independent voices.
lead_paragraph: In one social media clip, a young Iraqi woman dances at a national soccer tournament. In another, she dances at her son’s birthday party.

headline: ‘Everyone Expects Us to Win’: England Tries to Live in the Now
abstract: Injuries weakened the Lionesses, and recent results have raised eyebrows. But the players and their coach say it takes a lot to shake a champion.
lead_paragraph: Sarina Wiegman likes to look on the bright side of things. In April, England’s 30-match unbeaten run was ended with a 2-0 loss to Australia. But Wiegman, the team’s Dutch coach, deliberately focused on the positives.

headline: How a Vast Demographic Shift Will Reshape the World
abstract: The most powerful countries have benefited from large work forces for decades. What happens when they retire?
lead_paragraph: The most powerful countries have benefited from large work forces for decades. What happens when they retire?

headline: Netanyahu Released From Hospital After Undergoing Tests
abstract: The Israeli prime minister spent Saturday night in a hospital after feeling dizziness, but was said to be in “excellent condition” on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was discharged from the hospital on Sunday in what medical officials described as “excellent condition,” after an overnight stay involving a series of tests and being fitted with an implanted heart monitor.

headline: More Mothers Are Dying. It Doesn’t Have to Be This Way.
abstract: No mother should ever go into childbirth fearful that the cost of bringing a life into the world will be the loss of her own.
lead_paragraph: After Tori Bowie, an elite athlete, died in May, the reality of the health risks to Black women posed by childbirth was once again in the spotlight. The maternal mortality rate for Black women in America is, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2.6 times that for white women.

headline: ‘The Bear’ and the Need for a Place to Belong
abstract: The powerful moral message of FX’s hit show.
lead_paragraph: Every now and then, a fictional character can have a profound real-world impact. I’m thinking, for example, of Jason Sudeikis’s Ted Lasso in 2020. There was a moment in the first season of the character’s self-titled show when a simple act of immediate forgiveness symbolized the generosity of a show that radiated across American culture and reminded us of the power of kindness and mercy to alter the course of a person’s life.

headline: My Brave, Brilliant Friend Was Kidnapped in Iraq. Will the World Stand Up for Her?
abstract: Elizabeth Tsurkov, a Russian Israeli researcher who has been kidnapped in Iraq, took risks in pursuit of knowledge, understanding and doing what she felt was right.
lead_paragraph: It’s a beautiful summer day at my in-laws’ house in Los Angeles. The sun is out. My kids are playing on the grass with their grandparents, a rare treat since we live in Jerusalem. But I can’t enjoy it. One of my oldest friends, Liza — Elizabeth Tsurkov — is being held by a militia in Iraq, and I’m terrified.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Moral Crisis of America’s Doctors’
abstract: The corporatization of health care has changed the practice of medicine, causing many physicians to feel alienated from their work.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, a psychiatrist named Wendy Dean read an article about a physician who died by suicide. Such deaths were distressingly common, she discovered. The suicide rate among doctors appeared to be even higher than the rate among active military members, a notion that startled Dean, who was then working as an administrator at a U.S. Army medical research center in Maryland. Dean started asking the physicians she knew how they felt about their jobs, and many of them confided that they were struggling. Some complained that they didn’t have enough time to talk to their patients because they were too busy filling out electronic medical records. Others bemoaned having to fight with insurers about whether a person with a serious illness would be preapproved for medication.

headline: Biden Is Beating China on Chips. It May Not Be Enough.
abstract: The Biden administration, in its zeal to keep advanced chips away from China, is failing to miss the risks in many other sectors.
lead_paragraph: The White House is intent on outcompeting China on technology. The ground on which this competition is taking place is chip making. But the Biden administration shouldn’t sit back and savor this accomplishment for one reason: What if its core belief — that advanced semiconductors are one of the critical fronts in the contest — is wrong?

headline: Two Theories of What I’m Getting Wrong
abstract: Is it impossible for liberalism to build?
lead_paragraph: Two smart writers have written thoughtful pieces — one from the right, one from the left — explaining where I’ve gone terribly wrong.

headline: Black Sea Grain Deal Hangs on 11th-Hour Talks, Again
abstract: Russia has repeatedly threatened to pull out of the wartime export agreement, which has helped stabilize global grain prices and avert famines. The latest deadline to renew it is Monday.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations on Sunday awaited a response from Russia on renewing a deal that allows Ukraine to export its grain amid a wartime blockade, a necessity in helping keep global food prices stable.

headline: Remembering the Dead
abstract: Fans are saying goodbye, again, to the band that was once the Grateful Dead.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the Grateful Dead are saying goodbye to the band this weekend. It’s not the first time.

headline: The Lifelong Burden of a Chronic Illness
abstract: Responses to a photo series about treatment for multiple sclerosis. Also: An imperfect church; beyond the Ivy League; transgender rights; harassment of realtors.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Why Does God Keep Making Poets?’
abstract: Since ancient times, poetry has been our way of paying attention to the world and our place in it.
lead_paragraph: In the heat of the summer, this slow curve of the midyear, I find myself wanting to pause and catch my breath. As many people take summer vacations or simply enjoy a cold drink on their porch, it is a good time to take up new kinds of reading. I have written before about why I think poetry is crucial now, and I asked my former poetry teacher, Abram Van Engen, if he’d speak to us about how to read poetry.

headline: A Fruit Salad That Isn’t Sad
abstract: Tossing summer melons and berries with lime juice — and some sugar that’s been massaged with the zest — makes for a salad that’s delightful, not depressing.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. When you run into a fruit salad in the wild, it’s generally trash: unripe shards of cantaloupe mixed with cardboard honeydew, pale strawberry halves, slippery rounds of browned banana, fibrous hunks of pineapple, gritty blueberries, the occasional squishy grape. It’s depressing.

headline: Jane Birkin, Singer, Actress and Fashion Inspiration, Dies at 76
abstract: She was a lithe beauty of 1960s European film, a famous musical collaborator and lover of Serge Gainsbourg, and the namesake of elegant Hermès handbags.
lead_paragraph: Jane Birkin, who helped define chic female sexuality of the 1970s as an actress in arty and erotic European movies and in her relationship — equal parts romantic and artistic — with the singer Serge Gainsbourg, died on Sunday in Paris. Ms. Birkin, who later became known for inspiring one of the best known lines of luxury handbags, was 76.

headline: Five Dead in Flash Flooding in Philadelphia Suburbs
abstract: Sudden, torrential rains struck areas in Bucks County, Pa., trapping people in their cars. Much of the Northeast was experiencing periods of heavy rainfall.
lead_paragraph: Fierce thunderstorms, heavy rainfall and flash flooding wreaked havoc across the Northeast over the weekend, killing five people in Pennsylvania, halting flights at major airports in the New York metropolitan area and downing power lines. In one part of Long Island, five inches of rain fell in less than two hours.

headline: Sally Kempton, Rising Star Journalist Turned Swami, Dies at 80
abstract: She was making her name in New York journalism in the footsteps of her famous father and becoming an outspoken feminist when she met an Indian guru.
lead_paragraph: Sally Kempton, who was once a rising star in the New York journalism world and a fierce exponent of radical feminism, but who later pivoted to a life of Eastern asceticism and spiritual practice, died on Monday at her home in Carmel, Calif. She was 80.

headline: Joyce Carol Oates Figured Out the Secret to Immortality
abstract: “Everything that you think is solid,” says the celebrated writer, “is actually fleeting and ephemeral.”
lead_paragraph: “Everything that you think is solid,” says the celebrated writer, “is actually fleeting and ephemeral.”

headline: Alcaraz Wins Wimbledon in a Thrilling Comeback Against Djokovic
abstract: Carlos Alcaraz won his first Wimbledon title and left Novak Djokovic, the overwhelming favorite, with his first finals loss at the All England Club in a decade.
lead_paragraph: After years of false starts, men’s tennis finally has a proper war between the generations.

headline: In Phoenix, Firefighters Battle an Invisible Inferno
abstract: A two-week stretch of 110-degree days sends the fire department scrambling to rescue people overcome by heat, and tests a force already accustomed to tough summers.
lead_paragraph: Deirdre’s temperature was 104 degrees when the paramedics arrived on Saturday afternoon and started infusing ice-cold saline into her veins, racing to cool her before she became another victim of Phoenix’s merciless heat wave.

headline: Review: A ‘Semele’ Bound for New York Takes Its First Bows
abstract: Claus Guth’s entertaining and often sexy new staging of Handel’s opera-oratorio hybrid in Munich is a coproduction with the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Staging oratorios in the opera house is nearly routine nowadays, especially those by Handel; for every “Agrippina,” you’re likely to get a “Messiah” too.

headline: Biden’s ‘Final’ Order on Kennedy Files Leaves Some Still Wanting More
abstract: The president has finished a review first mandated by law in 1992, and while a vast majority of papers related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy have been released, some remain redacted.
lead_paragraph: On June 22, 1962, an intelligence official drafted a memo summarizing a letter intercepted between Lee Harvey Oswald and his mother. The memo was made public long ago. But for 60 years, the name of the letter opener was kept secret.

headline: Pay to Rise as Much as 40% in Deal Reached by United and Pilots
abstract: The proposed four-year agreement would be worth $10 billion over the life of the contract.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines pilots reached agreement with the company on Saturday on a contract valued at $10 billion that would increase pay up to 40 percent over four years.

headline: Over 700 Civil War-Era Gold Coins Found Buried on a Kentucky Farm
abstract: “This is the most insane thing ever,” said the man who unearthed the coins in a cornfield, according to a video posted last month.
lead_paragraph: A Civil War-era treasure of more than 700 gold coins was unearthed in a Kentucky cornfield, a find that has at least partly vindicated legends of lost Civil War gold that have driven American treasure hunters for more than 150 years.

headline: How Julie Ertz Got Her Game Back
abstract: Ertz, a two-time World Cup winner, knew she had to hustle to return to the national team after having a baby. A boys’ team offered a helping hand.
lead_paragraph: Even before Julie Ertz gave birth to her son, Madden, last August, she knew it would be a challenge to return to the fitness and form that would be required of her if she wanted to play in a third Women’s World Cup.

headline: ‘Mission: Impossible’ for Tom Cruise: Meeting Hollywood Expectations
abstract: The seventh film in the 27-year-old movie franchise was No. 1 at the box office, taking in $80 million over its first five days. But the movie industry was hoping for more.
lead_paragraph: Tom Cruise’s seventh “Mission: Impossible” spectacle, which arrived in theaters on Wednesday and cost at least $400 million to make and market, was supposed to mark a turning point at the troubled summer box office. Death-defying stunts! A new love interest! That thrilling theme song!

headline: Worlds Apart: Cup’s Expansion Brings the Games of a Lifetime
abstract: Vietnam, one of eight nations playing in their first Women’s World Cup, will face the U.S. this week. Its presence highlights the growth of women’s soccer, but also the challenges that remain.
lead_paragraph: When Vietnam fielded its first women’s national soccer team in 1997, its players wore oversized jerseys made for men. At times, the team had to travel an hour and a half from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, to reach an available training site. Some players pushed carts on the street and sold bread to sustain their nascent playing careers.

headline: Four Prisoners Test Positive as Covid-19 Re-emerges at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: One detainee with the coronavirus was charged in the destroyer Cole bombing, and another in the Sept. 11 attacks, both death penalty cases. A third was hospitalized for observation.
lead_paragraph: Four high-value prisoners at Guantánamo Bay have tested positive for the coronavirus, including one man who was moved to the base hospital for closer observation, according to people familiar with operations at the U.S. base in Cuba.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: U.S. and China Restart Climate Talks
abstract: Also, the G20 finance ministers prepare to meet in India, China targets Canadian politicians and cricket rises in Texas.
lead_paragraph: John Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, arrived in Beijing yesterday to restart climate negotiations with China. Over three days of talks, he and Xie Zhenhua, his Chinese counterpart, will look for ways to collaborate, despite simmering tensions.

headline: Jane Birkin: Decades of Effortless Elegance
abstract: The British-French singer, actress and style icon may have been known as the inspiration for the Birkin bag, but she was so much more.
lead_paragraph: There are few things more tedious than the term “fashion icon,” but that is not to suggest people don’t exist who definitively set styles for their time. Jane Birkin was one of them.

headline: Heralded Cuban Wins in an Unusual Introduction to Pro Boxing
abstract: Decorated as an amateur, Andy Cruz had an unusual entrance into the pros, fighting for more rounds than typical for a first-timer. Afterward, he had an eye on what could be next.
lead_paragraph: Andy Cruz toted his new title belt while he hugged friends and saluted his followers on Instagram Live. When he and his team gathered for a photo, Derek Ennis, the head trainer, draped his right arm over one of Cruz’s shoulders. Everyone else stared at the camera; Cruz’s attention was elsewhere.

headline: Carlos Alcaraz Shows Novak Djokovic That His Championships Are Numbered
abstract: Djokovic had won the past three Grand Slams he played in to reach 23 major titles, but Alcaraz, Wimbledon’s newest singles champion, proved on Sunday he is not invincible.
lead_paragraph: With the driving force of a forehand winner, Novak Djokovic slammed his racket into a net post, then quickly picked up the twisted wreckage and sat down. It was an uncharacteristic outburst of rage from the 23-time Grand Slam singles champion, and it seemed to be about more than the point he had just lost.

headline: Satellite Images of Belarusian Base Suggest Wagner’s Possible Arrival
abstract: More than a dozen vehicles have arrived at a rapidly built military field camp in Belarus, and video from Russia showed a convoy flying Wagner flags on the move.
lead_paragraph: Satellite images, analyzed by The New York Times, showed increased activity this weekend at a military field camp in Belarus, including the arrival of vehicles that resemble those used by the Russian mercenary group Wagner.

headline: Once, Once
abstract: Alexander Liebeskind is just checking in on us.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: Man Who Crashed Into Teens After Doorbell Prank Gets Life in Prison
abstract: Anurag Chandra was convicted of first-degree murder and attempted murder in April after crashing his car into another vehicle, killing three teenagers and injuring three others.
lead_paragraph: A California man who crashed into a car of six teenagers after they played a doorbell prank on him in 2020 was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole on Friday after his conviction on murder charges, officials said.

headline: Senate Democrats Outpace Republicans in Fund-Raising in Key States
abstract: The 2024 election map is a challenging one for Democrats — especially in states they need to hold for a majority. But the incumbents made a strong financial showing this quarter.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats staring down tough re-election fights can look to one bright spot: sizable fund-raising hauls and cash stockpiles more than a year before Election Day.

headline: A Sequel to Cristina García’s ‘Dreaming in Cuban,’ 30 Years On
abstract: “Vanishing Maps” returns to the del Pino family, now spread across three continents and four generations.
lead_paragraph: A halo representing a mother’s ghost appears in Cristina García’s “Vanishing Maps” as the Berlin drag queen La Ivanita — given name Ivanito Villaverde — prepares to perform Olga Guillot’s 1950s bolero “Miénteme,” in which the singer begs her paramour to lie to her, to keep the illusion of his love alive. Meanwhile, in Cuba, Ivanito’s nonagenarian grandmother Celia is surprised to discover even her doctor has left the country amid economic hardship on the island; as her granddaughter (and Ivanito’s cousin) Irina, living in Russia, romanticizes the time her parents met in Prague in 1968: “Hopes had been impossibly high then — for democracy, for freedom, even for love.” So opens this follow-up to García’s 1992 debut, “Dreaming in Cuban,” which traced the generational ruptures within one diasporic family from the 1930s to the 1980s.

headline: Jane Birkin: An Adventurous Artist Made in England, Forged in France
abstract: Birkin had a thriving career as a singer and an actress, in both communicating a seemingly nonchalant demeanor that camouflaged a melancholy core.
lead_paragraph: For most of her life, Jane Birkin, who died Sunday at 76, acted as a bridge — an elegant one, with an affectless grace that never betrayed the strains of load bearing. She connected her native Britain and her adopted France, two countries physically close but often at odds. She never lost her English accent when she spoke, somehow joining the two languages into her own Birkin-ese, “the improbable French that added to her charm,” as Le Monde put it. She floated among song, cinema and theater, and she could reach large, varied audiences while also connecting with France’s auteur culture.

headline: C.R. Roberts, Scoring Sensation in Milestone Game, Dies at 87
abstract: In 1956, he starred for the University of Southern California in a signal victory over an all-white University of Texas team after withstanding racial threats.
lead_paragraph: C.R. Roberts, a Black running back for the University of Southern California, was afraid of what might happen when his integrated Trojans football team traveled to the Jim Crow South to play the all-white University of Texas Longhorns in Austin in 1956.

headline: Why Every Women’s World Cup City Has Two Names
abstract: A concerted effort to say Indigenous names correctly, and tell the stories behind them, will show up in stadiums in New Zealand and Australia.
lead_paragraph: When soccer fans land in New Zealand this month ahead of the Women’s World Cup, they may find themselves welcomed not to Auckland or Wellington, but to “Tāmaki Makaurau” (“Tah-mah-key Ma-kow-row”) or “Te Whanganui-a-Tara” (“Tay Fung-a-noo-ee a Tah-rah”).

headline: A Pro-Trump Crowd, Sensing Disloyalty, Drowns Out Dissent
abstract: A day after former President Donald J. Trump headlined the Turning Point conference in Florida, two of his Republican opponents were booed and heckled at the same event.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the names on the marquee would have been right at home on Fox News: Stephen K. Bannon, Tucker Carlson and Roger J. Stone Jr.

headline: China’s Rebound Falters, Tripped Up by Debt and Weak Exports
abstract: Government data shows gross domestic product growth slowed in the second quarter from earlier in the year, even though it rose over the same period in 2022.
lead_paragraph: China’s economy slowed markedly in the spring from earlier in the year, official numbers released on Monday showed, as exports tumbled, a real estate slump deepened and some debt-ridden local governments had to cut spending after running low on money.

headline: Tim Baltz on How B.J. Grabbed a Win in ‘The Righteous Gemstones’
abstract: Sunday’s episode was a test for Baltz’s character, but B.J. seized the moment. Still, his victory came at a price.
lead_paragraph: This interview contains spoilers for Sunday night’s episode of “The Righteous Gemstones.”

headline: No Corrections: July 17, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: After 75 Years, Health Service in U.K. Teeters
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The N.H.S. became the nation’s religion. But it’s actually a National Sickness Service.”

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Britain’s troubled health service.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s National Health Service turns 75 this month. It is in the deepest crisis of its history: flooded by aging patients; starved of investment; and understaffed by doctors and nurses, many of whom are so burned out that they are either joining strikes or leaving for jobs abroad.

headline: Lionel Messi Gives M.L.S. First Taste of the Weight of His Star
abstract: One day after Messi’s contract with Inter Miami became official, the club presented him to fans in a rain-soaked stadium and on the league’s streaming platform.
lead_paragraph: Just before 9 p.m. on Sunday, the greatest soccer player of his era, and maybe the greatest of all time, walked across a makeshift stage in his new home stadium. He hugged the owners of his new team, including the former star David Beckham. As he held his new jersey — a pink No. 10 — Lionel Messi grinned and looked up at the crowd and the fireworks.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Below Deck’ and FIFA Women’s World Cup
abstract: One “Below Deck” spinoff wraps up its season, as another begins on Bravo. And Fox begins coverage of the women’s soccer championship.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 17-23. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Russia’s Embassy in Washington is enmeshed in a different kind of war.
abstract: WASHINGTON — On a warm June night, Benjamin Wittes was seated at a card table across the street from the Russian Embassy in Washington, kicking off his light show.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a warm June night, Benjamin Wittes was seated at a card table across the street from the Russian Embassy in Washington, kicking off his light show.

headline: Russia pulls out of the Black Sea grain deal.
abstract: The Kremlin terminated an agreement that had allowed Ukraine to export its grain by sea despite a wartime blockade, a deal seen as essential to keeping global food prices stable.
lead_paragraph: Russia said on Monday that it was ending its participation in an agreement that had allowed Ukraine to export its grain by sea despite Moscow’s naval blockade, upending a deal that had helped to keep global food prices stable and alleviate one element of the global fallout from the war.

headline: Word of the Day: glyph
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word glyph has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 13 in “Unearthing a Maya Civilization That ‘Punched Above Its Weight’” by Franz Lidz:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Is the Future of Twitter Hanging by Threads?
abstract: Ryan Mac, a New York Times technology reporter, discussed Twitter’s latest competitor and what it was like to be blocked from the platform he covered.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Mac, a technology reporter who covers Twitter for The New York Times, is used to changing his plans at a moment’s notice.

headline: Labor Day Looms as Crisis Point in Hollywood Stalemate
abstract: Ongoing strikes could disrupt the entertainment industry in fundamental ways, putting the 2024 box office and the fall broadcast lineup in jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: In May, when 11,500 movie and television writers went on strike, Hollywood companies like Netflix, NBCUniversal and Disney reacted with what amounted to a shrug. The walkout wasn’t great, but executives had expected it for months. They could ride it out.

headline: Trump and Allies Forge Plans to Increase Presidential Power in 2025
abstract: The former president and his backers aim to strengthen the power of the White House and limit the independence of federal agencies.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and his allies are planning a sweeping expansion of presidential power over the machinery of government if voters return him to the White House in 2025, reshaping the structure of the executive branch to concentrate far greater authority directly in his hands.

headline: Riots in France Highlight a Vicious Cycle Between Police and Minorities
abstract: Calls to overhaul the police go back decades. But violent episodes of police enforcement continue. So do violent outpourings on the street.
lead_paragraph: Years before France was inflamed with anger at the police killing of a teenager during a traffic stop, there was the notorious Théo Luhaka case.

headline: At N.Y.C. Police Union, Will the New Leader Be a Lot Like the Old One?
abstract: Patrick Hendry, a reserved, behind-the-scenes power, is succeeding the fiery Patrick Lynch, who ran the Police Benevolent Association at top volume.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Hendry, the new head of New York City’s police officers’ union, has much in common with his predecessor: Their mothers are from Ireland. They grew up in Queens, the sons of union men. And they believe a police union must defend officers, even those accused of wrongdoing.

headline: The Contenders
abstract: As the Women’s World Cup has expanded, so, too, has the group of nations with the firm belief that they can win it.
lead_paragraph: The Women’s World Cup, which opens this week, is the biggest in its 32-year history, but it may also be the most open field the tournament has seen.

headline: A Long, Shining River of Verse, Flowing From a Rower and Writer
abstract: Spend a day on the water with Wang Ping and you will discover a source of her poetry.
lead_paragraph: The heart beats alone, keeping its own pace

headline: After Arrest in Serial Killings, a Profile Looks Prescient
abstract: In several ways, Rex Heuermann, the suspect in the Gilgo Beach killings, fits a profile that criminologists assembled more than a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the suspect in the Gilgo Beach killings who was arrested last week.

headline: Kerry Says U.S. and China Must Set Aside Politics to Tackle Climate Change
abstract: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, is in Beijing for three days of talks between the world’s largest emitters of greenhouse gas pollution.
lead_paragraph: The United States and China are running out of time to avert a harrowing future brought on by global warming, John Kerry, President Biden’s envoy for climate change, warned on Monday at the resumption of talks with Beijing that had stalled for nearly a year amid geopolitical tensions.

headline: My Impossible Mission to Find Tom Cruise
abstract: The action star has gone to great lengths to avoid the press for more than a decade. But maybe our writer could track him down anyway?
lead_paragraph: In an interview with Playboy in 2012, Tom Cruise described Katie Holmes as “an extraordinary person” with a “wonderful” clothing line, and someone for whom he was fond of “doing things like creating romantic dinners” — behavior that, he confided, “she enjoys.” It would prove to be his last major interview with a reporter to date. Despite what may be recalled through the penumbra of memory, this sudden silence was not directly preceded by either of Cruise’s infamous appearances on television: not by his NBC’s “Today” show interview (in which he labeled host Matt Lauer both “glib” and “Matt — MattMattMattMatt”), nor even by his appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” (in which he reverse-catapulted himself onto Winfrey’s fawn-colored couch multiple times in a demonstration of his enthusiasm for Holmes). Those incidents occurred seven years earlier, in 2005; Cruise emerged from the hex of public bewilderment unscathed. In fact, Cruise gave no indication that the interview, pegged to the musical-comedy bomb “Rock of Ages,” was intended to serve as a farewell address to journalists. At the time he sat for it, another life milestone was hurtling toward him: The month after the article was published, Holmes filed for divorce.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A three-bedroom retreat in Sebastopol, a midcentury-modern home in Laguna Niguel and a 1965 house in Sonoma.
lead_paragraph: This house sits on a large piece of land, surrounded by mature trees, but is just 10 minutes from the city center and about five minutes from the smaller communities of Freestone and Occidental. Wine bars, a bakery, a breakfast spot with a train theme, a Whole Foods Market and a Safeway grocery store are all nearby.

headline: Trump’s Judges: More Religious Ties and More N.R.A. Memberships
abstract: A new study also found that judges appointed by the former president were more likely to vote for claims of religious freedom — unless they came from Muslims.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump was running for president in 2016, he vowed to appoint Supreme Court justices who would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade. Three justices and six years later, he made good on that promise.

headline: House Committee Targets U.C. Berkeley Program for China Ties
abstract: A House select committee is requesting more information about a university collaboration that it said could help China gain access to cutting-edge research.
lead_paragraph: A congressional committee focused on national security threats from China said it had “grave concerns” about a research partnership between the University of California, Berkeley, and several Chinese entities, claiming that the collaboration’s advanced research could help the Chinese government gain an economic, technological or military advantage.

headline: I Am Being Pushed Out of One of the Last Public Squares, the Library
abstract: A haven that should welcome all is too often becoming a battleground.
lead_paragraph: As far as my childhood self was concerned, the Carnegie Library in my tiny South Dakota hometown was the best place on earth. Once every week, I climbed its stairs and entered a space that smelled of mildew and oak.

headline: What We Can Learn From the Young Democratic Mayor Who Sent a Wing of His Own Party Into Exile
abstract: Hubert Humphrey’s 1948 triumph resonates today.
lead_paragraph: On the torrid afternoon of July 6, 1948, Hubert Humphrey departed one kind of inferno to plunge into another. Humphrey, the brash young mayor of Minneapolis, was leaving a city reeling under a 100-degree heat wave that had taken two lives that very day. He was bound for Philadelphia, the site of the impending Democratic National Convention, where the sweltering weather provided a fitting backdrop for a heated convention.

headline: The Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer
abstract: Christopher Nolan’s film delves deeply into what this country did to its most famous scientist.
lead_paragraph: One day in the spring of 1954, J. Robert Oppenheimer ran into Albert Einstein outside their offices at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. Oppenheimer had been the director of the institute since 1947 and Einstein a faculty member since he fled Germany in 1933. The two men might argue about quantum physics — Einstein grumbled that he just didn’t think that God played dice with the universe — but they were good friends.

headline: Paris Is Packed in the Summer. Here Are Six Ways to Dodge the Droves.
abstract: European hot spots are buckling with record numbers of travelers this season. But even in a global travel darling like the French capital, strategies exist to enjoy the sights without the crowds.
lead_paragraph: Summer has arrived in Paris, and the world with it. By day, international hordes pile into the Musée d’Orsay to catch the final month of the blockbuster “Manet / Degas” exhibition as throngs surround the closed, fire-damaged Notre Dame Cathedral to snap any possible selfies. By night, the available picnic space quickly disappears on the lawns of the Champ de Mars and its direct view of the Eiffel Tower.

headline: The Risks of Taking Drugs Like Ozempic When You’re Over 65
abstract: Medications that cause drastic weight loss raise specific concerns for older adults.
lead_paragraph: There are few constants within the world of weight loss, but one concept holds up: No matter how you lose weight — through restrictive eating, bariatric surgery or the new, buzzy class of injectable medications like Ozempic and Wegovy — you’re also probably shedding muscle.

headline: Honoring the Last of the ‘Boys of Summer’
abstract: Carl Erskine was a champion with the 1955 Brooklyn Dodgers, but what came after that is what will be celebrated with an award from the Baseball Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: It is the first inning, you might say, and Carl Erskine does not have his best stuff. A camera crew has set up in his living room, and a filmmaker, Ted Green, gently tries to guide Erskine through a short speech. This is hard work for the old Brooklyn Dodger, who needs several takes.

headline: At the Met, She Holds Court. At Home, She Held 71 Looted Antiquities.
abstract: Shelby White has given the museum generous gifts and 33 years of service as a trustee. But investigators recently seized many of her ancient artifacts, including 17 that were on loan to the Met.
lead_paragraph: The exhibition was a major one, featuring nearly 200 ancient artifacts from around the world, including Neolithic marbles and imposing Roman bronzes, and its title, “Glories of the Past,” was appropriately grand.

headline: Democrats to Press Supreme Court Ethics Rules Over G.O.P. Opposition
abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee is slated to approve new disclosure requirements, although the legislation is unlikely to advance.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats plan to push ahead this week with legislation imposing new ethics rules on the Supreme Court in the wake of disclosures about the justices’ travel and outside activities, despite blanket opposition by Republicans who claim the effort is intended to undermine the high court.

headline: She Opened a Bookshop in Brooklyn, Then Moved In Above the Store
abstract: A woman walking in Williamsburg saw an empty storefront for rent. It turned into a dream fulfilled. Upstairs, an apartment was being renovated.
lead_paragraph: For Simona Blat, the plan was to move to Europe and open a bookshop. It was early 2021, a global pandemic was still raging, and Williamsburg, her Brooklyn neighborhood of 12 years, felt like it was emptying out.

headline: The Gilgo Beach Serial-Killing Case: What We Know
abstract: A Long Island architect has been charged with killing three women. The victims were among 10 people whose remains were found along a stretch of beach on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: In December 2010, Officer John Malia and his police dog, Blue, were combing Gilgo Beach, a remote stretch of sand on the South Shore of Long Island, when they found human remains.

headline: One Reason China Is Willing to Engage Again: Its Troubled Economy
abstract: China was on track to recover after closing itself off during the pandemic. Now the country’s growth is staggering, and Beijing is signaling it is open to talking.
lead_paragraph: Three months ago it appeared that China’s economy was on track to recover relatively quickly after being closed off to the world during the pandemic. Consumers were spending again. Exports picked up. Even China’s beleaguered housing market gave hints it was stabilizing.

headline: It’s Getting Really Awkward for Speaker Kevin McCarthy
abstract: Swing voters aren’t all that keen on posturing, do-nothing Congresses.
lead_paragraph: Some days, Speaker Kevin McCarthy must look out over his House conference in awe and think: Are you maniacs trying to lose us the majority?

headline: Far From the Front, They Stand in Honor of Ukraine
abstract: The city of Chernivtsi in western Ukraine has been spared the mayhem of the Russian invasion. But like other towns in the region, it is doing its part, and has become, in effect, a back office of the war effort.
lead_paragraph: Every morning at the stroke of 9, in the western Ukrainian city of Chernivtsi, the entire town square comes to a standstill for a moment of silence to mourn the war dead.

headline: America Can’t Build a Green Economy Without China
abstract: With few exceptions, you either let yourself learn from your competitors or you fail to compete with them at all.
lead_paragraph: Roughly a century ago, when Henry Ford revolutionized modern car production, engineers from France, Japan, Germany and the Soviet Union flocked to Detroit to learn how to copy his miraculous methods. Ford’s River Rouge plant, then the world’s largest factory, ultimately inspired facilities by Renault, Volkswagen, Toyota and the Russian automaker Gaz. It also gave rise to the nightmarish wartime economies of World War II, when tanks, planes and toxic chemicals rolled off assembly lines worldwide.

headline: In Phoenix, 18 Days of 110-Degree Weather, and Counting
abstract: Tens of millions of people face dangerous levels of heat as record-breaking temperatures are expected this week from Texas to the lower Mississippi Valley, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: A relentless heat wave that has sent temperatures into the triple digits brought Phoenix its 18th consecutive day of high temperatures at or above 110 degrees on Monday, tying a record set in 1974, officials said.

headline: Today’s Top News: A New Voting Map in Alabama, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: China’s Economic Rebound Hits a Wall
abstract: When the country ended its lockdowns, business was expected to come roaring back. Here’s why it didn’t.
lead_paragraph: When China suddenly dismantled its lockdowns and other Covid precautions last December, officials in Beijing and many investors expected the economy to spring back to life. It hasn’t worked out that way.

headline: A Positive Covid Milestone
abstract: In a sign that the pandemic really is over, the total number of Americans dying each day is no longer historically abnormal.
lead_paragraph: The United States has reached a milestone in the long struggle against Covid: The total number of Americans dying each day — from any cause — is no longer historically abnormal.

headline: Smoke Pollution From Canadian Wildfires Blankets U.S. Cities, Again
abstract: Wildfires in western Canada are expected to create smoky conditions in the United States this week. Parts of the U.S. had unhealthy air in June from wildfires in other parts of Canada.
lead_paragraph: Smoke from wildfires in Western Canada drifted across the Midwest and the Northeast of the United States on Monday, blotting out blue sky and sun and blanketing dozens of cities with unhealthy air that triggered warnings to limit the time spent outdoors.

headline: Ramaswamy Looks to Supreme Court in Effort to Appeal to Conservatives
abstract: The long-shot Republican presidential candidate is releasing a list of potential justices to highlight his bona fides with key voters.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy, an entrepreneur running for the Republican presidential nomination, on Monday released a list of potential choices for the U.S. Supreme Court, in an effort to highlight his conservative credentials to early-state voters who may be skeptical of a candidate without a political background.

headline: What’s Next for Israel’s Judicial Overhaul?
abstract: Israeli lawmakers advanced parts of a contentious plan by the right-wing government to reduce the power of the Supreme Court, defying threats by protesters to shut down large parts of the economy.
lead_paragraph: Israeli lawmakers on Monday approved the contentious plan of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to restrict the influence of the Supreme Court, defying a wide array of opposition movements that have threatened to shut down large parts of the country with protests.

headline: China’s Economy Is Sputtering, Posing a Challenge for Global Growth
abstract: New data published on Monday shows a post-pandemic recovery has not materialized after restrictions were lifted last year.
lead_paragraph: When China finally lifted Covid restrictions last year, policymakers and companies hoped that it would help lift the global economy out of its post-pandemic doldrums. But data released on Monday shows that the hoped-for recovery in the world’s second-biggest economy still hasn’t materialized, raising wider questions about global growth, the implications for international business and China’s dealings with the outside world.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of July 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: The Jazzy Tune You Heard on Hold? This Part-Time Musician Made It.
abstract: Meet Harriet Goldberg, a late bloomer who went from a career in social work to the queen of hold music with her 2011 song “My Time to Fly.”
lead_paragraph: Harriet Goldberg is the composer of what may be one of the most heard songs in the world today.

headline: A Fossil Dream as Big as Texas
abstract: Andre LuJan’s ambition is to build a public museum focused on displaying the Lone Star State’s paleontological plenty.
lead_paragraph: Most people come to Ox Ranch — an 18,000-acre property outside Uvalde, Texas — for the thrill of hunting exotic animals in the Hill Country. But the ranch is also home to ancient secrets, as in lines of dinosaur tracks that cut across an empty creek bed and in a dark cave under a stony hillside that contains the remnants of Pleistocene animals and humans.

headline: Edward Caban Becomes First Latino Police Commissioner in New York
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams named Mr. Caban as the 46th commissioner of the New York Police Department. He follows Keechant Sewell, who resigned after 18 months.
lead_paragraph: Edward Caban, who grew up in the Bronx as the son of a Puerto Rican transit police detective, on Monday became the first Latino officer to lead the New York Police Department in its 177-year history.

headline: Millions of Californians Are Expected to Lose Medi-Cal Coverage
abstract: As the state verifies eligibility for its Medicaid program after a pandemic pause, up to 2.8 million Californians could be kicked off the rolls, officials say.
lead_paragraph: A big change is underway for one of California’s most popular safety net programs.

headline: Wildfire Forces Thousands to Evacuate in Canary Islands
abstract: The blaze on the island of La Palma has driven some 4,000 residents from their homes and burned about 10,000 acres. Wildfires also broke out in Greece.
lead_paragraph: Spanish firefighters on Monday were battling a wildfire that has raged for three days on the wooded slopes of La Palma in the Canary Islands, forcing the evacuation of more than 4,000 residents.

headline: Who Might Make the Cut for the G.O.P.’s First Presidential Debate?
abstract: Some candidates still have a ways to go to meet the criteria for getting on the debate stage.
lead_paragraph: Some candidates still have a ways to go to meet the criteria for getting on the debate stage.

headline: Elton John Testifies at Kevin Spacey’s Sexual Assault Trial
abstract: The British singer and his husband, David Furnish, appeared via video link to give evidence for the defense in the actor’s ongoing British trial.
lead_paragraph: Elton John and his husband, David Furnish, appeared on Monday as defense witnesses in the British trial of the actor Kevin Spacey, who is accused of multiple counts of sexual assault.

headline: Where Is China’s Foreign Minister? Beijing Won’t Clear Up the Mystery.
abstract: Qin Gang has not made a public appearance in three weeks. The Communist Party’s habitual secrecy around top officials has fueled speculation over the reasons for his absence.
lead_paragraph: After China’s leader, Xi Jinping, catapulted Qin Gang into the post of foreign minister in December, Mr. Qin set a frantic pace, meeting dozens of foreign officials as he pressed Beijing’s agenda in a divided, war-stricken world.

headline: Taylor Swift Now Has More No. 1 Albums Than Any Woman in History
abstract: The pop superstar’s “Speak Now (Taylor’s Version)” debuts at No. 1 this week as the year’s biggest new album, and three of her other titles also made the Top 10.
lead_paragraph: When Taylor Swift released “Speak Now (Taylor’s Version)” this month, there was no doubt it would debut at No. 1. The only questions were how forcefully it would smash records, how many mountains of vinyl it would sell and how far down the chart Swift’s catalog would push everybody else.

headline: Electric Vehicle Prices Fall as Automakers Raise Production
abstract: Ford, Tesla and other automakers are having to lower prices to lure buyers as the supply of battery-powered models begins to exceed demand.
lead_paragraph: After struggling to find enough batteries and other parts for the past couple of years, automakers are finally beginning to churn out large numbers of electric cars and trucks. More than 30 new models will arrive in showrooms this year.

headline: Wheat prices seesaw after Russia pulls out of the Black Sea grain deal.
abstract: Wheat futures rose more than 4 percent, raising fears of an increase in global food inflation.
lead_paragraph: The risk of renewed volatility in global food prices emerged Monday after President Vladimir V. Putin pulled Russia out of the Black Sea grain deal, rattling wheat markets and exposing vulnerable countries in Africa and the global south in particular to the prospect of a new round of food insecurity.

headline: Treating Alzheimer’s Very Early Offers Better Hope of Slowing Decline, Study Finds
abstract: A trial of donanemab, an experimental drug, found it modestly slowed the worsening of memory and thinking and worked better in patients at earlier stages and those under 75.
lead_paragraph: Treating Alzheimer’s patients as early as possible — when symptoms and brain pathology are mildest — provides a better chance of slowing cognitive decline, a large study of an experimental Alzheimer’s drug presented Monday suggests.

headline: Playwrights’ Hoop Dreams Take Flight Off Broadway This Summer
abstract: Basketball is central to the plot in new shows, including “Flex” and “The Half-God of Rainfall.”
lead_paragraph: In Inua Ellams’s new play, “The Half-God of Rainfall,” the gods play thunderous games of basketball in the heavens. For Candrice Jones’s “Flex,” high schoolers practice their defensive stances while scraping by in rural Arkansas. Near the end of Rajiv Joseph’s “King James,” the two main characters play a one-on-one game of basketball using a crumpled up piece of paper after waxing poetic about the greatness of the N.B.A. star LeBron James.

headline: What We Know About the Attack on the Crimean Bridge
abstract: Monday’s strike was the second in less than a year to target the Kerch Strait Bridge, which holds strategic and symbolic importance for Russia.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than a year, explosives have damaged the bridge that links Russia and Crimea, the southern Ukrainian peninsula that Moscow illegally annexed in 2014. The 12-mile-long bridge, which includes a road and rail line running side by side, is a heavily guarded piece of infrastructure that holds major importance for Russia.

headline: It’s Marathon Training Season. Here’s How to Build a Foundation.
abstract: The first few weeks should focus on the basics — easy pace, weight training and setting your expectations.
lead_paragraph: Every year, more than a million people around the world run a marathon. For some, it will be one of many, but for others, it will be a highlight of their lives. If you’re drawn to the challenge and excitement of running a “26.2” this year (or sometime in the future), you’ve got work to do. And we’re here to help.

headline: Paneer Chile Dry is Spicy and Sticky, Crisp and Melting
abstract: And if your basil plant is going bananas, there’s punchy, speedy pad krapow gai (Thai basil chicken) and basil butter pasta.
lead_paragraph: In college, when I was working as a coat checker in a fancy New York restaurant, I once asked the chef what his favorite food was.

headline: House Democrats Prepare Push to Censure George Santos
abstract: The move will face long odds of passing the Republican-led House, but Democrats believe it will place pressure on G.O.P. leaders who recently censured Representative Adam Schiff.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats unveiled a resolution on Monday to formally censure Representative George Santos of New York for blatantly lying to voters about his life story, teeing up a fresh attempt to reprimand the freshman Republican.

headline: John Harris Named Top Editor at Politico
abstract: Mr. Harris, who helped found the media outlet in 2007, will succeed Matt Kaminski as the publication’s editor in the United States, with additional oversight of international editions.
lead_paragraph: Politico said Monday that its top U.S. editor was stepping down and would be replaced by one of the publication’s co-founders, John Harris, who will also take on additional responsibilities for the media outlet’s international editions.

headline: How Do You Pitch to Stan Musial? Very Carefully.
abstract: Carl Erskine is one of the last stars left from a golden age of baseball. He offered insights into what it was like to face some of the greats, and how the game has changed.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, when The Sporting News polled writers about the players they covered, Carl Erskine stood out. Among his fellow Brooklyn Dodgers, Erskine was cited for several attributes, including “Best Marriage,” “Best Parent,” “Most Intellectual” and “Best Conversationalist.”

headline: After a Great Flood, a Struggle Between Faith and Reason
abstract: Khaled Khalifa’s new novel follows two friends through disaster and religious tension in early-20th-century Syria.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian writer Khaled Khalifa’s novels have cruel titles, of the sort Jean Genet might have composed for William S. Burroughs, or Verlaine for Rimbaud.

headline: Iran Steps Up Policing of Women Who Defy Strict Dress Code
abstract: The country’s morality police disappeared from the streets late last year as the authorities tried to calm anti-government protests. Now, patrols are once again watching for violators.
lead_paragraph: Iran is once again deploying police officers on the streets to enforce its conservative dress code for women, which many have flouted since the protest movement that rattled the country began last fall, according to state news media and social media posts.

headline: What Does It Mean to be Blind? A Writer Chronicles the Loss of His Vision.
abstract: In “The Country of the Blind,” Andrew Leland explores the history, the culture and the experiences of blind people.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Andrew Leland began writing a book about blindness, even as he was going steadily blind himself.

headline: A large Wagner convoy arrives at a camp in Belarus.
abstract: The troop movements are the private company’s biggest — and most public — showing since its failed rebellion in Russia last month.
lead_paragraph: A large convoy of vehicles carrying Wagner mercenary troops arrived at a military field camp in Belarus on Monday morning, in what is the private company’s biggest — and most public — showing since its failed rebellion in Russia last month.

headline: Biden Invites Netanyahu to U.S., Easing Tensions
abstract: The invitation to the Israeli prime minister came on the eve of a visit to the White House by Isaac Herzog, the Israeli president.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Monday invited Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to a meeting in the United States for the first time since Mr. Netanyahu re-entered office in December, easing months of tensions about the direction of Israel’s government.

headline: Harry G. Frankfurt, Philosopher With a Surprise Best Seller, Dies at 94
abstract: He spent his career exploring will and deceit. Then came a sudden success: a bluntly titled book that found that one strain of dishonesty with a barnyard name was worse than lying.
lead_paragraph: Harry G. Frankfurt, a philosopher whose fresh ideas about the human will were overshadowed in the broader culture by his analysis of a kind of dishonesty that he found worse than lying — an analysis presented in a bluntly titled surprise best seller, “On Bullshit” — died on Sunday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Skip the Reservation With Carbone’s Jarred Vodka Sauce
abstract: Try the sauce from Major Food Group as well as tomato alla vodka cannellini beans from Heyday Canning, sip a lightly fizzy refreshment from Tepache Sazón, and more food news.
lead_paragraph: When Carbone, the high-profile wiseguys restaurant from Major Food Group, introduced its jarred pasta sauces in 2021, missing from the lineup was the restaurant’s signature Alla Vodka.
