lead_paragraph: Donald Trump received a letter informing him that he was a target of the special counsel’s investigation into his role in the events surrounding the Capitol riot. The letter is a signal that Trump is likely to be indicted on federal criminal charges relating to his attempts to retain power after the 2020 election.

headline: Tracking Heat Across the World
abstract: See detailed maps of the latest temperature forecasts across the world.
lead_paragraph: See detailed maps of the latest temperature forecasts across the world.

headline: Stephen M. Silverman, Biographer of Stage and Screen, Is Dead at 71
abstract: An entertainment journalist, he persuaded the publicity-shy director David Lean to let him write his story and died before seeing his final book, on Stephen Sondheim, published.
lead_paragraph: Stephen M. Silverman, a longtime entertainment reporter and author who wrote a critically admired biography of the notoriously reticent British director David Lean and a forthcoming book about the Broadway titan Stephen Sondheim, died on July 6 in Manhattan. He was 71.

headline: Target Letter to Trump Raises Possibility of Obstruction and Fraud Charges
abstract: A person briefed on the matter said the letter cited three statutes that could be applied in a prosecution of the former president.
lead_paragraph: In the two and a half years since a mob laid siege to the Capitol in an effort to prevent Congress from certifying Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s electoral victory, a wealth of evidence has emerged about Donald J. Trump’s bid to stay in power after the 2020 election.

headline: Review: A Friendship Goes ‘Back and Forth’ in Central Park
abstract: Richard Hollman’s tender, site-specific play explores the awkward resumption of a Covid-interrupted friendship over a deceptively innocent game of catch.
lead_paragraph: Catch is one of the few basic children’s games that can extend into every phase of life. Taking turns tossing and catching the ball furnishes the game with built-in respites, which give the participants a chance to reflect on past choices and prepare for future ones.

headline: U.N. Officials Urge Regulation of Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Security Council members said they feared that a new technology might prove a major threat to world peace.
lead_paragraph: The U.N. Security Council for the first time held a session on Tuesday on the threat that artificial intelligence poses to international peace and stability, and Secretary General António Guterres called for a global watchdog to oversee a new technology that has raised at least as many fears as hopes.

headline: Angelo Mozilo, Whose Mortgage Giant Fell in Housing Bust, Dies at 84
abstract: He built Countrywide Financial into the country’s largest mortgage lender, but its increasingly risky loans helped precipitate the 2008 financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Angelo Mozilo, a founder of Countrywide Financial who presided over that lending giant’s rapid ascent and then its collapse during the financial crisis of 2008, died on Sunday. He was 84.

headline: Adams’s Re-election Bid Fueled by Real Estate Titans and Out-of-Towners
abstract: The mayor has raised $1.3 million for re-election since January, relying on many wealthy donors from New York City and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Despite falling poll numbers and critical news coverage, Mayor Eric Adams clearly has the continued monetary support of two influential spheres of influence: real estate leaders and the donor class from New York City and beyond.

headline: ‘Barbie’ Review: Out of the Box and On the Road
abstract: She’s in the driver’s seat, headed for uncharted territory (flat feet!). But there are limits to how much dimension even Greta Gerwig can give this branded material.
lead_paragraph: Can a doll with an ingratiating smile, impossible curves and boobs ready for liftoff be a feminist icon? That’s a question that swirls through Greta Gerwig’s “Barbie,” a live-action, you-go-girl fantasia about the world’s most famous doll. For more than half a century, Barbie has been, by turns, celebrated as a font of girlhood pleasure and play, and rebuked as an instrument of toxic gender norms and consumerist ideals of femininity. If Barbie has been a culture-war hot spot for about as long as it’s been on the shelves, it’s because the doll perfectly encapsulates changing ideas about girls and women: our Barbies, ourselves.

headline: Russia Bombards Ukraine Port After Bridge Attack and Grain Deal Collapse
abstract: Russian forces launched a barrage of missiles and drones at Odesa, not usually a major target, a day after important shifts in the conduct of the war.
lead_paragraph: Explosions thundered above Odesa, Ukraine, as Russia targeted it with missiles and drones before dawn on Tuesday, a day after an apparent Ukrainian strike damaged an important Russian bridge and the Kremlin halted a deal for safe passage of grain ships on the Black Sea.

headline: House Votes Resoundingly to Back Israel, Rebuking Democratic Critics
abstract: Republicans rushed to schedule a vote on the measure after a leading progressive Democrat condemned Israel as racist ahead of an address to Congress by the country’s president.
lead_paragraph: The House on Tuesday overwhelmingly passed a resolution pledging unfailing support for Israel, condemning antisemitism and declaring that the country is neither racist nor an apartheid state, in an implicit rebuke of Democrats who have criticized the nation ahead of an address by its president to a joint session of Congress.

headline: Actors’ Strike Won’t Halt 39 Independent Projects, Union Says
abstract: SAG-AFTRA confirmed the productions had no ties to the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents big studios. More exemptions could follow.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood actors’ union said Tuesday that it had exempted 39 independent film and TV projects from its strike, including two movies from A24, the secretive New York company that has become a force at the Academy Awards.

headline: Trump’s Conspirators Are Facing the Music, Finally
abstract: We are entering a new phase in the quest to hold people accountable not only for the violence on Jan. 6 but also for what got us there.
lead_paragraph: We’ve reached a turning point in the effort to ensure there are consequences for those who deliberately attempt to undermine our democracy: Michigan’s attorney general, Dana Nessel, charged 16 Republican leaders in her state on Tuesday for their role as fake electors working to overturn the results of the 2020 election. The charges, coming on the heels of news that the special counsel Jack Smith has informed Donald Trump that he’s a target of the Department of Justice’s investigation into the Capitol riot, mean we are witnessing a new and necessary phase in this quest for accountability, one in which the federal and state wheels of justice work to hold people accountable not only for the violence on Jan. 6 but also for what got us there: the alleged scheme to interfere with the transfer of power.

headline: Review: A Lack of Passion Keeps This ‘Orpheus Descending’ Earthbound
abstract: Erica Schmidt’s revival of this Tennessee Williams play for Theater for a New Audience downplays the melodrama.
lead_paragraph: Clad in a snazzy snakeskin jacket and carrying a guitar, Val Xavier steps into a small town’s mercantile like a handsome troubadour dropping by to serenade the locals. But he is a stranger whose car has broken down, and in the South of the 1950s, the local women are going to talk and the local men might just stalk.

headline: ‘Ya Dig?’
abstract: Billy Bratton’s grid gets with it.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Corrections: July 19, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the Christians United for Israel Summit misidentified the lawmaker who described Israel as “a racist state” at a progressive conference over the weekend and who is the chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus. She is Representative Pramila Jayapal, not Representative Rashida Tlaib. And it is Ms. Tlaib who is the first Palestinian American woman elected to Congress, not Ms. Jayapal.

headline: Biden to Netanyahu: Please Stop Trying to Rush Through Your Judicial Overhaul. Build a Consensus First.
abstract: In a rare move, President Biden publicly voiced his support for the monthslong democracy protests underway in Israel.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has had an intense week dealing with the battle inside Israel over the future of its judiciary, speaking with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu by phone on Monday and President Isaac Herzog in person at the White House on Tuesday.

headline: Kissinger Meets Top Officials in China and Gets a Warm Greeting
abstract: At 100, Henry Kissinger met with China’s top diplomat as well as its defense minister, who last month rejected an invitation to meet with the U.S. defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: Henry A. Kissinger, the 100-year-old former secretary of state who has pushed the United States to take a more conciliatory approach to China, has made a surprise visit to Beijing, meeting with China’s top foreign policy official and its defense minister.

headline: Biden Administration Moves to Ban Funding for Wuhan Lab
abstract: A memo said an official suspension of funding to the lab, which has not received any U.S. money since 2020, was necessary to “mitigate any potential public health risk.”
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is taking steps to impose a 10-year ban on funding for the Wuhan Institute of Virology, the Chinese research laboratory at the center of a heated debate over the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, according to a memo made public by a House subcommittee on Tuesday evening and an official familiar with the issue.

headline: Why Britain’s Mortgage Holders Are Being Squeezed
abstract: The Bank of England’s campaign to curb inflation is pushing up monthly payments for millions of homeowners.
lead_paragraph: Every six weeks, at noon on Thursday, mortgage holders in Britain brace for more bad news. It’s the moment the latest Bank of England decision on interest rates is announced.

headline: As Sunak Makes His Case to Britons, the Economy Could Undermine It
abstract: Britain’s Conservative government faces a morass of problems, some new, others longstanding, that are stymying Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak hopes to hold on to power by promoting himself as the repairman for a broken Britain. With the country’s high inflation, spiraling debt and sputtering growth, it often seems hard to know where he should start.

headline: For These Ukrainian Soldiers, the Fight Is Personal
abstract: Ukraine lets soldiers from towns occupied by the Russian military join the battle to reclaim them.
lead_paragraph: The objective for one private taking part in Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia is not complicated: it is a house near the beach, overflowing with flowers, the play room strewn with toys.

headline: There’s a British Open Winner Coaching High School Golf in Ohio
abstract: Ben Curtis was an international sensation after he won a major tournament on his first try. He is thrilled to have a quieter life now.
lead_paragraph: All of the noise is gone now. There is no entourage, no hubbub, no fuss. Instead of yukking it up with David Letterman, as he did 20 years ago this month, Ben Curtis is spending the morning teaching southeast of Cleveland and steeling himself for the roughly 750-mile drive to South Carolina for a family vacation.

headline: Facing a Future of Drought, Spain Turns to Medieval Solutions and ‘Ancient Wisdom’
abstract: Acequias, a network of water channels created by the Moors over 1,000 years ago, are being excavated and brought back to life to adapt to the crises of climate change.
lead_paragraph: High in Spain’s southern mountains, 40 or so people armed with pitchforks and spades cleared stones and piles of grass from an earthwork channel built centuries ago and still keeping the slopes green.

headline: Swimming the Lordly Hudson, All 315 Miles of It
abstract: Lewis Pugh, a British endurance swimmer, sees the river as the prime example of how a toxic waterway can be revived.
lead_paragraph: During its 315-mile journey from the Adirondacks to New York City, the Hudson River ranges from meek creek to mighty byway, flows past ghost towns, bombed-out factories and the state capital, and vacillates between stretches of pristine beauty and fetid intrusions of chemicals, bacteria and other toxic backwash.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Twenty Years Later, Overnight Sensation Enjoys the Quiet Life
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 19, 2023
lead_paragraph: “It made me realize I never wanted to be like that — like, I would never want to be in Tiger Woods’s shoes.”

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Extreme heat across the world.
lead_paragraph: Punishing heat waves in Europe, North America and Asia broke records in cities around the Northern Hemisphere less than two weeks after the Earth recorded what scientists said were most likely its hottest days in modern history.

headline: All Is Not Well on Russian Front Lines
abstract: In the wake of Yevgeny Prigozhin’s rebellion, Vladimir Putin is doubling down on failure.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of Yevgeny Prigozhin’s failed rebellion, it seems as if Russia’s leaders are living in an alternate reality.

headline: Jason Aldean Video for ‘Try That in a Small Town’ Pulled Amid Backlash
abstract: The country singer said the tune is an ode to the “feeling of a community” he had growing up. Critics say it is offensive.
lead_paragraph: Country Music Television has pulled a music video for the song “Try That in a Small Town,” by the country music superstar Jason Aldean, which was filmed at the site of a lynching, amid accusations that its lyrics and message are offensive.

headline: What Improv Can Do for Mathematicians
abstract: Coaching sessions at the People’s Improv Theater were aimed at helping math experts connect with laypeople and give engaging presentations.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll solve for x and y, where x is a group of high-level mathematicians and y is an improvisational theater workshop. This one’s easy, even if you’re not very good at math. We’ll also look at Mayor Eric Adams’s fund-raising.

headline: Word of the Day: megalopolis
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word megalopolis has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 21 in “Exploring a Plan to Remake the L.A. River” by Soumya Karlamangla:

headline: Protesters Gather in Thailand as Parliament Faces Gridlock
abstract: Demonstrations unfolded after lawmakers prevented a progressive candidate from contesting a vote for prime minister. Another vote will be held next week. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Protests erupted in Bangkok on Wednesday, hours after Thailand’s conservative establishment suspended a progressive leader and lawmakers denied him the chance to stand for a second parliamentary vote for prime minister.

headline: U.K. Inflation Rate Slows to 7.9%, as Price Pressures Ease
abstract: The larger-than-expected slowdown, led by motor vehicle fuel prices, offers some relief to the government and the Bank of England.
lead_paragraph: Consumer prices in Britain rose 7.9 percent in June from a year earlier, the Office for National Statistics said on Wednesday, the slowest pace of inflation in more than a year.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Curse Stalking Women’s Soccer
abstract: The World Cup is missing some of the sport’s biggest stars because of a knee injury epidemic. No one can say for sure why it’s happening, or how to fix it.
lead_paragraph: The third time around, Megan Rapinoe’s reaction to a potentially career-ending knee injury went no further than an eye roll. She had torn her anterior cruciate ligament. She could reel off the recovery schedule from the top of her head. She could see, crystal clear, the next nine to 12 months spooling out in front of her.

headline: For Families of Other Gilgo Beach Victims, an Agonizing Wait Goes On
abstract: Authorities continue to investigate whether 8 other corpses found along miles of sand are linked to Rex Heuermann, who they say is a serial killer.
lead_paragraph: Jasmine Robinson sat in a Suffolk County courthouse Friday, listening intently as prosecutors explained how they had tracked a man they suspected of killing and burying at least three women on Long Island’s South Shore. She heard how they had used DNA painstakingly harvested from his pizza crusts, triangulated his mobile phone signals and spent hours on old-school, shoe-leather stakeouts.

headline: The grain deal helped make food more affordable to poor nations.
abstract: The backlash was swift on Monday after Russia refused to extend a deal that allowed Ukraine to export millions of tons of grains, with experts warning that it would help drive food prices higher for the poorest nations.
lead_paragraph: The backlash was swift on Monday after Russia refused to extend a deal that allowed Ukraine to export millions of tons of grains, with experts warning that it would help drive food prices higher for the poorest nations.

headline: Jaguar Land Rover’s Owner to Build Battery Plant in England
abstract: The factory, made possible by government subsidies, could produce nearly half of the electric-car batteries needed in Britain by 2030.
lead_paragraph: Tata, the Indian-based conglomerate, announced on Wednesday that it would build a 4 billion-pound ($5.2 billion) battery plant in western England, a commitment sought by the auto industry and lawmakers hoping to stem fears of an exodus of car manufacturers from Britain.

headline: Official Data Hinted at China’s Hidden Covid Toll. Then It Vanished.
abstract: Epidemiologists say a rise in cremations in an eastern province was the latest indication that the country’s official death toll from Covid is a vast undercount.
lead_paragraph: Official data from China offered a rare, but brief, glimpse of the true toll of Covid, indicating that nearly as many people may have died from the virus in a single province earlier this year as Beijing has said died in the mainland during the entire pandemic.

headline: Newly Published, From a Bayou Thriller to Drugs in America
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: DOWN WITH THE POOR!, by Shumona Sinha. Translated by Teresa Lavender Fagan. (Deep Vellum, paperback, $16.95.) After a Bengali interpreter who works with asylum seekers in Paris is charged with assaulting a refugee, her resulting self-examination lays bare the callousness of France’s asylum system.

headline: How Well Do You Know Your Baseball Hall of Famers?
abstract: The language used to describe players on plaques at the Baseball Hall of Fame has evolved over the years. Can you pick out who is who in this quiz?
lead_paragraph: The language used to describe players on plaques at the Baseball Hall of Fame has evolved over the years. Can you pick out who is who in this quiz?

headline: ‘Break Point’ Is the Best Way to See the Full Psychodrama of Tennis
abstract: The Netflix docuseries gets the highs and lows of the pro circuit right.
lead_paragraph: In the sixth episode of the Netflix docuseries “Break Point,” Ajla Tomljanovic, a journeywoman tennis player who has spent much of the last decade in the Top 100 of the world rankings, is shown splayed across an exercise mat in a drab training room after reaching the 2022 Wimbledon quarterfinals. Her father, Ratko, stretches out her hamstrings. She receives a congratulatory phone call from her sister and another from her idol-turned-mentor, the 18-time major champion Chris Evert, before Ratko announces that it’s time for the dreaded ice bath. “By the way,” Tomljanovic says at one point, “do we have a room?” Shortly after his daughter sealed her spot in the final eight of the world’s pre-eminent tennis tournament, Ratko was seen on booking.com, extending their stay in London.

headline: Is ‘Yo’ the Gender-Neutral Pronoun You’ve Been Looking For?
abstract: Sometimes nonstandard English variants are the most sophisticated options out there.
lead_paragraph: I am in the middle of writing a book on pronouns in English. My focus this time out is on standard English rather than nonstandard English, since one of my recent books was about Black English. However, again and again I am struck that the most dynamic, “Who’da thunk it?” developments in pronouns are in the Englishes beyond the standard.

headline: ‘Gut-Level Hatred’ Is Consuming Our Political Life
abstract: Three more ways we are splitting apart.
lead_paragraph: Divisions between Democrats and Republicans have expanded far beyond the traditional fault lines based on race, education, gender, the urban-rural divide and economic ideology.

headline: Read Your Way Through Salvador
abstract: The writer Itamar Vieira Junior says that to “feel the intensity of life on the streets of Salvador” in Bahia, Brazil, a reader must start with Jorge Amado.
lead_paragraph: I was born in Salvador, in the Brazilian state of Bahia, and lived in the general vicinity until I reached the age of 15. But it was when I left that I really came to know my city. How was I able to discover more about my birthplace while traveling far from home? It might sound rather clichéd but, I assure you, literature made this possible: It took me on a journey, long and profound, back home, enveloping me in words and imagination.

headline: Biden Administration Unveils Tougher Guidelines on Mergers
abstract: The proposed road map for regulatory reviews, last updated in 2020, includes a focus on tech platforms for the first time.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s top antitrust officials unveiled tougher guidelines against tech mergers on Wednesday, signaling their deepening scrutiny of the industry despite recent court losses in their attempts to block tech deal-making.

headline: Republicans Shrug at Latest Possible Trump Indictment
abstract: News of a possible indictment related to Jan. 6 brought a muddled response from some of Donald Trump’s 2024 rivals, and familiar attacks on President Biden from his allies in Congress.
lead_paragraph: The indictments of Donald J. Trump — past and pending — are becoming the background music of the 2024 presidential campaign: always there, shaping the mood, yet not fully the focus.

headline: American Theater Is Imploding Before Our Eyes
abstract: Government bailouts saved the automotive and banking industries. American theater is in similar trouble and deserves to be saved.
lead_paragraph: The American theater is on the verge of collapse.

headline: The Victory for Over-the-Counter Birth Control Pills Is Just the Beginning
abstract: One brand of oral contraceptive will soon be available on pharmacy shelves. What else could follow?
lead_paragraph: Amid so much discouraging news about reproductive health access in the wake of Roe v. Wade’s demise, the announcement by the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday that it was approving Opill, a daily oral contraceptive, for over-the-counter sale to people of all ages, felt like a breath of fresh air. The evidence is clear that removing the prescription requirement for birth control pills — Opill was the first such medication to be approved but surely won’t be the last — will improve access to a highly effective form of contraception for millions of Americans.

headline: How a ‘Swole Woman’ Lifted Her Way to a New Outlook and Online Influence
abstract: For Casey Johnston, who has reinvented her physique and social media presence, weight training is about taking ownership of one’s body.
lead_paragraph: More Than Likes is a series about social media personalities who are trying to do positive things for their communities.

headline: Quadruplets With Schizophrenia? Researchers Were Confounded.
abstract: “Girls and Their Monsters,” by Audrey Clare Farley, recounts the tragic story of the Genain sisters, seeing the subjects at the crossroads of psychiatric and societal forces.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years ago, a psychologist at the National Institute of Mental Health named David Rosenthal published a famous but now largely forgotten study of four sisters with schizophrenia, quadruplets born to Carl and Sadie Morlok in 1930. The Morlok quadruplets — renamed Genain in the scientific literature — had grown up in the same house, and come from the same fertilized egg, but did not appear to have the same version of the disease.

headline: The Sandwich Southerners Wait for All Year
abstract: A lush tomato, eaten in peak summer, is meant to be pined over.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes even the most obvious combinations need recipes. Because a recipe is more than just instruction: It documents a habit, an account, a particular way of cooking a dish. And yet, it’s also the simplest dishes that can cause the most controversy.

headline: $860,000 Homes in California, Missouri and Massachusetts
abstract: A Spanish-style home in Altadena, a 2022 townhouse in St. Louis and an 1870 Carpenter Gothic cottage on Martha’s Vineyard.
lead_paragraph: This house is within a five-minute walk of two trailheads in Hahamongna Watershed Park, a 1,300-acre space with popular hiking trails, a disc golf course and a nursery specializing in native plants. A public elementary school and a public library are a few blocks away. Jet Propulsion Laboratory, one of the area’s biggest employers, is a five-minute drive.

headline: Public and Private Lives, Playing Out in Four Sultry Romance Novels
abstract: The tropes may be familiar in these romance novels — fake dating, falling for a celebrity — but the books themselves are fresh and beguiling.
lead_paragraph: Hana Sheik’s THE BABY SWAP THAT BOUND THEM (Harlequin, ebook, $3.99) starts with a pair of newborns in a Ugandan hospital: One is the son of Yusra, a divorced graphic designer; the other is an infant orphaned in a car crash, who must now be raised by a gruff, reclusive billionaire guardian named Bashir. Both birth experiences are marked by grief. There is love, but it is a desperate, dark feeling — love as need, as defensiveness, as loss.

headline: My City Has Run Out of Fresh Water. Will Your City Be Next?
abstract: It’s long since time for us to make potable water our first priority.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — For at least 80 days, ever since drought and mismanagement sapped the drinking water supply of my country’s capital, the water that has come out of our taps has tasted terribly of salt and smelled awfully of chemicals. Those of us who can afford bottled water use it for everything. We cook pasta, wash lettuce and make coffee with it, buying more and more plastic water containers that wind up in the dump. When we shower, we keep it short and keep the windows open, because trihalomethane compounds in the steam may be carcinogenic. Washing machines don’t foam, and the electric water heaters are failing from a buildup of sodium. Dishwashers leave salty streaks on glasses and plates. Brushing your teeth tastes like taking a gulp of pool water.

headline: L.A. by Subway
abstract: The newly expanded subway may not go everywhere, but for $5 a day it offers a gridlock-free way to get to plenty of great places.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of free and cheap things to do in Los Angeles. As a traveler, the issue is getting to them. From Los Angeles International Airport, rental cars recently priced out around $75 a day before tax and gas. Taxis and app-based rides between the airport and downtown cost $40 to $70, depending on the time of day. Then there’s overnight parking — $50 to $60 isn’t unusual.

headline: What a ‘Human-Centered’ Approach Can Do for Workers With Disabilities
abstract: Obtaining reasonable accommodations is often a messy, frustrating process for both employees and their managers. But there are solutions.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2015, Katherine Macfarlane was preparing to teach at the University of Idaho’s law school. It was her first teaching job on a tenure track, and she wanted to make sure she had everything she needed. So she submitted a request for a keyboard tray and a few other office items.

headline: ‘Training My Replacement’: Inside a Call Center Worker’s Battle With A.I.
abstract: To many people, chatbots and other technology feel like a ticking time bomb, sure to explode their work. But to some, the threat is already here.
lead_paragraph: “This A.I. stuff is getting really crazy.”

headline: Is the World Ready for Another Goop?
abstract: Sporty & Rich, a popular line of merch that promotes healthy, luxurious living, is opening its first store-spa-cafe. Next stop: colonic clubs?
lead_paragraph: There was once an Instagram account called Sporty & Rich. For a time, it served no commercial purpose. It was more of a brain tickle of pleasing images: a mood board of supermodels, interiors and advertisements, mostly from the 1980s and 1990s.

headline: Watching for the Bus Stop Gallery
abstract: Felipe Baeza’s “Unruly Forms” are coming to bus shelters in the U.S. and Mexico. Merging painting and printmaking, his images explore the displacement of migrants and antiquities.
lead_paragraph: The artist Felipe Baeza knows something about waiting for the bus. Growing up in Chicago in the 1990s, he rode the city bus on his own starting around age nine. Going to college at Cooper Union in New York to study art, he took the bus or subway from his home in Spanish Harlem to get to class. This year, living in Los Angeles for a period without a car, he’d take a bus — or two or three — to get across town, though he sometimes gave up after an absurdly long wait and called an Uber.

headline: In Florida, Swimmers Brave an Ocean That Feels Like Steamy Syrup
abstract: Toweling off seemed unnecessary, as no one felt cold emerging from water that reached record temperatures off the coast of South Florida in recent days.
lead_paragraph: The water temperature near Key Biscayne, a barrier island just east of Miami, had already passed 89 degrees one morning this week. And though the ocean off South Florida was slightly cooler than the recent record highs that had stunned scientists and threatened marine life, it remained phenomenally hot.

headline: Our Favorite Magical Creatures Live at Ghibli Park, So We Had to Go
abstract: The Japanese company Studio Ghibli opened a theme park to celebrate the eccentric, charming animated movies of its founder, Hayao Miyazaki. Could two ‘Totoro’-loving toddlers find happiness there?
lead_paragraph: One of our first infractions at Ghibli Park was hoisting our 1-year-old onto the polyester tummy of a woodland spirit creature. Another was letting him slip under a barricade and shelter inside a furry bus with cat eyes for headlights.

headline: Want to Help Feathered Friends Beat the Heat? Get a Birdbath.
abstract: A well-placed, properly maintained birdbath can be a vital resource for birds and other wildlife, and needn’t attract mosquitoes
lead_paragraph: Record temperatures, drought, smoky air and loss of habitat make it increasingly difficult for feathered and other winged creatures in urban and suburban areas to find the water they need.

headline: Our Favorite Workouts So Far This Year
abstract: Halfway through 2023, find the exercise that will help you finish the year strong — no matter your fitness level.
lead_paragraph: It’s mid-July, which means that summer, as well as 2023, is about halfway over. Now is a good time to get outside and get active, whether running, biking or just splashing in the water with friends and family. It’s also a great time to build good exercise habits that can carry you through the rest of the year.

headline: It’s an Honor to Wear This Jersey. It’s Also Kind of a Pain.
abstract: The yellow jersey worn by the Tour de France race leader can sometimes be an uncomfortable fit.
lead_paragraph: Jonas Vingegaard had been wearing the famed yellow jersey bestowed upon the leader of the Tour de France for almost a week when the question came.

headline: Working 9 to 5, Hopefully
abstract: “In college I was looking forward to becoming an adult, and now I’m here and it’s horrible.” Seventeen 2023 graduates show and tell us how they feel about entering the work force.
lead_paragraph: There’s good news for recent college graduates: The labor market is strong, unemployment is low and, according to a survey by the National Association of Colleges and Employers, businesses are expecting to hire almost 4 percent more graduates from the class of 2023 than they did from the previous class.

headline: Where the Sheriff Is King, These Women Say He Coerced Them Into Sex
abstract: Sheriff Eddie Scott has been the top lawman in rural Clay County, Miss., for more than a decade despite repeated allegations.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, three months after Eddie Scott became sheriff of Clay County, Miss., a claim by a woman he had helped put behind bars threatened to tarnish his earliest days in office.

headline: China’s Xi Rebuffs Kerry’s Call for Faster Climate Action
abstract: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, emerges from talks in Beijing without a new agreement. But just talking is progress, he said.
lead_paragraph: Chinese leaders rebuffed attempts by John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, to persuade them to commit to tougher climate action during three days of talks in Beijing, a response that suggested that tensions between the countries are making it difficult to work together on a crisis that threatens the planet.

headline: The U.S. Weather by the Numbers
abstract: How hot is it? No single temperature reading can capture the nation’s misery, so we’ve assembled a lot of figures to put the oppressive heat in context.
lead_paragraph: All signs indicate that this will be one of the hottest summers on record, as a heat wave scorches the Northern Hemisphere. Large portions of the United States are sweating through oppressive conditions that show no signs of easing, accompanied by a growing death toll.

headline: U.S. and China on Climate: How the World’s Two Largest Polluters Stack Up
abstract: From gas emissions to electric vehicles, here is how the world’s two biggest economies — and polluters — compare on taking steps to confront climate change.
lead_paragraph: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate change envoy, wraps up high-level talks with Chinese officials on Wednesday aimed at finding ways to work together on climate change despite simmering tensions between the two world powers.

headline: Today’s Top News: Trump Faces a Possible Second Federal Indictment, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: How the Birth Control Pill Got Over the Counter
abstract: The availability of the pill without a prescription could significantly expand access to contraception.
lead_paragraph: Last week, for the first time in U.S. history, federal regulators approved the sale of a birth control pill without a prescription.

headline: Living In ... Esopus, N.Y.
abstract: This Ulster County town is known for nature preserves, waterfront homes and quietly affluent residents: ‘They’re not in-your-face flashy.’
lead_paragraph: This Ulster County town is known for nature preserves, waterfront homes and quietly affluent residents: ‘They’re not in-your-face flashy.’

headline: Esopus, N.Y.: ‘Pristine Natural Surroundings’ and Stealth Wealth
abstract: This Ulster County town is known for its nature preserves, waterfront homes and quietly affluent residents: ‘They’re not in-your-face flashy.’
lead_paragraph: John Zindar moved to Esopus to become a father.

headline: Where the Two Koreas Meet
abstract: A look at Panmunjom, where officials say a U.S. soldier crossed into North Korea this week.
lead_paragraph: A look at Panmunjom, where officials say a U.S. soldier crossed into North Korea this week.

headline: ‘Leave No Bunny Behind’: A Florida Town Works to Rescue Dozens of Rabbits
abstract: After a former resident abandoned a pair of pet rabbits that bred dozens more, residents on a small island in Wilton Manors, Fla., have begun efforts to save and re-home the growing colony.
lead_paragraph: Residents of a suburb outside Fort Lauderdale, Fla., don’t quite know what to do about their new neighbors: dozens of domesticated rabbits, and counting.

headline: A Looming Indictment
abstract: Three big questions about a potential indictment of Trump in the special counsel investigation.
lead_paragraph: With a third indictment of Donald Trump now seeming quite likely — this one involving his attempts to remain in power after losing the 2020 election — today’s newsletter will cover three big questions about the case.

headline: What We Know About How a U.S. Soldier Ended Up in North Korea
abstract: The soldier, Pvt. Travis T. King, was supposed to be on a plane to the United States, but instead he joined a group tour of the DMZ. Then he bolted for the border.
lead_paragraph: The world was shocked on Tuesday when a United States soldier willfully and illegally crossed the inter-Korean border during a group tour of the Demilitarized Zone, or DMZ, becoming the latest American citizen to be held in custody by North Korea.

headline: Carvana, Used Car Dealer, Reaches Deal to Restructure Debt
abstract: Most of the company’s bondholders have agreed to accept bonds that are worth less than what they were owed but that are secured against real estate and other assets.
lead_paragraph: Carvana, the troubled used car retailer, announced on Wednesday that it had reached a debt restructuring agreement with most of its bondholders in an effort to lower interest payments over at least the next two years and put its business on more solid financial footing.

headline: Is the Cure to Male Loneliness Out on the Pickleball Court?
abstract: Men, go play. It’s good for you and for the health of the nation.
lead_paragraph: The more I learn about the epidemic of male loneliness, the more I’m convinced that America needs to send its men out to play: fishing, golfing, hiking, biking, bow hunting — or, for the less sporty types, Ping-Pong, poker, chess, competitive grilling. You get the idea. The particulars aren’t so important. What matters is that guys start clocking quality time together, preferably without wives or girlfriends along.

headline: Kim Kardashian’s Skims Is Now Worth $4 Billion
abstract: As the apparel company prepares to expand into physical stores and men’s clothing, its latest funding round may spur questions about when it intends to go public.
lead_paragraph: Four years into its existence, Skims, the apparel company co-founded by Kim Kardashian, has become a unicorn four times over.

headline: 175 Writing Prompts to Spark Discussion and Reflection
abstract: Here are all of our Student Opinion questions from the 2022-23 school year. Each question is based on a different New York Times article, interactive feature or video.
lead_paragraph: Each day of the school year we publish a Student Opinion question: an invitation for students to share their own opinions and experiences in response to New York Times stories on the news of the day. Each of these prompts is introduced with an article, interactive feature or video produced by The Times.

headline: Biden’s Antitrust Team Isn’t Backing Down From a Fight on Deals
abstract: New guidelines show that despite legal setbacks, top competition officials intend to maintain a tough approach to takeovers and technology giants.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission announced their long-awaited merger guidelines on Wednesday morning, and the proposed regulatory framework reveals that the regulators aren’t changing their aggressive approach despite losing a series of court cases when they tried to block transactions.

headline: Steep Profit Fall at Goldman Sachs Highlights Wall St. Giant’s Woes
abstract: The investment bank reported a profit half as large as its rival Morgan Stanley, to say nothing of larger lenders.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs on Wednesday reported quarterly profit that fell short of even dampened expectations, another reminder of the troubles facing one of Wall Street’s premier names.

headline: Microsoft and Activision Delay Deal to Settle British Regulatory Issues
abstract: The extension is most likely a signal that the companies believe they will eventually receive needed approvals.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft and Activision Blizzard said on Wednesday that they were delaying a $69 billion merger as the two companies scrambled to get final approval from British antitrust regulators.

headline: My Husband and I Sleep in Separate Bedrooms. Why Is My Mother-in-Law Obsessed?
abstract: A reader asks which details of her marriage — if any — she is obligated to share with her visiting mother-in-law.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have been married for 12 years and have a 7-year-old daughter. We no longer share a bedroom or have sex, but we continue living together peacefully to raise our child. My mother-in-law discovered our separate bedrooms while I was out of town: She was helping to care for our daughter and asking lots of questions, so my daughter told her. Since then, she asked a close friend about our situation — which bothered me. But she’s never said anything to me. Now, she and my father-in-law are planning a visit and she’s asking many questions about their sleeping arrangements. She even offered to sleep on an air mattress. I told her she was welcome to take our daughter’s room, as always, and our daughter would move to the guest room (just as she did before my husband started sleeping there). Am I obliged to discuss this with her?

headline: Need Some Coastal Escape? Got Gold Rush Fever? Explore These State Parks.
abstract: These five parks represent only a small fraction of California’s extensive park system, but they offer lots of summertime adventure.
lead_paragraph: Kids are out of school, the weather is balmy in much of the state and the days are long — it’s time for summer travel.

headline: Protests Simmer in Israel as Country’s President Prepares to Address Congress
abstract: The small protests reflect the broad nature of popular opposition to plans by Israel’s government to overhaul the judiciary, and seemed timed to coincide with the speech by President Isaac Herzog.
lead_paragraph: Small protests cropped up across Israel on Wednesday, illustrating the broad, grass-roots nature of popular opposition to plans by the government to overhaul the country’s judiciary, drawing in key sectors of the economy, the security establishment and society.

headline: This Summer Has Been a Travel Nightmare. Technology Isn’t Helping.
abstract: All those supposedly frictionless QR codes and apps can make things more annoying.
lead_paragraph: The past month has been — to borrow a phrase — a flightmare. Summer is generally the busiest travel season of the year, and the Northeast, where I live, has been hit with consecutive weekends of severe thunderstorms, leading to thousands of flight cancellations. Dealing with the fallout of the cancellations is an additional fiasco on top of the already chaotic summer airport scene.

headline: A Cow, a Camel and a Finch Exploded in Space. What Is Going On?
abstract: Astronomers have yet to determine the cause of luminous fast blue optical transients, and the latest they have detected is raising even more questions.
lead_paragraph: What do a cow, a koala, a camel, a Tasmanian devil and now a finch all have in common?

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: British Open Organizer Does Not Rule Out Deal With Saudi Wealth Fund
abstract: The Open is not looking for a title sponsor for one of the world’s most celebrated tournaments, but other options could be on the table.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the R&A, who only a year ago was among the fiercest critics of LIV Golf, did not rule out the possibility on Wednesday that the group, the British Open’s organizer, could someday accept money from Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund.

headline: She’s on a Mission From God: Suing Big Oil for Climate Damages
abstract: A lawyer started small with a creative tactic. It grew into an effort that could force fossil fuel companies to pay hundreds of billions in damages.
lead_paragraph: Missy Sims carefully picked her way through a field of ruined tombs in central Puerto Rico, in a cemetery where walls of water from Hurricane Maria had smashed open some coffins and sent others careering into a nearby stream.

headline: Israeli President Works to Ease Tensions With U.S., Calling Bond ‘Irreplaceable’
abstract: In a speech to Congress, President Isaac Herzog acknowledged problems at home that have strained Israel’s bond with the United States, but appealed for continued close ties.
lead_paragraph: President Isaac Herzog of Israel used an address to Congress on Wednesday to try to smooth over fresh tensions between his country and the United States, appealing to American lawmakers to continue investing in the “irreplaceable” relationship even as he acknowledged problems at home that have strained that bond.

headline: Wesleyan University Ends Legacy Admissions
abstract: With the Supreme Court’s decision to ban race-conscious admissions, the pressure is on selective colleges to end preferences for children of alumni.
lead_paragraph: Wesleyan University, a liberal arts college in Connecticut, is ending legacy admissions, which give a leg up to the children of alumni, just weeks after the Supreme Court struck down affirmative action.

headline: Reporting in Yiddish, Without Speaking Yiddish
abstract: In an Australian community working to preserve its identity, a journalist found subjects with plenty of questions for her.
lead_paragraph: The ground rules were simple: I would report an article on Australia’s Yiddish speakers at Sof-Vokh Oystralye, a Yiddish immersion weekend outside Melbourne last May, and remain “a flig oyf der vant” — a fly on the wall.

headline: Price of N.Y.C. Subway Ride Will Go Up for the First Time in Years
abstract: The M.T.A. board voted to raise the base fare to $2.90 from $2.75, after pausing increases to try to lure back riders lost during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the coronavirus pandemic decimated subway ridership in New York City, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has resisted raising the price of a ride out of fear that even more people would abandon mass transit.

headline: 1898: Riots in Shanghai Are Now Subsiding
abstract: Sailors remained on guard at the French settlement after violence in which 22 Chinese people were killed and 50 others wounded.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong, Monday. — The riots at the French settlement at Shanghai are subsiding. Twenty-two Chinese have been killed and fifty wounded. The French sailors are maintaining a guard.

headline: Can I Watch ‘Barbenheimer’ Despite the Hollywood Strikes?
abstract: People sympathetic with the strikers may be concerned, but the actors’ and writers’ unions say it’s OK to go to the movies and use streaming services.
lead_paragraph: A clip from the sitcom “The Nanny” has been making the rounds on social media. It shows Fran Fine — played by Fran Drescher, the current Screen Actors Guild president — telling her boss one of her mother’s three cardinal rules: “Never, ever, ever cross a picket line.”

headline: Dermot Doran, Priest Who Rallied Aid for Biafran Airlift, Dies at 88
abstract: In 1968, Father Doran, who had been in Nigeria as an educator, became the linchpin of one of the largest civilian humanitarian efforts in history.
lead_paragraph: The cargo plane flew in low over southeastern Nigeria, its lights out, its radio off, its pilot navigating by the glow of refinery flares along the coast. The runway, somewhere below, was dark. The pilot dropped his wheels and nosed the plane downward, seemingly into the void.

headline: This Soy-Butter Corn Ramen Has Peak Summer Flavor
abstract: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s new recipes make the most of everyday produce.
lead_paragraph: One cooking myth I’m ready to see disappear is that vegetable-based meals are harder or more time-consuming to make than meat-based ones. I’d argue that it’s just a matter of experience: The more you cook with vegetables, the more comfortable and confident you become with turning them into a quick and satisfying dinner. There’s nothing inherent in a piece of meat that makes it faster to cook than, say, a couple of zucchini or a bunch of kale.

headline: The Pandemic’s Labor Market Myths
abstract: Amid the pandemic, people thought the labor market had permanently changed in important ways. It was a bad bet.
lead_paragraph: Remember the “she-cession”? What about the early-retirement wave, or America’s army of quiet quitters?

headline: Could the Recession in the Distance Be Just a Mirage?
abstract: Rising interest rates were widely expected to put the U.S. economy in reverse. Now things are looking rosier, but don’t pop the Champagne corks yet.
lead_paragraph: The recession was supposed to have begun by now.

headline: Should You Check Your Bag, or Bring a Carry-On?
abstract: Readers react to a guest essay urging passengers not to check their luggage. Also: Musing about artificial intelligence; affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Starving Orcas and the Fate of Alaska’s Disappearing King Salmon
abstract: With the fish numbers at historic lows, scientists, chefs and others are asking whether we should be eating them anymore, and what it means for the future of all wild salmon.
lead_paragraph: In the waters of Puget Sound outside Seattle, 73 beloved and endangered orcas, known as the Southern Residents, are on the hunt, clicking. Using sound like a searchlight, they patrol the chilly depths. When they locate a target, they dive, sinking sharp white teeth into their preferred food, the fatty coral-colored flesh of king salmon.

headline: Is It Ever Morally Acceptable to Visit a Confederate Historical Site?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on tourism at Beauvoir, the former home of Jefferson Davis.
lead_paragraph: I recently moved back home to Biloxi, Miss., and I’m wondering about visiting the lavish grounds of Beauvoir, the historical site and home of Jefferson Davis, the president of the Confederate States of America.

headline: Why Odesa Is So Important to Ukraine in the War With Russia
abstract: Russia’s withdrawal from a U.N.-backed grain deal and its attacks on Odesa have brought the Black Sea port city’s importance back into focus.
lead_paragraph: The last two nights have brought some of the most furious Russian aerial assaults on Odesa, the southern Ukrainian port city, of the nearly 17-month-long war. The city on the Black Sea has long been Ukraine’s link to the global economy and home to its busiest ports.

headline: Heavy Rains Flood Southwestern Kentucky
abstract: Neighborhoods were flooded by several inches of rain in southwestern Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: Neighborhoods were flooded by several inches of rain in southwestern Kentucky.

headline: Floods Sweep Southwestern Kentucky
abstract: Graves County, on the border with Tennessee, received more than 11 inches of rain, leading to “flooding like many have never seen,” the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Strong thunderstorms and heavy rain caused significant flooding in southwestern Kentucky on Wednesday, breaking one daily rainfall record and prompting the authorities to scramble to rescue residents from rising waters.

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ Review: A Man for Our Time
abstract: Christopher Nolan’s complex, vivid portrait of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the “father of the atomic bomb,” is a brilliant achievement in formal and conceptual terms.
lead_paragraph: “Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s staggering film about J. Robert Oppenheimer, the man known as “the father of the atomic bomb,” condenses a titanic shift in consciousness into three haunted hours. A drama about genius, hubris and error, both individual and collective, it brilliantly charts the turbulent life of the American theoretical physicist who helped research and develop the two atomic bombs that were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki during World War II — cataclysms that helped usher in our human-dominated age.

headline: Netflix Reports Growth Amid the Backdrop of Two Strikes
abstract: The streaming company’s performance has been helped by its crackdown on password sharing and a relatively new advertising tier introduced last year.
lead_paragraph: Netflix added millions of subscribers in the second quarter and saw a rise in revenue, the company said on Wednesday in an upbeat earnings report that came at a moment when the entertainment industry is dealing with dual strikes inspired in part by the economics of streaming.

headline: Here’s Where Global Heat Records Stand So Far in July
abstract: Average temperatures for the entire globe have been at their highest on record, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: As cities around the world have been experiencing record temperatures, average temperatures for the entire globe in July have been at their highest on record, too.

headline: A New Summer Camp Activity: Dealing With Extreme Weather
abstract: Floods in New Hampshire and a heat dome in Texas have meant fewer happy campers this year.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy Sunday in July, the Trailblazers began to arrive at Camp Squanto, a 100-acre sleep-away retreat in southern New Hampshire. Parents drove them.

headline: Can’t Decide Whether to See ‘Barbie,’ ‘Oppenheimer’ or Both? Our Barbenheimer Quiz Can Help.
abstract: Answer these five questions about the biggest moviegoing weekend of the year.
lead_paragraph: Answer these five questions about the biggest moviegoing weekend of the year.

headline: Propaganda with an Ambiguous Message? That’s Art.
abstract: Josh Kline and the duo Komar and Melamid, in their respective museum shows, might seem to be telling you what to think — but they dwell between irony and sincerity.
lead_paragraph: Corona and Coca-Cola, sparklers and flags, a picnic with family and friends — it looks like a typical Independence Day in the United States — except that the flags are Confederate, and they’re being buried in a shallow grave.

headline: Chris Sununu Won’t Run for Re-election as Governor of New Hampshire
abstract: The decision by Mr. Sununu, a moderate Republican, sets up a competitive race next year to lead a battleground state, and Democrats will be eager to take advantage.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire, a Republican, said on Wednesday that he would not run for re-election in 2024, opening up a seat in a battleground state that Democrats will be eager to take.

headline: Stanford President Will Resign After Report Found Flaws in His Research
abstract: Marc Tessier-Lavigne was cleared of accusations of scientific fraud and misconduct. But the review said his work had “multiple problems” and “fell below customary standards of scientific rigor.”
lead_paragraph: Following months of intense scrutiny of his scientific work, Marc Tessier-Lavigne announced Wednesday that he would resign as president of Stanford University after an independent review of his research found significant flaws in studies he supervised going back decades.

headline: Britain’s Spy Master Says Putin Cut Deal With Wagner Mercenary Chief
abstract: Richard Moore, the chief of MI6, said the Russian leader acted “to save his skin,” offering rare insights into the events surrounding the sudden end of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s march on Moscow.
lead_paragraph: The chief of Britain’s intelligence agency, MI6, said on Wednesday that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had “cut a deal” with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner mercenary group, during Mr. Prigozhin’s failed rebellion last month.

headline: Rabbits Take Over a South Florida Suburb
abstract: About 75 rabbits have overrun a neighborhood outside of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
lead_paragraph: About 75 rabbits have overrun a neighborhood outside of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: Trump Promotes ‘Sound of Freedom,’ a Conservative Hit About Child Predators
abstract: Hosting a screening at his private club, the former president is the most prominent Republican to embrace a film lauded by both mainstream conservatives and far-right QAnon believers.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina called it an “amazing, gut-wrenching, emotional movie.”

headline: Insurers Deny Medical Care for the Poor at High Rates, Report Says
abstract: Investigators found that major companies overseeing Medicaid patients’ health care frequently rejected doctors’ requests for approval of treatments and procedures.
lead_paragraph: Private health insurance companies paid by Medicaid denied millions of requests for care for low-income Americans with little oversight from federal and state authorities, according to a new report by U.S. investigators published Wednesday.

headline: Global Warming Is Bringing More Change Than Just Heat
abstract: Climate change is already affecting the world in powerful ways. But it could also drive mass migration and reshape societies as its consequences add up.
lead_paragraph: Climate change is here, heating the world today, with direct and devastating consequences on human lives, the environment and more.

headline: There’s a Pesto Miracle Waiting in Your Freezer
abstract: Prepared pesto gives a one-pan orzo and zucchini dish its herby, garlicky bite.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a kitchen needs a last-minute miracle, and mine is always frozen pesto. At a moment’s notice, I can stir a spoonful of herby, garlicky zip into any dish that needs it, lifting it to a whole new level.

headline: ‘Barbie’ Reviews Are In: Slickly Subversive or Inescapably Corporate?
abstract: Some critics viewed the highly-anticipated movie as satirically capitalistic, while others saw it as capitalistically satirical.
lead_paragraph: As reviews for “Barbie” rolled out ahead of its weekend opening, a critical divide emerged.

headline: Egypt Pardons 2 Human Rights Activists Held in Prison
abstract: One of the presidential pardons came just a day after a graduate student was sentenced to three years for writing an article critical of the government.
lead_paragraph: Two of Egypt’s best-known political prisoners were granted presidential pardons on Wednesday, a day after one of them, a graduate student and human rights advocate, was sentenced to three years in prison over an online article he wrote describing discrimination against Egypt’s Coptic Christian minority.

headline: Where’s the Controversy in ‘Philip Guston Now’?
abstract: The show makes its final U.S. stop at the National Gallery without feared protests. But some caricatures in the artist’s “Poor Richard” series need better explanation.
lead_paragraph: When “Philip Guston Now” opened at the National Gallery of Art in Washington this spring, I could practically hear the collective sigh of relief on my Instagram feed. In 2020, shortly after the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis and the nationwide protests that followed, the four museums organizing a retrospective of his work announced a four-year delay of the exhibition, citing the need to make sure they were contextualizing Guston’s paintings — which include a series of cartoonish images of Klansmen as bumbling Keystone Kops — with proper sensitivity.

headline: One Economist Is Challenging How We Think Money Works
abstract: It’s “a surprisingly slippery concept,” he says.
lead_paragraph: What’s the difference between $100 in cash and $100 in a checking account? Nothing — and everything. The two are the same in the sense that they’re equally spendable and freely convertible from one form to the other. But the paper bill in your hand is an obligation of the federal government, while the electronic entry is an I.O.U. from your bank. Their interchangeability at a rate of one to one is not a fact of nature but a social construct. So, not the same.

headline: At BroadwayCon, Diversity in Theater Takes Center Stage
abstract: The eighth annual fan event will host a variety of discussions about how to diversify stages, songs and scripts. Here are six to look out for.
lead_paragraph: It’s the most musical time of the year, the weekend when thousands of fans from around the world descend on Midtown Manhattan for costume contests, Playbill swaps and theater idol meet-and-greets.

headline: Why Did 488 Golden Retrievers Gather in Scotland?
abstract: About every five years, owners and their dogs travel to Guisachan in the Highlands to celebrate the anniversary of the breed’s founding. This year’s edition was the biggest yet.
lead_paragraph: What is the sound of 488 golden retrievers barking?

headline: What Russia Sees: The traitor and the ‘indisputable hero.’
abstract: Viewers of state media were told that a mutiny and other events are causes for celebration.
lead_paragraph: We’re going to regularly break down how Russia is selling the war at home, as TV and other propaganda outlets create a distorted reality of what’s happening and who is responsible. Today, we look at how Russia portrayed the aftermath of a mutiny against the military.

headline: Trump Hush Money Case Will Remain in New York State Court, Judge Rules
abstract: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump had sought to move the first criminal case against him to federal court, but a judge put an end to the effort.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Wednesday denied former President Donald J. Trump’s request to move the Manhattan criminal case against him from state to federal court.

headline: Jiyai Shin Won a British Open at Royal Liverpool. She’s Got Some Advice.
abstract: Shin, who won by nine strokes in 2012, walks The Times through five holes that will test the men at the 151st Open.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to forget, given just how thoroughly Jiyai Shin romped to victory at the 2012 Women’s British Open, that she did not lead from start to finish. But her triumph at Royal Liverpool, the English club often known simply as Hoylake, nevertheless stands as one of the most commanding performances in the tournament’s history.

headline: What to Know About the Stanford President’s Resignation
abstract: An expert panel found fault, but not misconduct, in several neuroscience papers by Marc Tessier-Lavigne. Here are the details.
lead_paragraph: Marc Tessier-Lavigne, a renowned neuroscientist, announced on Wednesday that he would step down from his position as president of Stanford University, after the release of an external review of his scientific work found fault with several high-profile journal articles published under his purview.

headline: My Invisible Husband
abstract: David Khalaf’s family hid his husband Constantino from his 96-year-old grandmother for years.
lead_paragraph: The last time David visited his ailing grandmother, he hid his wedding ring in his pocket. He’d never told her about his identity as a gay, married man. Fearful David’s grandmother would disown him, his family never told her about David’s loving marriage with his husband, Constantino. It was an untruth David lived with until the day she died.

headline: The Fed Slaps Deutsche Bank With a $186 Million Fine
abstract: The regulator said the German lender was too slow to comply with orders to address its money-laundering controls.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve imposed a $186 million fine on Deutsche Bank on Wednesday, saying it moved too slowly to fix problems with the bank’s money-laundering controls that the bank regulator flagged in 2015 and 2017.

headline: Steve Pieters, Pastor Who Spoke of AIDS in Famed Interview, Dies at 70
abstract: He had the disease and was interviewed on the PTL network in 1985 by Tammy Faye Bakker, a broadcast that was said to have changed minds and hearts.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, when fear and homophobia were still driving much of the conversation surrounding AIDS, the Rev. A. Stephen Pieters, a gay pastor who had the disease, was a decidedly different voice.

headline: Tesla’s Profit Rose in the Second Quarter as Price Cuts Spurred Demand
abstract: Elon Musk’s electric car company is facing intensifying competition from newer Chinese automakers and established Western car companies.
lead_paragraph: Tesla reported a rise in profit for the second quarter after the company, led by Elon Musk, cut prices in response to increased competition and higher borrowing costs for car buyers.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Fans Misbehaving at Concerts, and Pinkydoll’s NPC TikTok
abstract: Plus: Music from Troye Sivan and Militarie Gun (as performed by Post Malone).
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Women’s World Cup Schedule: Teams, Kickoff Times and TV
abstract: Prepare for some late nights and some math: The Women’s World Cup will take place in multiple time zones in two countries.
lead_paragraph: Prepare for some late nights and some math: The Women’s World Cup will take place in multiple time zones in two countries.

headline: James Reston Jr., Author With a Hand in Nixon Apology, Dies at 82
abstract: A historian and novelist, he provided a 96-page “interrogation” memo for David Frost’s TV interviews that prodded Nixon to admit, “I let the American people down” over Watergate.
lead_paragraph: James Reston Jr., an eclectic historian and novelist who helped the British television host David Frost prod former President Richard M. Nixon into admitting his complicity in the Watergate scandal and apologizing in a wrenching broadcast interview, died on Wednesday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 82.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Kimberly Akimbo’ and More
abstract: I’m the reporting fellow on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve heard, seen and watched recently.
lead_paragraph: I’m the reporting fellow on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve heard, seen and watched recently.

headline: Judge Orders New York to Move Faster to Help Special Education Students
abstract: The city is often ordered to provide services to students with disabilities. But for two decades, thousands of families have faced long delays in receiving them.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered New York City to address failures to provide crucial services to public school students with disabilities, a major step that followed two decades of litigation and criticism from families in the nation’s largest school system.

headline: ‘Unhealthy’ Air Quality in Portland Caused by an Industrial Fire, Experts Say
abstract: Though some Air Quality Index spikes have been caused by wildfires, this time it was a fire at a paper mill in Washington. Some counties are under an air pollution advisory until Friday.
lead_paragraph: Air quality levels in Portland, Ore., reached “unhealthy” levels and were among the worst in the nation on Wednesday. Although wildfires in the region and beyond have been behind some of the recent spikes in air quality levels, this time the culprit was a factory fire an hour north of the city.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: China Rejects U.S. Climate Overtures
abstract: Also, escalating tensions in the Black Sea.
lead_paragraph: Chinese leaders rejected attempts by John Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, to persuade them to commit to more aggressive climate action during three days of talks in Beijing. The lengthy meetings ended with no new agreements, and the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, insisted in a speech that China would phase out carbon dioxide pollution at its own pace and in its own way.

headline: The Pentagon unveils $1.3 billion for Ukraine, bringing total new U.S. aid this week to $2.3 billion.
abstract: The money is expected to be used to buy new air-defense missile systems and other military equipment.
lead_paragraph: The United States will send $1.3 billion in financial assistance to Kyiv in order to purchase a host of new military equipment and ammunition, the Pentagon said on Wednesday. The new security support followed several U.S. announcements of humanitarian and other aid, and brought the total new U.S. commitment to Ukraine this week alone to $2.3 billion.

headline: Lilli Vincenz, Lesbian Crusader When Few Dared to Be One, Dies at 85
abstract: After being ousted from the U.S. military for being gay, she became an early fighter for gay rights and a prominent figure in the nascent L.G.B.T.Q. rights movement.
lead_paragraph: Lilli Vincenz, who became a gay rights activist in the hushed, repressive era before the Stonewall rebellion of 1969, when such a concept scarcely existed, making a mark as a newspaper editor, documentary filmmaker and psychotherapist devoted to L.G.B.T.Q. issues, died on June 27 in Oakton, Va. She was 85.

headline: Morocco Invites Netanyahu to Visit, in a Possible Opening to Deeper Ties
abstract: The invitation came in a letter from King Mohammed VI to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel thanking him for recognizing Moroccan sovereignty over Western Sahara.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Wednesday received an invitation from King Mohammed VI to visit Morocco, Mr. Netanyahu’s office said, laying the ground for the first such high-level visit since the two countries normalized relations in late 2020 and heralding a possible deepening of diplomatic and security ties.

headline: Police Unable to Verify Alabama Woman’s Report of Wandering Child and Abduction
abstract: The police said Carlee Russell, 25, had searched online for information about Amber Alerts before she disappeared for two days last week.
lead_paragraph: The police in Alabama said on Wednesday that they had not found any evidence to substantiate a woman’s report that she had been abducted and held for two days after she pulled over to help a toddler whom she had seen walking along the side of an interstate.

headline: China Rebuffed U.S. Calls for Tougher Climate Action
abstract: Also, Stanford’s president will resign. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s climate envoy, John Kerry, traveled to Beijing this week in hopes of persuading officials there to start reducing China’s carbon emissions on a faster timeline. After all, China is responsible for nearly a third of global emissions, and scientists say that its decisions — along with those of the U.S. — will be vital in the fight to stave off the most catastrophic impacts of climate change.

headline: New York City Tells Migrants There’s ‘No Guarantee’ of Finding Help Here
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams announced new shelter rules for some asylum seekers, and will begin discouraging migrants at the southern border from coming to New York City.
lead_paragraph: New York City will immediately begin discouraging asylum seekers from seeking refuge here, distributing fliers at the southern border that warn migrants there is “no guarantee” they will receive shelter or services, Mayor Eric Adams announced on Wednesday.

headline: Death of 16-Year-Old at Mississippi Poultry Plant Prompts Federal Investigation
abstract: The death of an underage worker at a chicken plant in Hattiesburg, Miss., has put a spotlight on the rising number of child labor violations across the country.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have opened an investigation into a Mississippi chicken plant after a 16-year-old boy died following a workplace accident there, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: University Departures Put Student Journalists in Spotlight
abstract: The president of Stanford and the head football coach at Northwestern left their positions after being scrutinized in campus newspapers.
lead_paragraph: Two prominent departures at top universities this month have a common link: inquisitive student journalists.

headline: Jerry Bradley, Who Helped Remake Country Music, Dies at 83
abstract: A longtime Nashville executive, he was the driving force behind “Wanted! The Outlaws,” the 1976 album that sold a million copies and shook up the status quo.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Bradley, a record executive who apprenticed with two of the most storied producers in country music — his father, Owen Bradley, and the guitarist Chet Atkins — before challenging that legacy and shaking up the industry, died on Monday at his home in Mount Juliet, Tenn., near Nashville. He was 83.

headline: 2 Killed in New Zealand Shooting Before World Cup Begins
abstract: There were also multiple injuries, the police said, and the 24-year-old gunman was also killed. The shooting was not far from where Norway’s national team is staying for the Women’s World Cup.
lead_paragraph: At least two people were killed and five others injured after a gunman stormed a building under construction in Auckland, New Zealand, early Thursday, hours before the first soccer match of the Women’s World Cup was scheduled to begin in the city.

headline: I.R.S. Whistle-Blowers Allege Political Bias in Hunter Biden Investigation
abstract: Two veteran investigators spent several hours detailing to a House committee the ways in which they believed President Biden’s son received preferential treatment.
lead_paragraph: Two veteran I.R.S. investigators leveled harsh criticism on Wednesday against the Justice Department over its handling of the tax case against Hunter Biden, accusing the agency of shielding him from felony charges because of politics and preferential treatment.

headline: Analysis Says Biden’s New Student Debt Plan Could Cost $475 Billion
abstract: The report estimates that the plan will slash borrowers’ payments and cost more than President Biden’s recently rejected debt cancellation plan.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s new repayment plan for federal student loans will cost the government $475 billion over the next decade, according to a new economic projection. The updated income-driven repayment plan would surpass the $400 billion cost of the debt forgiveness plan that the Supreme Court rejected last month.

headline: Japan’s Hall of Fame Goes Global With Induction of Foreign-Born Stars
abstract: Randy Bass and Alex Ramirez found unexpected stardom in Japan, and now they have gained the rarest of distinctions for foreign players with no Japanese heritage.
lead_paragraph: In a move without precedent in Japan’s long baseball history, players from Oklahoma and Venezuela were inducted into the country’s Baseball Hall of Fame on Wednesday. For the inductees, Randy Bass and Alex Ramirez, the event was yet another in a long line of opportunities to exceed all expectations for players from the Americas in Nippon Professional Baseball.

headline: Joe Manchin Has a Lot of Explaining to Do
abstract: The senator from West Virginia just loves New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Senator Joe Manchin, behave.

headline: Texas’ Harsh New Border Tactics Are Injuring Migrants
abstract: A “hold-the-line” operation has created tensions with federal agents who warn it could lead to more drownings. Officers ordered to carry out the measures are raising alarms.
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has pursued an increasingly aggressive approach to the border, sending thousands of National Guard troops and police officers to patrol the Rio Grande and testing the legal limits of state action on immigration.

headline: Potential Trump Charges Include Civil Rights Law Used in Voting Fraud Cases
abstract: A target letter sent by the special counsel investigating Donald Trump’s efforts to reverse his election loss cited three statutes that could be the basis for a prosecution.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have introduced a new twist in the Jan. 6 investigation by suggesting in a target letter that they could charge former President Donald J. Trump with violating a civil rights statute that dates back to the post-Civil War Reconstruction era, according to three people familiar with the matter.

headline: Why Trump’s Indictments Don’t Feel Like Part of the Finale
abstract: Trump recognized that for many Americans, celebrity was more powerful than character or civics.
lead_paragraph: It looks as though Donald Trump will be indicted — again.

headline: When Children Are Bought and Sold
abstract: A survivor warns that decriminalizing the sex trade to allow pimping would promote not empowerment but predation.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, I met a scared 15-year-old who was trying to recover her life after having been kidnapped by a pimp and sold for sex.

headline: Russia Hits Grain Ports and Threatens Ships Headed to Ukraine
abstract: Ukraine accused Moscow of specifically targeting the infrastructure for exporting food, after Russia pulled out of an agreement allowing ships carrying grain to sail past its Black Sea blockade.
lead_paragraph: As Russia resumes its blockade of ships carrying food from Ukraine, its military bombarded Odesa and an adjoining port late Tuesday and early Wednesday — specifically targeting the ability to export grain, Ukrainian officials said.

headline: Traveling to Europe? Here’s What You Need to Know About the Heat Wave.
abstract: The top tourist destinations of Italy, Spain and Greece are sweltering this summer. Travelers can take precautionary measures to protect themselves.
lead_paragraph: Southern Europe is baking, thanks to a relentless heat wave with temperatures breaking records across Italy, Spain and Greece. This extreme weather, coupled with one of the busiest tourist seasons in recent years, raises questions for travelers looking to enjoy their vacations while staying safe. Here’s what you need to know if you’re heading to Europe in the coming days, or are already there.

headline: Dallas Police Arrest Man in Killings of 3 Women
abstract: The women’s bodies were found over a three-month period in an area south of downtown.
lead_paragraph: The police in Dallas said on Wednesday that they had arrested a man who they believe killed three women whose bodies were found in a three-month span just south of downtown.

headline: Australia’s New Queen
abstract: Sam Kerr is the face of the World Cup. She has the weight of a nation on her shoulders. She does not seem to have noticed.
lead_paragraph: Sam Kerr’s tone barely shifted. She had not, she said, had time to think about it yet. She had put it to the back of her mind. She had other things on which to focus her attention.
