headline: Protesters Angry Over Quran Burning Storm Swedish Embassy in Baghdad
abstract: The demonstrators, responding to a protest in Stockholm last month and ahead of one on Thursday, set fire to parts of the building.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of protesters stormed the Swedish Embassy in Baghdad early Thursday and set fire to parts of it ahead of a demonstration outside the Iraqi Embassy in Sweden, where recent Quran burnings have inflamed anger in the Muslim world.

headline: Chart Topper
abstract: Drew Schmenner takes on Thursday puzzle trickiness.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Quotation of the Day: Kissinger, 100, Gets Accolades in China Visits
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 20, 2023
lead_paragraph: “American policy toward China needs Kissinger-style diplomatic wisdom, and Nixon-style political bravery.”

headline: Corrections: July 20, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a House measure pledging support for Israel misstated the day that Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan gave an emotional speech on the House floor. She spoke on Tuesday, not Wednesday.

headline: Google Tests A.I. Tool That Is Able to Write News Articles
abstract: The product, pitched as a helpmate for journalists, has been demonstrated for executives at The New York Times, The Washington Post and News Corp, which owns The Wall Street Journal.
lead_paragraph: Google is testing a product that uses artificial intelligence technology to produce news stories, pitching it to news organizations including The New York Times, The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal’s owner, News Corp, according to three people familiar with the matter.

headline: Ponzi Schemer Freed From Prison by Trump Faces New Fraud Charges
abstract: Eliyahu Weinstein, whose 24-year sentence President Donald J. Trump commuted, is now accused of bilking 150 people out of more than $35 million.
lead_paragraph: A convicted Ponzi schemer, whose prison sentence President Donald J. Trump commuted in one of his last official White House acts, is facing new fraud federal charges of bilking investors in a series of phony deals.

headline: Trump’s Legal Woes Mount as Trial Dates and Campaign Calendar Collide
abstract: The Republican front-runner is facing a growing tangle of criminal and civil trials that will overlap with next year’s presidential primaries.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump campaigns for the White House while multiple criminal prosecutions against him play out, at least one thing is clear: Under the laws of physics, he cannot be in two places at once.

headline: Tesla Wants to Double the Size of Its European Assembly Plant
abstract: The electric automaker wants to produce a million cars a year at its plant near Berlin, a step that would make it Europe’s largest car factory.
lead_paragraph: Tesla wants to double the production capacity of its assembly plant outside Berlin to one million electric vehicles a year, a move that would make it the largest car plant in Europe at a time when German automakers are struggling to keep pace in the transition to electric vehicles.

headline: Theme Park’s Selective History Appeals to a New Spanish Nationalism
abstract: Puy du Fou España has drawn visitors with spectacular shows about Spanish history. But part of its success lies in what goes unsaid.
lead_paragraph: Moving through the darkened holds of a replica of Christopher Columbus’s ship, visitors on a recent afternoon marveled at the tangle of compasses, cordage and barrels. They stumbled as the ship swang and creaked with the swell of the sea. At last, a voice shouted “Land!” and the white sands of America appeared.

headline: Europe Pushed Tunisia to Keep Migrants Away. The Result Is Harsh.
abstract: Tunisia has pushed African migrants to scorching no-man’s lands along its borders with little food and water. Under a deal with the European Union, Tunisia agreed to tighten border controls in exchange for aid.
lead_paragraph: For nearly three weeks now, more than 1,000 men, women and children from Africa have been clinging to survival in the no-man’s lands at Tunisia’s borders. A few scrubby trees offer fitful shade, videos taken by migrants show, and border guards from neighboring Libya and Tunisian aid workers occasionally drop off water and a bit of bread.

headline: On the Map, Nothing. On the Ground, a Hidden Maya City.
abstract: In a biological preserve in Mexico’s Campeche State, a team of archaeologists has documented pyramids, palaces, a ball court and other remains of an ancient city they call Ocomtún.
lead_paragraph: Armed with machetes and chain-saws, hacking through fallen trees and wading through dense scrub, the archaeologists cleared a path down rocky trails.

headline: The Joys of Links Golf Never Get Old
abstract: No matter which seaside, windswept course hosts the British Open, the final major tournament of the year puts a golfer’s imagination to work, and captures ours.
lead_paragraph: Tired of the whole golf-gone-wild thing? The one that has turned the men’s professional game into a new toy for Saudi investors? The one that has U.S. senators dragging golf (minus the bag) to work? The one that has left the PGA Tour star Rory McIlroy saying he feels like a sacrificial lamb in the proposed PGA Tour-LIV Golf partnership?

headline: Ukrainian Children With Cancer Fight Their Own War Within a War
abstract: The war with Russia compounds the struggles of pediatric cancer patients and their families, but it has also prompted positive changes in treatment in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen-month-old Mykola clutched his mother’s finger as he toddled up the hallway of the national children’s hospital in Kyiv, his still-unsteady legs eager to keep up with his desire to walk.

headline: Kevin Mitnick, Once the ‘Most Wanted Computer Outlaw,’ Dies at 59
abstract: Best known for an audacious hacking spree in the 1990s involving the theft of data and credit card numbers, he later became a security consultant and public speaker.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Mitnick, who at the dawn of widespread internet usage in the mid-1990s became the nation’s archetypal computer hacker — obsessive but clever, shy but mischievous and threatening to an uncertain degree — and who later used his skills to become “chief hacking officer” of a cybersecurity firm, died on Sunday in Pittsburgh. He was 59.

headline: New York to Pay $13 Million Over Police Actions at George Floyd Protests
abstract: The city settled a major class-action lawsuit that said unlawful police tactics had violated the rights of more than 1,000 people who protested after Mr. Floyd’s killing.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of June 2, 2020, Sabrina Zurkuhlen joined a protest march on the West Side Highway that was spurred by the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis eight days earlier.

headline: Why Heat Waves Are Deepening China’s Addiction to Coal
abstract: While pledging to reduce carbon emissions, the country is greatly increasing its use of the fossil fuel to generate electricity.
lead_paragraph: China has an answer to the heat waves now affecting much of the Northern Hemisphere: burn more coal to maintain a stable electricity supply for air-conditioning.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: China pushes back against U.S. climate pressure.
lead_paragraph: John Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, had traveled to Beijing in hopes of persuading officials there to start reducing China’s carbon emissions on a faster timeline. But after three days of talks, Kerry emerged without any new agreements.

headline: Spain Is Going to Be Fine
abstract: Sunday’s election will determine the country’s political direction, not the fate of its democracy.
lead_paragraph: A choice between democracy and autocracy.

headline: Why the Mayor Could Lose Control of Rikers Island
abstract: It will be up to a judge to decide if an outside authority will run the troubled jails complex. She appears to be losing patience with the city.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at the possibility of a federal takeover of the troubled Rikers Island jail complex. We’ll also get details on transit fare increases that will take effect within a month.

headline: The two host nations are embracing their moment.
abstract: Australia, a sports-mad nation with a long tradition of champions in other sports, has never been past the round of 16 at the Women’s World Cup. New Zealand, a rugby nation accustomed to life on the fringes of the biggest events in sports, has never won a game in the tournament.
lead_paragraph: Australia, a sports-mad nation with a long tradition of champions in other sports, has never been past the round of 16 at the Women’s World Cup. New Zealand, a rugby nation accustomed to life on the fringes of the biggest events in sports, has never won a game in the tournament.

headline: Protesters in Baghdad Storm Swedish Embassy
abstract: The demonstrators, angry over Quran burnings in Sweden, protested throughout the night, setting part of the embassy on fire.
lead_paragraph: The demonstrators, angry over Quran burnings in Sweden, protested throughout the night, setting part of the embassy on fire.

headline: It’s By-election Day in the U.K. What Does That Mean?
abstract: Three seats in Parliament recently occupied by Conservatives are up for grabs in an election that may show which way the political winds are blowing.
lead_paragraph: One of the last things Britain’s prime minister, Rishi Sunak, needs right now, while he’s trailing in the opinion polls as the economy stalls, is a test of his electoral popularity.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Gilgo Beach Suspect’s House Becomes a Macabre Tourist Attraction
abstract: On Long Island, the fascinated and obsessed come to gawk at the house where the suspect lived. Some bring the children.
lead_paragraph: Scarlett Fascetti approached the dilapidated red house as if it were a shrine.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Video of Sexual Assault Goes Viral in India, Renewing Attention on Ethnic Conflict
abstract: The attack on two women in the state of Manipur led to the first public comments from Prime Minister Narendra Modi, however indirect, about the monthslong violence in the state.
lead_paragraph: It took more than two months for word of the shocking sexual assault to spread, partly because the internet in the region had been shut down.

headline: For Young Arab Americans in Michigan, the Hookah Lounge Feels like Home
abstract: A new generation of immigrants, refugees and their descendants is finding a sense of connection and community around the shisha pipe.
lead_paragraph: A new generation of immigrants, refugees and their descendants is finding a sense of connection and community around the shisha pipe.

headline: 36 Hours in Copenhagen
abstract: Famous for its design, food and dedication to sustainability, the Danish capital is celebrating its architecture with a yearlong slate of events and exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Famous for its design, food and dedication to sustainability, the Danish capital is celebrating its architecture with a yearlong slate of events and exhibitions.

headline: Poem: The Desert
abstract: Brandon Shimoda wrote this short poem after encountering a lost migrant in the Arizona desert.
lead_paragraph: “The Desert,” from Brandon Shimoda’s new collection, “Hydra Medusa,” is emblematic of the complex lyric-historical landscape of borders, dreams, shrines and underworlds found throughout his work. I asked Shimoda about the context and composition of this poem, and his answer was a skillful, evocative illumination of the relationship between life and poetry: “I wrote this poem the night after going out on a water drop with a humanitarian-aid group. We drove for many hours through the desert, putting water out for migrants, people trying to stay alive. We met a man who, in the hallucinatory heat of Arizona, asked how far it was to Kentucky. Some important part of an individual exists in the places they are trying to reach, and it is excruciating. It is like we are following the signs and symbols of our future selves through the wilderness. I write poetry when I am feeling haunted by something — an image, encounter — although not as a means of exorcism. I think about what I have seen, heard, experienced, and I go under. I write poetry at night, partly because I believe there is a more humane, trustworthy logic to be found there, although like dreams, and like the landscapes in which they graze, the poems are themselves the interpretation.” Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: With Just a 5 Percent Down Payment, What Would $650,000 Buy in Bed-Stuy?
abstract: Miranda Haymon, a theater director and writer, was able to make (and save) money during the pandemic. How far would it go in Brooklyn in late 2022?
lead_paragraph: Miranda Haymon, a theater director and writer, was able to make (and save) money during the pandemic. How far would it go in Brooklyn in late 2022?

headline: New York’s Moldiest Neighborhoods
abstract: A recent study tracked mold complaints in the city over the last six and a half years. So where is mold the worst?
lead_paragraph: There are household nightmares, and then there’s mold. Getting rid of mold can be expensive and disruptive. Even worse, according to the World Health Organization, mold can trigger allergic reactions, aggravate asthma and release the mycotoxins that can cause acute poisoning. Mold is also linked to serious diseases like cancer and disorders like immune deficiency.

headline: The Overlooked Reason Our Health Care System Crushes Patients
abstract: A quarter of insured adults report delayed or missed medical care because of administrative tasks.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, I was called urgently to our small obstetric triage unit because a pregnant patient was very sick. At the beginning of her third trimester, she had come in with back pain and a 103-degree fever. Her heart was racing, her blood pressure was dangerously low, and her oxygen levels were barely normal. In sentences broken by gasps for air, she told us her belly was tightening every few minutes — painful contractions, three months before their time.

headline: The Vanishing Family
abstract: They all have a 50-50 chance of inheriting a cruel genetic mutation — which means disappearing into dementia in middle age. This is the story of what it’s like to live with those odds.
lead_paragraph: Barb was the youngest in her large Irish Catholic family — a surprise baby, the ninth child, born 10 years after the eighth. Living in the suburbs of Pittsburgh, her family followed the football schedule: high school games on Friday night, college games on Saturday, the Steelers on Sunday. Dad was an engineer, mom was a homemaker and Barb was the family mascot, blond and adorable, watching her brothers and sisters finish school and go on to their careers.

headline: More Visible L.G.B.T.Q. People Isn’t a Curiosity or a Crisis — It’s Normal
abstract: The increase in the number of visible gay and trans people is sometimes treated as a curiosity or a cause for concern by critics, but it’s not a surprise. It’s normal.
lead_paragraph: What’s the correct number of lesbians? Gay men? Bisexuals? Trans people? Is there a number that is too high? Too low? Just right?

headline: 33 Reading Recommendations for Your Summer Vacation
abstract: Whether you’re into mysteries or the making of mob movies, we’ve got something for you.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on What to Call a Subway Line
abstract: A native New Yorker struggles with her boyfriend’s choice to refer to them by their colors.
lead_paragraph: Leah writes: My boyfriend, Matt, refers to subway lines by color. Instead of “the A train,” he calls it “the blue line.” This embarrasses me as a native New Yorker. It also doesn’t work: The A, C and E are all blue but stop at different places.

headline: Richard Russo Misses the Purity of Childhood Reading
abstract: “When you become a writer, you inevitably lose your innocence as a reader,” says the Pulitzer-winning novelist, whose new book is “Somebody’s Fool.” “It’s like being given the underground tour of Disney World. Some of the magic dissipates.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: A Year of Upheaval on Abortion’s Front Lines
abstract: A Supreme Court decision created a 50-state patchwork of differing abortion laws. An eclectic network of volunteers and organizations has tried to fill the gaps in health care and support.
lead_paragraph: A Supreme Court decision created a 50-state patchwork of differing abortion laws. An eclectic network of volunteers and organizations has tried to fill the gaps in health care and support.

headline: Help! I Signed Up for a $4,800 Bird-Watching Trip but the Company Shut Down.
abstract: A family’s dream of seeing a rare warbler was dashed when Bird Watcher’s Digest collapsed. What happens when a tour operator goes under?
lead_paragraph: In 2021, my husband, my sister and I signed up for a five-day Tremendous Tawas Lake Huron tour run by Pardson, the Ohio company that publishes Bird Watcher’s Digest magazine. We paid almost $4,800 in all. The tour was canceled because of Covid that year, but we were so eager to see the rare Kirtland’s warbler that we accepted a credit. Shortly before the rescheduled trip was to leave in May 2022, the company emailed to tell us it was going out of business, and someone would contact us about a refund. No one did, but through my own efforts I got in touch with Jack Harris, the receiver responsible for the dissolution of Pardson. He told me the only way to get my money back would be through my credit card. But American Express said I was too late. Can you help? Paige, Atlanta

headline: Hoping for a Miracle, Hurtling Toward Disaster
abstract: Are we doomed to witness the Trump-Biden rematch nobody wants?
lead_paragraph: Have you met anyone truly excited about Joe Biden running for re-election? And by that, I mean downright Obama-circa-2008 energized — brimming with enthusiasm about what four more years of Biden would bring to our body politic, our economy, our national mood, our culture?

headline: Don’t Let Inflation Bury the Memory of a Government Triumph
abstract: We got our economic response to the coronavirus right. Why would we let go of that success?
lead_paragraph: The recession caused by the Covid-19 pandemic was the shortest on record, thanks to rapid, robust and bipartisan congressional action. It took just over two years to regain all of the jobs lost — hard to fathom given that more than six million people filed unemployment insurance claims in one week at the end of March 2020. Americans were made whole by their government, which staved off what otherwise would have been mass financial suffering.

headline: Survey of 30 U.S. Cities Shows Nearly 10 Percent Drop in Homicides in 2023
abstract: After a surge during the height of Covid, killings have fallen but remain well above prepandemic levels.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, amid the disruptions of the pandemic and the social upheaval following the police murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis,  the United States saw the largest increase in its homicide rate in modern history. Now, more than three years after the start of the pandemic, the country is on track to record one of its largest — if not the largest — annual declines in homicides, according to a report released on Thursday.

headline: A Novel of Sex and Crisis in the Aftermath of the 1960s
abstract: Henry Bean’s first novel, reissued as “The Nenoquich,” follows a young writer in Berkeley through a transformative affair.
lead_paragraph: Cynicism, laziness, anger, misplaced righteousness, vacillation between vanity and self-loathing: Such are the qualities of the superfluous men we’ve encountered in novels for centuries. Existing somehow outside the structures of family and regular employment, these prodigal sons have too much time on their hands — time to spend thinking, ranting, writing or intoxicating themselves.

headline: Is It Safe to Go Outside? How to Navigate This Cruel Summer.
abstract: Heat, flooding and wildfire smoke have made for treacherous conditions. Use this guide to determine when it’s safe to head out and when you should stay home.
lead_paragraph: Excessive rain and flooding in the Northeast, a dangerous heat wave with triple-digit temperatures across the South, West and Midwest, and smoke from wildfires in Canada have all come together to make this a summer of weather extremes in the United States, in which going outside can be riddled with perils.

headline: In ‘Twisted Metal’ Series, Killer Clowns Come With Class Commentary
abstract: Peacock’s new show indulges in the same ultraviolence as the video game that inspired it. But this time it has a message about the haves and the have-nots.
lead_paragraph: When Stephanie Beatriz likes a script she enjoys reading it aloud at home to get a better feel for the character and story. She warmed up quickly to “Twisted Metal,” the new Peacock mayhem machine based on the popular PlayStation game series that first burned rubber in 1995. But as she turned the pages, encountering psycho clowns, murderous religious cults, cannibalism and other manner of good times, she had to pause. Her 8-month-old daughter was in the room.

headline: A Test of the American Dream, Set in a Leprosy Ward
abstract: In her debut novel, “King of the Armadillos,” Wendy Chin-Tanner explores immigration, illness and opportunity through the story of a teenage immigrant who is diagnosed with Hansen’s disease.
lead_paragraph: When Hans Castorp arrives at the tuberculosis sanitarium in Davos-Platz, Switzerland, in “The Magic Mountain” — Thomas Mann’s monumental meditation on the metamorphosing process of illness, the mutability of time and the feast of death that is the human body — he thinks he’s there for a three-week visit. His short stay transforms into a seven-year passage through all the stages of the human tragicomedy.

headline: How TV Writing Became a Dead-End Job
abstract: The writers say Hollywood studios are increasingly limiting their roles in television productions, highlighting a trend for white-collar workers.
lead_paragraph: For the six years he worked on “The Mentalist,” beginning in 2009, Jordan Harper’s job was far more than a writing gig. He and his colleagues in the writers’ room of the weekly CBS drama were heavily involved in production. They weighed in on costumes and props, lingered on the set, provided feedback to actors and directors. The job lasted most of a year.

headline: House Overwhelmingly Passes Bill to Improve Air Travel
abstract: The House cleared away a number of potential sticking points that had threatened to hold up the bill to reauthorize the Federal Aviation Administration. It goes next to the Senate.
lead_paragraph: The House on Thursday overwhelmingly passed bipartisan legislation to reauthorize the Federal Aviation Administration for the next half-decade, moving at a time of growing dysfunction and disruption in the system to make a number of changes that affect passengers.

headline: Inside the Private Writings of Caroline Ellison, Star Witness in the FTX Case
abstract: Ms. Ellison, a top executive in Sam Bankman-Fried’s business empire, recorded her thoughts on private Google documents that offer new insight into the collapse of the FTX crypto exchange.
lead_paragraph: Three months before the cryptocurrency market imploded last year, Caroline Ellison, the 27-year-old chief executive of the crypto hedge fund Alameda Research, was racked with self-doubt.

headline: When It Comes to Death, Hadley Vlahos Tells It Like It Is
abstract: A new book by a hospice nurse helps readers wrap their minds around — and perhaps make peace with — the great unknown.
lead_paragraph: Ask enough newly minted best-selling authors to describe how their books were born and you’ll notice a trend: “It was March of 2020” is the new “Once upon a time.” In the annals of literary history, we have now arrived at the chapter in which the pandemic is part of most origin stories.

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Redding, Conn., and a three-bedroom in Rye, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 4,527-square-foot, expanded home built in 1910, with original stone walls and archways, hardwood flooring and wood beams; a cozy foyer preceded by a screen porch entryway; a great room with wood paneling and a fireplace; a kitchen with banquet seating; a bright dining room with wood shelving; a sunroom with floor-to-ceiling windows and a slider that leads to a stone patio; a step-down formal living room with built-in bookshelves and a bay window; an office alcove and lounging rooms; an en suite primary bedroom with a sitting area and a skylight; a landscaped yard with an in-ground pool, flower gardens, a stream, a barn and a detached two car garage with a guest apartment on 15.9 acres. Roni Agress, 203-733-2656; William Pitt Sotheby’s International, williampitt.com

headline: The Shows May Be Over. But John Mayer’s ‘Guitar Face’ Lives On.
abstract: For some fans of Dead & Company, which just finished its Final Tour, the faces made by John Mayer while performing are almost as memorable as the music.
lead_paragraph: During the final show of Dead & Company’s so-called Final Tour on Sunday night, the crowd at Oracle Park in San Francisco swayed and bobbed like the current of a turning river.

headline: The Strange Unseriousness of No Labels
abstract: Many Americans fear a second Trump term and are dissatisfied. No Labels is here to take advantage of that sadness with a half-finished idea.
lead_paragraph: GOFFSTOWN, N.H. — “I’m not afraid of losing,” Senator Joe Manchin said, with some real charm and conviction, on Monday night.

headline: Quick to Mock MAGA, Biden Stays Silent on Trump Indictments
abstract: The president has taken swipes at Republicans, including a video playfully featuring Marjorie Taylor Greene as a narrator, but he and his allies are avoiding one target: his predecessor’s legal woes.
lead_paragraph: For months, President Biden has appeared to delight in needling Donald J. Trump and his Republican allies, trying at every turn to make MAGA and ultra-MAGA a shorthand for the entire party.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 6 Fashion: No Way to Dress for the Weather
abstract: In the new episode, Carrie and her friends brave the streets of New York City in a blizzard.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for Episode 6 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”

headline: Heat Affects Older People More. Here’s How to Stay Safe.
abstract: If you’re over 65, it’s important to take high temperatures seriously.
lead_paragraph: We are experiencing the hottest days in history. Heat waves have blanketed the Northern Hemisphere this week, with temperatures reaching 100 degrees Fahrenheit on three continents.

headline: New Zealand’s Fruit-Rich Ice Cream Gets a Sugary American Makeover
abstract: The wholesome summer favorite is catching on in the U.S., but with sprinkles, drizzles and even cookies to satisfy the nation’s sweet tooth.
lead_paragraph: In New Zealand, one of summer’s great pleasures is known as real fruit ice cream: a scoop of vanilla blended with fruit in a machine that produces an airy, barely sweet twirl with a buttery texture. The dessert, which likely originated in the country’s berry orchards, has become a national favorite over the last few decades, prized for its freshness and simplicity.

headline: Catch Them if You Can
abstract: Corbin Carroll changed everything for Arizona and Elly De La Cruz has revitalized Cincinnati. The phenoms, and their contending teams, face off this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Midway through last season, Zac Gallen, the ace right-hander of the Arizona Diamondbacks, found himself surveying the baseball landscape. Everywhere he looked, terrific young players were remaking the game.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are on the Upper East Side, in the East Village and Spuyten Duyvil.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 950-square-foot apartment with an open living/dining area, a galley kitchen with a pantry, a king-size bedroom, ample closets and through-the-wall air-conditioning on the seventh floor of a 13-story doorman building with a courtyard, gym, bike room, live-in superintendent, basement storage cases and shared laundry and a public parking garage. Sheila Starr, Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices, 917-557-1173; bhhsnyproperties.com

headline: Christopher Nolan and the Contradictions of J. Robert Oppenheimer
abstract: The biopic director argues that the physicist who oversaw creation of the atomic bomb was both the most important person who ever lived and hopelessly naïve.
lead_paragraph: With the biopic “Oppenheimer,” due July 21, the writer-director Christopher Nolan, known for brain-twisting films like “Interstellar” and “Inception,” addresses an old childhood dread — one based not on science fiction but on real science, namely the threat of thermonuclear war and human annihilation.

headline: Today’s Top News: Russia Targets Ukraine’s Ports, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Frustrated by Biden, China Courts ‘Old Friends’ Like Kissinger
abstract: In meeting with Henry Kissinger, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, is turning to American contacts outside the Biden administration to try to influence Washington’s thinking on China.
lead_paragraph: The red carpet welcome in Beijing for Henry A. Kissinger, the 100-year-old former secretary of state, included China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, telling him that “the Chinese people will always remember you.” It featured praise from China’s top diplomat for his wisdom. And it involved a meeting with the Chinese defense minister, who has rebuffed multiple requests to engage with his American counterpart.

headline: The Man Trying to Save Phoenix From Historic Heat
abstract: The city is attempting to adapt to a new reality of extreme heat waves.
lead_paragraph: As a historic heat wave grips much of the world and the United States, no city has become more emblematic of the crisis than Phoenix, where temperatures have exceeded 110 degrees for the past three weeks.

headline: Tiered Work Forces
abstract: The rise of piecemeal work is a key issue in the Hollywood writers’ strike.
lead_paragraph: Universities devote a smaller share of faculty slots to tenured professorships than in the past — and hire more adjunct professors who have little chance for promotion. Law firms employ relatively fewer partners and more lawyers who are paid less. And Hollywood hires fewer writers to participate in the entire production process, relegating more of them to piecemeal work.

headline: North Korea Stays Silent on U.S. Soldier Who Fled Into the Country
abstract: It may take days or weeks for the country to acknowledge that it has Pvt. Travis T. King in custody, and past practices suggest its response will be determined by Mr. King’s motive.
lead_paragraph: North Korea has not yet responded to the mystery surrounding a United States Army private’s decision to flee across the inter-Korean border on Tuesday, and it may not ​comment on the case for days, or even months.

headline: ‘Return to Dust’ Review: Grit Against All Odds
abstract: Li Ruijun’s newest feature is a touching portrait of love and resiliency that doubles as a critique of China’s ruling class.
lead_paragraph: According to reliable news reports, the Chinese government never confirmed having banned Li Ruijun’s quietly heartbreaking feature “Return to Dust,” a touching portrait of love and resiliency in a collapsing rural community of Gansu Province.

headline: ‘Stephen Curry: Underrated’ Review: Court Transcript
abstract: Initially considered too short and too scrawny, Curry went on to be an N.B.A. superstar. But there’s little that feels fresh or spontaneous in this earnest portrait.
lead_paragraph: Toggling between time frames, the earnest documentary “Stephen Curry: Underrated” portrays Stephen Curry, the Golden State Warrior routinely described as the greatest shooter in the history of the N.B.A., as an underdog during at least two crucial points in his career.

headline: ‘Streetwise’ Review: A Bleak Upbringing in a Brutal Town
abstract: In Na Jiazuo’s striking directorial debut, young people inhabit a place seemingly made up of those who owe money and the thugs who try to beat it out of them.
lead_paragraph: This consistently striking and deeply sad picture is the directorial feature debut of Na Jiazuo, who executes it with an assurance that makes him more than merely promising. The story is set in 2004, in a town within China’s Sichuan Province where not much is going on, it seems, besides criminality and tattooing. Oh, yes, the local hospital is pretty busy, too.

headline: ‘They Cloned Tyrone’ Review: There’s Only One John Boyega
abstract: In Juel Taylor’s imaginative sci-fi movie, Boyega teams up with Jamie Foxx and Teyonah Parris to find the forces undermining their community.
lead_paragraph: “They Cloned Tyrone,” an ambitious, nightmarish tale about unsettled identity, opens with an image of two blue eyes, strained at the corners. The camera pulls back, revealing the owner of those peepers to be a grinning white man on a billboard with the tagline “Keep em’ smiling.” In front of the advertisement, Black people debate possible sightings of Tupac Shakur and Michael Jackson, now allegedly disguising himself with new Black skin. The food mart, with the billboard prominently displayed by its door, is where these gossiping Black folk hold court, and is one of the many institutions that dot the neglected, fictional urban landscape its residents refer to as the Glen.

headline: ‘Glitch: The Rise & Fall of HQ Trivia’ Review: Grandiose Pursuits
abstract: The fraught behind-the-scenes drama of the short-lived quiz game app is chronicled in this smart, briskly funny documentary.
lead_paragraph: “Glitch: The Rise & Fall of HQ Trivia,” by the director Salima Koroma, seems at first glance like many other recent rise-and-fall narratives, which usually describe, in sensational terms, the hubristic ascent and Icarian plunge of Silicon Valley start-ups, social media platforms, cellphone manufacturers and even video game developers.

headline: ‘While We Watched’ Review: A Lament and a Battle Cry
abstract: This documentary about the veteran broadcast journalist Ravish Kumar is less an inspiring tale than a wake-up call for India.
lead_paragraph: In the opening moments of Vinay Shukla’s documentary “While We Watched,” its subject, the veteran Indian news anchor Ravish Kumar, stands in a partly demolished building and wonders, “When you find yourself all alone, whom do you listen to?”

headline: ‘The Venture Bros.: Radiant Is the Blood of the Baboon Heart’ Review: Return of the Glorious Weirdos
abstract: A beloved Adult Swim cartoon comes back to tie up some loose ends.
lead_paragraph: Over seven seasons on Adult Swim, the Cartoon Network’s nighttime programming block, “The Venture Bros.” brought to the small screen a fantastical world steeped in absurdist humor, rooted in pop culture and presented in the style of old-time cartoon adventures. Within this exemplar of animated brain candy dwelled a host of glorious weirdos: chief among them, Dr. Thaddeus Venture (voiced by James Urbaniak), a man-child flailing in his superscientist father’s shadow; his goofy, fatality-prone sons, Hank (Chris McCulloch, a.k.a. Jackson Publick) and Dean (Michael Sinterniklaas), whose demises were easily remedied by a basement full of clones; their sex-and-death-machine bodyguard, Brock Samson (Patrick Warburton); and Dr. Venture’s equally petulant frenemesis, the Monarch (Publick), and his gravelly-voiced bombshell wife, Dr. Mrs. the Monarch (Doc Hammer).

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: Hey Stranger
abstract: In an episode with multiple explicit callbacks to the original series, Charlotte sets a progressive example and Miranda confronts painful consequences.
lead_paragraph: The O.G.s know this isn’t the first time Carrie has fanned old flames with Aidan via email. Way back in Season 4 of the original series, Carrie created her first ever email address (shoegal@aol.com!) solely for the ability to reach out to Aidan post-breakup in some way other than the phone.

headline: Belarus Says Wagner Fighters are Training Troops on the Polish Border
abstract: The Belarusian Defense Ministry said the country’s special operations units were jointly training with Wagner at a military range near the city of Brest.
lead_paragraph: The Belarusian Defense Ministry said on Thursday that mercenaries from the Wagner group were training troops on the border with Poland, a statement that was likely to increase tensions in an area where fears of conflict are already high.

headline: Netflix’s Strike Defense Is Strong. It May Have Some Cracks Anyway.
abstract: The company is best suited among media giants to cope with the Hollywood shutdown. But a lengthy strike by writers and actors will eventually cause damage.
lead_paragraph: Netflix’s latest financial report yesterday had a lot to impress shareholders, including renewed subscriber growth and expectations of better cash flow, thanks to strike-enabled cutbacks in content spending.

headline: Landslide Kills at Least 10 in Western India
abstract: More than 100 more people were feared to be trapped under debris, as torrential monsoon rainfall continued to pummel the country.
lead_paragraph: A landslide triggered by torrential rains in the western Indian state of Maharashtra killed at least 10 people late Wednesday night, with more than 100 feared trapped under debris, as rescue workers battled difficult terrain and heavy downpours searching for survivors.

headline: Gretchen Whitmer Would Like You to Meet ‘Governor Barbie’
abstract: It’s part of a social media stunt by the pink-loving politician. But does it represent a shift for women in politics?
lead_paragraph: The politician is having a busy week. She has events at the Capitol and an important bill to sign into law. Like her namesake, who calls the shade her “power color,” she wears a hot pink pantsuit.

headline: An A.I. Supercomputer Whirs to Life, Powered by Giant Computer Chips
abstract: The new supercomputer, made by the Silicon Valley start-up Cerebras, was unveiled as the A.I. boom drives demand for chips and computing power.
lead_paragraph: Inside a cavernous room this week in a one-story building in Santa Clara, Calif., six-and-a-half-foot-tall machines whirred behind white cabinets. The machines made up a new supercomputer that had become operational just last month.

headline: We’re Using A.I. Chatbots Wrong. Here’s How to Direct Them.
abstract: To mitigate the production and spread of misinformation from chatbots, we can steer them toward high-quality data.
lead_paragraph: Anyone seduced by A.I.-powered chatbots like ChatGPT and Bard — wow, they can write essays and recipes! — eventually runs into what are known as hallucinations, the tendency for artificial intelligence to fabricate information.

headline: What to Expect From Wildfire Season in California This Year
abstract: A wet winter may have delayed the state’s fire season, but it could ultimately make the blazes worse.
lead_paragraph: Compared with recent years, the 2023 fire season in California is off to a slow start.

headline: ‘How to Dance in Ohio,’ a Musical, Plans a Fall Broadway Opening
abstract: A teenage ritual takes on deeper significance as a setting where autistic young people can blossom — and exercise their social skills along the way.
lead_paragraph: “How to Dance in Ohio,” a poignant new musical about a group of young autistic adults gearing up for a spring dance, will open on Broadway late this year, with a cast of seven autistic performers playing the central roles.

headline: Investor Charged With Kidnapping ‘Crypto King’
abstract: Aiden Pleterski is accused of spending investors’ money on luxury cars and vacations before filing for bankruptcy, according to court records. Then he was kidnapped by one of his investors, police say.
lead_paragraph: Late one night in early December, Aiden Pleterski, a self-proclaimed “Crypto King,” was kidnapped, then beaten and tortured over three days, according to court records.

headline: The Perpetual Stew Is More About Community Than Cuisine
abstract: Annie Rauwerda has been cooking a stew in her Brooklyn apartment for over a month. Its flavor changes with the ingredients people bring to tasting events at a park in Bushwick.
lead_paragraph: They wore floppy toques and were flanked by an array of ingredients: vegetable broth, chili peppers, bay leaves, potatoes, shallots, radishes, garlic powder, canned beans, carrots and more — all crowdsourced from their eager guests.

headline: Word of the Day: petulance
abstract: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word petulance has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 5 in “John McEnroe Gets His Revenge” by Matthew Futterman:

headline: For Europe’s Older Population, Heat Is the New Covid
abstract: Scorching temperatures have threatened the health of the elderly and pushed them inside, while governments are trying to take extraordinary steps to protect them.
lead_paragraph: As a light, hot breeze blew through her living room and her gray hair, Donata Grillo, a 75-year-old cancer survivor with a pacemaker and serious sight problems, sat next to her balcony, a damp sponge on her lap.

headline: Blackstone Becomes First $1 Trillion Private Equity Manager
abstract: Passing that milestone puts the firm in the same league as mutual fund behemoths and banking giants.
lead_paragraph: For years, private equity firms have sought to join a special club: managing $1 trillion in assets, a milestone that would put them in the same league as mutual fund behemoths like BlackRock and Fidelity and banking giants like JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Roald Dahl Museum Calls Author’s Racism ‘Undeniable and Indelible’
abstract: A museum in England devoted to the best-selling children’s author, who died in 1990, condemned his antisemitic views.
lead_paragraph: A museum devoted to Roald Dahl, the best-selling British author, has condemned his antisemitic views and said his racism was “undeniable and indelible.”

headline: Should You Hire a Bridal Stylist?
abstract: These fashion experts will not only help you find the perfect wedding day look, but also curate a collection of ensembles for related events.
lead_paragraph: When it came to dressing for her May 6 wedding, Ashley Oliver Thomas had trouble narrowing down the many options available, while at the same time navigating a new job.

headline: Ukraine starts using American-made cluster munitions in its counteroffensive, U.S. officials say.
abstract: The weapons are being used in the southeast, the officials say.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces have started using American-made cluster munitions against Russia’s defensive positions, two United States military officials said on Thursday.

headline: What Do You Call a German Siesta? An Answer to the Europe Heat, Some Say.
abstract: The siesta, a sacred afternoon break in Spain, was once mocked as lazy. But now, countries like Germany, which were among the siesta haters, are taking another look.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, in the wake of a financial crisis, Spain’s sacred siesta seemed to be under serious threat. Criticism was mounting across Europe that Spain’s sluggish economy resulted, in part, from its long midday break. Worried about being stereotyped as a sleepy, lazy country, Spain pledged to abolish the siesta to increase productivity.

headline: What Russia’s Grain Deal Actions Mean for Ukraine
abstract: Moscow withdrew from a deal that allowed Ukraine to export grain across the Black Sea despite a wartime blockade, and warned that ships sailing around Ukrainian ports would be seen as military targets.
lead_paragraph: Russia warned on Wednesday that it would consider any ship sailing around Ukrainian ports a military target, days after Moscow pulled out of a yearlong deal that had enabled Kyiv to export its grain across the Black Sea despite a wartime blockade.

headline: This Summer, Pause for the Vermouth Hour
abstract: Good vermouth makes a great aperitif, fueling a delightful transitional moment before a meal.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year while in Madrid, I fell prey to what the Spanish call la hora del vermut, the vermouth hour, a break in the day for a glass, generally before eating. In Spain it customarily takes place before lunch. On my visit, though, I saw more people pausing for vermouth after the workday, as a transitional moment before embarking on whatever adventures the evening promised.

headline: Kenya Stares Into ‘Abyss’ as Soaring Prices and Feuding Leaders Bring Chaos
abstract: Antigovernment protests over price hikes and new taxes have left at least 31 people dead in recent weeks, prompting the country’s news outlets to join together to issue a dire warning.
lead_paragraph: Kenya’s boisterous news outlets are normally fierce rivals. But on Thursday they set aside their competitive instincts to issue an urgent appeal for calm as Kenya plunged deeper into chaotic anti-government demonstrations that have left at least 31 people dead in recent weeks and present the gravest challenge yet to the nearly year-old rule of President William Ruto.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: From global warming to a reality show set on Mars, and from “My Hijacking” to “My Murder,” we bring you an eclectic selection of recommended books this week. In fiction, Gina Apostol’s novel “La Tercera” braids a mother-daughter story with a history of the Philippines, Deborah Willis’s “Girlfriend on Mars” imagines the above-mentioned reality show and Katie Williams’s “My Murder” brings its heroine back from the dead. In nonfiction, we recommend Jeff Goodell’s study of climate change, along with a biography of the extended Shakur family and a handful of memoirs covering everything from war reporting to a very public gender transition. Happy reading.

headline: Should No Labels Run a Presidential Candidate?
abstract: Readers discuss the likely impact and the challenges of its possible third-party bid. Also: Oppenheimer’s lessons; animal disease outbreaks; wedding car cans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Where Paranoia Meets Legacy Admissions
abstract: R.F.K. Jr. and Trump belong to a new breed of arrogant oxymorons.
lead_paragraph: It feels dangerous to write about Robert F. Kennedy Jr.: In the lag between when I put the finishing touches on this and when it becomes publicly available, I could be a conspiracy theory or two behind.

headline: Review: ‘Minx’ Returns, Confident and Fully Exposed
abstract: Saved from cancellation, the porn-mag comedy is still a chaotic ride, but its ideas are more than skin-deep.
lead_paragraph: “This feels like the beginning of something,” Joyce Prigger (Ophelia Lovibond) says in Season 2 of “Minx.” She’s referring to the early ’70s, when America was rethinking gender roles and sexual rules, creating an opening for her to start the feminist porn magazine that gives the comedy its title.

headline: ‘The Deepest Breath’ Review: A Perilous Drop Into the Ocean
abstract: Astonishing underwater footage elevates this documentary about two people drawn to the extreme sport of free diving.
lead_paragraph: While watching “The Deepest Breath,” a documentary that palpably conjures the mystery and menace of the deep sea, I found it difficult not to think of the Titan submersible disaster last month. But this film, on Netflix, invites viewers to submerge alongside thrill-seekers unconfined by a vessel: Its subject is the extreme sport of free diving, in which competitors plunge into the depths for minutes at a time without scuba gear.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Insisting He Is Not a Bigot, Says Opponents Seek to Silence Him
abstract: At a hearing convened by House Republicans, the Democratic presidential candidate defended himself against charges of racism and antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. came to Capitol Hill on Thursday and pointedly declared that he is neither an antisemite nor a racist, while giving a fiery defense of free speech and accusing the Biden administration and his political opponents of trying to silence him.

headline: Summer Pastas for Summer Zodiac Signs
abstract: Happy birthday and happy pastas to you, Cancers, Leos and Virgos.
lead_paragraph: Ask any millennials born in July about their birthday and they’ll recount a childhood colored by anxieties about the day: no classroom cupcakes, no gift-wrapped locker and an ever-present fear that no one will come to your party because everyone is at sleep-away camp or the beach or their grandma’s house.

headline: Upstate Art Weekend Is Bigger Than It’s Ever Been
abstract: A great getaway awaits you up the Hudson: An annual festival of more than 100 participants across 10 New York counties, including NADA Foreland.
lead_paragraph: In just three years, Upstate Art Weekend has grown from an informal map for visiting city folk to an annual festival of more than 100 participants across 10 New York counties. At this weekend’s fourth edition, you’ll be able to wander through private artists’ studios at the Poughkeepsie Underwear Factory, Beacon Open Studios or Newburgh’s Atlas Studios; bid in an auction supporting the New York Abortion Access Fund at Noise for Now in Kingston; even preview a Borscht Belt Museum set to open in Ellenville in 2025. And then there are the performances: On Friday, the Hudson Valley Intertribal Noise Symposium brings a lineup of Indigenous sound artists to the idyllic sculpture park at Art Omi, and on Saturday, the CCS Bard Hessel Museum of Art hosts an outdoor performance by Emily Johnson in conjunction with its show “Indian Theater: Native Performance, Art and Self-Determination Since 1969.”

headline: Listen: The Mysterious Woman Next Door, Tom Hanks Talks, Phoenix Heat Wave
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Hey Audio fans,

headline: The Polygon and the Avalanche: How the Gilgo Beach Suspect Was Found
abstract: As investigators spent years looking for a suspect, a key clue was buried in their files. Could they have solved the case years earlier?
lead_paragraph: They called it the polygon.

headline: Airlines Are Thriving as People Keep Traveling
abstract: Three large U.S. airlines have reported strong quarterly sales and profits in recent days because of strong demand, high fares and relatively low fuel prices.
lead_paragraph: Summer travel is off to a roaring start, with little sign of a slowdown on the horizon. And airline executives say they are doing all they can to keep up, including contending with bad weather and congestion in the skies and on the ground.

headline: ‘Fear the Night’ Review: Party Raid
abstract: Neil LaBute’s new thriller, starring Maggie Q, feels stapled together from a pile of threadbare tropes.
lead_paragraph: One rarely roots for the bad guys in a home-invasion shocker, but, as the majority of the victims in Neil LaBute’s “Fear the Night” are either insufferably stupid or gratingly snippy, their survival is perhaps not the priority it ought to be.

headline: Union for Broadway Crew Members Reaches Tentative Deal, Averting Strike
abstract: The agreement would cover a subset of workers, including about 1,500 stagehands, hairdressers and other crew members on Broadway and in touring productions.
lead_paragraph: The union representing a segment of Broadway crew members reached a tentative agreement for a new contract with theater owners just as its members were voting on whether to authorize a potential strike, the organizations announced Thursday.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Supreme Court Ethics Bill With Dim Prospects
abstract: Republicans accused Democrats of trying to undermine the court with the measure and vowed to block it from advancing in the Senate, making it highly unlikely to become law.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved legislation that would impose strict new ethics rules on justices, moving over fierce objections from Republicans to address a string of revelations about Supreme Court justices taking free luxury trips and receiving other financial benefits from wealthy benefactors.

headline: Capturing a 21st-Century War With 19th-Century Technology
abstract: Edward Kaprov’s wet-plate technique is producing some of the most memorable and timeless photographs of the war in Ukraine close up.
lead_paragraph: The news coverage from Ukraine has been so intense and widespread over the past 16 months that it may seem that the war has been covered to the point of saturation. Yet for all the wealth of film and photographs to come out of the war, there have been significant gaps, most notable a shortage of combat photography.

headline: Best Place for A.I. Jobs (New Report Says) Won’t Surprise You
abstract: Brookings Institution researchers found that San Francisco and San Jose, Calif., dominate job listings for generative A.I. work, potentially solidifying their control of the tech industry.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Bay Area has ruled the technology industry for decades, from the early days of personal computers to the social media boom.

headline: Anchor Workers Want to Save Their Brewery by Buying It
abstract: About 39 unionized workers, who represent two-thirds of the brewery’s employees, agreed to pursue a bid to run it as a co-op, a union official said.
lead_paragraph: Unionized workers at Anchor Brewing Company, the oldest craft brewer in the United States, want to buy the 127-year-old company and run it as a co-op to save it from shutting down, a union official said.

headline: ‘Bawaal’ Review: Getting Some Perspective
abstract: In this Bollywood production, a narcissistic history teacher reconnects with his wife on a trip through Europe.
lead_paragraph: “Bawaal” is a sensationally absurd Bollywood production that tells a simple moral story about what it means to be a Real Man. Directed by Nitesh Tiwari (“Dangal”), this globe-trotting romance is, like many Bollywood movies, willfully over the top. But this one’s not very fun.

headline: The Most Essential Worker in a Heat Wave? The A.C. Guy
abstract: While trying to cool brutally hot Phoenix, Roberto Guerrero and his sons endure sweltering attics, blazing rooftops and nonstop calls for help.
lead_paragraph: José Guerrero’s phone buzzes from morning to midnight with sweaty pleas for help: The air-conditioner fan just quit. My grandma is stuck in a 90-degree house. My children are overheating. Please come, it’s so hot.

headline: Signature Biden Program Won’t Fix Racial Gap in Air Quality, Study Suggests
abstract: The White House aimed for a race-neutral environmental justice strategy, but a new analysis questions whether the program can actually achieve its goals.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis has found that the White House’s signature environmental justice program may not shrink racial disparities in who breathes the most polluted air, in part because of efforts to ensure that it could withstand legal challenges.

headline: Building a Legal Wall Around Donald Trump
abstract: American legal institutions have passed the Jan. 6 test so far, but the tests aren’t over.
lead_paragraph: The American legal system is on the cusp of a remarkable historical achievement. In real time and under immense pressure, it has responded to an American insurrection in a manner that is both meting out justice to the participants and establishing a series of legal precedents that will stand as enduring deterrents to a future rebellion. In an era when so many American institutions have failed, the success of our legal institutions in responding to a grave crisis should be a source of genuine hope.

headline: How Extreme Heat Affects Workers and the Economy
abstract: “It drains your brain. It slows your cognitive function. You’re overwhelmed.”
lead_paragraph: Linda Ressler is an airplane cabin cleaner at the airport in Phoenix, where the temperature has reached or surpassed 110 degrees Fahrenheit for 20 days in a row and counting.

headline: Obstruction Law Cited by Prosecutors in Trump Case Has Drawn Challenges
abstract: Hundreds of Jan. 6 rioters have been charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, but the charge, which could be applied to former President Donald J. Trump, has come under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Well before the prosecutors investigating Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election laid out for him three laws that could be the basis for an indictment, one of the statutes, covering obstruction of an official proceeding, had already been used against — and challenged by — scores of rioters who took part in the storming of the Capitol.

headline: Biden Administration Moves to Raise the Cost of Drilling on Federal Lands
abstract: The royalty rates paid by oil, gas and coal companies for the right to drill and mine on land owned by the public have not changed since 1920.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Thursday proposed a rule that would raise the royalties that fossil fuel companies pay to pull oil, gas and coal from public lands for the first time since 1920, while increasing more than tenfold the cost of the bonds that companies must pay before they start drilling.

headline: ‘Lioness’ Spotted in Germany Was Probably a Wild Boar, Officials Say
abstract: Repeated sightings of what some believed was a large cat near Berlin had prompted concern. The authorities later said that a search did not turn up what they were expecting.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Germany have ended a frantic search for a “free-roaming lioness” that caused a panic in Berlin after determining that the animal that was seen was probably a wild boar.

headline: Wheat prices remain high as concern grows about Black Sea instability and disruption to the grain supply.
abstract: There’s a robust supply of grain globally, but a long-term disruption to exports from Ukraine and a reliance on fewer countries for grain could cause prices to become more volatile.
lead_paragraph: As Black Sea-bound vessels clustered in the waters near Istanbul, wheat prices remained elevated on Thursday, up 13 percent since Monday, when Russia pulled out of a wartime agreement that had been considered critical to stabilizing global food prices.

headline: AMC Theater Chain to Stop Charging for Better Seats
abstract: The contentious initiative will be abandoned next month, though the company will roll out a new one involving lounge-style seating in the front rows.
lead_paragraph: AMC is abandoning plans to charge more for movie seats depending on their location. But higher prices for center-middle seats at theaters where AMC has been testing the concept will remain in effect this weekend, when “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” are expected to draw significant crowds.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a snappy new comedy, a grounded drama and an absurd spin on a postapocalyptic tale.
lead_paragraph: ‘Praise Petey’

headline: Disruption to Ukraine Grain Exports Could Worsen Hunger in Some Countries, Experts Warn
abstract: Moscow terminated a deal this week that allowing Ukraine to export its food crops, an agreement that had helped to stabilize grain prices and to ease a global food shortage.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s disruption of Ukraine’s grain exports exacerbates hunger in some countries facing shortages, though as long as grain prices remain relatively stable, the crisis is unlikely to become catastrophic in the short term, aid officials said on Thursday.

headline: Aspartame: What to Know
GWS-MISSION-IMPOSSIBLE
Names Old and New Top British Open Leaderboard
abstract: Conditions were calm at Royal Liverpool as the final men’s golf major of the year began. Don’t expect them to stay that way.
lead_paragraph: A strategy for winning one of golf’s major championships only rarely looks like this: Find your flight canceled and the next one delayed, walk about a half-mile to passport control, endure a grinding wait at baggage claim less than 48 hours before the tournament’s first tee times and stare down jet lag.

headline: N.F.L. Approves $6 Billion Deal for Washington Commanders, and Dan Snyder’s Exit
abstract: Josh Harris will buy the Washington franchise for a record $6.05 billion from Snyder, who faced sexual harassment allegations, decades of losing and public pressure to change the team’s name and logo.
lead_paragraph: Owners of the N.F.L.’s 31 other teams unanimously approved the sale of the Washington Commanders to a group led by Josh Harris, the private equity billionaire, who agreed to pay a record $6.05 billion to Daniel Snyder, the scandal-plagued owner of the team.

headline: June Was Earth’s Hottest on Record. August May Bring More of the Same.
abstract: In its monthly call, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Adminstration analyzed how June’s temperatures stacked up and said it expects August to continue the trend.
lead_paragraph: Last month was the planet’s warmest June since global temperature record-keeping began in 1850, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said in its monthly climate update on Thursday. The agency also predicts unusually hot temperatures will occur in most of the United States, almost everywhere except the northern Great Plains, during August.

headline: SPAC Tied to Trump’s Media Company Will Pay $18 Million to Regulators
abstract: Digital World will pay a penalty to the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle an investigation into its planned merger with Trump Media & Technology Group.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that it had reached a settlement with the cash-rich shell company that planned to merge with former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company, potentially paving the way for the much-delayed deal to proceed.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: The First Wins in the Women’s World Cup
abstract: Also, tensions between Iraq and Sweden and a gathering of golden retrievers.
lead_paragraph: The first matches of the Women’s World Cup showcased the growth and promise of women’s soccer — but also some of the sport’s persistent challenges.

headline: Tornado Tears Through Pfizer’s N.C. Site, Threatening Crucial Drug Supplies
abstract: Extensive damage occurred at the company’s property in Rocky Mount, and many products used by hospitals appeared to have been affected. This could further exacerbate shortages.
lead_paragraph: A tornado caused extensive damage to a Pfizer drug manufacturing site in Rocky Mount, N.C., on Wednesday, threatening critical supplies for hospitals across the country.

headline: Texas to Leave Voting Integrity Group Targeted by Right-Wing Attacks
abstract: The nonprofit group ERIC, which helps maintain accurate voter rolls, was once widely embraced. But since last year, Trump allies have pushed red states to reject it.
lead_paragraph: Texas said on Thursday that it would drop out of a bipartisan voter integrity group that once included about three dozen states, further destabilizing an organization that has been undermined by right-wing attacks and defections by Republican-led members.

headline: Is This the End of the Red Carpet?
abstract: The actors’ strike could have far-reaching implications for how we watch and consume fashion.
lead_paragraph: At first it seemed impossible to imagine: No more red carpets! No more photos of movie stars and names to watch in fabulous gowns blanketing the internet. Could “Oppenheimer” and “Barbie” be the last gasp of that marketing Valhalla of fashion and film that was the modern premiere — at least for the foreseeable future?

headline: N.F.L. Fines Snyder $60 Million for Sexual Harassment and Withholding Revenue
abstract: Daniel Snyder will pay $60 million in restitution after a league investigation found that he sexually harassed a female employee and improperly withheld revenue when he owned the Washington Commanders.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Snyder was fined $60 million, by far the largest penalty ever levied against an N.F.L. team owner, after he was found to have sexually harassed a woman who was both a former cheerleader and a marketing employee for the Washington Commanders.

headline: Martha Saxton, Historian Who Explored Women’s Lives, Dies at 77
abstract: Her wide range of subjects included the actress Jayne Mansfield, the novelist Louisa May Alcott and Mary Washington, the mother of a president.
lead_paragraph: Martha Saxton, a historian whose penetrating examinations of women’s lives led her to new insights into figures ranging from the author Louisa May Alcott to the 1950s actress and sex symbol Jayne Mansfield to Mary Washington, the mother of the first president of the United States, died on Tuesday at her home in Norfolk, Conn. She was 77.

headline: Trump Seeks U.A.W.’s Support as the Union Wavers on Backing Biden
abstract: A video from the former president attacked electric vehicles, predicting the demise of the American automotive industry.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, seeing an opening with organized labor, appealed on Thursday for an endorsement from the United Auto Workers for his White House bid and said only his return to the presidency could save the automotive industry from President Biden’s “ridiculous Green New Deal crusade.”

headline: This Heat Wave Has Become Dangerous for the Elderly
abstract: Also, the Women’s World Cup begins. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: An onslaught of heat waves — across the Southern U.S., as well as much of Europe and the Middle East — has elevated average global temperatures to historic highs. Extended exposure to the sweltering heat can be a potential health risk for anyone, particularly those who do outdoor work.

headline: Nebraska Teen Who Used Pills to End Pregnancy Gets 90 Days in Jail
abstract: Celeste Burgess, 19, and her mother, Jessica Burgess, 42, were charged last year after the police obtained their private Facebook messages.
lead_paragraph: A Nebraska teenager who used abortion pills to terminate her pregnancy was sentenced on Thursday to 90 days in jail after she pleaded guilty earlier this year to illegally concealing human remains.

headline: Status of Soldier Who Entered North Korea Remains Unknown, U.S. Says
abstract: The Biden administration is trying to determine Pvt. Travis T. King’s condition and location.
lead_paragraph: U.S. officials said Thursday that they had no information on the whereabouts or condition of an Army soldier who crossed into North Korea without authorization and had not spoken to North Korean authorities about the incident.

headline: Jury Awards $800,000 to a Girl Burned by a Chicken McNugget
abstract: The 7-year-old deserved to be compensated by McDonald’s for a second-degree burn caused by a wayward piece from a Happy Meal when she was 4, a Florida jury decided this week.
lead_paragraph: A Florida jury awarded $800,000 in damages to a 7-year-old girl on Wednesday for the suffering and mental anguish caused when a Chicken McNugget fell on her thigh, causing a second-degree burn.

headline: A Collision in Court: Trump Grand Jury Proceedings Delay a Jan. 6 Verdict
abstract: A defense lawyer was late. A judge grew irked. Prosecutors were hauled out of a grand jury. It was an example of the complexities stemming from the multiple proceedings involving Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: For several months, Federal District Court in Washington has been ground zero for the Justice Department’s various attempts to deal with the legacy of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Dick Biondi, Fast-Talking Star of Top 40 Radio, Dies at 90
abstract: “Wild, outrageous, goofy and uplifting,” as one fan put it, he was based in Chicago for most of his career but had fans all over the country.
lead_paragraph: Dick Biondi, an exuberant, fast-talking Top 40 radio personality, nicknamed “the Screamer,” who in the early 1960s became one of Chicago’s most popular disc jockeys and, thanks to the strength of his station’s signal, was heard well beyond the city, died on June 26 in Chicago. He was 90.

headline: Read the Full Report on the Investigation Into Dan Snyder
abstract: The N.F.L. spent 17 months looking into allegations of widespread sexual harassment against executives of the Washington Commanders, as well as claims of financial improprieties.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. spent 17 months looking into allegations of widespread sexual harassment against executives of the Washington Commanders, as well as claims of financial improprieties.

headline: 6-Year-Old Suffocated and Bus Monitor Didn’t Notice, Prosecutor Says
abstract: The girl, who was unable to speak, was in a wheelchair at the back of the bus, and the monitor had her earbuds in. A New Jersey prosecutor charged the woman with manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Davila, a 27-year-old school bus monitor, was sitting toward the front of her bus on Monday morning, focused on her cellphone and wearing her earbuds. Several rows back was one of the children she was supposed to keep an eye on: a disabled 6-year-old girl in a wheelchair who was unable to speak, on her way to a summertime education program in New Jersey.

headline: As Russia Steps Up Attacks on Grain Ports, U.S. Warns of Possible Ruse
abstract: A White House official said Moscow might stage an attack on a commercial ship and blame Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia on Thursday stepped up its aerial assaults on Ukrainian ports critical to the world’s food supply, as the White House warned that the Kremlin has mined sea routes and might be setting the stage for attacks on commercial transport ships.

headline: Beware the New American Triumphalism
abstract: Our economy has done well lately. Don’t become complacent.
lead_paragraph: U.S. economic news has been pretty good lately. Our job market has fully recovered from Covid and then some, defying predictions of permanent “scarring” from pandemic disruptions. Inflation is down, falling faster than in any other large advanced economy. At the same time, economic trouble seems to abound abroad, notably in China, where the end of the “zero Covid” policy hasn’t brought the expected economic surge.

headline: Missouri Supreme Court Allows Abortion Ballot Initiative to Move Ahead
abstract: The effort to put abortion rights before voters was held up when the attorney general said the state auditor had vastly underestimated the potential cost to taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: The Missouri Supreme Court ruled against the state attorney general’s position on an abortion ballot initiative, a decision that allows an effort to restore abortion rights there to move forward.

headline: Carlin Glynn, 83, Actress Whose Comeback Brought Her a Tony, Dies
abstract: After putting her career on hold to raise children, she won the part of the madam in “The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas” — and then a statuette hailing her performance.
lead_paragraph: Carlin Glynn, a stage actress who, after a long hiatus spent raising a family, stepped back into the footlights, sang onstage for the first time and walked away with a Tony Award for her performance as the madam in the 1978 hit “The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,” died on July 13 at her home in upstate New York, in the Hudson Valley. She was 83.

headline: Hacking of Government Email Was Traditional Espionage, Official Says
abstract: The hackers penetrated the accounts of senior State Department officials, including the U.S. ambassador to China.
lead_paragraph: The hack of Microsoft’s cloud that resulted in the compromise of government emails was an example of a traditional espionage threat, a senior National Security Agency official said.

headline: With Aaron Rodgers, Jets Enter Era of Expectation
abstract: Adding Rodgers, the star quarterback, to a team with young talent and a strong defense has players eyeing the Super Bowl. It is a big jump for a franchise that has missed the past 12 postseasons.
lead_paragraph: For a brief moment on Thursday, Aaron Rodgers and the Jets showed everyone what rejuvenation looks like.

headline: U.S. Investigating Why Delta Passengers Were Kept on Plane in Extreme Heat
abstract: The flight, from Las Vegas to Atlanta, was stalled at Harry Reid International Airport, leaving passengers sweltering in triple-digit temperatures, the department said.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Department of Transportation said Thursday that it was investigating why passengers on a Delta Air Lines flight had been left to swelter for hours in triple-digit temperatures while the plane waited on the tarmac at a Las Vegas airport on Monday.

headline: Review: Dancing With Dictators in David Byrne’s ‘Here Lies Love’
abstract: A new Broadway musical tells the disturbing story of Imelda Marcos by putting her, and the audience, in a disco.
lead_paragraph: It’s the applause — including my own — I find troubling.

headline: Trinity Nuclear Test’s Fallout Reached 46 States, Canada and Mexico, Study Finds
abstract: The research shows that the first atomic bomb explosion’s effects had been underestimated, and could help more “downwinders” press for federal compensation.
lead_paragraph: In July 1945, as J. Robert Oppenheimer and the other researchers of the Manhattan Project prepared to test their brand-new atomic bomb in a New Mexico desert, they knew relatively little about how that mega-weapon would behave.

headline: C.I.A. Chief Says Wagner Mutiny Revived Questions About Putin’s Rule
abstract: William J. Burns gave the most detailed public account yet by a U.S. official of the damage done to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia by last month’s uprising by the mercenary group.
lead_paragraph: In the most detailed public account yet given by a U.S. official, the director of the C.I.A. offered a biting assessment on Thursday of the damage done to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia by the mutiny of the Wagner mercenary group, saying the rebellion had revived questions about Mr. Putin’s judgment and his detachment from events.

headline: ‘Ding, Ding, Ding, We Have a Winner!’
abstract: Robyn Weintraub opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Chain Link
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners brings us a puzzle full of intricate connections.
lead_paragraph: CHAIN LINK — This is a formidable-looking grid, but if you can break in just a little bit, it is actually doable — a wordplay paper tiger. It’s a clever adaptation of a rows garden puzzle in that there are two sets of clues, overlapping letters and entries that run in either a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.

headline: Top contenders took the field.
abstract: Spain came away with an easy win, while Canada tied Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: After Australia and New Zealand, the co-hosts of the Women’s World Cup, kicked off the tournament with victories, the focus now shifts to the next games of group play, and to three top contenders taking the field: Canada, Spain and the United States.

headline: U.K. Voters Hand Sunak’s Party Two Defeats and a Win in By-elections
abstract: The governing Conservatives retained Boris Johnson’s former Parliament seat in northwest London, but lost in two districts, including a sobering defeat in northern England.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Conservative Party suffered crushing defeats in the race for what had previously been two safe seats in Parliament, but narrowly avoided losing a third contest, in election results Friday that sent an ominous signal about the political future of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.

headline: Corrections: July 21, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the impact that general election outcomes could have on efforts to exhume mass graves in Spain misstated the profession of a woman executed and buried in the mass graves in Viznar, Spain. She was a tailor, not a barmaid.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Stranded Along Tunisia’s Borders, Migrants Wait for Death
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 21, 2023
lead_paragraph: “I’m hoping that I’ll close my eyes and find myself in Italy. There’s no hope, no horizon, no future in this country.”

headline: The Pandemic Era Tinder Match That Turned Into More
abstract: Andrew Gilmoor and Nicholas Leddy matched a month before they ran into each other at a Black Lives Matter protest in Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: In June 2020, when Andrew Roderick Gilmoor left his neighborhood in Amsterdam for the first time in weeks, he spotted a familiar face. He had been self-isolating at his apartment and was on his way to a Black Lives Matter protest. At Dam Square, through a crowd of thousands, “I saw this really tall, handsome man in a face mask,” he said. He suspected it was Nicholas James Leddy.

headline: Why My Father Called Me Son, Daughter, He, She and It
abstract: As my father lost his memory, he began to regard my gender as increasingly fluid.
lead_paragraph: My father and I were in Starbucks about a year after he learned he had Alzheimer’s when he looked me up and down with his judge’s eye and said to the barista, “This young — ahem — man will have a latte.”

headline: This U.S. World Cup Team Is One for the Ages. All the Ages.
abstract: The U.S. team includes past champions, veterans of the equal pay fight and 14 players experiencing their first World Cup. How they come together will shape the future.
lead_paragraph: The story seemed like one Alex Morgan might tell around a campfire.

headline: Crosswords and Dad Jokes Lead to a Deeper Connection
abstract: Sophia Wang and Marcus Fleming first bonded over crossword puzzles. On their second date, they knew they had stumbled on to something more.
lead_paragraph: Their love began with a clue — a crossword clue, to be exact.

headline: She Dreamed of Love at Whole Foods, but Twitter Proved a Better Option
