lead_paragraph: Adrianne Peterson, the manager of the Rancho Peñasquitos branch of the San Diego Public Library, was actually a little embarrassed by the modest size of her Pride Month display in June. Between staff vacations and organizing workshops for graduating high school students, it had fallen through the cracks and fell short of what she had hoped to offer.

headline: ‘How To With John Wilson’ Is Ending. What Will He Do Now?
abstract: Now that the filmmaker’s HBO series is wrapping up, would he rule out directing a season of “The Bachelor”?
lead_paragraph: John Wilson likes trilogies. “There are only three seasons of ‘Jackass,’” he pointed out during an interview this month from his home in Queens.

headline: A Mystery in the E.R.? Ask Dr. Chatbot for a Diagnosis.
abstract: At a medical school in Boston, instructors are using ChatGPT in training exercises to help teach students how to think like doctors.
lead_paragraph: The patient was a 39-year-old woman who had come to the emergency department at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. Her left knee had been hurting for several days. The day before, she had a fever of 102 degrees. It was gone now, but she still had chills. And her knee was red and swollen.

headline: How Do the White House’s A.I. Commitments Stack Up?
abstract: Seven leading A.I. companies made eight promises about what they’ll do with their technology. Our columnist sizes up their potential impact.
lead_paragraph: This week, the White House announced that it had secured “voluntary commitments” from seven leading A.I. companies to manage the risks posed by artificial intelligence.

headline: A Mental Health Crisis. An Officer’s Gun. A Too-Common Tragedy.
abstract: The death of Melissa Perez in San Antonio is renewing vexing questions about how police deal with people who have mental health issues.
lead_paragraph: The San Antonio Police Department, like the police in other cities, has a Mental Health Unit available around the clock to respond to calls that require trained, empathetic responses and support for people in distress.

headline: Lawyers Say Helping Asylum Seekers in Border Custody Is Nearly Impossible
abstract: The Biden administration changed the way “credible fear” interviews are conducted and raised the bar for who is eligible to seek asylum.
lead_paragraph: In the first weeks after President Biden’s new border policies were put in place, his administration recorded a sharp drop in the number of people allowed to apply for asylum after crossing into the United States illegally.

headline: In Belarus, the Protests Were Three Years Ago. The Crackdown Is Never-Ending.
abstract: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko brutally repressed those who opposed his claim of re-election as president. The crackdown on dissent has only deepened since.
lead_paragraph: The recent high school graduate selected her wardrobe carefully as she headed off to a summer folk festival.

headline: A Decade Ago, Jeff Bezos Bought a Newspaper. Now He’s Paying Attention to It Again.
abstract: The Amazon founder, who purchased The Washington Post for $250 million in 2013, has taken a more active role in the paper’s operations this year.
lead_paragraph: During his tenure as executive editor at The Washington Post, Martin Baron ran into a persistent problem.

headline: What’s the Status of Flaunting Your Status?
abstract: In the world of the ultrawealthy, luxury is only quiet if you don’t know what to listen for.
lead_paragraph: In what now seems the quaint era of Truman Capote’s baroque social diagrams, what distinguished the truly wealthy from the merely rich was the better vegetables they served: “tiny ones.”

headline: Tim Scott Awaits His Moment. But Will It Come?
abstract: The South Carolina senator is gaining in early-voting states and has money, a positive message and a compelling story. Now he needs to take on the Republican front-runners.
lead_paragraph: He is rising in the polls and turning heads in Iowa and New Hampshire, behind heavy spending on ads that play to voters’ appetite for a leader who is upbeat and positive in a dark political moment.

headline: Student Loans Come Due Again: Many Borrowers Will Lose a Lifeline
abstract: The payment pause freed up money that gave people breathing room — or allowed them to help family members in need. They will soon have to budget for that expense.
lead_paragraph: With her student loan payments on hold for three years, Ashley Dorn, a public school music teacher, found another use for the money she saved during the moratorium. She used the extra cash to pay off $10,000 in credit card debt, a bill that had been nagging at her for a decade.

headline: A Story of Arab Loss Comes to Life at a Kibbutz in Israel
abstract: A museum founded by pioneering Zionists has been hosting a sweeping retrospective of Palestinian art.
lead_paragraph: For years, the kibbutz of Ein Harod has prospered in the Jezreel Valley, a fertile plain in northern Israel still scarred by the convulsions that accompanied the creation of the Jewish state 75 years ago.

headline: Venezuela’s Oil Industry Is Broken. Now It’s Breaking the Environment.
abstract: Gas flares and leaking pipelines from Venezuela’s once-booming oil industry, hobbled by U.S. sanctions and mismanagement, are polluting towns and a major lake.
lead_paragraph: Each morning, José Aguilera inspects the leaves of his banana and coffee plants on his farm in eastern Venezuela and calculates how much he can harvest — almost nothing.

headline: Japan Says It Can Make Coal Cleaner. Critics Say Its Plan Is ‘Almost Impossible.’
abstract: Japan says that by blending ammonia with coal in its boilers, it can make coal less damaging to the planet. But the technology faces many hurdles.
lead_paragraph: The world’s advanced economies have committed to phasing out coal over the next seven years. But not Japan, which stands alone in insisting it can make coal less damaging to the planet.

headline: Nico Muhly Modernizes Monteverdi With ‘Irreverent Veneration’
abstract: Muhly has reorchestrated Monteverdi’s foundational “L’Orfeo” for a new production at Santa Fe Opera.
lead_paragraph: When a new production of Monteverdi’s “L’Orfeo” premieres at Santa Fe Opera on July 29, something about it might seem slightly odd.

headline: Lionel Messi Ventures Into Charted Territory
abstract: The Argentine star’s signing is seen as a way to push soccer into the American mainstream. But it’s already there.
lead_paragraph: Tempting Lionel Messi to the United States could not solely be a matter of money. The money had to be right, of course. It had to be competitive. It was, Jorge Mas knew, perfectly possible that his attempt to persuade Messi, the greatest player of his generation, to sign for Inter Miami would fail because of money. But it would not succeed because of it. Not exclusively, anyway.

headline: Malaysia Halts Music Festival After Kiss Between Bandmates Onstage
abstract: The episode comes as rights groups have warned of growing intolerance against lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people in the country, where homosexuality is a crime.
lead_paragraph: Malaysia’s government halted a music festival in the capital, Kuala Lumpur, on Saturday, a day after the frontman of the British pop rock band The 1975 kissed a male bandmate onstage and criticized the country’s anti-L.G.B.T. laws.

headline: Challenged by Tech and Market Forces, Independent Bookshops Bounce Back
abstract: Their demise was long predicted and pandemic closings were a heavy blow, but many local shops are thriving again.
lead_paragraph: While traveling around Canada on assignment, I usually try to visit museums and art galleries and, when they’re available, local bookshops.

headline: As Tensions Rise, Zelensky Pushes for Way to Ship Grain Through Black Sea
abstract: The Ukrainian leader said he had spoken with the NATO chief and the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a key mediator between Russia and Ukraine since the full-scale invasion began last February.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was pushing forward with diplomatic efforts on Saturday to reopen the Black Sea to Ukraine’s grain shipments, strategizing with NATO’s chief a day after discussing with the Turkish president the collapse of a deal that allowed ships to bypass Russia’s blockade.

headline: Welcome to Barbenheimer Weekend
abstract: You have little choice but to surrender to the dark and the air conditioning and the allure of two of the summer’s biggest movies.
lead_paragraph: Start the day with the darker fare: Christopher Nolan’s moody “Oppenheimer,” about the physicist who ran the Los Alamos Laboratory during the development of the atomic bomb. A morning screening is best, so you can get some fresh air, some sustenance other than Milk Duds, clear your head before Greta Gerwig’s “live-action, you-go-girl fantasia,” “Barbie,” the second half of the double feature known, for better or worse, as “Barbenheimer.”

headline: Sophia Smith Has Been Ready for Her World Cup Moment
abstract: Smith had two goals and an assist in her debut in the tournament. And she believes, along with her teammates, that there could have been more.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks before the Women’s World Cup, Sophia Smith admitted that she wanted to be the first United States player to score a goal in the tournament. Of course she did. Like every great athlete, she has long envisioned herself as a star.

headline: Complicated Stories of Affirmative Action
abstract: Readers react to John McWhorter’s account of how it affected his education and career. Also: Race and artistic achievement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Moment of Truth for Our Liar in Chief
abstract: Has Florida Man met his match in an Ironman?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A man is running to run the government he tried to overthrow while he was running it, even as he is running to stay ahead of the law.

headline: The Risks of One of the Most Severe Tools in America’s Foreign Policy Arsenal
abstract: Punishing countries with harsh sanctions rarely works as intended without clear goals for lifting them.
lead_paragraph: There is nearly universal consensus that certain egregious violations of international laws and norms demand a forceful and concerted response. Think only, for example, of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine or the development of nuclear weapons capabilities in Iran and North Korea. Harsh economic sanctions have long been viewed as the answer.

headline: The Birds Are Singing, but Not for Me
abstract: Evolution’s curse of creeping deafness changes how a biologist experiences nature.
lead_paragraph: Animal sounds are my connection to the changing seasons. Every week, a new voice appears or fades. Early winter arrives with the chip of juncos. The chitter of nestling bluebirds signals the onset of summer, closely followed by the first cicadas.

headline: Whatever You Think of the Movies, the Barbenheimer Memes Are Glorious
abstract: This explosion of fan-driven creativity is so much more entertaining than mere marketing could ever be.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I bought a T-shirt from Rob Sheridan, the co-founder of the design company Glitch Goods and the former art director for the industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails. It’s a sleeveless black muscle shirt that has an eyeless melting Barbie doll face dripping with blood and set against a fiery backdrop and says, ominously, “This Barbie opened the ark of the covenant … She betrayed the word of God.” Mr. Sheridan promoted the shirt to coincide with the same-day opening of Greta Gerwig’s “Barbie” and Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer,” a new, unofficial phenomenon the moviegoing masses have called “Barbenheimer.”

headline: With Israel, It’s Time to Start Discussing the Unmentionable
abstract: Does it make sense for the United States to provide $3.8 billion annually to another rich country, indefinitely?
lead_paragraph: Israel is in the headlines, evoking tumultuous debate. Yet one topic remains largely unmentionable, so let me gingerly raise it: Is it time to think about phasing out American aid for Israel down the road?

headline: Listen to This American Life: House on Loon Lake
abstract: The search for a mysterious family who disappeared without a trace.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Stagnation of Ron DeSantis
abstract: The great non-Trump hope has faltered. He’s still the only contender with a path.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to rapidly “reboot” a struggling presidential campaign? Pundits have to hope so, since otherwise our advice-giving beat becomes a bit irrelevant. But thinking back over recent primary candidacies that seemed to sag and then recovered, from John Kerry in 2004 to John McCain in 2008 to Joe Biden in 2020, it’s hard to identify brilliant strategic pivots. Instead what you see is candidates with fundamental strengths who hung around until events conspired to make those strengths more relevant, their opponents’ weaknesses more manifest, and their campaigns suddenly triumphant.

headline: Extreme Heat Shows the Need for Another Kind of Climate Investment
abstract: Almost all climate finance focuses on mitigating climate change. But money is increasingly pouring in to helping people adapt to the effects of global warming.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. In today’s newsletter: Extreme heat highlights the need for another kind of climate investment; A.I. puts shadow libraries in the spotlight; and Aly Wagner, a co-founder of a new women’s soccer team, talks about the money in women’s sports. (Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: Fact-Checking Mike Pence on the Campaign Trail
abstract: The former vice president has made misleading claims about abortion, fiscal policy and military spending.
lead_paragraph: Since beginning his long-shot presidential campaign in June, former Vice President Mike Pence has struggled to gain traction among Republican primary voters.

headline: ‘Conan,’ ‘Goodfellas’ and MTV: How Tony Bennett Revived His Career
abstract: Mr. Bennett’s career went downhill in the 1970s, as drug and financial problems haunted him. Then his son became his manager, and everything took a rags-to-riches turn.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, Tony Bennett’s career and life were in disarray.

headline: Would You Drink Wastewater? What if It Was Beer?
abstract: In an era of drought, turning treated wastewater into drinking water may be the future. Utility companies are working with breweries to get people past the “ick factor.”
lead_paragraph: Epic OneWater Brew looks like your classic hipster craft beer.

headline: The Question After Every Mass Shooting: How Much Do We Deserve to Know?
abstract: A court in Nashville may decide whether releasing the musings of a killer could help prevent future losses, despite adding to survivors’ pain.
lead_paragraph: After every mass shooting it comes: recordings of pleading 911 calls, photos of the scene, grim evidence released by law enforcement. This tsunami of investigative detail could save lives, but it inflicts fresh agony on the families of the dead.

headline: A Thrilling, Rediscovered Nina Simone Set, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Snoh Aalegra, DeYarmond Edison, Explosions in the Sky and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: 11 Killed in Suspected Arson in Mexico Club
abstract: Prosecutors say a man hurled a firebomb at the bar after being ejected. Mexico has struggled to tamp down on raging violent crime.
lead_paragraph: Eleven people were killed and four injured in a suspected arson attack at a bar in the northern border city of San Luis Río Colorado, Sonora, on Saturday morning, Mexican authorities said, as the country continues to struggle with violent crime.

headline: Can This Man Fix France’s Women’s Team?
abstract: Hervé Renard has led two men’s teams to the World Cup. But in taking over his country’s talented but troubled women’s squad, he may have his toughest job yet.
lead_paragraph: The banner hangs just beneath the central staircase of the elegant hotel that has been taken over by the France women’s national team for the World Cup. Hervé Renard wanted to make sure no one in his squad could miss it.

headline: The Steep Cost of Ron DeSantis’s Vaccine Turnabout
abstract: Once a vaccine advocate, the Florida governor lost his enthusiasm for the shot before the Delta wave sent Covid hospitalizations and deaths soaring. It’s a grim chapter he now leaves out of his rosy retelling of his pandemic response.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday in September 2020, with Covid-19 killing more than 600 Americans daily and hundreds of thousands of deaths still to come, Dr. Deborah L. Birx, a member of the White House coronavirus task force, heard her cellphone ring. It was Dr. Scott Rivkees, the Florida surgeon general. He was distraught.

headline: Far Right May Rise as Kingmaker in Spanish Election
abstract: A messier political landscape has lent leverage to the extremes, leaving a hard-right party with a chance to share power for the first time since Franco.
lead_paragraph: If Spain’s national elections on Sunday turn out as most polls and analysts suggest, mainstream conservatives may come out on top but need allies on the political fringe to govern, ushering the first hard-right party into power since the Franco dictatorship.

headline: Huge Protest March Reaches Jerusalem After 5-Day Trek From Tel Aviv
abstract: Tens of thousands of protesters reached Jerusalem on Saturday, some having walked 40 miles from Tel Aviv. The march highlighted the depth of opposition to a government plan to restrain the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: A miles-long column of antigovernment demonstrators marched into Jerusalem on Saturday evening, turning the main road to the city into a sea of blue-and-white Israeli flags, to protest the far-right government’s plan to limit judicial power.

headline: The Real Power of Super Shoes Could Be Supercharged Training
abstract: Super shoes are ubiquitous for both track and road races. But does the real benefit come from training in them?
lead_paragraph: One month before the year’s biggest track and field event, a dizzying number of fleet-footed performances have lit up local and professional meets.

headline: Kidnapped Girl’s ‘Help Me!’ Sign Leads to Her Rescue
abstract: A passer-by saw the girl’s sign at a parking lot in Long Beach, Calif., after a 61-year-old man had taken her from Texas days earlier, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 13-year-old Texas girl was kidnapped, driven across multiple state lines and then rescued after she held up a handmade “Help Me!” sign in a California parking lot, the authorities said.

headline: Wildfires Imperil Greek Isle of Rhodes, Forcing Big Relocation
abstract: Greek Coast Guard vessels were dispatched to rescue visitors and residents trapped in threatened seaside villages on the large island, a leading tourist destination. Some fled in their bathing suits.
lead_paragraph: Greek Coast Guard vessels on Saturday evacuated hundreds of tourists and locals trapped in seaside villages on Rhodes that were threatened by five-day-old wildfires, moving them to safer parts of the island.

headline: How the Hunt for a Lioness Near Berlin Turned Into a Wild Boar Chase
abstract: The heavily armed search that upended the southern edge of the German capital met an anti-climactic end — and left some scratching their heads: “A wild boar doesn’t really look like a lion.”
lead_paragraph: A frenzied hunt for a loose lioness on the outskirts of Berlin that prompted the deployment of helicopters, drones and night-vision-goggle-clad police officers came to an unexpected end after the authorities announced that it was likely a case of mistaken identity.

headline: Mike Reynolds, 79, Dies; Champion of California’s Three-Strikes Law
abstract: The murder of his daughter sent him on a successful quest to push for tougher sentencing at a time when violent crime was a top concern nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Mike Reynolds, a California photographer who, after his daughter was murdered in 1992, became a driving force behind stricter sentencing reforms in his state, including its contentious three-strikes law, died on July 9 in Fresno, Calif. He was 79.

headline: At the British Open, a Mom’s Influence Looms Large for Many Golfers
abstract: Golf has long had a tradition of fathers and sons, but when the British Open was last held at Royal Liverpool in 2014, Rory McIlroy put golf’s moms on equal footing.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, there was Old Tom Morris and his son, Tommy, both of St. Andrews. The father won the British Open — the only championship then — four times and his namesake son won it four times, too. Yes, wet wool, 19th-century golf, in all its paternalistic glory. The men marched off the first tee and into a heavy sea wind and nobody knew when, or if, they would come back.

headline: 3 Dead in Listeria Outbreak in Washington State
abstract: Health officials said five cases of listeriosis in Puget Sound were probably caused by the same unidentified food source. All of those infected were older than 60.
lead_paragraph: Health officials in Washington State said on Friday that three people had died and two had been hospitalized in the Puget Sound area after contracting food-borne listeria infections in what appeared to be an outbreak.

headline: Richard Barancik, Last of the World War II Monuments Men, Dies at 98
abstract: He played a role in the celebrated Allied operation to preserve European artworks and cultural treasures stolen by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Richard Barancik, the last surviving member of the Allied unit known as the Monuments Men and Women, which during and after World War II preserved a vast amount of European artworks and cultural treasures that had been looted and hidden by Nazi Germany, died on July 14 in Chicago. He was 98.

headline: Stars Muted No More at British Open, Rahm Roars Up Leaderboard
abstract: Jon Rahm’s 63 was a record for an Open at Royal Liverpool, but Brian Harman will enter Sunday with a five-shot lead.
lead_paragraph: Every major tournament has the cruel, curt power to humble golf’s stars. Rory McIlroy at the Masters. Justin Thomas at the P.G.A. Championship. Phil Mickelson at the U.S. Open (OK, make that a lot of them).

headline: Four Remain Missing After Torrential Rains in Nova Scotia
abstract: Parts of the province recorded its heaviest rainfall since 1971. The flooding forced hundreds to evacuate, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Four people remained missing on Sunday after floods swept through Nova Scotia and parts of the province recorded its heaviest rainfall since 1971, forcing hundreds to evacuate and damaging or destroying 25 bridges, the authorities said.

headline: Aural Surgery
abstract: Tread lightly through Chandi Deitmer’s complex crossword operation.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: No Opposition. No Choice. Cambodia’s Election Paves Way for Dynastic Rule.
abstract: The party of Hun Sen, who has been prime minister for nearly four decades, declared victory on Sunday in parliamentary elections that set the stage for his son to rule the country.
lead_paragraph: The party of the Cambodian prime minister, Hun Sen, declared victory on Sunday in stage-managed parliamentary elections that prepared the way for the first change in leadership since he took office nearly four decades ago.

headline: Jamie Foxx Says He Is ‘Coming Back’ After Hospitalization
abstract: The actor posted a video on Instagram after being largely absent from public life since his family said he was hospitalized in April.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Foxx, the comedian, Oscar-winning actor and Grammy-winning singer, said in a video on Instagram that he could return to work after he was hospitalized with an undisclosed illness in April.

headline: Don Is Downgraded to a Post-Tropical Cyclone
abstract: The storm, which poses no threat to land, had strengthened into the first Atlantic hurricane of the 2023 season over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: The former Tropical Storm Don, which briefly strengthened over the weekend to become the first hurricane in the Atlantic this year, had degraded to a post-tropical cyclone, meteorologists said on Monday morning.

headline: 4 Killed in Helicopter Crash in Remote Alaskan Lake
abstract: The victims included a pilot and three people who worked for the Alaska Division of Geological and Geophysical Surveys, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A helicopter carrying a pilot and three passengers who had been conducting field work for an Alaskan government agency crashed on Thursday night, killing all four people on board, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Saturday.

headline: 50 Rappers, 50 Stories: Behind the Scenes
abstract: A look at how we assembled a sweeping collection of personal narratives, and the threads that tie them together.
lead_paragraph: This week, The New York Times published 50 Rappers, 50 Stories, a collection of oral histories gathered from hip-hop artists across generations, regions and styles. It includes testimonials from superstars like Lil Wayne, 50 Cent, Cardi B and Eminem; local heroes like Project Pat, Uncle Luke, Bun B and Krayzie Bone; and outlier champions like Trippie Redd, stic, Slug and Boots Riley.

headline: Bungled Hiring of Journalism Director Exposes a Rift at Texas A&M
abstract: The failed effort to hire Kathleen McElroy, a journalism professor who ultimately turned down what she said was a watered-down offer, has revealed wide divisions at the school over diversity.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting with student leaders in February 2022, the president of Texas A&M University described an ambitious plan to confront the school’s biggest challenges and turn it into a world class institution.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Story of Arab Loss Comes to Life at a Kibbutz in Israel, 75 Years Later
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 23, 2023
lead_paragraph: “There is no point in trying to erase history. It never disappears.”

headline: Corrections: July 23, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 34 this weekend about Wikipedia and artificial intelligence refers imprecisely to what Margaret Mitchell has said about why she was fired from Google. She has said she was fired for criticizing how the company treated colleagues working on bias in A.I., not for criticizing the direction of its work.

headline: The Morocco Women’s Team Has Already Won
abstract: Morocco is the first North African and majority Arab nation to qualify for the Women’s World Cup. It’s hoping to pick up the baton its men’s team carried in Qatar.
lead_paragraph: Khadija Rmichi’s path to the Women’s World Cup started on a bicycle.

headline: Spain’s Vote on Sunday: Here’s What to Know
abstract: The national elections could see a far-right party enter the Spanish government for the first time since the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Spaniards went to the polls on Sunday to vote in an early general election that could see the right return to power and, more crucially, the far right enter the national government for the first time since the Franco dictatorship, nearly a half-century ago.

headline: Jamaica gets an unexpected draw with France.
abstract: Despite a successful run in international play over the past few years, France has been in turmoil behind the scenes. In March, the French federation fired its longtime coach, Corinne Diacre, after players complained of an unhealthy environment on the team.
lead_paragraph: Despite a successful run in international play over the past few years, France has been in turmoil behind the scenes. In March, the French federation fired its longtime coach, Corinne Diacre, after players complained of an unhealthy environment on the team.

headline: With Israel in Turmoil, Netanyahu Is Hospitalized for Pacemaker
abstract: Doctors said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was “doing very well” after the unexpected procedure early Sunday, but the news only compounded the chaos over a government plan to limit judicial power.
lead_paragraph: With his country on knife’s edge over his campaign to rein in the power of the judiciary, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was rushed to the hospital early Sunday morning to have a heart pacemaker fitted.

headline: Deadly Russian Strikes Hit Odesa Cathedral and Apartment Buildings
abstract: Moscow has renewed its attacks on the port city since pulling out of the Black Sea grain deal last week.
lead_paragraph: The civilian toll is rising in Odesa, the Ukrainian port city that has been under relentless attack by Russian forces in the past week after the Kremlin pulled out of an agreement that allowed for the export of Ukrainian grain through the Black Sea.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Drugmakers Are ‘Throwing the Kitchen Sink’ to Halt Medicare Price Negotiations
abstract: The government will soon announce the first 10 medications that will be subject to price negotiations with Medicare under a new law. Drugmakers are fighting the measure in court.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical industry, which suffered a stinging defeat last year when President Biden signed a law authorizing Medicare to negotiate the price of some prescription medicines, is now waging a broad-based assault on the measure — just as the negotiations are about to begin.

headline: ‘She Proceeded to Empty the Bag’s Contents Onto the Small Table’
abstract: A surprising response to a compliment, a circle of urban life and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Wales Has a Prince, But It Has Never Hosted a British Open
abstract: The Open is being played for the 151st time, this time at Royal Liverpool in England. It has never once been to Wales.
lead_paragraph: The rain rat-a-tatted atop the umbrellas around Royal Liverpool Golf Club’s 17th green one afternoon this past week, the air so chilled that it did not feel like even an English summer. A veil of mist clouded the landscape. Still near enough to peek through, though, was the Welsh coast, a handful of long tee shots across the estuary.

headline: Was the Rolled-Up Painting in the Dog Walker’s Closet Worth Millions?
abstract: The dog walker thought so. Sotheby’s planned the auction — at first.
lead_paragraph: In March of 2022, Mark Herman, a dog walker and recreational drug enthusiast in Upper Manhattan, came into possession of a dog, a painting and a story.

headline: In San Francisco, a Levi Strauss Heir and a Former Ally Prepare to Challenge London Breed
abstract: The mayor is drawing challengers more than a year before the election, a sign that she will face a tough race in a city where most voters remain in a foul mood.
lead_paragraph: London Breed sailed to victory as the mayor of San Francisco. A local who rose from the housing projects to become the first Black woman to lead the liberal city, she won a special election in 2018 and then a full term in a landslide the following year. Times were good; the pandemic had yet to happen. If homelessness and crime worried San Franciscans, few of them blamed her.

headline: Are Google and Meta to Blame for the Racist Massacre in Buffalo?
abstract: Two new lawsuits filed by the victims’ families are the most recent attempt to hold social media companies responsible when men steeped in violent ideologies on those platforms open fire.
lead_paragraph: Ask the families of the victims of last year’s racist massacre in Buffalo what they want and one goal comes up again and again.

headline: Watch Amateurs Race Against the Tour de France’s Top Climbers (Sort Of)
abstract: Thousands of amateurs tried the same steep climbs that Tour cyclists did, and uploaded their rides to Strava.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of amateurs tried the same steep climbs that Tour cyclists did, and uploaded their rides to Strava.

headline: A Number That Should Guide Your Health Choices (It’s Not Your Age)
abstract: Life expectancy increasingly figures into calculations about whether screenings and treatments are appropriate. Here’s how to find out yours.
lead_paragraph: At her annual visit, the patient’s doctor asks if she plans to continue having regular mammograms to screen for breast cancer, and then reminds her that it’s been almost 10 years since her last colonoscopy.

headline: How a Mexican Lager Quietly Rose to Become America’s Best-Selling Beer
abstract: A decade before Bud Light faced a conservative-led boycott over a transgender influencer, Modelo Especial was on track to take the No. 1 spot.
lead_paragraph: More beers in America are being paired with lime than ever before.

headline: Regarding North Bath, Richard Russo Saved His Best for Last
abstract: Like “Nobody’s Fool” and “Everybody’s Fool,” “Somebody’s Fool” is set in a fictional town with lots of problems.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to North Bath, scrappy sibling to the larger, wealthier Schuyler Springs, down the road in woodsy upstate New York. While Schuyler Springs is famous for wine bars, pricey restaurants and a racetrack, North Bath (or “Bath”) prides itself on a rustic vibe, greasy spoons and scrapyards and grand Victorian fixer-uppers. Here everyone knows your name. Burgers and pitchers of beer are just a stroll away, and bed-hopping is a town sport.

headline: Vladimir Putin Is Still Useful to Xi Jinping. Until He Isn’t.
abstract: China’s track record on foreign friendships does not bode well for the Russian leader.
lead_paragraph: In 1969, China and the Soviet Union seemed on the brink of war.

headline: In Louisiana, a Democratic Governor Leans on Vetoes to Stall Conservative Agenda
abstract: John Bel Edwards, the only Democratic governor in the Deep South, has successfully vetoed bills that have glided into law elsewhere in the region. Soon, he’ll leave office.
lead_paragraph: The Republican supermajority in the Louisiana State Legislature pushed through a bill this year banning gender-transition care for minors, along with other legislation banning Covid vaccine requirements in schools and any classroom discussion of gender identity and sexual orientation.

headline: The Sputtering DeSantis Campaign Looks for a Restart
abstract: The campaign’s missteps and swelling costs have made donors and allies anxious. One person close to the Florida governor said he had experienced a “challenging learning curve.”
lead_paragraph: Throughout the spring, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and his advisers waved off his sagging poll numbers with the simple fact that he wasn’t yet an actual candidate for president.

headline: It’s Scorching in Iran, and There’s Less and Less Water to Help
abstract: Water shortages from longtime mismanagement have left people with shrinking options, as temperatures spike and growing poverty makes air-conditioning unaffordable for many.
lead_paragraph: For a month and 10 days of unrelenting summer heat, Sepideh, a physician in southern Iran, and her dentist husband have left the house only for work (and only in the mornings) and for groceries (and only when the fridge is utterly bare). At one point last week, her car’s dashboard thermometer read 57 degrees Celsius, about 135 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Ann Roth Is Hollywood’s Secret Weapon
abstract: Inside the studio of the costume master who helped give the world “Klute,” “The English Patient,” “Midnight Cowboy,” “Working Girl,” “Mamma Mia!” “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom” — and more.
lead_paragraph: Ann Roth began with a few instructions: “Do NOT call me amazing. Do NOT call me a 91-year-old legend. Do NOT call me the oldest person in the ‘Barbie’ movie.”

headline: Weary Soldiers, Unreliable Munitions: Ukraine’s Many Challenges
abstract: A month of reporting by New York Times journalists found the fighting mostly stalemated and Ukraine facing an array of obstacles against a determined foe.
lead_paragraph: The headquarters of one of the battalions in Ukraine’s 53rd Mechanized Brigade smells of freshly cut pine trees. The scents are from the wooden support beams in the labyrinth of trenches that make up most of the unit’s rudimentary base outside the embattled town of Avdiivka.

headline: Can Jelly Roll Heal the Broken Soul of America?
abstract: In the outlaw country music star, millions like me seem to have found a preacher who delivers both reality and spirituality.
lead_paragraph: On one level — let’s call it the superficial level — the recent and rapid rise to stardom of Jason DeFord, the country singer and rapper known as Jelly Roll, might seem surprising.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Trillion-Gallon Question’
abstract: Extreme weather is threatening California’s dams. What happens if they fail?
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Feb. 7, 2017, two electricians were working on a warning siren near the spillway of Oroville Dam, 60 miles north of Sacramento, when they heard an explosion. As they watched, a giant plume of water rose over their heads, and chunks of concrete began flying down the hillside toward the Feather River. The dam’s spillway, a concrete channel capable of moving millions of gallons of water out of the reservoir in seconds, was disintegrating in front of them. If it had to be taken out of service, a serious rainstorm, like the one that had been falling on Northern California for days, could cause the dam — the tallest in the United States — to fail.

headline: What I Learned in Ukraine
abstract: Memo from a nation of closed skies, air-raid apps and bustling urban life.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Last week, a friend asked me what I could learn from a four-day trip to Ukraine I was planning that I couldn’t glean just by reading the news. It was a fair question. With the trip now behind me, I can answer.

headline: Pedro Pascal and Jenna Ortega Shouldn’t Be Exceptions in Hollywood
abstract: There are generations of talented scriptwriters, producers and filmmakers who have been underutilized and countless rich stories and ideas that have yet to be told.
lead_paragraph: Corporate America’s treatment of Latinx people as a homogeneous monolithic group, instead of the diverse demographic it is, has for decades perpetuated stereotypes of Latino authenticity. These stereotypes have disproportionately depicted Latinos on TV and in movies as Spanish speakers that hailed from Latin America and shared a particular Latin “look.”

headline: A Crisis in America’s Theaters Leaves Prestigious Stages Dark
abstract: As they struggle to recover after the pandemic, regional theaters are staging fewer shows, giving fewer performances, laying off staff and, in some cases, closing.
lead_paragraph: There is less theater in America these days. Fewer venues. Fewer productions. Fewer performances.

headline: Rethinking the Circus
abstract: Can Cirque du Soleil get Gen Z’s attention?
lead_paragraph: The idea of Cirque du Soleil might invite images of extravagant live shows with clowns, acrobats and fire breathers. The company is trying to change that.

headline: Rising Heat Deaths Are Not Just About the Temperature
abstract: It is unconscionable that in our wealthy country, we let blue-collar workers and the economically disadvantaged needlessly die in oppressive heat.
lead_paragraph: The day I found out that 10 people had died of heat-related illness in Laredo, Texas, I happened to be on a road trip with my daughter from our home in Austin to the Gulf Coast. Our hotel had a pool with an outdoor bar. As I read about this tragedy on a cushioned lounge chair, the contrast between these horrific deaths, just a few hours away, and the happy sunbathers sipping boozy frozen drinks around me was troubling and revelatory. We are all experiencing record-breaking heat, but it’s clear that we do not all experience it in the same way.

headline: In Philadelphia, City Pools Bring Relief as Closed Ones Stir Frustration
abstract: The continuing shortage of lifeguards has hindered the city’s efforts to open facilities, leaving some neighborhoods feeling neglected.
lead_paragraph: At their neighborhood pool in West Philadelphia, Markyda Anderson’s little boys could not wait to get back in. They had grown tired of playing in a nearby splash pad as lifeguards conducted a periodic check of chlorine levels. So once the break was over and swimmers were welcome again, they dashed back and — plunk, plunk — into the water they went.

headline: Raging Fires on Greek Island Force Thousands to Scramble for Refuge
abstract: As firefighters fought blazes kindled by tinder-dry conditions, the authorities sent tourists and residents on Rhodes to schools, gyms and boats moored at the port for shelter.
lead_paragraph: For the sixth day in a row, firefighters were battling on Sunday to douse blazes on the Greek island of Rhodes that have trapped thousands of tourists and locals, forcing many to spend the night in hotel lobbies, gymnasiums, schools or boats docked at the port.

headline: Pacific Seabed Mining Delayed as International Agency Finalizes Rules
abstract: Efforts to extract the metals used in car batteries have been pushed off amid pressure from environmentalists and nations that oppose them.
lead_paragraph: The start of industrial-scale seabed mining to extract car battery metals from the bottom of the Pacific Ocean has been delayed after the international agency charged with overseeing the work concluded late last week that it needed more time to finalize mining rules.

headline: How to Reduce the High Rates of Maternal Mortality
abstract: Responses to a doctor’s guest essay. Also: U.S.-China relations; underpaid teachers; admissions at Harvard; ending “holds” in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cheri Pies, Who Guided Lesbian Couples in Parenthood, Dies at 73
abstract: She made her name with a watershed book for same-sex parents and later studied the impact of racial and economic inequality on health.
lead_paragraph: Cheri Pies, a professor of public health who broke barriers with her landmark 1985 book, “Considering Parenthood: A Workbook for Lesbians,” a bible of the “gayby boom” of the 1980s and beyond, died on July 4 at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 73.

headline: How to Improve a Summer Tomato Sandwich? Furikake.
abstract: Eric Kim has a new recipe for the seasonal favorite that plays the savoriness of the tomato against a Japanese spice blend.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There may be no better summer sandwich than a tomato one, on white bread smeared wall-to-wall with mayonnaise and sprinkled lightly with flaky salt and a little cracked black pepper. I thought it unimprovable.

headline: Spain General Election Results
abstract: See results, maps and analysis from the general election in Spain.
lead_paragraph: See results, maps and analysis from the general election in Spain.

headline: Wildfires on Greek Island Force Mass Evacuations
abstract: Thousands of tourists and residents spent the night in makeshift shelters as raging blazes threatened seaside areas on Rhodes.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of tourists and residents spent the night in makeshift shelters as raging blazes threatened seaside areas on Rhodes.

headline: Israel’s Identity Hangs in Balance Ahead of Key Vote on New Law
abstract: Lawmakers are set to vote Monday on whether to limit the Supreme Court’s power as one element of a government plan to overhaul judicial authority. It is part of a profound rift over Israel’s nature and future.
lead_paragraph: When tens of thousands of Israelis marched up to Jerusalem this weekend to protest the far-right government’s plan to limit judicial power, many were driven by an urgent fear that the government is trying to steal the country that their parents and grandparents fought to build against the odds.

headline: ‘Barbie’ Box Office to the World: The Pandemic Is Officially Over
abstract: With the biggest revenues since 2019, “Barbenheimer” gives the usual franchises a run for their money, selling out even predawn screenings.
lead_paragraph: The movie business lives!

headline: Only Biden Can Save Israel Now
abstract: Mr. President, this Israeli government needs another dose of your tough love about our shared interests and about U.S. strategic interests.
lead_paragraph: News update: Since the publication of this column, the Israeli Knesset has approved the bill limiting the powers of the Israeli Supreme Court.

headline: Tony Bennett Used His Celebrity to Promote Civil Rights
abstract: The singer witnessed racism in the military and in the music industry, experiences that informed his decision to join the Selma-to-Montgomery march in 1965.
lead_paragraph: In explaining the roots of his commitment to civil rights, Tony Bennett often told a story from his Army days, when he brought a Black soldier as his guest to Thanksgiving dinner, prompting a furious reprimand and a demotion.

headline: Elon Musk Changes Twitter Logo to an X
abstract: The tech billionaire replaced the company’s blue bird silhouette with “X,” a term for what he has described as an “everything app.”
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has made one of the most visible changes to Twitter since he took control of the social media company last fall: replacing its widely recognized bird logo.

headline: Brian Harman Romps to British Open Victory at Royal Liverpool
abstract: Harman, a 36-year-old American, came close to winning the 2017 U.S. Open, but his triumph on Sunday gave him his first major title.
lead_paragraph: Brian Harman knew Saturday evening that sleep might be hard to come by, as much as he knew he needed it. He had been in this situation — the 54-hole leader at a major tournament — six years ago and knew the agonizing cost of a fitful night: a runner-up finish, months and then years of what-ifs, a career not on the margins but not among the ultra-elite.

headline: Russian Attack on Odesa Badly Damages Historic Cathedral
abstract: Overnight Russian missile strikes damaged Odesa’s largest Orthodox cathedral. The attack on the city killed one person and injured 22 others, according to Ukrainian officials.
lead_paragraph: Overnight Russian missile strikes damaged Odesa’s largest Orthodox cathedral. The attack on the city killed one person and injured 22 others, according to Ukrainian officials.

headline: Former Republican Aides Shepherd Whistle-Blowers Through Congress
abstract: Empower Oversight, a group of lawyers including former aides to Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, is part of a constellation of groups facilitating G.O.P. investigations in Congress.
lead_paragraph: When Gary Shapley, a longtime I.R.S. investigator, wanted to air his accusations that the federal government had mishandled the tax investigation into President Biden’s son Hunter, the information he had was so sensitive he couldn’t even provide it to his own lawyer without potentially committing a felony.

headline: U.S. Confronts Tight but Turbulent Relationship With Israel
abstract: President Biden has cautioned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu against pursuing a proposal to rein in Israel’s judiciary, a plan that has deeply divided Israeli society.
lead_paragraph: Long before moving into the White House, President Biden compared the relationship between the United States and Israel to that of close friends. “We love one another,” he said, “and we drive one another crazy.”

headline: Jonas Vingegaard Wins Tour de France Again After Vanquishing His Rival
abstract: What started as a tense two-man battle became a foregone conclusion when Tadej Pogacar couldn’t stay with Vingegaard in the 17th stage of the race.
lead_paragraph: When Tadej Pogacar slipped behind Jonas Vingegaard on the Col de la Loze mountain pass through the Alps on Wednesday, eight kilometers and a world away from the top of the hot, punishing climb, it was only briefly unclear why. Pogacar’s own voice, over his team’s radio and broadcast on television during the Tour de France’s 17th stage, provided an immediate explanation for the rare sight of him being left behind like a mere mortal.

headline: Pretty (Devoted) in Pink: ‘Barbie’ Hordes Spill Into Theaters
abstract: Fans nationwide shopped their closets for the rosiest interpretations of the Barbie ethos: sparkly bags, open-toed pumps, stretchy headbands and more.
lead_paragraph: Karma Masselli woke up Thursday morning knowing it was a special day. The “Barbie” movie was finally here.

headline: As Inquiries Compound, Justice System Pours Resources Into Scrutinizing Trump
abstract: For all their complexity, the Trump-related prosecutions have not significantly constrained the ability of prosecutors to carry out their regular duties, officials have said.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel overseeing criminal investigations into former President Donald J. Trump, employs 40 to 60 career prosecutors, paralegals and support staff, augmented by a rotating cast of F.B.I. agents and technical specialists, according to people familiar with the situation.

headline: Firefighter Dies After ‘Targeted Attack’ on an Alabama Fire Station
abstract: A second firefighter was also shot in the attack at a Birmingham fire station this month. A motive for the shooting is unknown.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Birmingham, Ala., are searching for leads and a motive in a daytime shooting at a city firehouse this month that left one on-duty firefighter dead and another wounded.

headline: Review: ‘Henri VIII,’ an Operatic Rarity About a Tudor Tyrant
abstract: Saint-Saëns’s 1883 work is seldom performed today, but it is being well staged and excitingly sung at Bard College.
lead_paragraph: Henry VIII was, by many accounts, an intelligent and sophisticated man — an author and reader, a musician and composer.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: A Major Vote in Israel
abstract: Also, Cambodia’s elections, Ukraine’s counteroffensive and Japan’s coal plants.
lead_paragraph: Israeli lawmakers are expected to hold a binding vote today on one part of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s plan to overhaul the judiciary. It will come after a weekend of protest and turmoil, and the issue has become a proxy for a broader emotional and even existential battle about the nature of the Israeli state.

headline: Inconclusive Election Thrusts Spain Into Political Muddle
abstract: The returns showed no party winning the support needed to govern, leaving the country facing weeks of uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Spain was thrust into political uncertainty on Sunday after national elections left no party with enough support to form a government, most likely resulting in weeks of horse trading or potentially a new vote later this year.

headline: Yes, Shaun Cassidy Is Still Dreamy
abstract: A fan finds herself in a backstage hug, decades after she kissed her poster of the onetime teen idol.
lead_paragraph: I was approaching the George Washington Bridge when my friend Lynn fired a text into the Shaun Squad group chat: “GET READY, PARTY PEOPLE!”

headline: ‘Futurama’ Review: Latest Go-Round Mines the Past
abstract: The animated sci-fi comedy, now on Hulu as a reboot of a reboot of a reboot, is the same show as ever. For fans, that will be enough.
lead_paragraph: “Information wants to be free” may be a dubious maxim, but it has a more obviously true corollary: Intellectual property wants to be exploited.

headline: Friendly Gathering
abstract: With this theme, John Ewbank traces a clear arc.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: A New Arrival in ‘The Country of the Blind’
abstract: In his memoir, Andrew Leland discovers that slowly losing one’s sight offers a special understanding of vision — and its limits.
lead_paragraph: After reading Andrew Leland’s memoir, “The Country of the Blind,” you will look at the English language differently. You will even look at the word “look” differently. (And, at intervals: “reading.”)

headline: ‘New York, New York’ Will End Its Abbreviated Run on Broadway
abstract: The big-budget musical that tried to position itself as a nostalgic love letter to the city will close after a summer of dropping sales.
lead_paragraph: “New York, New York,” a big-budget musical that tried to position itself as a nostalgic love letter to the city, will close on July 30 after underwhelming critics and failing to find a sufficient audience to sustain a Broadway run.

headline: Dorrance Dance and a Mythili Prakash Premiere at Jacob’s Pillow
abstract: Stormy weather at a summer festival wraps performances of a debut and some classic works by two very distinct choreographers.
lead_paragraph: Rain was in the forecast here at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival on Friday, but the first rumble came from inside the Ted Shawn Theater. It was partway through the matinee performance of Dorrance Dance and the lights were dimmed. The dancers had spread themselves around the auditorium and were drumming the floor and walls, working up a storm in surround sound.

headline: Biden to Name National Monument for Emmett Till and His Mother
abstract: The monument, expected to be established on Tuesday, will consist of three protected sites in Illinois and Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will establish a national monument on Tuesday honoring Emmett Till, the Black teenager who was brutally killed in 1955, and paying tribute to his mother, Mamie Till-Mobley, according to White House officials.

headline: Well-Traveled Stars Find Their Forever Home in Cooperstown
abstract: Fred McGriff played for six franchises and Scott Rolen played for four, but consistent production, and lots of determination, got them into the Baseball Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Fred McGriff played for six franchises, so many that his new plaque at the Hall of Fame has no logo on the cap. Scott Rolen represents the St. Louis Cardinals, but he played for four teams in all.

headline: Russia Destroys Drones Targeting Moscow, and Blames Ukraine
abstract: Two buildings were hit but there were no reports of casualties. Video verified by The New York Times shows smoke and damage to several buildings.
lead_paragraph: The Russian authorities said they destroyed two attack drones targeting central Moscow on Monday morning in what they called a strike by Ukrainian forces. No one was injured, they said. There was no immediate comment from Ukraine.

headline: At Wagner’s Festival, New Technology Reveals a Leadership Rift
abstract: The Bayreuth Festival’s production of “Parsifal” will feature augmented reality. Securing the equipment set off a financial and philosophical dispute.
lead_paragraph: The American director Jay Scheib was looking at a bank of monitors inside the Bayreuth Festival Theater on a recent afternoon.

headline: The Mind Is Willing, So the Body Doesn’t Have Much Choice
abstract: These men, many in their 80s, may have titanium hips and implantable defibrillators. But they plan to play hockey until they go to that big locker room in the sky.
lead_paragraph: Mike Duggan and his hockey buddies were strapping on their gear one recent morning when their banter hopscotched, as it frequently does, to the subject of joint replacement surgeries.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: An important vote on Israel’s political future.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s governing coalition is set to pass a law today that would limit the ways in which Israel’s Supreme Court can overrule the government. The plan has become a proxy for a broader emotional and even existential battle about the nature of the Israeli state, who controls it and who shapes its future.

headline: Sticker Shock in Restaurants: Still There, Despite a Food Price Drop
abstract: Rare exceptions aside, restaurants have not lowered their prices. Also, why a small, scum-covered pond in Morningside Park is the perfect place to study algae.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at why food prices have come down but menu prices in many restaurants have not. We’ll also look at why an algae-covered pond is the perfect site for researchers from Columbia University.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Righteous Gemstones’ and ‘Heels’
abstract: The third season of HBO’s dark comedy comes to an end. And the Starz show about professional wrestlers begins its second season.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 24-30. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Buckle Your (DeLorean) Seatbelt: ‘Back to the Future’ Lands on Broadway
abstract: In adapting a beloved franchise for the stage, the creative team sought to develop the story for new audiences while remaining true to the spirit of the films.
lead_paragraph: If he could go back in time and do it again, Bob Gale probably wouldn’t change much about “Back to the Future.” This 1985 science-fiction comedy, about a teenager taking a whirlwind trip to the year 1955 in a time-traveling DeLorean built by an eccentric inventor, became an endearing and endlessly quotable box-office smash.

headline: No Corrections: July 24, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Philadelphia, City Pools Bring Joy. At Least, the Ones That Opened.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “This isn’t just an essential service; it’s a renaissance in the use of public spaces.”

headline: Passenger Boat in Indonesia Capsizes, Killing 15
abstract: Most passengers traveling on the overcrowded boat survived Monday’s accident off the island of Sulawesi.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An overloaded passenger boat capsized off the Indonesian island of Sulawesi early Monday, killing 15 people.

headline: Word of the Day: composure
abstract: This word has appeared in 81 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word composure has appeared in 81 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 28 in “Simone Biles Signals a Return to Elite Gymnastics” by Jeré Longman:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Not to Jinx It, but Is the Commute Easier Lately?
abstract: With most hybrid workers in the office only three days a week, getting to work on Mondays and Fridays is surprisingly not bad.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Maralee Sanders suddenly realized something was different in her commute: she was getting to work earlier than expected.

headline: From Norway, a Voice Unafraid to Call Out FIFA From the Inside
abstract: Lise Klaveness is a rarity in soccer: a woman leading a national federation. But in pointing out her sport’s failures, she has made powerful enemies.
lead_paragraph: Lise Klaveness was only a few weeks into her post as the president of Norway’s soccer federation last year when she decided to start saying the quiet parts out loud.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Woman Is Killed by a Bear Near Yellowstone, Officials Say
abstract: The woman’s body was discovered on a trail near the national park after an apparent encounter with a grizzly bear, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A woman was killed by a bear over the weekend on a trail near West Yellowstone, Mont., officials said on Monday, noting that grizzly bear tracks and a bear cub had been found near the scene.

headline: Study of Elite College Admissions Data Suggests Being Very Rich Is Its Own Qualification
abstract: Extraordinarily detailed data shows how elite colleges prefer the richest students, even among students with similar test scores.
lead_paragraph: Extraordinarily detailed data shows how elite colleges prefer the richest students, even among students with similar test scores.

headline: How Do I Wear a Vintage Dress Without Wrecking It?
abstract: A reader hopes to rock a silk chiffon dress from the ’80s without damaging its delicate fabric.
lead_paragraph: You have identified one of the biggest issues in the current conversation around the virtues of vintage: condition and wearability. It is all well and good for us to talk up how important it is to keep clothes in circulation, how significant the future resale market is and how great it is that Gen Z (or a portion of it) seems to gravitate to used clothes rather than new. But if those resellable clothes are not actually rewearable, all of that potential is destined to remain more theory than practice.

headline: The 21st-Century Shakedown of Restaurants
abstract: How influencers are shaking down restaurants — a reflection of the power an unregulated industry has handed web-savvy people.
lead_paragraph: Tell me if you’ve heard this one: A social media influencer walks into a bar ….

headline: Host Gift Guide: Fun Ferments, Cozy Quilts and More
abstract: What T Magazine’s editors and contributors are bringing to thank their hosts this summer, including surrealistic serving spoons and bubbles to entertain children.
lead_paragraph: When the French interior designer Camille Vergnes throws a dinner party in Paris, she opts for unfussy white table linens and white plates. This allows her Art Deco-style set of serving spoons, salad servers and carving knives, all with almond green shagreen handles, to take center stage. “I use [the serving set] as the key piece of the table along with the flowers or candleholders,” she says. Vergnes’s approach reflects a shift in focus when it comes to tableware, away from handblown glassware and patterned napkins to sculptural utensils. In Copenhagen, stirred by her homeland’s history of silversmithing, the Danish jeweler Olga Bonne has added delicate hand-wrought silver spoons, forks and knives with handles in the shape of fish, kestrels or hares to her roster of whimsical creations. She takes inspiration from eras past, “when arts and crafts did not have to be functional but most of all ornamental and extravagant,” she says. Some designers are marrying the functional and fanciful: In Brighton, the British designer Alessandra Williams recently launched her namesake homeware label with sets of hand-carved salad servers in green leopard stone and blackened jacaranda wood made by Fair Trade co-operatives in Zimbabwe and Nairobi. Frank Traynor, the United States-based artist behind the Perfect Nothing Catalog, adorns everything from cheese graters to cake knives with copper and tin combined with semiprecious stones and shells, lending quotidian objects new charm. Then there’s the British chef and farmer Ben Bodman, who makes carbon Damascus steel knives with swirling patterns on the blades and myrtlewood and rosewood handles in Melksham, a small town in Wiltshire, England, under the label Bodman Blades. Presented to a hostess in lieu of a bottle of wine, these are practical gifts that will pull double duty as décor.

headline: Cary Elwes Is Soothed By Grunge and a Maltese Poodle
abstract: The actor, who appears in the latest “Mission: Impossible,” picked up a deep interest in Napoleon’s life from Stanley Kubrick.
lead_paragraph: When Cary Elwes got a call about appearing in “Mission: Impossible — Dead Reckoning Part One,” he said yes to the movie before he knew much about the part. He came to learn that his role was that of Denlinger, the director of national intelligence. But the character’s biography and place in the “Mission” universe was long a mystery, even to the man who played him.

headline: How Evangelical Christians Went From Jimmy Carter to Donald Trump
abstract: Where do evangelical conservatives go from here, after Dobbs and as Trump tries to return? Jane Coaston interviews the author Jon Ward.
lead_paragraph: Many white evangelical Christians love Donald Trump — a fact of American politics that has shaped the makeup and rulings of the Supreme Court, the culture and morality wars waged by the Republican Party and the political evolution and power of evangelicals themselves. At the same time, some forms of evangelical Christianity are becoming less Christian, with believers less likely to attend church and less likely to embrace some of the faith’s most bedrock beliefs.

headline: There’s No Escaping Trump
abstract: He has turned Republicans into the Opposite Party.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. We skipped our conversation last week because I was in Ukraine. But even from there, it was hard to miss the news about Donald Trump’s most recent pending indictment. Your thoughts?

headline: $1.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1924 Spanish-style home in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom condominium in an Edwardian house in San Francisco and a hillside retreat in Monrovia.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Mid City, a neighborhood known for its central location: It is close enough to areas like West Adams, Koreatown and downtown that they can be reached in 20 minutes or less without ever getting on the freeway. The property is a few blocks from a branch of Roscoe’s House of Chicken and Waffles, a beloved Southern California chain restaurant, and from a bookstore that sells Spanish-language children’s literature.

headline: Stories Like Norman Rockwell Paintings, if Rockwell Painted Guillotines
abstract: In his new story collection, “Disruptions,” Steven Millhauser reveals the bizarre within the mundane.
lead_paragraph: Steven Millhauser was the surprise winner of a Pulitzer Prize for his novel “Martin Dressler” (1996), a syntactically bracing reverie about a young entrepreneur in 19th-century New York. For many readers at the time, the response was: Steven who?

headline: From Pet Cemetery Owner to Identity Thief to Best-Selling Ghostwriter
abstract: How did a felon and former heroin addict spin her background in canine cremation into a lucrative publishing career?
lead_paragraph: From the driver’s seat of her Tesla, Lara Love Hardin leveled a steady gaze at a house on a sun-bleached cul-de-sac in Aptos, Calif. and talked about the afternoon in November 2008 when she was handcuffed and yanked out the front door by a sheriff’s deputy who told her she didn’t deserve to be a mother.

headline: $7,200 for Every Student: Arizona’s Ultimate Experiment in School Choice
abstract: More states are making all students eligible for private school subsidies. In Arizona, it has often benefited wealthier families.
lead_paragraph: Tom Horne’s whole job is public education. It’s in his title — superintendent of public instruction in Arizona — where he oversees the education of 1.1 million public school students.

headline: Rebooting Ron
abstract: The presidential campaigns of John McCain, Hillary Clinton, Jeb Bush and others hold lessons for Ron DeSantis as he tries to turn things around.
lead_paragraph: Admitting you’ve made mistakes is tough for anyone. For a hard-charging, hyperscrutinized political candidate who presents himself as infallible, it can be as excruciating as a root canal without anesthetic.

headline: We’ve Been on the Front Lines. We Know What Ukraine Needs.
abstract: The war in Ukraine is changing fast. The U.S. must also be ready to pivot in its military assistance.
lead_paragraph: Both of us have been the targets of enemy fire. It nearly cost one of us her life. We know a truth every combat veteran learns: For all the planning and consideration that goes into a war, much of it gets thrown out the window the moment the shooting starts. You often learn more about your enemies in the first 24 hours of a conflict than you do from years of studying them.

headline: In Search of a Crowd-Free Summer Getaway? Try These 6 Hotels.
abstract: A guest ranch in Wyoming, a boutique hotel in Argentina’s wine country, a revamped beachside motel in New York: Here’s where to go if you want to ditch big-city crowds.
lead_paragraph: Why battle the crowds in Europe this summer when there are so many charming, even unexpected, destinations? Below are a few places to while away the summer, including a revamped motel on a beach in New York; Airstream suites under the stars in Utah; new addresses in Kentucky that pay homage to horse culture; and a ranch in Wyoming that’s introducing activities like cuddling with goats and learning about llamas. And if you’re longing for an international getaway, it’s low season in Argentina, where a boutique hotel has opened amid the vineyards and wineries of Mendoza. Whether you’re interested in raising a glass or in the raising of llamas, a quiet getaway awaits.

headline: Hollywood Strikes Mean Steady Diet of Reruns, Game Shows and Reality TV
abstract: TV viewers across the U.S. will see fewer new scripted shows, a trend that could continue well into next year if the walkouts continue.
lead_paragraph: Scripted television series premiering at a slower pace. The “New Releases” and “Just Added” banners on streaming services piling up with reality shows, documentaries and international fare. Ninety-minute episodes of “Survivor” and “60 Minutes.” A steady diet of Pat Sajak, Steve Harvey and David Spade hosting game shows in prime time.

headline: Making Peace With the House Wrens’ Havoc
abstract: When you are paying attention to nature, you will always see something you don’t want to see.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The drama started the first time a house wren showed up, nearly a decade ago. House wrens are the feathered agents of chaos: tiny, secretive, furiously destructive. I love their magnificent courtship song, but my heart always sinks when I hear the first house wren of springtime announcing his arrival after the long migration from South America. Once he gets here, the year-round inhabitants are in trouble.

headline: On the Road With Will Hurd, the Bipartisan Candidate in Search of a Base
abstract: Hoping to break through a crowded presidential field in 2024, the former Texas congressman is pitching himself as a modern and moderate Republican with a bipartisan vision.
lead_paragraph: It is the stuff of viral internet legend now. After snow disrupted their flights, Will Hurd, the former Republican congressman, and Beto O’Rourke, a Democrat from a neighboring district, climbed into a rented Chevy Impala and took a cross-country road trip from their home state of Texas to Washington.

headline: Are You Ready? The Nu Metal Renaissance Is Upon Us.
abstract: Bands like Deftones and Slipknot are resonating with younger fans, thanks to TikTok, the Y2K revival and, of course, enduring teenage angst.
lead_paragraph: When Deftones’s hit “Change (In the House of Flies)” blared out of Tyson Burden’s car stereo in April 2020, he started to choke up. It wasn’t the tune’s familiar growls or the teenage nostalgia it prompted that made him almost cry; it was his 15-year-old daughter, Nia LaVey Burden, sitting in the passenger seat and reciting the words to the song.

headline: Short-Term Pain for Long-Term Gain? Nigerians Buckle Under Painful Cuts.
abstract: In his first two months in office, President Bola Tinubu has ripped the Band-Aid off Nigeria’s ailing economy. Time will tell if it can heal, but for now, Nigerians are feeling the pain.
lead_paragraph: A teacher in northern Nigeria walks three hours to school every day, no longer able to pay for a ride in a tuk tuk rickshaw. Bakers operate at a loss amid soaring flour prices. Workers in Lagos sleep overnight in their offices to avoid the prohibitive cost of commuting.

headline: Seeking Full Honors, Some Ukrainian Families Wait to Bury Their Dead
abstract: Thousands of families have buried soldiers in cemeteries across Ukraine in “Alleys of Heroes.” But some have held off, awaiting a version of Arlington National Cemetery.
lead_paragraph: Dmytro Gubariev’s remains have been sitting in his bedroom for 10 months, unmoved. That’s how long his mother has been waiting to bury his ashes.

headline: What It’s Like to Live With a Tick-Borne Disease
abstract: Chronic pain, fatigue, rashes: As tick territories are expanding, so too are the number of illnesses they cause.
lead_paragraph: When Reema Shah was 13 years old, she became plagued by a mysterious suite of symptoms: rashes, brain fog, fatigue. Her exhaustion was so extreme that walking up stairs would leave her winded, and she had to quit her high school tennis team; she could barely even keep up with her schoolwork.

headline: Iranian Mothers Choose Exile for Sake of Their Daughters
abstract: Some have risked their lives to escape to Iraq or other nearby countries, where they have found havens to start over.
lead_paragraph: One rainy spring evening, a young Iranian mother with a mangled arm, her husband and their 3-year-old daughter met a smuggler near the Iraqi border who gave them a stern ultimatum: Ensure the child’s silence or leave her behind.

headline: A Lebanese Feast at a Traditional Dutch Canal House
abstract: Carmen Atiyah de Baets hosted an intimate alfresco dinner at her Amsterdam guesthouse and store to introduce a new collection inspired by her mother’s homeland.
lead_paragraph: Hospitality comes naturally to the Lebanese Dutch creative strategist Carmen Atiyah de Baets. While her professional background is in fashion, she has an instinct for organizing generous, family-style gatherings that she honed during trips to Beirut with her Lebanese mother. “Lebanon is a place of contrasts,” says Atiyah de Baets, who was raised in the Netherlands and has a degree in Middle Eastern studies from SOAS University of London. “Hosting, sharing and hospitality are, despite hardships, deeply ingrained in both our history and the stories we hear from our parents.”

headline: Today’s Top News: An Update on Trump’s Legal Woes, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: A One-Man Blockade Against the U.S. Military
abstract: A Republican senator has been blocking promotions to protest a Biden administration policy.
lead_paragraph: For the past few months, a single senator — Tommy Tuberville — has blocked hundreds of promotions in the U.S. military.

headline: Behind the Scenes of College Admissions
abstract: Plenty of students from modest backgrounds are qualified to attend elite colleges and would benefit from doing so.
lead_paragraph: For almost 20 years, I have been writing about economic diversity at selective colleges. Many of my articles have suggested that the colleges are not enrolling as many low- and middle-income students as they could.

headline: At Least 11 Killed After School Gym Roof Collapses During a Volleyball Practice in China
abstract: A building contractor improperly stored material on the gym’s roof, official media reported. Most of the victims were children.
lead_paragraph: Anger rose in China on Monday following the collapse a day earlier of the roof of a middle school gym near the Siberian border, killing at least 10 members of the school’s trophy-winning girl’s volleyball team who were practicing inside, as well as a coach.

headline: Why Elon Musk Bid Twitter Goodbye
abstract: Rebranding the social network as X marks the billionaire’s latest gamble to reinvent the company, after buying it last year for $44 billion.
lead_paragraph: Bye-bye, blue bird: Twitter overnight began rebranding itself as X, replacing its longtime logo with a stylized symbol that was projected onto its San Francisco headquarters.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of July 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: A California Bill Would Cap Renters’ Security Deposits
abstract: The legislation, which easily passed the Assembly, is part of a broader effort to lower the cost of housing in California.
lead_paragraph: As rents have soared in California, so have security deposits.

headline: How Many Novels Set in the Mid-Atlantic States Do You Know?
abstract: Test your literary knowledge with this short trivia quiz.
lead_paragraph: Test your literary knowledge with this short trivia quiz.

headline: A Singles Party, Where Chaos Is the Point
abstract: The monthly event asks guests to bring someone they’ve matched with on Tinder, but whom they don’t yet know. What could go wrong?
lead_paragraph: “Are any of you guys drinking Jack and Coke right now,” Jesus Valdes shouted at two women who were sipping cocktails during a crowded singles mixer at American Whiskey, a bar in Midtown Manhattan. They were not, and Mr. Valdes let out a sigh of frustration.

headline: Altice USA Said to Be Considering a Sale of Cheddar News
abstract: The cable company acquired the network, once billed as “CNBC for millennials,” in 2019 for $200 million.
lead_paragraph: The cable company Altice USA is said to be weighing a potential sale of Cheddar News, the network once billed as “CNBC for millennials,” less than five years after buying the company.

headline: Thieves Make Off With ‘Beetlejuice 2’ Props
abstract: A 150-pound art sculpture and a decorated lamppost were taken from the movie set in Vermont, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Juno, the shrewd, chain-smoking caseworker in the movie “Beetlejuice” in 1988, said it best, “Never trust the living.”

headline: A Flood of New Workers Has Made the Fed’s Job Less Painful. Can It Persist?
