lead_paragraph: Snap, the parent company of Snapchat, reported its second straight decline in quarterly sales on Tuesday as it continued to struggle with bringing in more advertising.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: China has replaced its foreign minister, the world gets some good economic news, Israel faces a cliffhanger.
lead_paragraph: Qin Gang was abruptly removed as China’s foreign minister after disappearing from public view for 30 days. The move ended the career of a diplomat who had been one of President Xi Jinping’s most trusted rising stars.

headline: Voting by Formerly Imprisoned in Tennessee, Already Hard, Gets Harder
abstract: Tennessee has the nation’s second highest number of residents who remain disenfranchised because of past felony convictions.
lead_paragraph: Tennessee has sharply restricted the conditions under which it will restore voting rights to people who have completed prison sentences for felonies, joining a growing list of Republican-controlled states that have rolled back access to the ballot by former felons.

headline: Alphabet Steams Past Ad Worries, Fueled by Google’s Search Engine
abstract: Despite concerns of a shaky ad market and growing competition in A.I., Google’s bounce forward in the second quarter was aided by accelerating revenue from its search engine and the video platform YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, gained ground in its most recent quarter against several of its lingering challenges, according to financial results released on Tuesday.

headline: Will Translation Apps Make Learning Foreign Languages Obsolete?
abstract: And if so, is that really such a disaster?
lead_paragraph: In Europe, nine out of 10 students study a foreign language. In the United States, only one in five does. From 1997 to 2008, the number of American middle schools offering foreign languages dropped from 75 percent to 58 percent. From 2009 to 2013, one American college closed its foreign language program; from 2013 to 2017, 651 others did the same.

headline: Microsoft Revenue Up 8% to $56.2 Billion in Latest Quarter
abstract: The company’s profit topped $20 billion as it pointed to early interest in its artificial intelligence products.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft reported record sales and profits on Tuesday, as it shook off recession fears and began seeing the early impacts of its investments in generative artificial intelligence.

headline: Where the Republican Candidates Stand on Border Security and Immigration
abstract: Support for a wall is now routine, and some presidential candidates say they would use military force to secure the border if elected.
lead_paragraph: The blistering immigration policy that Donald J. Trump enacted when he was in the White House shifted his party’s baseline on the issue to the right.

headline: Both Sides Plan for Next Battles Over Israel’s Court Overhaul
abstract: The government’s vote to limit judicial power set off a night of street chaos. More showdowns are expected, but with Parliament about to recess, it is not clear when or in what form.
lead_paragraph: After frenzied days capped by Israeli lawmakers voting to limit judicial power and protesters clashing with police, doctors went on strike on Tuesday, the military tried to stave off resignations and all sides girded for a longer fight over the government’s court overhaul.

headline: Trevor Reed, Former U.S. Marine, Injured While Fighting in Ukraine
abstract: Trevor Reed’s condition was not immediately clear. His decision to return to the region and volunteer to fight for Ukraine created some “exasperation” within the Biden administration, an administration official said.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Reed, the former U.S. Marine who was detained in Russia for nearly three years and later freed in a prisoner swap, was injured while fighting in Ukraine, the State Department said on Tuesday.

headline: Bidens’ Dog Has Bitten Several Secret Service Agents, Emails Show
abstract: One agent went to the hospital after being bitten by the Bidens’ German shepherd, Commander, in a series of at least 10 incidents of “aggressive behavior.”
lead_paragraph: One of President Biden’s dogs has bitten several Secret Service agents, and even sent one to the hospital, part of a series of at least 10 incidents of “aggressive behavior,” according to internal emails recently obtained by a conservative watchdog group.

headline: Ohio Officer Is Fired for Releasing Dog on Black Truck Driver
abstract: Body-camera video shows the Circleville, Ohio, police officer releasing his dog on a truck driver who had his hands up after he was stopped by the Ohio State Highway Patrol.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio police officer has been fired three weeks after he was recorded on a body camera releasing his police dog on a Black truck driver who had his hands up after he was pulled over, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: PacWest Bank, Thrashed by Deposit Crisis, Will Be Taken Over
abstract: Banc of California is set to absorb PacWest, a larger lender that has seen its depositors flee this year.
lead_paragraph: PacWest Bank, which never fully recovered from its hammering during this year’s banking crisis, will be absorbed by a smaller lender, Banc of California, the banks announced on Tuesday.

headline: Putin Plans Trip to China, Another Russian Leader to Visit North Korea
abstract: The visits reflect Moscow’s ongoing efforts to strengthen ties with Asian allies, given its isolation from the West.
lead_paragraph: As part of Russia’s ongoing efforts to strengthen ties with Asian allies, President Vladimir V. Putin will travel to a conference in China in October, while the defense minister, Sergei K. Shoigu, will join a Chinese delegation at a celebration in North Korea this week, according to Russian state news media.

headline: A Federal Judge Blocked Biden’s Immigration Restrictions
abstract: Also, Harvard’s legacy admissions come under scrutiny. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The number of migrants apprehended at the southern U.S. border has plummeted over the past two months, in spite of expectations of a big influx after the lifting of Title 42 in May. Perhaps the biggest reason for the drop, officials say, is that President Biden’s stringent new asylum rules have effectively turned migrants away.

headline: ‘Joe Biden May Be the Last Pro-Israel Democratic President’
abstract: Tom Friedman on what contentious judicial changes mean for the U.S.-Israeli relationship.
lead_paragraph: Despite forceful opposition, Israel’s government passed a judicial reform law that limits the ability of the country’s Supreme Court to overrule the government. In this audio short, our columnist Tom Friedman explains how the new law could destabilize the United States’ relationship with Israel and complicate American interests in the Middle East. “We are in a completely new phase now of relations between America and the Jewish state,” Friedman says.

headline: Prosecutors Follow Multiple Strands as Jan. 6 Indictment Decision Looms
abstract: The special counsel, Jack Smith, continues to push ahead on several fronts as he assembles evidence about former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to retain power after the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Even as the special counsel, Jack Smith, appears to be edging closer toward bringing charges against former President Donald J. Trump in connection with his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, prosecutors have been continuing to investigate multiple strands of the case.

headline: Greta Gerwig on the Blockbuster ‘Barbie’ Opening (and How She Got Away With It)
abstract: “I think it was a particular ripple in the universe that allowed it to happen,” the director said on Tuesday of her highly anticipated movie making a staggering $162 million in its first weekend.
lead_paragraph: It’s a “Barbie” world. We’re all just living in it.

headline: Jill Biden Takes the 2024 Campaign to Paris in Another Overseas Appeal
abstract: As the United States officially rejoined UNESCO, the first lady delivered what sounded like a campaign message, saying the president had rebuilt bonds that frayed under his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Jill Biden’s work on her trips overseas appears to be rooted in the traditional duties of first ladies: She has cheered on American Olympians in Tokyo, made a secret trip to Ukraine to meet with the country’s first lady and attended the royal wedding of the crown prince of Jordan.

headline: Judge Vacates Bowe Bergdahl’s Conviction and Dishonorable Discharge
abstract: The Army colonel overseeing the court-martial trial had applied for a job with the Trump-era Justice Department, raising the appearance of bias.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday wiped out the conviction and sentence of Bowe Bergdahl, the former Army sergeant who walked off a base in Afghanistan in 2009 only to be held captive by the Taliban for five years, and whose release in a prisoner swap prompted intense controversy.

headline: With Grain in the Cross Hairs Again, So Is a Jewel of Ukraine
abstract: Odesa, a port city long beloved by travelers, had been largely spared the worst of the war, but that began changing this week.
lead_paragraph: There are no longer walls behind the main altar of the Transfiguration Cathedral, a landmark heavily damaged when Russian missiles struck the Ukrainian port city of Odesa.

headline: Man Sentenced to 30 Months in Death of ‘The Wire’ Actor
abstract: Carlos Macci, 72, was part of a crew that sold Michael K. Williams fentanyl-laced heroin that killed him in 2021.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Macci spent decades struggling with addiction, selling heroin and fentanyl not to make money but to ease his own cravings, according to court records.

headline: The Prize for the Longest Pregnancy in Mammals May Go to This Whale
abstract: Bowhead whales may carry their babies for as long as 23 months, although more research is needed to confirm the finding.
lead_paragraph: For animals that humans almost drove into extinction, there’s a lot about whales we still don’t know. Consider the bowhead whale in particular.

headline: Senate Targets China, Voting to Restrict Farmland Purchases and U.S. Investment
abstract: Senators voted overwhelmingly to block Chinese businesses from buying farmland and mandate that American investment in the country’s national security industries be tracked.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Tuesday voted overwhelmingly to block businesses based in China from purchasing farmland in the United States and place new mandates on Americans investing in the country’s national security industries, taking the first legislative steps of the new Congress to counter Beijing’s espionage activities and curtail its economic power.

headline: Republicans in Congress Seek to Block Hunter Biden’s Plea Deal
abstract: The chairman of the Ways and Means Committee filed a brief in federal court saying the plea agreement for the president’s son had been tainted by political interference.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Hunter Biden’s court appearance to enter into a plea deal for misdemeanor tax crimes that would allow him to avoid prison time, House Republicans and conservative groups sought to intervene in the case, urging a judge to throw out the agreement he reached with prosecutors.

headline: 3 Marines Found in Car at Gas Station Died of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
abstract: Autopsy results on Wednesday revealed the cause of death.
lead_paragraph: Three Marines who were found dead on Sunday inside a car parked at a gas station in Hampstead, N.C., died of carbon monoxide poisoning, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: McCarthy, Pressured by the Right, Escalates Talk of Impeaching Biden
abstract: The speaker’s comments came on the eve of a hearing in the tax case against Hunter Biden, and ahead of a potential third indictment of former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Kevin McCarthy, under pressure from the hard right to take aggressive steps against the Biden administration, suggested on Tuesday that the House was moving toward opening an impeachment inquiry against President Biden, as Republicans search through bank records hunting for damaging information about the first family.

headline: Rocky Wirtz, Owner of N.H.L.’s Chicago Blackhawks, Dies at 70
abstract: He assumed control of the team after his father’s death and helped bring it to prominence. But the mishandling of an assault accusation dimmed that success.
lead_paragraph: Rocky Wirtz, who after taking over as the principal owner of the Chicago Blackhawks from his father won three Stanley Cup championships in the 2010s — a stellar run that lost its glimmer several years later after an investigation into the sexual assault of one of the franchise’s minor league players by a coach — died on Tuesday in Evanston, Ill. He was 70.

headline: Wild Guess
abstract: Mary Crane makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Family Died in Rockies After Trying to Live ‘Off the Grid,’ Official Says
abstract: Two sisters and a teenage son moved to a Colorado campsite last July, living off canned food. They had wanted to take a break from a world that distressed them, a local coroner said.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, Rebecca Vance talked with her family about a dream she’d had: She wanted to live in a land disconnected from the world, which she viewed as chaotic and dangerous.

headline: A Commitment to Green Policy Is Tested by an Election Win
abstract: British conservatives kept a seat in a recent election by opposing an ultralow emissions zone, and some are now questioning ambitious emissions-reduction targets.
lead_paragraph: Britain, blanketed by cool, damp weather, has seemed like one of the few places in the Northern Hemisphere not sweltering this summer. Yet a fierce political debate over how to curb climate change has suddenly erupted, fueled by economic hardship and a recent election surprise.

headline: Why I’m Rooting for Haiti
abstract: The 2023 Women’s World Cup has the largest field of competitors in tournament history. Les Grenadiers, as the Haitian team is known, may be the scrappiest of them all.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve read this column regularly over the last few years, my rooting interests should be clear by now. I pull for the outsiders and outliers. The strugglers and stragglers. The players and teams who toil hard for the simple chance, however slim, of winning.

headline: ‘They Shoot Without Stopping’: Where Russia Is on the Attack in Ukraine
abstract: Along the vast 600-mile front line, Russia is mostly playing defense. In the northeast, it is once again mounting fierce offensive operations.
lead_paragraph: Three Russian attack helicopters swooped in low over the city of Kreminna, strafing Ukrainian frontline positions just outside the city. Russian drones circled overhead while Moscow’s ground forces fired heavy machine guns to flush out Ukrainians from foxholes hidden in the dappled light of the pine forest.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Russia seeks more troops.
lead_paragraph: Russian lawmakers on Tuesday voted to raise the top age for military conscription, aiming to expand the pool of trained recruits who could potentially join the war in Ukraine.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Taliban Shut Beauty Salons, One of Last Public Spaces for Afghan Women
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “This isn’t about getting your hair and nails done. This is about 60,000 women losing their jobs.”

headline: Corrections: July 26, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the pharmaceutical industry’s attempt to halt a federal drug pricing program described incorrectly the reason that Medicare’s reported spending per patient for two blood thinners in 2021 was lower than their sticker prices. The lower amount reflected that some patients took the drugs for less than a full year. It did not reflect discounts negotiated by pharmacy benefit managers, which were not factored into the spending figures.

headline: Fiji’s Leader Declines Invitation to China, Saying He Tripped and Fell
abstract: The prime minister, wearing a bloodstained shirt, said he struck his head on a door. One analyst called it “very convenient.”
lead_paragraph: Fiji’s uneasy relationship with China has hit an unusual roadblock, in the form of an office door.

headline: Monsoon’s Fury Sours Romance of Wet Season Travel in India
abstract: Long considered a life-giving panacea, India’s rainy season has become more violent and unpredictable. It is upsetting many rhythms of life, among them, leisure travel.
lead_paragraph: The honeymoon, at first, was magical. Akash and Parvani Kapadi drove up pine-covered forests to a hill town in northern India with a view of the snow-capped Himalayas. In their hotel room, the gentle pitter-patter of monsoon rains on the roof set the stage for a week of romance — away from the heat and grime of the city.

headline: Word of the Day: happenstance
abstract: This word has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word happenstance has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 19 in the Opinion essay “Cormac McCarthy Had a Remarkable Literary Career. It Could Never Happen Now” by Dan Sinykin:

headline: The Harbor Porpoises Are Here, Putting Up With the Noise
abstract: Like seasoned New Yorkers, the porpoises have adapted to the sounds troubling their universe. Also, investigators find an arsenal at the Gilgo Beach suspect’s home.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll find out about harbor porpoises, which have made New York a year-round destination — to the surprise of researchers who tracked them. We’ll also see what investigators found at the Long Island home of the architect charged in the Gilgo Beach killings.

headline: Floods in the Philippines After Typhoon Doksuri Makes Landfall
abstract: One video showed a house floating through a town. In another, several motorcycles on a shaky ferry toppled over. Residents in other areas waded through the floodwaters with belongings, including livestock.
lead_paragraph: One video showed a house floating through a town. In another, several motorcycles on a shaky ferry toppled over. Residents in other areas waded through the floodwaters with belongings, including livestock.

headline: An Energy Correspondent Hunts for Alternatives
abstract: Ivan Penn reports on the new sources we rely on to power our world.
lead_paragraph: Few things cause more anxiety than flipping on the light switch only to find there’s no power.

headline: Hollywood Strike Leaves Influencers Sidelined and Confused
abstract: Despite not being in the actors’ union, many content creators are passing up deals to promote films or TV shows because they don’t want to be barred from the guild or face online vitriol.
lead_paragraph: Deanna Giulietti is not in the actors’ union, but she turned down $28,000 last week because of its strike.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: How George Santos Used Political Connections to Fuel Get-Rich Schemes
abstract: Mr. Santos, a first-term House member under federal indictment, often tried to use his candidacy and ties to Republican donors to create moneymaking opportunities.
lead_paragraph: About a year before George Santos was elected to Congress, he and three other men approached a loyal campaign donor with a potentially lucrative opportunity.

headline: Joe Lewis, Billionaire Owner of Tottenham Hotspur, Is Charged With Insider Trading
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan accused the British billionaire of illegally funneling nonpublic information to associates to trade on.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors charged Joseph C. Lewis, the British billionaire who owns the Tottenham Hotspur English soccer club, with insider trading, accusing him of illegally funneling nonpublic information to associates to trade on.

headline: Hun Sen, One of World’s Longest-Serving Rulers, to Step Down Next Month
abstract: Mr. Hun Sen, whose party won stage-managed parliamentary elections on Sunday, has been prime minister of Cambodia since 1985. He said he would hand power to his son.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia, one of the world’s longest-serving leaders, said on Wednesday that he would resign next month and hand power to his son.

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ and the Siren Song of World-Ending Technology
abstract: The story is a warning. Will we heed it?
lead_paragraph: Christopher Nolan’s blockbuster hit “Oppenheimer” tells the story of the father of the atomic bomb and the invention he hoped would end all wars. (Spoiler alert: It did not.)

headline: Republican Attack Ads in Iowa Show Conservative Voters Who Turned on Trump
abstract: Hoping to persuade G.O.P. voters that Donald Trump cannot win another general election, the Republican Accountability Project is running ads that feature voters who grew disillusioned with him.
lead_paragraph: A Republican group that opposes Donald J. Trump is unveiling an advertising campaign featuring voters who supported him in the past two presidential elections but have now turned against him, in an effort to put questions of electability at the center of the G.O.P. primary race.

headline: High Heat Raises Risks for Homeless Floridians
abstract: As Orlando, Fla., experiences what could be the hottest July on record, soaring rents and an affordable housing crisis are pushing a growing number of people onto the streets.
lead_paragraph: Each morning, Rickquita Monroe, 34, and Curby Monroe, 32, wake up beneath an overpass in downtown Orlando, Fla. Several other people are usually spread out beside them on the sidewalks lining either side of the five-lane road. Throughout the night, they count on gusts of wind from passing traffic for relief from the thick, increasingly blistering Florida heat. It is especially dangerous to Ms. Monroe, who has a seizure disorder that is exacerbated by high temperatures.

headline: North and South Korea Drift Farther Apart Every Day
abstract: Seventy years after the Korean War, the two sides are as far apart as ever.
lead_paragraph: When North Korean forces surged across the 38th parallel in June 1950, starting the three-year Korean War, my grandfather Kang Yeon-gu was a teenage student on summer break.

headline: In Israel, the Worst May Be Yet to Come
abstract: The right-wing coalition’s hobbling of the Supreme Court is just the start of a campaign against the country’s democratic foundations.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Many Israelis are bracing for what comes next. Anger over a bill that eliminates the courts’ power to overturn government and ministerial decisions on grounds of reasonableness, and the constitutional overhaul of which it’s part, had set off huge protests for seven months. Just before the bill’s passage on Monday, more than 1,100 air force reservists, including more than 400 pilots, declared that they would refuse to turn up for duty if the legislation was approved. In the aftermath of the vote, tens of thousands of protesters, in a collective cry of rage, blocked highways, shut down major intersections, and confronted a police force intent on dispersing them with horses, water cannons and brute force. Dozens were arrested.

headline: Here’s What to Watch at the Fed’s July Meeting
abstract: The Federal Reserve is poised to raise interest rates after pausing in June. What comes next is crucial, but don’t expect clear commitments.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise interest rates at its meeting on Wednesday, and economists will be watching for hints at what officials expect next — and how they think the central bank’s fight against rapid inflation is going.

headline: A Fight to Save Soldiers, From the Lab to the Battlefield
abstract: “In the Blood” traces how an engineer and a salesman took on military leaders and Big Pharma to get a revolutionary clotting agent to those in dire need.
lead_paragraph: Reading, like riding shotgun with a stranger, is an act of faith, whose first moments matter. An accurate, judicious beginning often allows us to settle back and enjoy the ride, whereas an early slip or swerve means we might be white-knuckling the rest of the journey. Charles Barber’s “In the Blood” treats a consequential topic, and contains moments of real insight, drama and humor. Trouble is, Barber opens with several omissions and slights that left me on edge for the balance of the book.

headline: The Friend Trip: Fun Without the Friction
abstract: Sometimes even best buds have trouble making travel plans together or splitting costs, but there are some ways you can take that big trip without a major falling-out.
lead_paragraph: Whoever said a friend is a friend forever has clearly never experienced a group trip that has devolved into a maelstrom of conflicting plans and bickering over restaurant bills. Traveling with your besties can be tricky. Here are some ways to do it without anyone getting unfriended.

headline: $550,000 Homes in Virginia, Oklahoma and Maine
abstract: An 1820 townhouse in Portsmouth, a 1940 home in Oklahoma City and a Colonial Revival house in Westbrook.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the city’s Olde Towne historic district, on a street with brick sidewalks a few blocks from the waterfront. It is within walking distance of the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard Museum, the Children’s Museum of Virginia and a ferry terminal with boats departing for Norfolk. The Portsmouth Art & Cultural Center, a 1945 Art Deco-style movie theater and the city’s welcome center are also nearby, on High Street.

headline: How Do You Personalize Your Cubicle? We Want to See It.
abstract: Once ridiculed as a symbol of homogeneity and ennui, the work space is popular again as employees seek privacy and quiet in the office. How have you decorated your cubicle? Share your photos with us.
lead_paragraph: Cubicles were once such a commoditized fixture in offices across the nation that they were used to represent the boredom of unfulfilled corporate workers in late ‘90s movies like “Being John Malkovich,” “The Matrix” and, most notably, “Office Space.” The confined spaces gradually fell out of favor as companies began to opt for fewer walls to encourage collaboration.

headline: How Those ‘Barbie’ Dreamhouses Came to Life: ‘We All Had to Believe in It’
abstract: To make their Barbieland sets a reality, the movie’s production team embraced the surreal, going big on bright pinks and shrunken proportions.
lead_paragraph: While working on films like “Atonement,” “Anna Karenina” and “Darkest Hour,” the production designer Sarah Greenwood and the set decorator Katie Spencer, both Oscar nominees many times over, had to turn soundstages into period-accurate sets, using their extraordinary attention to detail to embroider these spaces with texture and soul.

headline: Hiding From the Yips Will Only Make It Worse
abstract: Eileen Canney Linnehan was a star pitcher at Northwestern who suddenly could not throw to first base. Now she helps young athletes get through the debilitating issue.
lead_paragraph: Maddy Wood was an incoming freshman at Western Kentucky last fall, on scholarship, in shape and elated to pitch for the Hilltoppers. The feeling lasted only a few days, before that old, insidious anxiety gripped her. Wood could no longer throw the ball to the catcher’s glove.

headline: What ‘The Bear’ Gets Right About Chicago
abstract: The show celebrates a kind of ambition — humane and independent — that’s often neglected by Hollywood. Maybe that’s why the setting is so important.
lead_paragraph: FX’s “The Bear,” now in its second season, is about grief and family and food, but there’s something else there, too. Its protagonist, Carmen Berzatto, is an accomplished chef who has worked in the vaunted kitchens of restaurants like Noma, the French Laundry and Eleven Madison Park. When the show began, he had come home to Chicago after the death of his brother, who left him a struggling shop selling a local staple, Italian beef sandwiches. Carmy could have run the place like any of the hundreds of modest lunch counters in the city, or else he could have sold it and angled to return to the world of fine dining. Instead, we watched him attempt a third thing, turning the business into a new, forward-thinking restaurant. This is the other stuff the show is about: ambition, and Chicago, and the freedom the nation’s third-largest city can offer to follow your ambitions on your own terms.

headline: For Natalie Gulbis, the Thrill of Winning the Evian in 2007
abstract: It was her lone tournament win, and she remembers the relief of getting that first one.
lead_paragraph: Like two other long-ago visitors to France, Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman, who always had Paris in the 1942 movie “Casablanca,” Natalie Gulbis of the United States, a longtime member of the L.P.G.A. Tour, can say she will always have Evian.

headline: Why Legacy Admissions Are at the Center of a Dispute in Higher Education
abstract: Systems that give preference to children of alumni are under renewed scrutiny after the Supreme Court issued a ruling against affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court ruling gutting race-conscious admissions last month placed a spotlight on legacy preferences in higher education, a practice that mostly helps white and wealthy students.

headline: 6 Thought-Provoking Y.A. Thrillers That Tackle Social Issues
abstract: Angeline Boulley, the author of “Firekeeper’s Daughter” and “Warrior Girl Unearthed,” recommends exhilarating young adult books that explore important social topics.
lead_paragraph: I was in the sixth grade when a book changed me. I was already a voracious reader, and I loved mysteries and thrillers. Yet something was different about Robert Cormier’s 1977 novel, “I Am the Cheese.” There was an immediacy to Adam Farmer’s narration of his bike journey to visit his father. I hadn’t encountered an unreliable narrator and the lingering impact of an unsettling ending in the books I’d read before this one.

headline: How to Know When a Prosecution Is Political
abstract: Even if the subject is a politically powerful person or the outcome of a trial could have a political impact, that doesn’t necessarily mean the action itself is political.
lead_paragraph: As the criminal indictments of Donald Trump continue to pile up like boxes in a Mar-a-Lago bathroom, the former president’s defenders have settled on a response: They don’t claim their man is innocent of the scores of federal and state charges against him — a tough case to make under the circumstances. Instead they accuse the Biden administration and Democratic prosecutors of politicizing law enforcement and cooking up an insurance policy to protect President Biden, who trails Mr. Trump in some polls about a very possible 2024 rematch.

headline: The Fight for the Right to Trespass
abstract: A group of English activists want to legally enshrine the “right to roam” — and spread the idea that nature is a common good.
lead_paragraph: The signs on the gate at the entrance to the path and along the edge of the reservoir were clear. “No swimming,” they warned, white letters on a red background.

headline: This Hummus Holds Up After 800 Years
abstract: First written down in the 13th century, this recipe has an enduring simplicity — but no garlic.
lead_paragraph: We do not eat quite like our ancestors. Gone from our tables are the roasted hedgehogs of Stone Age Britain and the flamingo tongues of ancient Rome. Nor do we know if, decades from now, our descendants will toast Pop-Tarts and dust steaks with edible gold. Or if the future climate will support agriculture of any kind, or human life at all — a scenario explored in C Pam Zhang’s eerily timely novel, “Land of Milk and Honey,” coming in September, in which deadly smog kills off nearly all the earth’s crops, forcing people to subsist on mung-bean powder.

headline: Replacing Your Lawn? Instead of a Meadow, Consider a Food Forest.
abstract: Or just start by planting a few pawpaw or persimmon trees. Chances are, you’ll want more.
lead_paragraph: Your first taste of a ripe pawpaw or persimmon can leave you hungry for more. That’s why Michael Judd is confident that he can persuade you to make room for several of these trees in your front yard — or even to surrender your lawn altogether.

headline: Credit Markets Are Creaking, Creating Economic Uncertainty
abstract: Analysts warn that bankruptcies and defaults could jump as the world adjusts to higher interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Investors and economists have become optimistic that the Federal Reserve might successfully slow inflation without plunging the economy into recession, but many are still eyeing a risk that threatens to derail the effort: a tower of dicey-looking corporate debt.

headline: What You Can Do at Home to Help Stem Climate Change
abstract: Relatively simple measures like thermostat control, composting and switching to electric appliances can make a big difference.
lead_paragraph: Just the headlines from the past few weeks are enough to make a homeowner sweat:In Phoenix, the mercury has soared above 110 degrees every single day for three straight weeks. In Florida, Farmers Insurance has discontinued new policies, making it the latest in a string of insurance companies pulling out of the state in the past year. And in Arizona, where the Colorado River is shrinking dramatically, the rumble of new construction in one of America’s fastest-growing areas has gone silent after the governor put the brakes on new home-building, citing a lack of water.

headline: Judge Puts Hunter Biden’s Plea Deal on Hold, Questioning Its Details
abstract: Judge Maryellen Noreika sent the two sides back to try to work out modifications that would address her legal and constitutional concerns and salvage the basic contours of the agreement.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday put on hold a proposed plea deal between Hunter Biden and the Justice Department that would have settled tax and gun charges against the president’s son, stunning the courtroom and raising legal and constitutional questions about the agreement.

headline: Blistering Heat Spreads to U.S. Midwest as Wildfire Smoke Lingers
abstract: Midwestern residents sweltered in the heat wave that has scorched the South and Southwest for many days.
lead_paragraph: The heat wave that has scorched much of the American South and Southwest is now spreading through the Midwest, bringing temperatures above 100 degrees, dangerous conditions for millions of people and pleas from state and local officials to avoid spending time outdoors.

headline: The Solo Trip: Explore at Your Own Pace
abstract: Traveling alone can be rewarding, and a little daunting. Here’s how to get the most out of your trip, and stay safe, when you’re a party of one.
lead_paragraph: Solo travel has the power to transform: Think of the memoirs “Eat Pray Love” or “Wild.” But you don’t have to circumnavigate the globe or hike 1,100 miles to see why some people choose to go it alone. The freedom to explore at your own pace, open to connecting with people you meet along the way, can feel as intoxicating as a tropical breeze. But solo travel can be daunting, too, especially when problems arise. And of course, solo travelers need to keep certain safety considerations in mind.

headline: Delays and Cancellations: Know Your Rights
abstract: Advocating for yourself after an airline delay or cancellation can be challenging and confusing. Here’s how to best achieve the result you want — or at least get you where you want to go.
lead_paragraph: Flight delays and cancellations are unfortunate inevitabilities, especially in summer, when more people are flying and severe weather tends to occur more frequently.

headline: Democrats and Republicans Are Living in Different Worlds
abstract: How you view the crisis of men and boys — and whether you think there is one — is just one of the ways you reveal your political leanings.
lead_paragraph: Competing partisan views on how we see men and masculinity are emerging as key factors in the run-up to the 2024 election.

headline: In Milan, Giving the Aperitivo a New Twist
abstract: The nightly cocktail ritual is central to the Italian city’s culture. Here’s where to find both the classic bitters-based drinks and new spins on them.
lead_paragraph: To understand how central the aperitivo is to Milan culture, you need only stand in the middle of the Piazza del Duomo, the city’s pulsing center, and face the cathedral. To your right you’ll see a huge version of the Martini vermouth logo glowing atop a modest skyscraper in nearby Piazza Armando Diaz. At its top is the rooftop bar Terrazza Martini. There, Martini’s various vermouths are poured into everything from Americanos to Manhattans.

headline: Use These Fans to Keep Cool. Or to Channel Beyoncé.
abstract: They could also be used to say, “I love you.” Can an air-conditioner do that?
lead_paragraph: In the 19th century, Duvelleroy, a hand fan manufacturer in Paris, published a marketing pamphlet called “The Language of the Fan.” It featured a list of gestures one could make with a fan and the meaning of each.

headline: Gov. Abbott’s Policing of Texas Border Pushes Limits of State Power
abstract: The governor brought in razor wire, floating barriers and state troopers to deter unauthorized migration. The federal government mounted its first legal pushback this week.
lead_paragraph: Along Texas’ 1,200-mile-long border with Mexico, state troopers routinely arrest migrants for trespassing. Texas National Guard troops unspool razor wire along the banks of the Rio Grande. State game wardens patrol the river in fast-moving boats.

headline: The Very Private Life of Melania Trump
abstract: The former first lady has mostly retreated from public view — and steered clear of the campaign trail — while her husband fights to return to the White House and faces increasing legal peril.
lead_paragraph: Since leaving the White House, Melania Trump’s world has gotten smaller.

headline: Britpop’s Back. But What Happened to Cool Britannia?
abstract: Some of the biggest ’90s bands are playing major gigs across Britain again, and headlining festivals abroad. Yet Britpop’s swaggering sense of national self-belief feels like a distant memory.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, Luis Chuva was 14 and on summer vacation at his grandparents’ home in Costa Nova, Portugal, when, one Saturday, he glimpsed something on TV that changed his life: a music video for “Girls and Boys,” by the British band Blur.

headline: Life Along the Korean DMZ, 70 Years After the Fighting Ended
abstract: The Korean War Armistice was signed seventy years ago, separating the two Koreas and putting an end to the fighting, but not the war itself.
lead_paragraph: Seen from the sky, the Demilitarized Zone, or DMZ, looks like a gigantic geographical wound across the Korean Peninsula, the continuous wire fences snaking up the hills and down the valleys from coast to coast.

headline: Read Your Way Through Maine
abstract: Reading and writing are deeply valued in Maine. The novelist Lily King recommends fiction, nature writing, memoirs, children’s books and inspiration for writers.
lead_paragraph: In American fiction, my state is code for outpost. Maine is where you send a character you want to get rid of, someone who goes off to raise goats, farm oysters, prep for the apocalypse — or write a novel. Apart from California, I can think of no other state in the Union that lives as strongly in the national collective imagination as a place to play out a festering dream.

headline: Today’s Top News: A Blow to Biden’s Border Strategy, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Internet Trolls Propelled Prigozhin’s Rise. Now Some Celebrate His Fall.
abstract: The Kremlin, which has moved quickly to take down parts of Wagner leader Yevgeny Prigozhin’s empire, may seek to use his troll farms to its advantage, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: When President Vladimir V. Putin said recently that the Wagner mercenary group legally “does not exist,” a collection of social media accounts that have historically been associated with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the group’s founder, quickly endorsed the Russian leader’s statement.

headline: ‘I Feel Like I’m in Hell’: High Heat and Housing Crisis Collide in Florida
abstract: As Orlando, Fla., experiences what could be the hottest July on record, soaring rents and an affordable housing crisis are pushing a growing number of people onto the streets.
lead_paragraph: As Orlando, Fla., experiences what could be the hottest July on record, soaring rents and an affordable housing crisis are pushing a growing number of people onto the streets.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Day in Court
abstract: A yearslong federal investigation has ended with the president’s son agreeing to plead guilty to tax misdemeanors.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, Hunter Biden was scheduled to a guilty plea in a Delaware courtroom, marking the end of a yearslong federal investigation that many Republicans believed would put the president’s son in prison, and put an end to the Biden presidency.

headline: Rise of Far Right Leaves Germany’s Conservatives at a Crossroads
abstract: The surge of the Alternative for Germany party has shaken the country’s political establishment. But for mainstream conservatives, it has also prompted an acute identity crisis.
lead_paragraph: Mario Voigt, a leader of Germany’s mainstream conservative party, has watched with concern the slow but steady string of victories notched by the far-right Alternative for Germany, known as the AfD.

headline: The Covid Origins Debate
abstract: The picture has changed as more evidence emerges, but we might never get a clear answer.
lead_paragraph: Did Covid jump from an animal to a person at a food market in Wuhan, China — or leak from a research lab there? That question remains the pandemic’s central mystery.

headline: The Whales Gathered in a Heart Shape. Experts Feared What Would Come Next.
abstract: A pod of nearly 100 pilot whales displayed unusual behavior before beaching themselves in Australia. More than 50 died, and the rest were later euthanized.
lead_paragraph: The pod of pilot whales huddled together for nearly a full day in the shallow waters off a remote beach in Western Australia. At times it made the shape of a circle, or spread into a line, or even, for a few moments, formed a loose heart shape.

headline: ‘Annihilation,’ ‘Support the Girls’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: This month’s rundown of off-the-radar picks on your subscription streaming services includes indies of all stripes, plus three documentary explorations of our changing media landscape.
lead_paragraph: You’d think that a science-fiction adventure featuring the “Star Wars” alums Natalie Portman and Oscar Isaac, as well as Portman’s “Thor” co-star Tessa Thompson, would have been a giant hit. But Paramount Pictures seemed baffled by how to market a sci-fi picture about ideas and creeping dread (rather then lasers and intergalactic dogfights), dumping it onto Netflix overseas and into theaters with a shrug in the United States. They fear what they don’t understand; the writer and director Alex Garland, adapting the novel by Jeff VanderMeer, crafts a thrilling yet thoughtful combination of head trip and hero’s journey that owes more to Tarkovsky than Lucas.

headline: Oregon Wildfire Destroys Dozens of Homes and Disrupts 911 Service
abstract: Emergency calls in Lake County, in southern Oregon, were being rerouted after the Golden fire damaged about six miles of fiber-optic cables and more than 100 power poles, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A wildfire in southern Oregon that started over the weekend was so intense that it disrupted 911 services and burned dozens of homes, which officials were not able to reach for days.

headline: In Rare Move, Japanese Pop Star Comes Out Publicly as Gay
abstract: “I don’t want people to struggle like me,” said Shinjiro Atae, making an announcement that is extremely unusual in conservative Japan.
lead_paragraph: At first, there was total silence. Then, there were shrieks, wild applause, weeping and shouts of “I love you!”

headline: Do Legacy Admissions Policies Have a Future?
abstract: Critics have accused them of boosting white, wealthy college applicants. But elite schools like Harvard may be reluctant to shut a source of alumni cash.
lead_paragraph: In opening a civil rights investigation into Harvard’s legacy admissions policy — in which relatives of alumni and donors are given preference — the Biden administration inserted itself into a fierce debate amid efforts to remake the world of higher education.

headline: The Church of Group Fitness
abstract: For some formerly religious people, exercising together creates connection and community.
lead_paragraph: This is a follow-up to my series on Americans moving away from organized religion. Read part one, part two, part three, part four and part five.

headline: Why Won’t Simon Ateba Stop Shouting?
abstract: The Today News Africa gadfly has become a hero on the right, thanks to his confrontational behavior in the White House briefing room.
lead_paragraph: After 19 months of making a scene, Simon Ateba finally heard from the White House this month.

headline: Military in Niger Announces Coup After Soldiers Detain President
abstract: President Mohamed Bazoum was one of the West’s most reliable partners in a volatile region threatened by militant extremists and prone to coups.
lead_paragraph: Military officers in the West African nation of Niger ousted the country’s president on Wednesday, they said in an address on national television, throwing into uncertainty the future of one of the West’s few reliable partners in a region marred by coups and widespread insecurity.

headline: Crane Partially Collapses in Midtown Manhattan, Injuring 11
abstract: Nine civilians and two firefighters were hurt when the crane on 10th Avenue collapsed, officials said.
lead_paragraph: In a dramatic scene, a construction crane atop a high-rise building in Midtown Manhattan burst into flames and partially collapsed onto the street on Wednesday morning, injuring 11 people, officials said.

headline: Graphs, Charts and Maps From “What’s Going On in This Graph?” (Sept. 2020 — May 2023)
abstract: A slide show including some of our favorite graphs from the weekly “What’s Going On in This Graph?” activity.
lead_paragraph: A slide show including some of our favorite graphs from the weekly “What’s Going On in This Graph?” activity.

headline: Over 75 New York Times Graphs for Students to Analyze
abstract: A new collection of graphs, maps and charts organized by topic and type from our “What’s Going On in This Graph?” feature.
lead_paragraph: What do you notice?What do you wonder?What’s going on in this graph?

headline: Easy Mode: Clues for July 28
abstract: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.

headline: I Am Estranged From My Toxic Mother. Should I Go on Her Birthday Trip?
abstract: A reader doesn’t want to upset his father, who requested his presence, but the idea of taking a vacation to celebrate a woman he has cut out of his life makes him squirm.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, I cut my toxic mother out of my life. It was a good decision. The problem: My father, whom I still see one on one, is distraught that I skip family events to avoid her. Now, he’s decided to pay for the whole family to go to an expensive resort to celebrate my mother’s 80th birthday, and he is pressuring me to join them. I think it would be hypocritical to go on vacation to celebrate a woman whom I no longer speak to. But my dad is 85. He has always been loving and supportive to me, and I know my being there would mean a lot to him. I’m torn: I don’t want to subject myself to my mother, but I don’t want to ruin the vacation for my father. Thoughts?

headline: Batteries in E-Bikes and Other Devices Are Sparking Fires in San Francisco
abstract: Two people jumped out of an apartment window on Monday to escape what was the city’s 24th fire this year linked to rechargeable batteries.
lead_paragraph: Two people jumped out of an apartment complex window in the Tenderloin neighborhood of San Francisco to escape a fire that was spreading in their unit on Monday. One of them was seriously injured and taken to a hospital burn center, officials said.

headline: Giuliani Concedes He Made False Statements About Georgia Election Workers
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani said he still had “legal defenses” in a case brought by two election workers who said he had defamed them as he asserted that the 2020 election was marred by fraud.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani has conceded that while acting as a lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump, he made false statements by asserting that two Georgia election workers had mishandled ballots while counting votes in Atlanta during the 2020 election.

headline: Israel’s High Court Says It Will Review Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul
abstract: The justices will hear petitions in September against a new law that curbs their own authority, which Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has pushed ahead despite Israel’s political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Supreme Court said Wednesday that it would review a contentious new law that diminishes the court’s own role, setting the stage for a constitutional crisis and renewed social turmoil if the judges end up overturning the legislation.

headline: Simpson Kalisher, Photographer Who Captured Urban Grit, Dies at 96
abstract: He emerged from a largely commercial background to join the towering figures who defined an art form — street photography — in the 1950s and ’60s.
lead_paragraph: Simpson Kalisher, who liberated his lens from slick images in corporate reports and trade magazines to emerge as a discerning photojournalist whose street scenes froze the panorama of urban American life in the 1950s and ’60s, died on June 13 in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 96.

headline: Russia’s Online Censorship Has Soared 30-Fold During Ukraine War
abstract: A report from Citizen Lab laid out how much online censorship has increased on one of Russia’s biggest social media sites.
lead_paragraph: What’s the difference between Russia’s internet before and after the invasion of Ukraine? The answer: a thirtyfold increase in censorship.

headline: Kevin Spacey Found Not Guilty of Sexual Assault
abstract: A British jury on Wednesday found the actor not guilty of nine charges.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Spacey, the two-time Oscar-winning actor known for his movie and TV roles including “House of Cards,” was on Wednesday found not guilty by a jury in Britain of nine counts of sexual assault.

headline: Crane Catches Fire and Partially Collapses in Manhattan
abstract: A thick plume of black smoke rose over the crane in midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A thick plume of black smoke rose over the crane in midtown Manhattan.

headline: War Brought Putin Closer to Africa. Now It’s Pushing Them Apart.
abstract: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia prepares to host African leaders at a summit, a collapsed grain deal and the uncertain fate of Wagner mercenaries have cast a shadow.
lead_paragraph: Shunned in the West, his authority tested by a failed mutiny at home, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia needs to project normalcy and shore up support from his allies. So on Thursday, he will host African leaders at a flashy summit in St. Petersburg, part of his continuing outreach to a continent that has become critical to Moscow’s foreign policy.

headline: A Shoe Entrepreneur’s Globally Inspired Barbecue
abstract: Mickey Ashmore, the founder of the footwear brand Sabah, gathered friends at his Long Island ranch house for Texas ribs, Middle Eastern sides and Thai desserts.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Mickey Ashmore was working in finance when he decided to start a side business selling handmade shoes under the label Sabah, which means “morning” in Turkish. Early on, he convinced a neighbor to let him borrow the parlor floor of her townhouse in the East Village to host Sunday afternoon trunk shows, which he called Sabah Sundays. At these convivial get-togethers, he served wine and snacks, played music and sold pair after pair of the leather slip-ons, a traditional style he had discovered while living in Istanbul between 2010 and 2012. “He had told me it would be just ‘a few friends coming over,’” Pamela Bell, the generous neighbor with the townhouse, recalled recently. “It wasn’t long before we needed a bouncer!”

headline: What You Should Know About the Potential Risks of Kratom
abstract: The herbal product remains widely available, despite lawsuits and warnings from health authorities.
lead_paragraph: Across gas stations, smoke shops and the internet, consumers can easily buy kratom — an herbal substance that some users claim is an antidote to opioid dependence and a lifeline for alleviating mental and physical pain. In 2021 alone, roughly 1.7 million Americans used kratom, although the F.D.A. has not approved it for any medical use.

headline: How Fake Science Sells Wellness
abstract: Dubious claims in product marketing are everywhere. Don’t fall for them.
lead_paragraph: You can’t browse a grocery store or pharmacy without being subject to flashy labels that promote health benefits. In the beverage aisle, for example, you might find “prebiotic” sodas that supposedly support “gut health.” In the beauty department, you’ll see “medical-grade” serums, “probiotic” facial creams and “skin detoxing” treatments. Go to the supplements section for promises of “immunity support,” “hormone balance” and “energy enhancement,” among other things.

headline: How Regional Banks Got Healthy Again
abstract: The crisis set off by Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse has waned. Its peers have more capital and deeper customer ties.
lead_paragraph: After depositor runs led to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank this spring, investors and onlookers wondered how similarly sized institutions would fare. Would they have to merge with bigger banks? Break up their businesses and shrink drastically? Or were more of them simply doomed?

headline: A Five-Star, Five-Ingredient, Fifteen-Minute Zucchini Recipe
abstract: More summer classics: Eric Kim’s watermelon and feta salad and Rick Martinez’s Tajín grilled chicken.
lead_paragraph: Here at New York Times Cooking we publish hundreds of new recipes every year, so it would be easy to overlook the tens of thousands already available in our vast archive. But let’s not do that, because sometimes a classic, like Pierre Franey’s exquisite zucchini with shallots, is just what a meal needs.

headline: For Adults With No Heart Attack or Stroke History, Evidence Says Not to Start Baby Aspirin
abstract: A new analysis of older people who have never had a heart attack or stroke suggests limited protective power of daily low-dose aspirin, and worrisome side effects.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis of data from a large clinical trial of healthy older adults found higher rates of brain bleeding among those who took daily low-dose aspirin, and no significant protection against stroke.

headline: Wastewater Data Mirrored Covid Case Counts During First Omicron Wave
abstract: As Covid testing increasingly moved to the home, the wastewater data fell out of sync with case and hospitalization rates, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Early last year, as the United States grappled with a record Covid-19 surge, the levels of coronavirus in a community’s wastewater were closely aligned with two other statistics that measured the toll of virus: local case and hospitalization rates. But by last fall, these measures had fallen out of sync, and the wastewater data was no longer such a good predictor of the officially reported case or hospitalization numbers, according to a new study, which was published in JAMA Network Open on Wednesday.

headline: When Ancient Eruptions Pumped Diamonds to Earth’s Surface
abstract: A new study offers clues to the mysteries of kimberlite eruptions, the source of most of the diamonds mined on Earth today.
lead_paragraph: While diamonds might look pretty perched atop a ring, the rocks they hail from venture to Earth’s surface in a journey that’s anything but glamorous. Millions of years ago, some of our planet’s strangest and most violent volcanic outbursts dredged from deep underground most of the diamonds mined today in the form of blue-tinged rocks called kimberlites.

headline: Fed Raises Rates After a Pause and Leaves Door Open to More
abstract: Federal Reserve officials lifted borrowing costs by a quarter-point after pausing in June. Rates could rise more, but the central bank is not ready to commit.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates to their highest level in 22 years and left the door open to further action as they continued their 16-month campaign to wrestle inflation lower by cooling the American economy.

headline: What Higher Interest Rates Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
abstract: Savers benefit from higher rates, but borrowers have faced bigger bills on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates on Wednesday, the latest in a series of increases that have squeezed the budgets of debt-laden Americans, while rewarding those with money to stash in savings.

headline: G.M. and Other Automakers Will Build 30,000 Electric Vehicle Chargers
abstract: The companies will jointly spend at least $1 billion to build a North American network in an effort to persuade more people to buy battery-powered cars and trucks.
lead_paragraph: Seven major automakers announced a plan on Wednesday to nearly double the number of fast chargers in the United States in an effort to address one of the main reasons that people hesitate to buy electric cars.

headline: Flipping a Switch and Making Cancers Self-Destruct
abstract: Researchers at Stanford devised a strange new molecule that could lead to drugs that arm genes and make cancers work against themselves.
lead_paragraph: Within every cancer are molecules that spur deadly, uncontrollable growth. What if scientists could hook those molecules to others that make cells self-destruct? Could the very drivers of a cancer’s survival instead activate the program for its destruction?

headline: A Vibrant Vegan Dinner on the British Coast
abstract: The musician and chef Denai Moore and the photographer and designer Ronan Mckenzie launched their new projects with a Jamaican-inspired meal.
lead_paragraph: On a balmy recent evening, the Carl Freedman Gallery in the English coastal town of Margate was the setting for a double celebration. Fourteen guests gathered to mark both the opening of “To Be Held” — a group show curated by the filmmaker, photographer and fashion designer Ronan Mckenzie — and the launch of “Plentiful,” the debut cookbook by the Jamaican-born British musician and vegan chef Denai Moore. The two honorees first met at a vegan cafe in London in 2019, where they bonded over their shared Caribbean heritage (Mckenzie’s family is from Barbados) and approach to their creative pursuits. “The foundations we come from are quite similar,” said Mckenzie. “In our practices, there’s a sense of connection through shared experience.”

headline: A Prominent Bank C.E.O. Exits Amid a Political Storm in Britain
abstract: Alison Rose of NatWest, one of the country’s largest banks, resigned after Nigel Farage, a Brexit firebrand, said his account had been shut because of his political views.
lead_paragraph: Alison Rose, the chief executive of NatWest, one of Britain’s largest banks, resigned on Wednesday, just weeks after becoming embroiled in a dispute over the closure of the bank account of Nigel Farage, who is best known as a champion of Britain’s exit from the European Union.

headline: Gap, Looking for Barbie Magic, Hires Mattel’s President as C.E.O.
abstract: Richard Dickson helped improve Barbie’s image, culminating in the blockbuster film. Now he faces a similar turnaround challenge at the retailer.
lead_paragraph: Gap hopes its new chief executive can help it achieve a Barbie-like turnaround.

headline: Greek Hotels Fear a Burning Future: ‘Even the Animals Are Moving Away’
abstract: The fiercest wildfires have hit only parts of a few islands. But the effects of climate change pose a far wider threat to Greece’s tourism industry.
lead_paragraph: As thousands of tourists have fled the flames devouring the Greek island of Rhodes, locals were left with scorched land, and the ashes of the cypresses, olive trees and pines surrounding their empty bars, shops and hotels.

headline: Big Consumer Companies Keep Raising Prices, Complicating Fed’s Job
abstract: Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and Unilever have each reported raising prices significantly in the second quarter, complicating the Federal Reserve’s efforts to tame inflation.
lead_paragraph: Some of the largest consumer brands in the country have continued to raise prices aggressively this year while raking in large profits, posing a tough problem for the Federal Reserve as it aims to tame inflation.

headline: My Friend Is Mistreating Her Nanny. Should I Say Something?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the social costs of speaking up about an unjust situation.
lead_paragraph: My friend’s nanny is good friends with my own nanny. Over the years, my nanny has told me about instances when my friend has mistreated nannies she has hired — withholding food, refusing payment for extra work and reneging on benefits she agreed to. This friend displays nothing but lovely behavior toward me and our other friends, but knowing how she treats her nannies is increasingly disturbing me, to the point where I don’t think I can be friends with her and not say anything about what I know. This friend introduced me to her circle of friends a few years ago, and it’s because of her that I am part of a great group of women. Should I intervene and risk her behaving even worse toward her nannies and creating a rift in the friend circle? Or do I say nothing and continue with business as usual? — Name Withheld

headline: Markets Trade Cautiously Ahead of Pivotal Fed Meeting
abstract: Stock markets often exhibit caution ahead of major events like Fed meetings, waiting until there is clarity over the central bank’s next move.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets slipped on Wednesday morning, as cautious investors parsed mixed earnings reports and prepared for the Federal Reserve to resume raising interest rates.

headline: Readers, Show Us Your Wit
abstract: Have a little fun by expressing your opinions in forms other than letters to the editor.
lead_paragraph: We invite readers to have a little fun by expressing their opinions in forms other than letters to the editor. Take a well-known song, poem or other kind of text (from Shakespeare to Seuss), and rewrite the words in response to something or someone in the news.

headline: Mayor Eric Adams to Name New Chief Counsel Amid Migrant and Rikers Crises
abstract: Lisa Zornberg, who oversaw high-profile and complex cases, is arriving as Mayor Eric Adams develops policies to address several crises.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Zornberg, a lawyer in private practice and a former senior Manhattan federal prosecutor, will return to public service as chief counsel to Mayor Eric Adams, the mayor said Wednesday.

headline: ‘Get Down’ From the Car. ‘Make’ the Line. Is Miami English a Dialect?
abstract: A linguistics professor found that even Miamians who aren’t fluent in Spanish use or understand phrases that are direct translations.
lead_paragraph: The stereotype of how many Miamians speak involves a sing-songy rhythm with a heavy-sounding “L” and a generous sprinkling of Spanglish. But what if the conversational language of South Florida were more than a lively accent? What if it were a distinct regional dialect of American English?

headline: How to Wash Your Swimsuit
abstract: Please don't put it in the dryer.
lead_paragraph: Please don't put it in the dryer.

headline: How Barbie, the Doll and the Movie, Reflects Our Society
abstract: Readers react to all the media coverage of the doll’s influence. Also: Madison Square Garden; a path for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: TEMP Video
abstract: This is a temp video for video paid posts
lead_paragraph: This is a temp video for video paid posts

headline: What to Know About Bronny James’s Cardiac Arrest
abstract: James was hospitalized after suffering cardiac arrest during a practice at the University of Southern California. He was released Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James Jr., the son of the Los Angeles Lakers star LeBron James who is an incoming freshman at the University of Southern California, collapsed at practice on Monday after suffering a cardiac arrest. James Jr., who is known as Bronny, was hospitalized in the intensive care unit but later released from the I.C.U.  in stable condition, according to a statement from a spokesman for LeBron James and his wife, Savannah. James Jr. was released from Cedars Sinai on Thursday and sent home to rest.

headline: A Dusty Fast-Food Costume Sets Off a Very Canadian Bidding War
abstract: The government of Alberta is auctioning off an adult-size suit shaped like a donair, a uniquely Canadian take on the gyro and doner kebab that is a beloved late-night staple in Nova Scotia.
lead_paragraph: Josh Robinson, who grew up outside Halifax, Nova Scotia, can remember eating his first donair when he was around 7 years old, roughly two decades after the sandwich, composed of spiced, spit-roasted meat topped with a sweet sauce and wrapped in pita bread, first emerged as a regional delicacy.

headline: Restaurateur Who Paid Off New York Politicians Sentenced to 4 Years in Prison
abstract: Harendra Singh pleaded guilty to bribing the former executive of Nassau County, and admitted he also tried to bribe former Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island restaurateur who was a key witness in a public corruption investigation was sentenced to four years in prison Wednesday, ending an episode that churned up allegations of endemic wrongdoing that stretched across New York City and one of its most populous suburban areas.

headline: A Looming Retraction Casts a Shadow Over a Field of Physics
abstract: Misconduct allegations are leading scientists to question the work of Ranga Dias, including his claimed discovery of a room-temperature superconductor.
lead_paragraph: A major physics journal is retracting a two-year-old scientific paper that described the transformations of a chemical compound as it was squeezed between two pieces of diamond.

headline: Review: At Mostly Mozart, the Sense of an Ending
abstract: Louis Langrée, in his last season with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, conducted a classic Langrée program: Mozart and a premiere by Amir ElSaffar.
lead_paragraph: Change is coming for the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and for its longtime music director, Louis Langrée — this month is the beginning of the end of his tenure with the orchestra. When the ensemble appears at Lincoln Center next year it will be with a freshly conceived name, and with the conductor Jonathon Heyward at the helm. (Heyward also leads the orchestra in concerts on Aug. 4 and 5.)

headline: Who Is Maryellen Noreika, the Judge in the Hunter Biden Case?
abstract: Judge Noreika was appointed by President Donald J. Trump, but had the support of Delaware’s two Democratic senators.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge presiding over the Justice Department’s case against Hunter Biden is Maryellen Noreika, who serves on the United States District Court for the District of Delaware.

headline: 16 People Sickened in Salmonella Outbreak Linked to Ground Beef
abstract: People who became ill reported eating lean ground beef that was sold at ShopRite locations in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, the C.D.C. said.
lead_paragraph: A salmonella outbreak linked to lean ground beef sold in ShopRite stores in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York has left 16 people sick, including six who were hospitalized, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Review: Wagner Would Have Liked AR, but Not This ‘Parsifal’
abstract: Cutting-edge technology has again come to the Bayreuth Festival, where Wagner premiered his final opera with the latest stagecraft in 1882.
lead_paragraph: For Richard Wagner, the latest technology was crucial to staging his operas.

headline: A Pancaked Turtle Fossil’s 150-Million-Year-Old Tale
abstract: A beautifully preserved shelled reptile recovered from a Bavarian limestone deposit helps tell the story of how turtles first took to the seas.
lead_paragraph: Today it is Bavaria, a region of Germany. But in the Late Jurassic Period, it was a shallow tropical archipelago ringed with sponge reefs. The hyper-saline, oxygen-poor conditions of these waters prevented scavengers from disturbing the bodies of animals that died in the lagoons.

headline: Sinead O’Connor, Evocative and Outspoken Singer, Is Dead at 56
abstract: She broke out with the single “Nothing Compares 2 U,” then caused an uproar a few years later by ripping up a photo of Pope John Paul II on “S.N.L.”
lead_paragraph: Sinead O’Connor, the outspoken Irish singer-songwriter known for her powerful, evocative voice, as showcased on her biggest hit, a breathtaking rendition of Prince’s “Nothing Compares 2 U,” and for her political provocations onstage and off, has died. She was 56.

headline: Biden Orders U.S. to Share Evidence of Russian War Crimes With Hague Court
abstract: The step signals a major shift in American policy and ends months of resistance by Pentagon officials who feared setting a precedent that could pave the way for the court to prosecute U.S. troops.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has quietly ordered the U.S. government to begin sharing evidence of Russian war crimes in Ukraine with the International Criminal Court in The Hague, according to officials familiar with the matter, signaling a major shift in American policy.

headline: A Brexit Champion’s Feud With His Elite Bank Brings a C.E.O. Down
abstract: Nigel Farage, a political insurgent and ally of Donald J. Trump, exposed his bank for dropping him over “reputational risks.” Some analysts say he could parlay his situation into a comeback.
lead_paragraph: When Nigel Farage campaigned for a fellow populist, Donald J. Trump, in 2020, he seemed like a faded star seeking the spotlight abroad after it had swung past him at home. Mr. Farage, who helped mobilize the pro-Brexit vote in 2016, was marginalized in Britain, then consumed by the pandemic.

headline: Companies Aren’t Eager to Cut Their Prices as Costs Fall
abstract: Prices that go up don’t necessarily have to come down.
lead_paragraph: “Rockets and feathers” is economists’ name for how prices change in some less-than-competitive markets. When companies’ input costs go up for some reason, the prices they charge their customers go up like a rocket. When their input costs go back down, their prices fall, but ever so slowly, like a feather. The example most of us can relate to is the retail price of gasoline.

headline: Federal Reserve Raises Interest Rates to Highest Level in Two Decades
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, announced that the central bank raised interest rates to a range of 5.25 to 5.5 percent, the highest level since 2001.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, announced that the central bank raised interest rates to a range of 5.25 to 5.5 percent, the highest level since 2001.

headline: Protest Scene Removed From Jason Aldean ‘Try That in a Small Town’ Video
abstract: A news clip of a Black Lives Matter protest in Atlanta was edited out of the music video after criticism that the song and video were offensive.
lead_paragraph: The music video for the song “Try That in a Small Town” by the country music star Jason Aldean appears to have been edited to remove violent images of Black Lives Matter protests after criticism that the song and the accompanying video were offensive.

headline: Lawmakers and Former Officials Press for Answers on U.F.O.s
abstract: Pentagon officials have said most reported incidents involved items like airborne trash, weather balloons and drones.
lead_paragraph: Even by the extraordinary standards of contemporary political theater, Wednesday’s House Oversight subcommittee hearing on U.F.O.s stood out.

headline: Ato Blankson-Wood on Playing a Hamlet Who ‘Leads With Love’
abstract: The actor is starring in a modern-dress production of the play through Aug. 6 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: As a veteran of the Public Theater’s free Shakespeare in the Park productions, Ato Blankson-Wood is used to contending with the elements. “The bugs, the helicopters flying overhead: There’s an intense focus that is necessary,” he said.

headline: How I Lost the Fiancé but Won the Honeymoon
abstract: Alone on a honeymoon trip intended for her and her ex, Nell Stephens learns to leave behind the rules others set for her.
lead_paragraph: Bored and in love, Nell Stevens found a hobby combing the internet and entering her name into online contests. But, when she actually wins a prize — a luxury honeymoon in India — her world falls apart: The man she thought she was going to marry breaks up with her.

headline: Bo Goldman, Oscar-Winning Screenwriter, Dies at 90
abstract: He was a struggling writer when he won an Academy Award for “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.” He won another for “Melvin and Howard.”
lead_paragraph: Bo Goldman, one of Hollywood’s most admired screenwriters, who took home Oscars for his work on “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” (1975) and “Melvin and Howard” (1980), died on Tuesday in Helendale, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Nikki Haley Answers a Thorny Abortion Question: Should Women Be Punished?
abstract: The former South Carolina governor — who is trying to break out in a packed 2024 Republican presidential primary — gave a nuanced response on one of the thorniest issues facing Republicans.
lead_paragraph: At town halls and political events in New Hampshire, where she has made far more campaign stops than her rivals, Nikki Haley has mostly sidestepped any discussion of abortion, a fraught issue for the Republican Party.

headline: Mitch McConnell Suffers an Episode at the Capitol, Freezing Midsentence
abstract: The 81-year-old Senate Republican leader, who had a serious fall earlier this year, was temporarily unable to speak during a news conference, raising questions about his health and future.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the longtime Republican leader who had a serious head injury in a fall earlier this year, froze midsentence during an appearance at his weekly news conference in the Capitol on Wednesday and was briefly escorted away from the microphones to recover.

headline: Meta Profit Is Up 16% to $7.8 Billion in Recent Quarter
abstract: Wall Street investors were hoping the social media giant would regain its footing after more than a year of problems, including slumping ad sales.
lead_paragraph: Long before it was called Meta, Facebook was a Wall Street darling because of its breakneck growth and big profits. But the company had lost its luster with investors over the past 18 months thanks to a slump in ad sales and what some saw as self-inflicted wounds.

headline: Barboncino, a Brooklyn Pizza Restaurant, Becomes a Union Shop
abstract: Staff at this Crown Heights restaurant voted to join Workers United, making the pizzeria New York City’s first to have a unionized staff.
lead_paragraph: Barboncino, a Neapolitan-style pizza restaurant in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, has become the first unionized pizzeria in New York City after its workers unanimously voted to approve the formation of a union.

headline: 1 Dead and 22 Injured in Cargo Ship Fire Off the Netherlands
abstract: The ship was carrying nearly 3,000 vehicles near the Dutch island of Ameland in the North Sea when the fire was reported late Tuesday, officials said.
lead_paragraph: One crew member has died and 22 others have been injured in a fire on a large cargo vessel loaded with nearly 3,000 vehicles off the Dutch island of Ameland in the North Sea, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: A Grim Climate Lesson From the Canadian Wildfires
abstract: For all our plans to control emissions, humans are no longer fully in charge.
lead_paragraph: You may have forgotten about the Canadian wildfires, once the smoke cleared from your American lungs and the orange disappeared from American skies. But the fires have not forgotten to burn.

headline: How Hunter Biden’s Judge Came to Have Doubts on the Deal
abstract: In just a few hours, Judge Maryellen Noreika exposes a gulf in understanding between the president’s son and prosecutors on an agreement they had spent weeks hashing out.
lead_paragraph: Judge Maryellen Noreika kicked off Wednesday’s hearing on Hunter Biden’s proposed plea deal with the Justice Department by telling lawyers that they did not need to keep “popping” up and down every time she asked them a question.

headline: 101°F in the Ocean Off Florida: Was It a World Record?
abstract: Measuring and comparing sea surface temperatures is complex, but scientists agree on one thing: A high reading this week is bad news for wildlife.
lead_paragraph: The reading from a buoy off Florida this week was stunning: 101.1 degrees Fahrenheit, or just over 38 Celsius, a possible world record for sea surface temperatures and a stark indication of the brutal marine heat wave that’s threatening the region’s sea life.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Launches Full Offensive
abstract: Also, Cambodian succession, Sinead O’Connor’s death and a lemon bar recipe.
