lead_paragraph: Two U.S. officials said that the main thrust of Ukraine’s counteroffensive is now underway in the southeast. The Russian Defense Ministry also reported a “massive” assault in the region.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): ‘Barbie,’ Jason Aldean’s Culture War and Drake’s Tour
abstract: Plus: Violent J in our 50 Rappers, 50 Stories project, new songs and new snacks.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Colonization Was the ‘Luckiest Thing’ to Happen to Australia, Ex-Leader Says
abstract: The backlash was swift after John Howard made the remarks ahead of a referendum on Aboriginal representation in the government.
lead_paragraph: A former prime minister of Australia has stirred a storm of outrage by describing colonization as “the luckiest thing that happened to this country” and praising Britain for being a better overlord than other nations ahead of a contentious referendum on Aboriginal representation in the country.

headline: White House Condemns Fox News Over Host’s Holocaust Comments
abstract: In a debate over Florida’s African American history curriculum, Greg Gutfeld said Jews in Nazi concentration camps “had to be useful” to survive, remarks that the White House called “an obscenity.”
lead_paragraph: The White House denounced Fox News this week over comments by one of its hosts, Greg Gutfeld, that some Jews “had to be useful” as a means for survival in Nazi concentration camps, calling his remarks “an obscenity.”

headline: A Simple 14-Minute Workout That Could Lower Your Blood Pressure
abstract: A new study points to the humble wall squat as the most effective tool to fight hypertension.
lead_paragraph: It has become almost a cliché across doctor’s offices: One of the most trusted tools to lower blood pressure is to exercise.

headline: After Fatal Ship Fire, Newark Mayor Wants Special Port Unit
abstract: Mayor Ras J. Baraka said he had begun discussions with the Port Authority and Coast Guard about creating a special team to battle shipboard fires.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after two firefighters from his city died battling a blaze aboard an Italian cargo ship, the mayor of Newark said he wanted to create a unit within the fire department that would be specially trained to respond to emergencies in the city’s giant commercial port.

headline: NASA Seeks a Nuclear-Powered Rocket to Get to Mars in Half the Time
abstract: The space agency and DARPA will work with Lockheed Martin to build a vehicle that uses the power of the atom for space propulsion.
lead_paragraph: In less than four years, NASA could be testing a nuclear rocket in space.

headline: Keeping Track of the Trump Investigations
abstract: See a guide to the major criminal cases involving the former president.
lead_paragraph: See a guide to the major criminal cases involving the former president.

headline: When Will the Rate Hikes End?
abstract: Also, a new phase of Ukraine’s offensive. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates today to their highest level in 22 years, pressing on with a campaign to bring inflation down by cooling the American economy. The hike was widely expected.

headline: The Bald Power of Sinead O’Connor
abstract: The Irish singer’s shaved head was as much a part of her identity and allure as her sound.
lead_paragraph: It was the bald head that became the avatar of a million dreamy rebellions; the shaved pate that bridged the gap between the angry and the sublime. It is almost impossible to think about Sinead O’Connor, the Irish singer whose death was reported on July 26, or her work, without thinking about her hair. Or lack of it.

headline: A Sheet-Pan Chicken for Corn Season
abstract: Caramelized corn, pickled jalapeños and basil chicken make the most summery of sheet-pan dinners.
lead_paragraph: The beginning of corn season requires speed and simplicity. You want the fastest, easiest way to get that pile of evanescently sweet, nubby cobs on the table, ready for butter-slathering and gleeful chomping. A dip in boiling water, a quick sear on the grill or even a zap in the microwave all make the most of those fleeting first ears without much fuss.

headline: How and Why Illegal Border Crossings Have Dropped So Dramatically
abstract: The Biden administration’s new asylum policy, which a judge blocked this week, has contributed to a plunge in illegal border crossings at the southern U.S. border.
lead_paragraph: In the 76 days since President Biden imposed tough new restrictions on the nation’s asylum system, the number of migrants crossing the United States’ southern border illegally every day has dropped significantly.

headline: Sinead O’Connor’s Life in Pictures
abstract: The Irish singer had an evocative voice and cast a powerful silhouette onstage.
lead_paragraph: With her short hair and wide eyes, the Irish singer Sinead O’Connor, who has died at the age of 56, cast a powerful silhouette onstage during her music career. The height of her power came in the late 1980s and early 1990s, including a divisive 1992 appearance on “Saturday Night Live” in which she ripped up a photo of Pope John Paul II to protest sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: The Real College Admissions Scandal
abstract: We need to end legacy admissions and look beyond the Ivy League if we’re going to fix our unequal education system.
lead_paragraph: YAMHILL, Ore. — Before I make an argument about affirmative action, let me tell you how I was a beneficiary of it.

headline: Court Rejects New Sentencing for Al Qaeda Recruiter
abstract: Ali Hamza al-Bahlul is the only convict serving a life sentence at Guantánamo Bay. Lawyers have appealed his case six times.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Tuesday rejected a bid by a Yemeni prisoner at Guantánamo Bay to have a new military jury reconsider his life sentence for conspiring to commit war crimes as a propaganda chief for Al Qaeda and an aide to Osama bin Laden.

headline: U.S. Moves to Improve Airplane Bathrooms for People With Disabilities
abstract: New regulations announced by the Transportation Department will mandate that more new planes have accessible lavatories, though the requirement will not take effect for years.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department announced on Wednesday that it had finalized new regulations to require more commercial aircraft to have accessible bathrooms, a long-awaited step to address complaints from disabled travelers about the difficulties of flying.

headline: Main Thrust of Ukraine’s Offensive May Be Underway, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: After holding back many of its units trained and armed by the West, Ukraine is now committing them, the officials said, but it remained unclear whether a full-scale assault was taking place.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has launched the main thrust of its counteroffensive, throwing in thousands of troops held in reserve, many of them Western-trained and equipped, two Pentagon officials said on Wednesday, hours after Russian officials reported major Ukrainian attacks in the southern Zaporizhzhia region.

headline: The Night Sinead O’Connor Took on the Pope on ‘S.N.L.’
abstract: Tearing up a photo was the moment nobody forgot. The performance that preceded it was just as powerful.
lead_paragraph: What people remember about Sinead O’Connor’s Oct. 3, 1992, appearance on “Saturday Night Live” is this: At the end of her second performance of the show, a cover of Bob Marley’s “War,” O’Connor intoned gravely, “We have confidence in the victory of good over evil.” As she held tight to the word, stretching it like a castigation, she grabbed a photo of Pope John Paul II and held it up to camera. When she let the word go, she punctuated her exhale by tearing the photo three times, followed by an exhortation to “fight the real enemy.” She tossed the fragments to the ground, removed her in-ears, and stepped off the stage into culture-war infamy.

headline: Affirmative Action Ruling Shakes Universities Over More Than Race
abstract: At what was billed as an Education Department “summit” in Washington on Wednesday, a wide range of college admissions practices were on the table.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision to effectively end race-conscious admissions in higher education last month was historic in its own right, removing a tool that the nation’s colleges have used for decades to increase racial diversity on their campuses.

headline: 2 Supervisors at Juvenile Lockup in Bronx Are Charged in Beating of Teenager
abstract: The charges were another sign of the problems that have plagued New York’s detention of adults and minors alike.
lead_paragraph: Two supervisors at a juvenile detention center operated by New York City’s child welfare agency were charged by federal prosecutors on Wednesday with assaulting a 16-year-old resident who was awaiting trial and with then trying to cover up the attack.

headline: Zwirner Pivots on Plans for New Chelsea Gallery
abstract: Because of financial problems the project’s developer encountered during the pandemic, the gallerist is abandoning a 21st Street development and pursuing another building project.
lead_paragraph: Citing a developer’s “financial headwinds during Covid,” the art dealer David Zwirner said he has decided not to proceed with a 50,000-square foot, five-story, $50 million gallery designed by Renzo Piano on a corner lot at 540 West 21st Street.

headline: Black History Is a Casualty in Ron DeSantis’s Christian Nationalist Quest
abstract: Florida’s distortion of the history of slavery is more consequential than many comprehend.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Florida approved an overhaul of its African American history standards, including guidance that middle schoolers should be instructed that “slaves developed skills which, in some instances, could be applied for their personal benefit.”

headline: 10 Essential Songs by Sinead O’Connor
abstract: Her catalog is full of raw passion and raw nerve.
lead_paragraph: Sinead O’Connor did not hold back. Not her voice, not her ideas, not her troubles, not her rage, not her sorrows, not her faith. From the moment her debut album, “The Lion and the Cobra,” appeared in 1987, O’Connor — whose death was announced on Wednesday — flaunted raw passion and raw nerve.

headline: Bars for Checking People Out
abstract: Guilherme Gilioli adds another New York Times Crossword to his body of work.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Prominent Horse Trainer Sentenced to 4 Years in Prison in Doping Scheme
abstract: Jason Servis, the highest-profile defendant among more than two dozen people charged after a sprawling F.B.I. investigation, pleaded guilty to two counts related to the use of banned substances.
lead_paragraph: The former thoroughbred trainer Jason Servis was sentenced on Wednesday to four years in federal prison after pleading guilty to participating in what prosecutors called a far-reaching doping scheme meant to improve the performance of his horses.

headline: Corrections: July 27, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 27, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the scaling back of technology companies in New York misstated the scope of layoffs by large technology companies since early 2022. They have laid off more than 386,000 workers worldwide, not just in the United States.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hiding From the Yips Will Only Make It Worse
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 27, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “They hid me in a back room so no one would see me. It was like I was stuffed into a broom closet. That only makes it worse by stigmatizing it.”

headline: A South African Biographer Brings Winnie and Nelson Back to Earth
abstract: Jonny Steinberg tells the story of Nelson Mandela and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela at a moment when a new generation is reassessing their legacies.
lead_paragraph: The South African leader and anti-apartheid activist Nelson Mandela died in 2013, suffering from dementia. We can only guess at the memories that whirled around his mind as he passed from one world to the next, but we know that at some point in his final hours he began calling for his ex-wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.

headline: The Looming Crisis in the Bridal Industry? Not Enough Seamstresses.
abstract: The skilled professionals who work on wedding dress alterations play a crucial role for brides, but their numbers are dwindling.
lead_paragraph: On a video call in mid-June, a dozen women from across the country — many of them seated at sewing machines and enveloped by clouds of white tulle — debated the pros and cons of working in the busy world of bridal alterations.

headline: With a Temporary Contract Fix, Saquon Barkley and the Giants Get Back to Business
abstract: Barkley, the Giants running back, attended training camp after a last-minute, one-year deal ended talk that he would sit out. He and the team’s rush-heavy offense are still figuring out how much they need one another.
lead_paragraph: As Saquon Barkley, the Giants star running back, jogged from the huddle during a team drill Wednesday at a training camp practices, the couple hundred fans in attendance chanted his name in rhythmic cadence.

headline: Biden and Meloni May Find Common Ground at White House
abstract: The president has been wary of the Italian prime minister’s hard-right politics. But when they meet on Thursday, they may see eye to eye on key issues.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Giorgia Meloni rose in Italian politics campaigning against migrants and the European Union while seeking alliances with supporters of Donald J. Trump. Now prime minister of Italy, she would seem to have little in common with President Biden, who once compared the hard-right philosophy she shared with Mr. Trump to “semi-fascism.”

headline: Life Under U.K. Sanctions: Chauffeurs, Chefs and $1 Million Allowances
abstract: Despite tough talk, Britain’s new sanctions program against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has proved shaky. Some oligarchs have received generous exemptions. Officials have at times overreached.
lead_paragraph: The British government has allowed Russian oligarchs to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on perks like private chefs, chauffeurs and housekeepers, despite ostensibly having their bank accounts frozen, documents show.

headline: An American Energy Giant Sees Israel as a Springboard to Europe
abstract: Chevron finds itself with an abundance of natural gas on Europe’s doorstep. Amid competing regional interests, the question is how to develop it.
lead_paragraph: Six miles off the coast of Israel, beyond the brightly colored sails of wind surfers, an ungainly steel structure looms above the blue Mediterranean.

headline: The Korean War in Photos, 70 Years After the Truce
abstract: American troops led United Nations forces to defend South Korea against the North. The war ended with a cease-fire agreement and a Korean Peninsula that is still divided.
lead_paragraph: The Korean War broke out when a Soviet-backed, Communist North invaded the pro-American southern territory of the Korean Peninsula in 1950, leading to one of the most harrowing conflicts of the 20th century and setting the tone of the Cold War in Asia.

headline: South Korea Unveils Harry Truman Statue
abstract: The 13.8-foot statue, unveiled in Dabu-dong, Gyeongsangbuk-do, South Korea, honors former President Truman on the 70th anniversary of the Korean War armistice.
lead_paragraph: The 13.8-foot statue, unveiled in Dabu-dong, Gyeongsangbuk-do, South Korea, honors former President Truman on the 70th anniversary of the Korean War armistice.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine begins the “big test” of its counteroffensive
lead_paragraph: Thousands of reinforcements poured into the two-month battle in the nation’s southeast, many of them trained and equipped by the West and, until now, held in reserve. “This is the big test,” one senior U.S. official said.

headline: What’s Happening in Italy Is Scary, and It’s Spreading
abstract: In galvanizing the political right behind resentful identity politics, Giorgia Meloni is leading the way.
lead_paragraph: ROME — What a difference a few months can make.

headline: Lindsey Graham and Elizabeth Warren: When It Comes to Big Tech, Enough Is Enough
abstract: We need a nimble, adaptable new agency with the expertise, resources and authority to rein in the tech giants that control our digital lives.
lead_paragraph: The digital revolution promised amazing new opportunities — and it delivered. Digital platforms promoted social interaction, democratized information and gave us hundreds of new ways to have fun.

headline: The next stage of the counteroffensive appears to be taking shape.
abstract: Ukrainian forces trying to punch through Russian lines are facing perhaps their biggest test of the war as, according to two Pentagon officials, Kyiv begins the main thrust of its counteroffensive, pouring the bulk of their Western-trained reserves into the fight to sever Moscow’s hold on the south.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces trying to punch through Russian lines are facing perhaps their biggest test of the war as, according to two Pentagon officials, Kyiv begins the main thrust of its counteroffensive, pouring the bulk of their Western-trained reserves into the fight to sever Moscow’s hold on the south.

headline: Word of the Day: in tandem
abstract: This phrase has appeared in 155 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The phrase in tandem has appeared in 155 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 23 in “Facing Brutal Heat, the Texas Electric Grid Has a New Ally: Solar Power” by J. David Goodman:

headline: Finally, a Memorial to the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire’s Victims
abstract: Steel panels will bear the names of the 146 workers, most of them women, who died in the 1911 blaze. Also, a “pay to play” Long Island restaurateur is sentenced to prison.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at plans for a memorial to one of the city’s worst tragedies, a deadly fire that led to changes in the workplace. We’ll also find out how much time a restaurateur who paid off politicians is going to spend in prison.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Atop a Mountain, a Reporter in Search of New Heights
abstract: For Jesse McKinley, a Metro correspondent, searching for the perfect dateline proved to be an uphill battle. An 8.7-mile one, to be exact.
lead_paragraph: Talk to enough reporters and you will eventually hear the Story of Their Best Dateline.

headline: Biden’s Fight With Harvard Is a Political Winner and Policy ‘Band-Aid’
abstract: After an affirmative action ruling, legacy admissions are a ripe target. Still, skyrocketing tuition costs and mountains of debt remain far greater worries for many Americans.
lead_paragraph: In the final month of his 2020 presidential campaign, Joe Biden stood before a drive-in crowd in Toledo, Ohio, and announced he had “a chip on my shoulder” about people with fancy college degrees.

headline: How Big Is the Legacy Boost at Elite Colleges?
abstract: In the same week as a civil rights inquiry into Harvard, new data shows legacies are slightly more qualified yet are four times as likely to get into top schools.
lead_paragraph: The Education Department’s civil rights investigation into Harvard’s preference for admitting the children of alumni and donors is based on a complaint that it gives less-qualified applicants an edge over those who are more deserving, including students of color.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Self-Portrait of the Roma, Without the Stereotypes
abstract: The exhibition “Barvalo” is billed as the first show of its kind to combine contributions from multiple Romani artists and curators. They are sharing their culture on their own terms.
lead_paragraph: When Gabi Jimenez, a French Spanish Romani painter, first heard several years ago that a major museum in France was planning an exhibition on Romani culture and history, he said he thought it would be “a mess.”

headline: The Roller Rink Popcorn Factory and the Jailhouse Pub
abstract: A look at the endless reinvention of the forgotten old buildings of the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: When the owners of a solar-powered popcorn company in the Hudson Valley were looking to expand operations, they saw an opportunity in an empty roller rink. A former magazine editor who dreamed of opening an antiques store in the Catskills knew she’d found the perfect place when she came upon an 1870s firehouse. And about 20 miles away, a film producer turned liquor entrepreneur realized he could make and sell his products out of a retro drive-in movie theater.

headline: How Aimé Leon Dore Took New York
abstract: The brand, which bridges the streetwear-luxury gap and has taken on investment from LVMH, is a template for the future of men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: On the May evening before Aimé Leon Dore was set to make its grand return to Mulberry Street following eight months of construction on an extravagant new storefront, Teddy Santis, the brand’s founder, was walking around the shop floor, sweating the details.

headline: South Korea Unveils Truman Statue on Armistice Anniversary
abstract: Conservatives appreciate Truman’s decision to send U.S. troops to fight for their country in the Korean War.
lead_paragraph: On the 70th anniversary of the armistice that halted the Korean War, one American received a special honor in South Korea: former President Harry S. Truman, in whose memory a new, nearly 14-foot-tall statue was unveiled on Thursday.

headline: Putin Promises Free Grain at Africa Summit, Aiming to Help Russia’s Image
abstract: At a summit for African countries, the Russian president insisted that Western hypocrisy rather than his invasion of Ukraine was to blame for disruptions in the global food supply.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pledged on Thursday to ship free grain to at least six African countries over the next four months, scrambling to shore up Moscow’s image on the continent in the wake of the Kremlin’s refusal to extend a deal that had protected Ukrainian grain exports that help feed millions of people around the world.

headline: North Korea Vows Support for Moscow in Visit by Russian Delegation
abstract: Pyongyang vowed increased military cooperation against the United States, a common enemy, during a visit by Russia’s defense minister.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, vowed to expand military cooperation with Moscow in its confrontation with the United States as the Russian defense minister, Sergei K. Shoigu, led a delegation to Pyongyang, the North Korean state news media reported on Thursday.​

headline: 36 Hours in Newport, R.I.
abstract: The glamorous “Sailing Capital of the World” on Rhode Island offers plenty of rewards beyond the yachts and Gilded Age mansions.
lead_paragraph: The glamorous “Sailing Capital of the World” on Rhode Island offers plenty of rewards beyond the yachts and Gilded Age mansions.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Wordle Hints
abstract: What should be allowed to keep your solving streak alive?
lead_paragraph: Liz writes: My husband and I are daily Wordle players. I currently have a solving streak of 145. If I get to the final guess, I’ll Google hints of the day for an assist. My husband objects to this practice. Who’s right?

headline: Women in Taiwan Are Tired of Being Nice
abstract: Women still struggle to protect themselves from predators, but we won’t let it go.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, Taiwan’s a nice place to live.

headline: Two Empty Nesters Strive to Come Up With a Down Payment. Which House Could They Buy?
abstract: For one couple, renting near a college campus in Bloomington, Ind., lost its luster after the children moved out. Would $300,000 be enough for a new house?
lead_paragraph: For one couple, renting near a college campus in Bloomington, Ind., lost its luster after the children moved out. Would $300,000 be enough for a new house?

headline: The Insidious Habit That Can Hurt Your Relationship
abstract: Ignoring a partner in favor of your phone, or “phubbing,” can lead to feelings of distrust and ostracism. Here’s how to stop.
lead_paragraph: If you have had a romantic partner, you’ve most likely had the maddening experience of realizing that while you were blabbering on about something or another, they were focused on their phone.

headline: ‘Haunted Mansion’ Review: A Disney Ride to Nowhere Fun
abstract: Starring LaKeith Stanfield and Rosario Dawson, this movie plays like a feature-length ad for Disney’s theme-park attraction of the same name.
lead_paragraph: There is a mansion, it is haunted, boo, blah, the end.

headline: Once Wary, Biden Welcomes Italy’s Meloni to the White House
abstract: President Biden had feared the electoral victory of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s far-right party last fall would spell trouble. But she has proved to be a strong ally in the American-led effort to support Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Biden warmly welcomed Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy to the White House on Thursday, embracing her as a friend and casting aside initial doubts that her far-right party might prove to be troublesome for the United States.

headline: Biden Announces Steps to Help Communities Deal With Extreme Heat
abstract: The measures include protections for workers and funds for better weather prediction, but they are unlikely to satisfy activists who have pushed the president to do more to combat climate change.
lead_paragraph: President Biden directly linked recent record heat waves with climate change on Thursday and announced new measures aimed at helping communities endure extreme weather, as rising temperatures scorch much of the country and amplify alarms about global warming.

headline: Poem: My Life in the New Millennium
abstract: Joshua Clover begins with hating people and loving cats, quickly adding juxtapositions and surprises.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Clover’s “My Life in the New Millennium” begins with a thorny, if familiar, either/or. Then the poem moves quickly to accrue its juxtapositions and surprises, providing room for both Whitney Houston and the world system, for both wit and committed seriousness, for gravity and light. By the end of the poem, its initial dilemma has found a resolution: a shared category, capacious enough for both people and cats — and for history itself. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: How Does a Prolific Author Deal With Cold Feet?
abstract: Riley Sager has been on a publishing tear since 2017. His seventh book, “The Only One Left,” almost interfered with his breakneck pace.
lead_paragraph: In the past six years, Riley Sager has published seven novels — all of them best sellers except his first, “Final Girls,” which won a 2018 International Thriller Writers Award. The Pennsylvania native reliably produces one book a year on a strict schedule that sounded remarkably uncomplicated (if dizzying) when he described it in a phone interview.

headline: Amid Shared Pain Over Synagogue Massacre, Divisions on Death Penalty
abstract: Since the 2018 attack that left 11 people dead, Jews in Pittsburgh have weighed whether the government should seek the execution of the killer.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after 11 people were murdered in the Pittsburgh synagogue where he worshiped, Stephen Cohen wrote a letter to the U.S. attorney general. The Justice Department had not yet declared its intent to seek a death sentence in the case, and Mr. Cohen, the co-president of New Light, one of the three congregations that met in the Tree of Life synagogue, wanted to weigh in.

headline: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
abstract: The latest in a series of Julius Eastman recordings, a new opera by Christopher Cerrone and an EP from Ashley Bathgate are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: This is the third in Wild Up’s series of recordings of works by Julius Eastman (1940-90), and it showcases the range of Eastman’s indelible naming style: witty (“If You’re So Smart, Why Aren’t You Rich?”); poetic (“The Moon’s Silent Modulation”); inflammatory. These are stormy, swiftly shifting, open-ended scores, rendered in new arrangements by Wild Up’s large and varied ensemble with passion, richness and complexity — a forest of details — and a controlled chaos inspired by free jazz.

headline: Tara Westover Likes to Read Herself to Sleep, When She Can
abstract: “My thinking is that reading will focus my mind, bring a hush over the chaos of the day so I can drift off,” says the author of the memoir “Educated,” one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2018. “But from time to time a book takes hold in that peculiar way that a book can, and I end up reading through the night. ... Books are both the best and worst thing for my sleep.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Michigan Judge Weighs Whether School Shooter Could Ever Leave Prison
abstract: A Supreme Court ruling from 2012 requires judges to consider eventual release for young defendants. A state judge must decide what that means for the shooter who killed four students at a Michigan high school.
lead_paragraph: If the teenager who killed four students at his Michigan high school and pleaded guilty to first-degree murder had been a few years older, there would be no question: He would be going to prison for the rest of his life.

headline: Jobs Sit Empty in the Public Sector, So Unions Pitch In to Recruit
abstract: Shortages of state and city personnel, especially those who must work on site, are so dire that unions are helping to get people in the door.
lead_paragraph: The State of Minnesota, like nearly every public-sector employer across the country, is in a hiring crunch.

headline: How Supreme Court Justices Make Millions From Book Deals
abstract: The deals have become highly lucrative for the justices, including for those who used court staff members to help research and promote their books.
lead_paragraph: Only three months into Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson’s first Supreme Court term, she announced a book deal negotiated by the same powerhouse lawyer who represented the Obamas and James Patterson.

headline: D.E.I. Programs Are Getting in the Way of Liberal Education
abstract: Highly ideological D.E.I. programs erode the environment of open, substantive debate that is the basic prerequisite for liberal education.
lead_paragraph: Academia is in the midst of a generational turmoil. Blue states such as California and Oregon have recently transformed their public universities with expansive “diversity, equity and inclusion” programs that have profound implications for admissions, speech, hiring and scholarship. Red states such as Florida and Texas have recently passed legislation abolishing them, concluding that the programs that have sprung up to execute D.E.I. promote a stifling orthodoxy that undermines the pursuit of truth.

headline: Researchers Poke Holes in Safety Controls of ChatGPT and Other Chatbots
abstract: A new report indicates that the guardrails for widely used chatbots can be thwarted, leading to an increasingly unpredictable environment for the technology.
lead_paragraph: When artificial intelligence companies build online chatbots, like ChatGPT, Claude and Google Bard, they spend months adding guardrails that are supposed to prevent their systems from generating hate speech, disinformation and other toxic material.

headline: At New York’s Coenties Slip, an Artist Colony and a ‘Rebellion’
abstract: Prudence Peiffer’s “The Slip” is a group biography of six visual artists and the work they created on the edge of Manhattan in the 1950s and ’60s.
lead_paragraph: “I look forward to a rebellion,” said Alfred H. Barr Jr., the founding director of the Museum of Modern Art. It was 1958, and Jackson Pollock was two years gone. Barr wanted something, anything, to replace Abstract Expressionism. Pop, minimalism, hard-edge painting — the next big thing hadn’t grown big enough to assert itself.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Reunited
abstract: Valentine’s Day drama abounds in this week’s episode, but the most important involves a major figure from Carrie’s past.
lead_paragraph: At least one aspect of “the old Miranda” is still very much intact. She told us back in Season 2 of “Sex and the City” that when a romance ends, she “would love to be one of those people who’s all: ‘We loved, thank you. You enriched my life. Now, go, prosper.’” But that’s just not her vibe. In her own words, she is much more: “We didn’t work out, you need to not exist.”

headline: A Jets Star Emerges, and Helps to Pull in Another
abstract: Garrett Wilson broke out in his rookie season as the dynamic receiver the Jets have long lacked. Now he’s reminding Aaron Rodgers of a productive partnership from the past.
lead_paragraph: The diner resembled so many others peppering New Jersey. Garrett Wilson held high expectations as he climbed from an idling S.U.V. This was Sopranos country, after all, where bottomless menus and bustling service await every eager lunchtime patron.

headline: The Kidnapped Child Who Became a Poet
abstract: At age 3, Shane McCrae was taken from his Black father by his white grandparents — a rupture he explores in a new memoir.
lead_paragraph: “The weird thing about growing up kidnapped,” Shane McCrae, the 47-year-old American poet, told me in his melodious, reedy voice one rainy afternoon in May, “is if it happens early enough, there’s a way in which you kind of don’t know.”

headline: Where to Drink Wine in Madrid
abstract: This warm, generous city overflows with great wine lists in restaurants and wine and tapas bars. Here are nine places you should try.
lead_paragraph: To many tourists, Madrid is kind of an afterthought, Spain’s second city after Barcelona, which, in their minds, abounds with youthful energy, quirky architecture, a thriving arts scene, beautiful beaches and superb restaurants.

headline: A Time Capsule of Human Creativity, Stored in the Sky
abstract: The Lunar Codex, an archive of contemporary art, poetry and other cultural artifacts of life on Earth, is headed to the moon.
lead_paragraph: “Just keep telling the story,” says the director character in Wes Anderson’s latest film, “Asteroid City,” which takes a stylized look at midcentury America’s fascination with space and interstellar communications. Later this year, the Lunar Codex — a vast multimedia archive telling a story of the world’s people through creative arts — will start heading for permanent installation on the moon aboard a series of unmanned rockets.

headline: Don’t Call Her ‘Karen’
abstract: A viral video about a dispute over a rental bike was about much more. Or perhaps much less.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Comrie is a 34-year-old physician assistant from San Diego. After getting a master’s degree from Cornell, she took a job at Bellevue, a public hospital in New York that serves many people that the city’s for-profit hospitals might decline to treat, including the uninsured, the homeless and members of the Rikers Island jail population. In 2020, she was profiled by The Times as one of the workers who risked their health to care for others during the pandemic.

headline: Labor Department Denounces Surge in Exploited Migrant Children
abstract: The agency said it had found thousands of cases where minors were employed in illegal, often dangerous jobs. Congress has accused the health secretary of failing to protect them.
lead_paragraph: The Labor Department on Thursday denounced a national surge in child labor, saying the agency’s inspectors had found thousands of violations and were investigating a slaughterhouse where a 16-year-old boy from Guatemala was killed this month.

headline: How Clever Tech Can Keep You Safe Outdoors
abstract: These apps and devices allow you to find your way, triage an injury and generally stay out of trouble on the trail.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, it wasn’t hard to get lost on a hike: read the map wrong and you could wander too far into the woods or down the wrong trail. But over the last few years, digital tools like trackers and apps have made exploring the outdoors safer and more accessible.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 7 Fashion: Aidan’s Return
abstract: Carrie’s other great love reappears just in time for Valentine’s Day.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for Episode 7 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”

headline: Has Scott Joplin’s ‘Thoroughly American Opera’ Found Its Moment?
abstract: “Treemonisha” — brilliant, flawed and unfinished — is ripe for creative reimagining at a time when opera houses are looking to diversify the canon.
lead_paragraph: “He has created an entirely new phase of musical art and has produced a thoroughly American opera.”

headline: What Happened When 15 of Twitter’s Top Celebrities Joined Threads
abstract: We examined the daily activity of Ellen DeGeneres, Wiz Khalifa, Selena Gomez and others among Twitter’s most-followed to deduce if Threads has staying power.
lead_paragraph: Threads, the new social app from Meta, had a fast start this month when it racked up 100 million downloads in less than a week. With so much momentum, the app seemed well on its way to dethroning Twitter.

headline: When It Comes to Swimming, ‘Why Have Americans Been Left on Their Own?’
abstract: The biggest reason so many Americans can’t swim is that they have too few places to learn how.
lead_paragraph: As a young child in New Orleans, Raychelle Ross fell into one of the city’s many canals and nearly drowned.

headline: Episode 4: The Clinic
abstract: From Serial Productions. What went wrong at Yale.
lead_paragraph: After the nurse is sentenced, patients file a lawsuit against the fertility clinic at Yale. The nurse, Donna, is just one person. There is an entire institution that needs to account for what went wrong.

headline: Today’s Top News: The Fed Raises Rates to a 22-Year High, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Affirmative Action for the 1 Percent
abstract: In elite college admissions, a new study has found, being very rich is its own qualification.
lead_paragraph: A major new study has revealed just how much elite colleges admissions in the U.S. systematically favor the rich and the superrich.

headline: Slack Experiences a Brief but Widespread Outage
abstract: For a little over an hour, desk workers scrambled to find other ways to communicate.
lead_paragraph: Slack, the widely used messaging platform, experienced an outage of just over an hour early Thursday, disrupting life in offices around the world (including this reporter’s).

headline: Flash of Anger Led to a Moment of Brilliance for U.S.
abstract: Lindsey Horan’s tying goal against the Netherlands saved her team at the World Cup. But it came from a dark place she knows well.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Horan was still curled up on the field when she decided, enough already.

headline: The Fed’s Difficult Choice
abstract: The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates again. When should it stop?
lead_paragraph: After raising interest rates again yesterday, the Federal Reserve now faces a tough decision.

headline: The U.S. Government Wants Your Dead Butterflies
abstract: Residents of six states have been asked to send dead butterflies, moths and other Lepidoptera to help scientists study population declines.
lead_paragraph: Got any dead butterflies lying around? Consider sending them to the U.S. government.

headline: Held Hostage by His Military, Niger’s President Vows to Save Democracy
abstract: The army chief declared his support for a group of mutineers that seized power on Wednesday. President Mohamed Bazoum and his allies insisted the coup could be reversed.
lead_paragraph: Hours after soldiers seized power in the West African nation of Niger, the country’s ousted president sounded a defiant note on Thursday morning, vowing to protect his “hard won” democratic gains, even as he was being held hostage in the presidential palace by his own guards.

headline: After Ousting a Top Official, China Erases Him and Evades Questions
abstract: China blasted “malicious hype” around the abrupt removal of Qin Gang. The Foreign Ministry’s fumbling response pointed to its diminished influence under Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: China’s abrupt removal of Qin Gang as foreign minister did not stop the questions that had dogged Chinese officials in the month since he vanished from public view: Where is Mr. Qin? Does he have health issues? Is he under investigation?

headline: Putin claims Russian lines are holding.
abstract: The Ukrainian military said on Thursday that its forces were pushing in two directions in southern Ukraine, aiming to rip through Moscow’s heavily fortified defensive lines, as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia acknowledged a major uptick in attacks but claimed Russian lines were holding.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian military said on Thursday that its forces were pushing in two directions in southern Ukraine, aiming to rip through Moscow’s heavily fortified defensive lines, as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia acknowledged a major uptick in attacks but claimed Russian lines were holding.

headline: A Split Subway Series Leaves Both Teams Shrugging
abstract: It may be too late to save the Mets season, and the Yankees are not a sure bet for the postseason even once Aaron Judge returns.
lead_paragraph: The final installment of the 2023 subway series — lowercase, alas — began with a nifty bit of symmetry on Wednesday night in the Bronx. Brandon Nimmo, the Mets’ $162 million center fielder, faced Carlos Rodón, the Yankees’ $162 million left-hander. They fought to a draw — a full count, then a foul — before Nimmo struck out on high heat.

headline: ‘The First Slam Dunk’ Review: Style Points
abstract: A popular sports manga about a Japanese high school basketball team vaults to the big screen in an exhilarating, gorgeous anime.
lead_paragraph: “The First Slam Dunk” is a great basketball movie because it understands what’s great about basketball. When a character catches a pass, drives toward the paint, steps back, squares up and releases a clutch 3-pointer, the movie slows time, drops the sound and homes in on exactly the right detail — the perfect, crystalline swish of the ball passing through the basket and gently grazing the net.

headline: ‘Talk to Me’ Review: Letting the Wrong One In
abstract: A bereaved young woman falls under the spell of a dangerous artifact in this vibrant and poignant horror debut.
lead_paragraph: Steeped in yearning and chockablock with shocks, “Talk to Me,” the first feature from the Australian filmmaking brothers Danny Philippou and Michael Philippou, is a horror movie huddled tightly around a story of filial grief. The result is an enduring melancholy that no amount of ghouls or gore can entirely dispel.

headline: ‘Susie Searches’ Review: The Sleuth Is Out There
abstract: Kiersey Clemons plays an amateur detective with a true-crime podcast and a secret in this quirky mystery movie.
lead_paragraph: Cinematic plays on the true-crime podcast craze are about as fresh as warmed-over veggie patties, yet “Susie Searches,” the debut feature film from Sophie Kargman, uses the trend to launch a satisfying if familiar mystery movie. Susie (Kiersey Clemons) is a college overachiever who in her spare time works at a burger joint, volunteers at the sheriff’s office and hosts a podcast investigating cold cases. This vast extracurricular catalog populates the story with an array of oddballs who, soon enough, make for a quirky cast of suspects when Jesse (Alex Wolff), a New Age influencer and campus celebrity, goes missing.

headline: ‘The Beasts’ Review: Bad Neighbors
abstract: Class tensions and masculine power games abound in this engrossing rural thriller from Spain.
lead_paragraph: “The Beasts,” an engrossing rural thriller by the Spanish director Rodrigo Sorogoyen, has a deeper take on the class tensions of most hill-people horror movies. Antoine (Denis Mé nochet) and Olga (Marina Foïs), a middle-class French couple, have recently settled in the Galician village of Ourense, where they run a modest farm and spend their surplus of free time rebuilding dilapidated homes. Their neighbors, Xan (Luis Zahera) and Lorenzo (Diego Anido), a tetchy pair of middle-aged brothers, despise them. A Swedish wind-turbine company has offered to pay out the village’s residents should they approve the installment of an energy farm on the land — by voting “no,” Antoine and Olga deny the impoverished brothers what for them would be a considerable sum.

headline: ‘The Beanie Bubble’ Review: Caught in a Fad Romance
abstract: This dramatic comedy about Beanie Babies, starring Zach Galifianakis, Elizabeth Banks and Sarah Snook, arrives at the tail end of a summer of corporate biopics.
lead_paragraph: John Updike once described writing as a matter of “taking a deep breath, leaning out over the typewriter and trying to drive a little deeper than the first words that come to mind.” Unfortunately, the writing in “The Beanie Bubble,” a dramatic comedy based loosely on the true story of the short-lived Beanie Baby toy craze, sits on the surface.

headline: ‘North Circular’ Review: A Musical Tour Through Dublin
abstract: In this black-and-white documentary by Luke McManus, the camera finds stories and songs near a road north of the city’s center.
lead_paragraph: The discursive documentary “North Circular” takes viewers on a tour of the history, music and geography of Dublin. The title refers to North Circular Road, which forms an arc that passes north of the city’s center, and that offers a loose map for the film’s themes. Directed by Luke McManus and shot in a ghostly black-and-white, “North Circular” finds stories and songs near the thoroughfare’s path.

headline: ‘Zoey 102’ Review: Grown Up, Washed Up
abstract: 15 Years after her Nickelodeon show, “Zoey 101,” ended, Jamie Lynn Spears returns in a serviceable movie sequel.
lead_paragraph: When the Nickelodeon show “Zoey 101” ended its four-season run, in 2008, Zoey (Jamie Lynn Spears) finally got together with Chase (Sean Flynn), putting a fairy tale ending on a will-they-or-won’t-they relationship that fascinated a large slice of early-2000s tweens. A decade and a half later, in “Zoey 102,” a movie-length sequel to (and update of) the show, the two have become estranged. Years before, Zoey ghosted Chase during a trip to Hawaii.

headline: ‘Happiness for Beginners’ Review: Live, Laugh, Hike
abstract: Ellie Kemper and Luke Grimes star in “Happiness for Beginners,” an outdoorsy rom-com that’s inoffensive to a fault.
lead_paragraph: In Happiness for Beginners,” directed by Vicky Wight, the “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt” star Ellie Kemper portrays a divorced 30-something, Helen, on a journey of self-discovery and romance. Wight’s second adaptation of a novel by Katherine Center (after the 2020 drama “The Lost Husband”), the movie trades in warm-and-fuzzy predictability, where the most uprooting event imaginable for Kemper’s character is falling in love with her brother’s best friend, Jake (Luke Grimes), on a group hiking excursion along the Appalachian Trail.

headline: ‘El Agua’ Review: After the Flood, the Legends
abstract: This film from Elena López Riera follows what happens when floods drench a village in southeastern Spain.
lead_paragraph: In the southeastern Spanish village where the director Elena López Riera grew up — and where her debut feature, “El Agua,” is set — water is both a boon and a curse. This dry region doesn’t get enough rain for its lemon and orange crops, but when it does pour, there are frequently devastating floods. And as is often the case with forces we cannot control or understand, it’s the village’s women who are blamed for nature’s caprices.

headline: ‘Bobi Wine: The People’s President’ Review: A Pop Star Turns Politician
abstract: Uganda has been under authoritarian rule for decades. Wine has doggedly challenged its leader, and this documentary shows the price he’s paid.
lead_paragraph: The pop-culture personage turned politician is not so novel a figure as it used to be. But the Ugandan pop singer Robert Kyagulanyi Ssentamu, who goes by the stage name Bobi Wine, has earned, by way of his courage and resilience, the special consideration this documentary affords him.

headline: A Guide to Art Exhibitions in New York and Massachusetts
abstract: The weekend arts scene, offering a history of Indigenous performance and a roller coaster stashed inside a museum, has breadth and depth that is worth a trip.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers desiring cooler summers and fresher air have been racing upstate and to the Berkshires for generations. The buildup of smaller artist communities near the Hudson River and beyond have created a rich tapestry of cultural offerings for visitors to enjoy.

headline: What Russia Sees: In Crimea, ‘Everyone Is Having Fun’
abstract: Since Russia invaded Ukraine last year, Russian government officials and state television have hammered home the message that everything is fine.
lead_paragraph: On Russian state television, explosions on the roadway of a 12-mile bridge are no reason to cancel your vacation to the beaches of the Crimean Peninsula, even with a war raging nearby on mainland Ukraine.

headline: Shell Reports Sharply Lower Earnings as Energy Prices Ease
abstract: After a record-breaking profit last year, Shell’s quarterly earnings fell 56 percent. But the energy provider will increase dividend payments.
lead_paragraph: Shell, Europe’s largest energy company, said Thursday that its profit fell 56 percent in the second quarter from record-breaking earnings of a year earlier, to $5.07 billion.

headline: Warren and Graham Team Up to Take on Big Tech
abstract: The senators have forged a bipartisan alliance to create a new federal agency to police the power of tech giants like Amazon, Apple and Meta.
lead_paragraph: For years, policymakers have worried about the growing power of digital giants like Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta and Microsoft, as they came to dominate more and more of everyday life. Now, two prominent senators are pushing to create a new federal agency to rein in the power of Big Tech.

headline: High Interest Rates and Low Savings Could Put Renovations on Hold
abstract: As housing stock ages in the coming years, homeowners could face challenges financing needed renovations.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. housing stock is aging, which means lots of bathrooms and kitchens need remodeling. The number of existing homes that have reached the age at which renovations are typically done — between 20 and 39 years old — is projected to increase to about 24.2 million in 2027, from 20.5 million in 2018, according to an industry report from the National Kitchen & Bath Association (NKBA), shared with The New York Times.

headline: European Central Bank Lays the Ground for a Rate Increase or a Pause
abstract: “We have an open mind,” the bank’s president said after raising interest rates for a ninth consecutive time.
lead_paragraph: For the past year, the European Central Bank has raised interest rates at every one of its policy meetings in an effort to rein in high inflation. Looking forward, that can no longer be the expectation.

headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 2.4% Rate in Second Quarter
abstract: The reading on gross domestic product was bolstered by consumer spending, showing that recession forecasts early in the year were premature, at least.
lead_paragraph: The economic recovery gained momentum in the spring as buoyant consumer spending and resurgent business investment helped, once again, to keep a recession at bay.

headline: A Mexican Craft Brewery Where You Can Spend the Night
abstract: Plus: an exhibition of Remedios Varo’s surrealist paintings, daybeds upholstered in classic textiles and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Seen from the outside, Red Jane, a new bakery in the center of Chania, a Greek port city on the island of Crete, looks like a Berlin nightclub, with no obvious sign and a concrete facade covered in graffiti. Inside, it might pass for a New York boutique: There are Italian tiles on the floor and an exposed-brick ceiling and on a long red marble counter, lit by minimalist pendant lamps, pastries are laid out like jewels in a glass vitrine. Owned by Nikos Tsepetis, the hotelier behind the nearby beach resort Ammos (a favorite of the art and design crowd), the space is the first fully realized interiors project overseen by the London-based lighting and furniture designer Michael Anastassiades. Eyal Schwartz, the former head baker and co-owner of London’s E5 Bakehouse, created the menu. On its opening day this month, Red Jane sold out of its chocolate-filled croissants, koulouri (Greek sesame-topped bagels) and baklava swirls by noon. Locals lingered for an hour after, despite the fact that Tsepetis and Anastassiades designed the space without tables. redjaneproject.com.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are on the Upper West Side, in Murray Hill and South Park Slope.
lead_paragraph: A 585-square-foot condo that has a kitchen with granite countertops and a dishwasher, a limestone and marble bathroom, a sleeping alcove, and a washer/dryer, on the third floor of the Heritage at Trump Place, a 31-story doorman building from 2005 with a concierge, security team, children’s room, screening room, interior courtyard, valet parking garage, and a 15,000-square-foot gym and spa with several pools. Andy Kim, Olesia Goncharova and Cornell Jones, Nest Seekers International, 718-288-8022; nestseekers.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Locust Valley, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Wilton, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, three-full-and-two-half-bath, 3,698-square-foot house built in 1964, with a wood-burning fireplace and bay window in the living room; built-ins, a fireplace and a wet bar in the den; an island, two dishwashers and skylights in the eat-in kitchen; a main-floor laundry room; and an attached two-car garage, on 1.36 acres. Kimberly Greene Bancroft, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-404-5053; danielgale.com

headline: Busloads of Migrants Keep Arriving in L.A. From Texas
abstract: A fifth bus arrived in the city last weekend, bringing the number of migrants who have been transported since June to 199.
lead_paragraph: Something many people have criticized as a political stunt playing out elsewhere in the country arrived in Southern California starting in mid-June.

headline: Prosecutors Drop Campaign Finance Charge Against Sam Bankman-Fried
abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried’s legal team had argued that the United States mishandled the process of extraditing him from the Bahamas.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors pursuing the criminal case against the cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried said on Wednesday that they were dropping a charge that he violated campaign finance rules.

headline: This Looks Like Earth’s Warmest Month. Hotter Ones Appear to Be in Store.
abstract: July is on track to break all records for any month, scientists say, as the planet enters an extended period of exceptional warmth.
lead_paragraph: Weeks of scorching summer heat in North America, Europe, Asia and elsewhere are putting July on track to be Earth’s warmest month on record, the European Union climate monitor said on Thursday, the latest milestone in what is emerging as an extraordinary year for global temperatures.

headline: A Strange, but Elegant, Artistic Match
abstract: On the surface, Piet Mondrian and Hilma af Klint made very different work. But an exhibition at Tate Modern explores the pair’s shared obsessions, including astrology, X-rays and atoms.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the exhibition “Hilma af Klint and Piet Mondrian: Forms of Life,” currently showing at Tate Modern, in London, sits a pair of maquettes that encapsulate the artists’ differences.

headline: What’s Behind the Coup in Niger?
abstract: Military mutineers ousted the country’s elected leader, shaking a pillar of democracy in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: After a days of uncertainty in Niger, the commander of country’s presidential guard claimed the leadership of the West African country Friday in a televised address after ousting Mohamed Bazoum, the country’s democratically elected president.

headline: King Charles Doesn’t Have as Many Swans as He Used to
abstract: For hundreds of years, the royal family has laid claim to many of England’s swans. An annual count found a worrisome drop in cygnets along a stretch of the River Thames this year.
lead_paragraph: Six wooden skiffs set out from the town of Sunbury-on-Thames this month on a five-day mission with a single goal: to uphold one of Britain’s more obscure royal traditions and report back to the king on how many swans he owns.

headline: Spared the Worst of Summer Until Now, the Northeast Joins a Nation Scorched
abstract: The heat index reached the triple digits across the nation’s most populous region, and could peak on Friday. Many cities took precautions to help vulnerable residents.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s power company asked customers to cut back on electricity use Thursday afternoon, and Philadelphia declared a health emergency as the dangerous heat that has scorched other parts of the country for more than a month spread to the nation’s most populous region.

headline: Bid to Reassign Netanyahu Prosecution Hints at Next Steps in Israel
abstract: The corruption case against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is overseen by the attorney general. Lawmakers in his party proposed stripping her of that responsibility, prompting anger and a swift reversal.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has long denied seeking to use his power to undermine his long-running corruption trial, and rejected the notion that his government’s ongoing judicial overhaul was partly an attempt to get his case dismissed.

headline: Elon Musk’s Quixotic Quest to Turn X Into an ‘Everything App’
abstract: Mr. Musk, the owner of Twitter, is the latest Silicon Valley mogul to pursue an all-in-one app, the kind that has thrived in Asia but not elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, a billionaire tech executive leading one of the world’s pre-eminent social platforms laid out a vision to transform it into an app that could do it all. In an online manifesto, he wrote that the app would not only be central to written communications but have audio, video, payments, commerce and more.

headline: Biden Is Weighing a Big Middle East Deal
abstract: Senior Biden officials are in Riyadh on Thursday exploring the possibility of some kind of U.S.-Saudi-Israeli-Palestinian understanding.
lead_paragraph: For the hundreds of thousands of Israeli democracy defenders who tried to block Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s judicial coup on Monday, the stripping of the Israeli Supreme Court’s key powers to curb the executive branch surely feels like a stinging defeat. I get it, but don’t totally despair. Help may be on the way from talks between the United States and Saudi Arabia.

headline: Trump’s Lawyers Meet With Prosecutors as Election Interference Charges Loom
abstract: The former president’s legal team had a last-ditch chance to provide information to the office of Jack Smith, the special counsel leading the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump met on Thursday with officials in the office of the special counsel, Jack Smith, as federal prosecutors edged closer toward bringing an indictment against Mr. Trump in connection with his wide-ranging efforts to overturn the 2020 election, according to three people familiar with the matter.

headline: Blood of Young Mice Extends Life in the Old
abstract: Infusions of youthful blood led older mice to live 6 to 9 percent longer, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: A team of scientists has extended the lives of old mice by connecting their blood vessels to young mice. The infusions of youthful blood led the older animals to live 6 to 9 percent longer, the study found, roughly equivalent to six extra years for an average human.

headline: Jeffrey Gibson, Indigenous U.S. Artist, Is Selected for Venice Biennale
abstract: The multimedia artist is known for incorporating a Native American perspective into legacies of modernism and craft that define today’s cultural foundations.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Gibson, a multimedia artist who challenges the absence of Native American practices in visual culture, will represent the United States at the next edition of the Venice Biennale.

headline: Volkswagen Seeks to Regain Edge in China as It Cuts Delivery Forecast
abstract: The German automaker lowered its outlook for deliveries and announced changes to its China strategy as it struggles to regain ground lost to other automakers.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen, Europe’s largest automaker, is scaling back its forecast for deliveries in 2023 as it grapples with lagging sales of its electric vehicles, but the company said on Thursday that it hoped to bolster its position in China through increased collaboration with local technology companies.

headline: Supreme Court Clears the Way for Pipeline as Appeal Moves Forward
abstract: A congressional measure on the Mountain Valley Pipeline, championed by Senator Joe Manchin and added to legislation to raise the debt limit, was intended to thwart legal challenges to the project.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday temporarily cleared the way for construction of a 300-mile pipeline capable of carrying two billion cubic feet of natural gas daily from northern West Virginia to southern Virginia.

headline: Where Wildfires Are Raging in Europe and North Africa
abstract: Firefighters have scrambled to extinguish blazes in at least 10 countries as a heat wave has swept the Mediterranean region. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of wildfires have burned their way through Southern Europe and North Africa this week, with residents of nearby communities forced to flee the billowing smoke and advancing blazes. Firefighters in at least 10 countries in the region have mobilized firefighting planes and trucks to douse the blazes, which have blackened thousands of acres of land, consumed buildings and killed dozens of people.

headline: The Life and Death of a ‘Punk Rock Warhol’
abstract: Frank Kozik made his name with his playfully gruesome concert posters for Nirvana, Soundgarden and Butthole Surfers. He added to his underground fame with his boundary-pushing “art toys.”
lead_paragraph: Last month at the Columbarium funeral home in San Francisco, mourners gathered for the artist Frank Kozik, who died recently at 61.

headline: A Trumpeter Stretches Past the Bounds of Jazz
abstract: Chief Xian aTunde Adjuah’s new album, “Bark Out Thunder Roar Out Lightning,” is his first on which he doesn’t touch the trumpet. Instead, he extends the legacy of Black masking Indians in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in New Orleans, Chief Xian aTunde Adjuah was raised at the corner of two traditions. He learned to play the trumpet at the elbow of his uncle and mentor, the saxophonist Donald Harrison Jr., whose career took off after a stint in Art Blakey’s band. Harrison was a true-blue jazz musician, and Adjuah — who was born, and first introduced to the listening public as, Christian Scott — seemed destined to become one, too.

headline: Review: Young Bros and Maidens Harmonize in ‘Love’s Labor’s Lost’
abstract: This peculiar early Shakespeare comedy gets updated with 10 songs for a youthful alfresco production.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s rock!” is something I’m pretty sure no character in Shakespeare ever said. But on a sandy stage under a jaunty tent, with a green hillside as a welcoming backdrop, it seemed an apt way to begin “Love’s Labor’s Lost.”

headline: ‘How To With John Wilson’ Loves All of You Weirdos
abstract: The third and final season of the HBO docu-comedy begins this week, finding the universal in the oddball and the mundane.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a toilet is more than just a toilet.

headline: How to Stay Cool in New York City During Extreme Heat
abstract: Officials are encouraging residents to take advantage of cooling centers and splash pads. They are also warning against operating air conditioning at maximum capacity.
lead_paragraph: Officials are urging New Yorkers to find safe and reliable ways to stay cool over the next few days while the city is expected to face dangerously high temperatures.

headline: A Requiem for Diet Soda
abstract: The story of this beverage is the story of us.
lead_paragraph: Back in high school, I often woke before my parents did, and I could tell when my mother was about to get out of bed. A sound alerted me. I don’t mean an alarm clock. I mean the crunch-woosh of a can of diet soda being opened. Mom kept one on her night stand. That way, she could have her first sip the very moment her day began.

headline: If You Can’t Stand the Heat … We’ve Got Some Suggestions
abstract: A little advice for August: Structure your days around beating the heat. Or, if you’re tempted by one of these outdoor events, stay hydrated.
lead_paragraph: As fireworks danced across the sky on the Fourth of July, the Earth heated up at record levels.

headline: At Soho Rep, Eric Ting and Caleb Hammons to Join Leadership Team
abstract: Following the departures of Sarah Benson and Meropi Peponides, the two will join Cynthia Flowers as the company continues its shared leadership model.
lead_paragraph: Eric Ting and Caleb Hammons will join Cynthia Flowers as the next directors of Soho Rep, the Lower Manhattan theater announced on Thursday.

headline: Sinead O’Connor’s Death Is Not Suspicious, Police Say
abstract: The London police force said that the Irish singer was found dead at a home in the city.
lead_paragraph: Sinead O’Connor was found dead in a private home in London, the city’s police said on Thursday, a day after the provocative Irish singer’s death was announced. While few details have been released about the death, the police said that it was not being treated as suspicious.

headline: Are You a Legacy Alum?
abstract: We’d like to hear what you think about colleges giving admissions preference to relatives of alumni.
lead_paragraph: After the Supreme Court’s rejection of affirmative action at American colleges and universities, another admissions practice has come under scrutiny: preferences for relatives of alumni. Known as legacy admissions, the practice tends to favor wealthy white applicants over others, including Black, Hispanic, Asian American and Native American students.

headline: How to Make the Hats at Home
abstract: Step-by-step instructions for creating your own fantastical headpieces.
lead_paragraph: Step-by-step instructions for creating your own fantastical headpieces.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? The War on Drugs and More
abstract: I’m an editor who works on features for The Times’s print edition. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m an editor who works on features for The Times’s print edition. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: DeSantis Debuts a Leaner Campaign. But Donors Have Their Doubts.
abstract: As the Florida governor reboots in Iowa, tensions still plague the highest levels of his operation and a supportive super PAC.
lead_paragraph: On the day his presidential campaign said it had laid off more than a third of its staff to address worries about unsustainable spending, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida began his morning by boarding a private jet to Chattanooga, Tenn.

headline: Unverified photographs of Prigozhin surface as African leaders convene in St. Petersburg.
abstract: The whereabouts of the leader of the Wagner mercenary group has been a subject of continuing questions since an aborted mutiny last month.
lead_paragraph: Unverified photographs began circulating on social media Thursday suggesting that Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Russian mercenary boss who led a short-lived mutiny in June, was meeting with African officials in St. Petersburg, where some of the continent’s top leaders have converged for a summit with President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Don’t Take Zucchini for Granted
abstract: Summer’s ubiquitous squash shines when raw, sliced and smashed into panzanella and salads.
lead_paragraph: Like many, I took in Greta Gerwig’s fluorescent “Barbie” this past weekend. No moment of the surreal film has stuck with me quite like the use of “Push,” the angsty, alt-rock ’90s hit from the band Matchbox Twenty.

headline: Alvin Ailey Celebrates Its 65th Season With Tribute to Ailey Women
abstract: The winter season at City Center features premieres by Amy Hall Garner and Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish, and a program honoring women who shaped the organization.
lead_paragraph: Revivals of works by Ronald K. Brown and Jamar Roberts and world premieres by Amy Hall Garner and Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish will come to the City Center stage for Alvin Ailey Dance Company’s winter season, the company announced Thursday.

headline: A Half-Million Americans May Have Tick-Linked Meat Allergy, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Many doctors said that they were unfamiliar with the condition, known as alpha-gal syndrome, the agency found.
lead_paragraph: As many as 450,000 Americans may be living with alpha-gal syndrome, a meat allergy that has been linked to tick bites, with many of those people going undiagnosed, according to two new studies from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: ‘Kokomo City’ Review: Dispatches From the Down Low
abstract: The director D. Smith’s new documentary follows four Black transgender women, who talk about how they got into sex work.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Kokomo City” features interviews with people who aren’t often given the chance to publicly share their life stories. The film follows four Black transgender women, who speak directly to the camera about how they got into sex work and what they learned about human nature once they got there.

headline: Soft Landing Optimism Is Everywhere. That’s Happened Before.
abstract: People are often sure that the economy is going to settle down gently right before it plunges into recession, a reason for caution and humility.
lead_paragraph: In late 1989, an economic commentary newsletter from the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland asked the question that was on everyone’s mind after a series of Federal Reserve rate increases: “How Soft a Landing?” Analysts were pretty sure growth was going to cool gently and without a painful downturn — the question was how gently.

headline: Justice Dept. Opens Civil Rights Investigation of Memphis Police
abstract: The department will examine allegations of pervasive problems with excessive force and unlawful stops of Black residents that were amplified by the fatal beating of Tyre Nichols.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Thursday that it had begun a sweeping civil rights investigation into policing in Memphis, digging into allegations of pervasive problems with excessive force and unlawful stops of Black residents that were amplified by the fatal beating of Tyre Nichols in January.

headline: Oppenheimer and the Chain Reactions of Our Own Making
abstract: The film “Oppenheimer” is not just about the life of a man central to the atomic bomb project: It tells a story of ambition and petty grievances spiraling out of anyone’s control.
lead_paragraph: Dark matter is invisible to normal means of detection, neither emitting or reflecting light. But its existence can be traced through its gravitational influence on other, more detectable objects. Map its influence and you can map its existence.

headline: What’s a Plant-Based Diet? Here’s What You Need to Know to Eat Less Meat.
abstract: It’s not the same as going vegan, but it can also have a strong impact on reducing your carbon footprint.
lead_paragraph: One thing much of the country seems to agree on is eating more plants. More than half of Americans (63 percent, regardless of political affiliation, according to a 2021 study by the Yale Program on Climate Change Communication) are actively trying to eat less red meat. In the United States, plant-based products grew into an $8 billion industry in 2022, with a growth rate of 7 percent since the year before.

headline: ‘The Unknown Country’ Review: A Granddaughter’s Road Trip
abstract: Lily Gladstone’s achingly measured performance braided with the actual stories from nonprofessional actors makes Morrisa Maltz’s film a memorable road trip.
lead_paragraph: Snow-bordered highways, a cat winking its jade eye, the tentative yet always observant expressions of the main character Tana (Lily Gladstone) are among the low-key pleasures of “The Unknown Country,” the director-writer Morrisa Maltz’s luminously photographed, delicately paced road movie.

headline: Facebook’s Algorithm Is ‘Influential’ but Doesn’t Necessarily Change Beliefs, Researchers Say
abstract: In four new studies, researchers found complicated results from experiments on Facebook’s and Instagram’s algorithms, suggesting there was no silver bullet to fixing the platforms.
lead_paragraph: The algorithms powering Facebook and Instagram, which drive what billions of people see on the social networks, have been in the cross hairs of lawmakers, activists and regulators for years. Many have called for the algorithms to be abolished to stem the spread of viral misinformation and to prevent the inflammation of political divisions.

headline: Listen: The Vanishing Family, The Retrievals, Oppenheimer
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Julian Barry, Who Made Lenny Bruce Into ‘Lenny,’ Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Barry’s scripts for a hit Broadway play and later a Hollywood movie about that rule-breaking comic helped give Mr. Bruce a lasting place in pop culture lore.
lead_paragraph: Julian Barry, whose scripts for a Broadway play and a Hollywood movie about Lenny Bruce, both titled “Lenny,” became definitive portraits of the comedian as a truth teller who drove himself mad in a righteous struggle against American hypocrisy, was found dead on Tuesday morning at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 92.

headline: ‘War Pony’ Review: The Sad Absurdities of Reservation Life
abstract: Riley Keough and Gina Gammell’s stellar debut, starring many first-time actors, takes a deadpan look at a Lakota-Sioux reservation in South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: The Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota, home to the Lakota-Sioux, has one of the highest poverty rates and shortest life expectancies in the United States. Over 80 percent of adults are unemployed. “War Pony,” a stellar debut from Riley Keough and Gina Gammell, written in collaboration with two of its residents, Franklin Sioux Bob and Bill Reddy, has every right to be a furious tragedy.

headline: Sinead O’Connor Was Ireland’s Alternative Moral Compass
abstract: In any society, she would have been radical for a pop star. But in Ireland, she was revolutionary.
lead_paragraph: On March 9, Sinead O’Connor stood onstage at the Vicar Street concert venue in Dublin. Her presence was greeted by a prolonged standing ovation. O’Connor was at the RTE Choice Music Prize, an evening celebrating the best Irish albums of the past year. A new award had been invented for the occasion: classic Irish album, and O’Connor was there to accept it for her 1990 record, “I Do Not Want What I Have Not Got.”

headline: Justices Ignoring the ‘Scent of Impropriety’
abstract: Readers respond to a judge’s guest essay. Also: The Trump inquiry costs; Rudy Giuliani; legacy admissions; Joe Biden’s dog; a Briton’s struggles.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Beyond the City, Summertime Theater That’s Worth the Drive
abstract: A guide to some of what’s onstage at theater festivals in upstate New York and the Berkshires.
lead_paragraph: In summertime, a lot of stage talent heads for the Hudson River Valley and western Massachusetts, where curious audiences follow. Here is some of what theaters there have on tap this year.

headline: A Summer Dinner Party That’s Actually Fast and Easy
abstract: The New York Times Food columnists share their favorite simple dishes for a gorgeous spread.
lead_paragraph: The confusing spirit of August — the urge to relax while also making the most of lazy days — extends to cooking for friends. There’s a craving to casually have people over for a beautiful meal that takes nearly no effort. These special, unfussy dishes from the New York Times columnists — Melissa Clark, Yewande Komolafe, Eric Kim and Genevieve Ko — are perfect for an impromptu gathering because they come together so quickly.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Brian Dillon’s essay collection “Affinities” is nominally a book of art criticism — most of the essays take visual artists as their starting point, and the book is subtitled “On Art and Fascination” — but its real charm (for this reader, anyway) is in the “fascination” part of that equation, as Dillon meditates on the various ways an image or story or striking detail can come to exert a hold on our imagination.

headline: Bill Geddie, a Creator of ‘The View,’ Is Dead at 68
abstract: His partnership with Barbara Walters began when he produced her prime-time specials. He later helped turn her idea for an all-female talk show into a long-running hit.
lead_paragraph: Bill Geddie, whose long working relationship with the barrier-breaking television newswoman Barbara Walters began when he produced her prime-time specials on ABC, then expanded when he collaborated with her on “The View,” one of TV’s most successful daytime talk shows, died on July 20 at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 68.

headline: Russia’s promise of free grain reflects the Kremlin’s priorities in Africa.
abstract: The Russian leader made the overture days after pulling out of the Black Sea grain deal that benefited many countries on the continent.
